movie_review_blurb: No matter what your personal opinion is concerning the war in Iraq, this documentary is a must see!
The one scene of Lassie standing alone on the highlands of Scotland is worth the price of admission.
It is a powerful indictment of any organization that chooses to turn a blind eye to an extremely serious problem.
This film has more thrills, excitement and tense moments than any I have seen in a long while.
It's (Tom) Wilkinson who really saves the movie. His acting is always outstanding --- he makes it appear so effortless.
"Bewitched" was not so beguiling --- what a shame!
This was one really intense, terrifying film that must be seen on the big screen!
One indication that a movie is REALLY good is being unable to stop thinking about it.
This movie is truly delightful, a real must-see, even if you're not a sports fan.
...an action adventure film, complete with implausible situations, and perfectly timed rescues and escapes. Who cares? It's still fun, exciting and thoroughly entertaining
'The Upside of Anger' demonstrates the downside of moviemaking.
Violence is everywhere, but I couldn't take my eyes off the screen.
One could have a field day with this movie --- it is so stupid and ridiculous.
That Robin Williams sure is something else! He is the perfect goofball sidekick to the soft-spoken, thoughtful Ewan McGregor in this delightful adventure.
Say what you "Will", but Mr. Smith is one entertaining guy
......as far as I'm concerned, this movie was a disaster.....
Director Michael Radford has assembled a terrific cast.......
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This is an achingly stunning film. Using a word my partner is very fond of, it is riveting!
This is an intelligent, lovely film, truly one of the year's best.
This is an intelligent, lovely film, truly one of the year's best.
A quality film with near-perfect writing, marvelous acting and quite a few laughs thrown in.
"The Aviator" is one of the best films of the year, and chock full of fabulous performances.
.......an unbelievable ride on a truly magical train. This is a film that must be seen on the big screen.
"This is a blast to watch! The bursts of color are phenomenal, and the action is fast and furious."
'What woman wouldn't want a handsome husband showing up at work in a tuxedo, holding one perfect rose?'
'Alfie is a funny, breezy film. Law is especially sexy, sultry and charming to watch. I'm not convinced, though, that it needs to be seen on the big screen.'
'When all is said and done, and Oscar time rolls around, Jamie Foxx will be difficult to beat in the Best Actor category.'
Please, do not be put off by the subject or subject matter. This is nothing more than a terrific film about two men sharing an historic journey -- at least for themselves.
Out of the Tibetan mountains comes a new, more inventive version of the Caped Crusader's story than we've ever seen before!
I was spellbound by the documentary, "Spellbound", and now I'm mad for "Mad Hot Ballroom".
This is not just a children's movie! This is a Tim Burton classic, and it must be seen on the big screen.
If you want to have a little old-fashioned, questionable fun at the movies, don't miss this midsummer treat.
'Cache' is French for hidden, but about the only thing 'hidden' in this supposed thriller is the suspense.
Wow! What a delightful, colorful, magical little gem of a movie.
There were a plethora of bad lines, but I don't have enough room to list them all.
If you've seen all of the holiday releases, and are looking for something which won't make you run out of the theater screaming, this is a good choice.
This is an important film --- a searing, gut-wrenching, heartbreaking re-telling of a tragic event and its aftermath, as only Steven Spielberg can do.
If you truly enjoy a well-crafted story and outstanding acting, then you must see this final installment of a great partnership.
This film is funniest when it doesn't try so hard.
It doesn't matter how many fine actors are assembled in a film, if the script is terrible, then the movie can't be good.
You would be hard pressed to find finer performances this year.
You may not leave the theater humming a happy tune, but if you're a fan of this musical, I'm sure you'll find it a treat.
Wow! Harry and his pals are back and they are better than ever.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's not that 'Firewall' is a bad movie --- it's just not that great. Plus I am so over Harrison Ford.
This production is marvelous, and I was one of the ones who thought the A & E version couldn't be topped!
Gyllenhaal is remarkable, especially in his Christmas Eve scene, dressed only in two Santa hats......
"Capote" proves a small-budget film can still afford a superb cast.
Julianne Moore is absolutely outstanding in this role, giving an Oscar-worthy performance.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: I know this film is the critics' darling, but this critic is here to tell you, take a pass.
Clever animation and storylines are always intriguing and entertaining. Add to that a terrific score by Danny Elfman, and I simply must insist that you see this movie.
Jodie, Jodie, Jodie ---- what could you have been thinking?
Despite the requisite Hollywood ending, everyone can leave the theater happy.
It isn't very often that a perfect little movie comes along about a perfect little crime.
movie_title: The Perfect Crime (El Crimen Perfecto)(Crimen ferpecto) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Don't miss Steve Carell's debut in a lead role......it's truly refreshing.
You will be appalled....you will be grossed out.... but, you will also be entertained!
if you are an ardent fan of Bill Murray's, this is a must-see performance ---- truly his best thus far.
Cage and Caine are accomplished actors, enjoyable to watch in almost everything, except this drivel.
"Tokyo Sonata" is partly brilliant and partly melodramatic soap opera.
It's a great assemblage of characters and actors without a great script.
Okay, I was willing to reserve judgment until I saw the film, but now it's official ---- I don't like a blonde Bond!
If you like saucy period pieces, this is definitely for you.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Although this is no 'Ferris Bueller's Day Off', Matthew Broderick does return to Chicago for a wonderful, wacky little gem.
One of those poorly chosen movie titles that does not do justice to the beautiful story told within.
'Mongol' is so beautifully photographed that it should knock your socks off.
In a world of blockbusters and super-hero movies, one "small" film about five mystical heroes can be more satisfying than all of the others put together.
New York is fabulous, the clothes are fabulous and the shoes are beyond fabulous --- what more can a 'Sex and the City' devotee ask for? A sequel?
Lelouch has a wicked yet playful sense of humor.
This is a movie with wonderful, strong performances from three very talented women.
movie_title: How the Garcia Girls Spent Their Summer (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This film is not the equivalent of brain surgery, but it is entertaining.
After Errol Morris' "Fog of War", I was expecting something more provocative from him --- instead, what we get is a very lengthy, often repetitive viewing of the infamous photographs of Abu Ghraib.
This is one of those surprising little gems that make you happy to be an ardent moviegoer.
An uplifting account of elderly people we should all emulate!
This is one slick flick about a world most of us will never experience. 'Deception' almost pulls it off ---- almost.
Tautou is simply the most delightful, delectable imp to grace the silver screen in years.
This may appear to be a simple film of a boy's determination to be with his mother, but in reality, it is so much more.
Simon Pegg has a great face! Not since Jerry Lewis has anyone been able to look pathetic, adorable and stupid, all at the same time.
There are no joyous moments to balance the heavy-handed dose of everyday reality some people are forced to endure.
Kolirin's writing conveys the poignancy and heartwarming touches that make this movie the triumph that it is.
'Penelope' is a sweet film that I rather enjoyed. It never hurts to be reminded that we should all be happy with who we are.
Enough with the teenage coming-of-age movies, already! And this one is particularly offensive.
After a while, even seeing the Roman Coliseum again is boring.
It's a delightful movie with great writing and a splendid cast.
It is a feat in filmmaking from a young director wise beyond his years.
You gotta love Meryl Streep! Is there anything this actress can't do?
When one thinks of on-screen chemistry, rarely, if ever, do you think of characters in their seventies.
At times it feels as though we're watching a scripted movie with paid actors instead of "real" kids, but that doesn't prevent the audience from becoming emotionally invested in each of their plights.
The writing rears its ugly head and manages to obliterate an otherwise interesting premise.
Predictability in a film is a major offense, but the real crime in "Stand Up Guys" is the squandering of the talented cast assembled.
Alan Arkin gives another quirky performance.
Malkovich is superb as the outwardly gracious, inwardly hostile and acerbic has-been.

Movies featuring exceptional young actresses have always been near and dear to my heart. Elizabeth Taylor, Tatum O'Neal, Anna Paquin ------ to mention a few ----- are particular favorites of mine. Now I must add Elle Fanning to that list.
This movie is way too long, and one more "meaningful" close-up of Dr. Manhattan and I would have run screaming from the theater.
Yes, it's a movie about conspicuous consumption ---- that's what shopping your brains out means!
At times, the writing becomes a bit like a sermon about the woes of the oceans, but, in all honesty, I think we can't hear it enough that our environments are changing ----- and not for the better.
A fascinating, cautionary tale for those of us who are always thinking the grass is always greener
Joel Hopkins should be given 20 lashes with a wet noodle for ripping off every prototypical moment in truly romantic films.
'The Reader' is so perfectly executed that it will be a contender for many awards.
A beautifully animated film with a gorgeous soundtrack.
It is a marvelous piece of filmmaking with a story that begs to be seen and understood.
The screenplay starts out clever enough, but devolves into a ridiculous mishmash of incoherent subplots.
I'm not a big fan of scary movies like I once was, but I was mesmerized by the entire film (when I didn't have my head covered).
---- a truly inspirational film ----
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It is a story of truth, hope and redemption, so wonderfully performed by everyone in the cast.
Passengers is not a film I would recommend that you rush right out to see. However, it will make a good rental on a snowy night this winter
This is a real life drama that will shake you to the core!
.....biting, edgy and truly hysterical
Very disappointing ---- I was so in the mood for a great western!
It is the chemistry between Leoni and Gervais that makes this film the great romantic comedy that it is.
Shame on English for wasting an opportunity to make a modern-day classic.
Czech writer/director Jiri Menzel, in an effort to maintain a lighter spirit to the movie, tends to gloss over many of the atrocities committed during this time.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Weiland has given us something we can cheer and feel good about.
'A Christmas Tale' has revived my love for goofy families as only the French can do.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It is truly astounding that one off-the-cuff remark could cause such a commotion. And please, I don't care what your politics are --- this was downright disturbing.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: When it comes to wrapping up the story, Allen can't seem to make up his mind.
The Orphanage is the first film in many moons that reminds me of those terrific nail biters of yesteryear.
The acting in 'Red Road' is understated and superb, however that doesn't compensate for the overall dreariness of this film.
Charming, funny and delightful.
A rare treat --- don't miss it!
A perfect example of a crisp script that is hilarious to boot!
A gripping story of duplicity, intrigue and evil that grabs your attention from the very first frame and never lets go.
The conspiracy theory involving Hughes and then U.S. President Richard Nixon threw me ---- it lacked development as part of the storyline, which I found unnecessary.
Make sure you sit through the credits to learn about the victims who survived and worked on this film ---- extraordinary!
Paris looks stunning in the film, but even the City of Lights can only do so much for a poorly-written script. C'est dommage.
I always love it when I'm pleasantly surprised by a film I was not excited to see --- 'The Host' is a highly entertaining testament to the genre of 'monster movies'.
This movie is much better than 'Flags of Our Fathers' and every bit as good as 'Letters From Iwo Jima'.
This is billed as a comedy and there are some very funny moments. The writing is crisp and believable.
I could have watched Spiridonov as Vanya for hours. He is superbly cast and his wistful eyes rope you in immediately.
Definitely not funny, and not appropriate for young teenagers! Yuck!
Romantico is a very simple film about a very complex problem.
The most ridiculous character was Madame Louise (Anjelica Huston), who appears out of nowhere in the middle of the desert.
Director Zhang Yimou has an incredible eye for color, and this offering does not disappoint when it comes to the exquisite employment of a vibrant palette.
The film itself is way too long, culminating in a ludicrous orgy scene.....
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: I loved this movie. It is never overly sentimental.....it is simply the honest tale of a rebirth of a community deeply in pain.
.....an almost perfect film.....
Last year's 'Good Night, and Good Luck' was a great film. 'The Good German' is beautifully filmed, yet not so great.
A simple film, yes, but a wonderful one, nonetheless. But then, I am a sucker for any film with little girls and dogs.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Both Nicholson and Kirk are terrific actors, but the script limits them and their performances.
I am a huge Pedro Almodovar fan, and his latest offering, "Volver", is another gem in his repertoire of films about women.
Polley has constructed a complex film about love, relationships, honor and commitment. It is a beautiful thing to watch.
Costner is sufficiently creepy, yet incredibly down-to-earth as Mr. Brooks. I must say this is one of my favorite performances of his in a very long time.
This film is too out there for a strong recommendation.
It's a shocking story, fraught with strained emotions and fear.
---- a biting, sometimes hilarious drama ----
The part of the film set in Kabul (actually filmed in China) is fascinating, breathtaking and exciting.
For what it is --- a fast-paced, violent thriller, based on a video game, of all things --- it's actually entertaining.
'I'm mad as hell, and I'm not going to take this anymore!' the quote from "Network", sums up nicely my current feelings about horror films, specifically 'The Mist'.
'Love in the Time of Cholera' is breathtakingly filmed. It is an Oscar-worthy movie.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: If you are craving a juicy thriller, then put this movie at the top of your list.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: 'Bella' is a good beginning for Monteverde. He exhibits the making of an excellent director. This film is not quite there yet, but it's close.
This is Ben's debut as a director and he does an admirable job. Of course, with such a stellar cast, it would be hard to screw this up.
Alexandre Desplats composed the music for this film and it is superb. It sets the entire tone, and is completely enthralling.
This is not a film which will appeal to the masses, which is unfortunate. Go see this rare offering and make your own decision.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Gere is almost unmatched at portraying wacky characters like Hunt. He is so charismatic that you believe he can charm, manipulate and/or con just about anyone.
--- a drama/thriller that is also quite funny ---this is the first film in which I truly realized the importance of cinematography.

Seeing 'In the Shadow of the Moon' brought back all of the excitement I remember experiencing in 1969 when Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin took those first steps on the moon. What a fabulous achievement that was ---- for them and for all of us!
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Wow----- who needs horror flicks?? 'The 11th Hour' is scarier than anything I've seen in the theater in a long time.
Speaking of Carol and Ben ---- absolutely no chemistry! Call me silly ---- but for the life of me, I can't see what all the fuss is about concerning Daniel Craig.
We all need to learn a few lessons from this and ratchet up our outrage.
This film is so much more believable, amusing and entertaining than the crap we had to listen to in 'Knocked Up'.
It's a beautiful movie with a heartwarming and, at times, very sad story, along with an important message for all of us.
Steve Buscemi is a multi-talented craftsman consistently putting out good work.
A phenomenal cast ----- there is not a loser in the bunch.It gets its point across in a most effective way.
There always seems to be snickering involved whenever 'Lady Chatterley's Lover' is mentioned. I hope this timeless, gorgeously photographed film will put an end to that.
Michael Moore has given us an evenhanded, insightful look into the mess known as health care in this country.
Do we really need an action film in the middle of summer to remind us how "good" some Americans can be?
It is Marion Cotillard that makes this movie an unforgettable experience.
Haggis has put together a masterful work here ---- it is not to be missed!
The running time is over two hours, but the lives here are richly revealed and vastly rewarding.
The end itself is unsatisfying, as is the movie as a whole. It's unfortunate, especially when you consider what might have been.
Based on the novel of the same name by Rudolfo Anaya, "Bless Me, Ultima" is a magical compilation of family, life, death, religion and the meaning of it all.
Dev Patel and Jeremy Irons excel in this unusual but true story. "The Man Who Knew Infinity" is a timeless tale of immense dedication to one's passion and the strong bonds of friendship.

My biggest complaint --- and one I'm weary of repeating --- is the habit of such films to include massive carnage by bombings, guns, car chases, etc. "Captain America: Civil War" would have been every bit as entertaining without this excessive violence.
With way too much going on, this movie at two hours feels a lot more like three.
There are none of the big laugh-out-loud moments one would expect from these two very talented and hilarious performers.
I am decidedly exhausted by all of the prequels/sequels which make up stories to prolong the life of a once-loved fairy tale.
Ryan Reynolds should be very thankful he got to bow out early in the movie.
Jon Favreau's "The Jungle Book" is an exquisite movie-going experience --- his combination of live action and CG is breathtaking to behold.
Cheadle's portrayal is right in step with Davis' paranoia and almost psychotic personality. His scenes with McGregor are vastly entertaining.
I love McCarthy --- I strongly believe she's better than this. If you really want to laugh, find "Spy" from last year. It's a much better film.
Perhaps we've come to expect too much from Nichols --- or maybe he should re-team with Matthew McConaughey.
Unfortunately, not all of "I Saw the Light" is compelling. Despite Hiddleston's masterful portrayal, Abraham's script is very uneven --- and it's all about the writing.
"Batman V Superman: Dawn of Justice" takes an inordinate amount of time setting up the story --- and getting to the good part.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Vardalos' screenplay this time out is not nearly as original, endearing or amusing as the first. She forgets to interject the humor.
It's a tough slog to get through this movie.
Do not be hoodwinked into believing this is meaningful, abstract thought. It is a load of crap.
"Eye in the Sky" is an extremely tense and absorbing exposé of the moral, legal and political aspects of unmanned warfare.
It's thrilling and suspenseful to a point, but ultimately hard to swallow.
Sure to become a classic.
"Eddie the Eagle" is a delightful true tale of a light-hearted fellow who would not be denied.
"Risen" is beautifully filmed, and the gorgeous soundtrack is an important complement to this moving story of a non-believer's experience with Yeshua.
"Race" is an inspiring and entertaining movie....and it's long overdue.
A ridiculously inane script that is sometimes very funny, mostly not.
It's a clever diabolical twist on Austen's foray into the English class system.
This is not rocket science --- it's Marvel Comics. But it's really good Marvel Comics.
"Money Monster" grabs you at the very beginning and doesn't let go. Is it perfect? No. Is it unusually entertaining? Yes!
Trivial, mundane and senseless, "High-Rise" is a pretentious slog!
Osmond has given moviegoers a delightful and inspirational experience we may have otherwise missed
"The Girl on the Train" is saved solely by Blunt's superior portrayal. It is by no means better than the book, but it is worth a look.
The 1960 movie has always been a favorite of mine....remakes never usually match up, and that is the case here.
"Bridget Jones's Baby" boasts a great cast and overall pretty solid writing. It's not perfect, but it is well worth a viewing.
"Hands of Stone" is an amazing story of how strength, determination and self pride can change the course of one's life.
I abhor seeing talented actors wasted on less-than-acceptable writing.
Everything about this spectacular film is dedicated to creating an epic fantasy that will be viewed many times over and appreciated for its astounding beauty.

To write that Streep is magnificent would be an understatement. She's as good as she has ever been --- no one can out-nuance her. She holds the screen like no other actor, and she brings Florence to life with a joyful, bigger-than-life verve.
"Pete's Dragon" is nearly perfect family entertainment. Grab your children --- or go alone!
Though "Jason Bourne" is well-acted, sporting a terrific cast, it's just another in a long line of supposed "thrillers" that just don't possess that certain excitement any more.
I simply wish director Justin Lin and his crew had done the franchise justice.
"Cafe Society" may not be his best, but it is, at times, hilarious, and as always with Allen's films --- vastly entertaining.
"Son of Saul" is completely horrifying, and yet, we cannot, and should not, look away.
The ultimate pinnacle of "Life, Animated" comes when Owen gives a brilliant speech at a conference on autism in France. If this doesn't move you, you cannot have a heart.
I can report that it is very sweet and funny --- perhaps not completely endearing, but good enough that you will want to round up the kids and get to a movie theater pronto.
Fantastical, offbeat and far-out are not necessarily a good or bad thing. Daniels have proven that they can think outside the box --- and that's a great thing.
Despite my misgivings about certain parts of "The BFG", the movie is totally worthwhile as a family adventure.
A marvelous and exciting action adventure for the entire family.
Logan has penned an engaging script, and he and Grandage have assembled a luminous cast.
"Finding Dory" will have a strong place in the summer animation line-up, but may get lost in the Oscar shuffle.
The most egregious fault with "Now You See Me 2" lies in the complete waste of talent.
"Me Before You" is a chaste love story, a true rarity these days. It's a film you can see with the entire family, and one that you can watch --- and will be watching --- over and over again.
A gorgeous production with marvelous special effects and set designs. It's a treasure trove of delights to behold.
"Weiner" is disappointing because it doesn't tell us anything we don't already know about this narcissistic congressman who seems headed for greatness but simply can't help himself.
The biggest problem with "The Nice Guys" is that it can't decide what it wants to be when it grows up --- a comedy or a violent thriller?
It's a beautiful and moving "buddy" story --- full of hilarity.
"The Accountant" is entertaining enough. I enjoyed the characters and storyline and particularly liked the ending, which I found endearing rather than false in its efforts.
I was truly shocked and very disappointed when the Oscar nominations were recently announced and Ms. Smith's name was not among the nominees for Best Actress.
Last year at this time we had "Paddington" to relieve the blahs. Unfortunately, "Norm of the North" is no "Paddington!"
Laugh-out-loud funny...people of a certain age, i.e., Baby Boomers, will especially appreciate its humor.
A rare summer gem.
"No Escape" could have gone either way --- bad or good. And, at 103 minutes, it came very close to capturing the "bad" moniker.
A serious, thought-provoking, funny, moving tale of a self-evolved winner.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "The Man From U.N.C.L. E." is totally enjoyable for everyone.
"Shaun the Sheep Movie" is a totally engaging, delightfully clever bit of filmmaking. The stop-motion clay animation is seamless and flawless.
In a summer filled with too many action/adventure films, "Kahlil Gibran's The Prophet" is a lovely break from all of that nonsense.
"The Gift" is full of various ludicrous acts, though, in full disclosure, I did scream at one predictable surprise --- shame on me!
See it with your girlfriends, and leave your husbands at home.
I have nothing good to say about "Fantastic Four" --- so let's just leave it at that.
"The End of the Tour" is entertaining repartee between two accomplished writers with genius minds.
"Best of Enemies" is one of the most interesting and revelatory documentaries in years. It blows last year's Oscar winner, "Citizenfour" out of the water.
Though the film doesn't provide any answers, it does give voice to the millions who suffer these same situations daily.
Every bit as exciting and mind-boggling as its predecessors.
Is it silly --- yes! Did I laugh --- yes!
A stunning performance by Gyllenhaal, but it's not enough to save "Southpaw". Everything is so neat and so predictable.
Allen's directing skills have not diminished in "Irrational Man", but his writing suggests a less-thought-out philosophical pattern than some of his much better efforts such as "Match Point".
I am not sure a film about mothers tracking vicious gang bangers is such a great idea, specifically since there are many glaring faults.
The key to the success of "Mr. Holmes"....McKellen is clearly the right choice to portray Holmes in his advanced years --- and he is simply marvelous, as always.
Judd Apatow and Amy Schumer --- what a combination! ...an outrageous and naughty comedy about one woman's struggle to be her own person.
Filmmaker Matthew Heineman places himself in the line of fire more than once in this shocking and eye-opening real-life expose of the illegal drug industry in Mexico.
If watching "Batkid Begins" doesn't move you, I seriously don't know what will. And who doesn't love a five-year-old superhero?
Though the first few minutes of "Minions" are rather amusing, it quickly devolves into the same mean-spiritedness which abounded in "Despicable Me".
A beautiful movie wrapped around a moving story --- one that should not be missed.
I found Meyers' script charming and delightful. Plus the added charisma of De Niro and Hathaway on screen helps to keep "The Intern" from getting stupid.
Denis Villeneuve has directed a super-bloody killer of a film. But without cinematographer Roger Deakins, "Sicario" would not be nearly as dramatic.
Zemeckis' spin on the story is terrifying --- electrifying ---- and I'm not even afraid of heights.
"The Hateful Eight" is grotesquely violent and full of misogynists. I am overwhelmingly tired of Quentin Tarantino's shtick.
I laughed out loud a few times, but mostly I was appalled by the juvenile, and distinctly, unfunny screenplay.
As far as I'm concerned, "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" is the best film of the year.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Fast-paced, cleverly informative and hilarious, "The Big Short" will leave you gasping --- and fuming.
"The Danish Girl" is a masterpiece!
"The Letters" is a beautiful and deeply moving tribute to the self-sacrificing Mother Teresa.
Inárritu and DiCaprio have given us an adventure we will not forget --- and Leo should be accepting a Best Actor Oscar come February.
"Spotlight" makes you long for the days of real investigative journalism, when reporters got their facts straight, and exposes were only written when they could be corroborated.
"The Good Dinosaur" is full of breathtaking vistas and amazing animation.
Tom Hardy's portrayals make this a "See It Now!" for those who appreciate Oscar-worthy performances.
The only good thing I can write about "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2" is watching Philip Seymour Hoffman as Plutarch Heavensbee one last time.
Although I am growing extremely weary of these teen novels being turned into lengthy productions, "The 5th Wave" is not as bad as I was expecting.
"Brooklyn" is sure to keep you engrossed from beginning to end.
"By The Sea", by Jolie Pitt's own admission, is not a film for the masses. But any opportunity to watch Angelina and Brad in a film together is a plus for me.
This sweet homage to Schulz's body of work manages to capitalize on Charlie Brown's misfortunes, and give us an experience worth remembering ---- and seeing again.
"Spectre" is, like "Skyfall", waaaaayyyyyy too long, with a story that is significantly less than intriguing.
"Suffragette" is a must-see, especially for all of the young women who find the word "feminist" so disdainful.
"Our Brand is Crisis" is not in the least entertaining, and possesses one of the worst and phoniest endings in movie history.
"Room" is a touching and thought-provoking film --- one of the best so far this year.
"Bridge of Spies" takes a while to get rolling, but eventually this true story turns into a chilling tale of intrigue, power and a true sense of right and wrong.
Every single actor in "Steve Jobs" is immensely gifted, with Fassbender leading the charge.
Guggenhiem has captured a beautiful, truthful portrait of an incredibly brave girl.
It's all intriguing and breathtaking, along with a mournful, lovely score by Klaus Badelt, but not enough to compensate for the miserable writing.
Scott has directed a phenomenal film --- one that will be a real crowd-pleaser. It's impossible for it not to be --- the adventure is intense, frightening and coming so close to being a reality.

The resilience of these men and their families, who would not back down from a fight with the Chilean government, which was forced to do the right thing, is remarkable, and deserves to be brought to life in this inspiring film.
Co-writers/brothers Alex and David Pastor have taken what could have been a science "future" thriller and turned it into a science/less dud.
There is nothing new --- just the same high-octane chase scenes and overtly violent battles.
You know your film is in deep trouble when even Hanks can't save it .

movie_review_blurb: Writers/directors Maymon and Granit have penned a marvelous script full of humor and pathos --- then selected a celebrated cast, including comedic actors, to bring this moving tale to life.
Skeptics will discount this new version of Maleficent, but with Jolie's bravura performance and Fanning as precious as ever, it's not hard to swallow this fairy tale.
It's an unbelievably clever take on the adolescent mind and how it all works.
For a generation not familiar with the original "Jurassic Park", they will revel in the pure fantasy of this film. It's a crowd pleaser, even for those who have become nonplussed by such magic.
The last time I wrote that I wanted to see a film a second time was "Paddington" in January. Now I'm saying this again --- I must see "Spy" at least one more time --- it's that HILARIOUS!
What should have been an entertaining romantic comedy from Crowe turns out to be an overly disappointing one. Shame on him for squandering such talent!
This is a film I could watch again and again because it so beautiful --- and beautifully acted.
The screenplay doesn't capitalize on the revelatory aspects, but devolves into the same narcissistic male bonding shenanigans we've endured before.
Joss Whedon brings along his "A" game for this installment, and it doesn't disappoint.
Filmmakers have been manipulating moviegoers' emotions since the beginning of this art form. However, rarely has one film been so patently blatant in those efforts than "Little Boy".

"The Water Diviner" is an uneven effort by first-time director Russell Crowe, and the occasionally preposterous screenplay by Andrew Knight and Andrew Anastasios doesn't exactly help Crowe as director, either.
How this did not beat out "Ida" for Best Foreign Film at the Oscars last Sunday I will never understand.
movie_title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Goold never allows the script or actors to make light of the relationship --- or its importance.
This latest production showcases lavish, breathtaking cinematography, in addition to heartwarming stories about the inhabitants of these gorgeous lands.
Not only is the truth unforgettable, heartbreaking and triumphant, but Mirren, Reynolds and Bruhl make it all the more special.
"Home" is a truly lovely and adorable film to attend with children, though doing so is not a requirement. I have a feeling Oh will be with us for a long time.
"Get Hard" does have a few laugh-out-loud moments, and a couple of priceless scenes. But, as with most comedies lately, it has more than its share of cringe-inducing shots,
We are way past the time for pandering. Colleges and their administrations must be held accountable. No longer should even one victim of sexual assault be treated in the manner evidenced here.
This intimate look at the supremely mild-mannered piano virtuoso will find its audience.

From the opening scene through to the very last frame, "The Gunman" is completely predictable, and a brutally violent, gory mess. Despite its insane savagery, the beginning and end of "The Gunman" are downright laughable.
I am not a fan of such stories, usually, but by the end of "Insurgent" I was duly impressed, and interested in the outcome awaiting us in the next film in this series.
Not just any "Cinderella", but genius visionary Kenneth Branagh's majestic, gorgeous, sweeping version of this beautiful tale of a kind, courageous girl.
"Unfinished Business" is sloppy, tiresome, poorly constructed and ultimately awful.
"Chappie" is one of those movies that's forgettable before you even leave the theater.
It's the predictability that ultimately hurts "Ex Machina". Talk about killing the suspense ---
"HB2" isn't awful, it's simply not that amusing.
"Clouds of Sils Maria" is such a gorgeous movie --- I could sit through it again and again.
The dialogue is clean, meaningful and chilling, the necessary component to make this an unforgettable movie.
Another often hilarious buddy/food/road trip through some of the most picturesque vistas Italy has to offer.
The script is dull, heavy-handed and predictable, with only a few twists and surprises...these characters are simply not compelling.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It is the dichotomy of the beauty of the setting with Mengele's monstrous deeds that make "The German Doctor" so unnerving.
Great filmmaking is an art. McDonagh and Gleeson have showcased that art with "Calvary".
"Get On Up" is a revelation --- and a breathtaking step back into the world of James Brown's soul.
A delightful film filled with fun and food, funny and heart-warming.
It's a summer blockbuster worthy of the moniker.
"Hercules" is great fun and highly entertaining if you enjoy Greek mythology and action/adventure films.
"Happy Christmas" tries very hard to be cool and relevant. But, in the end, it's pretty average and never gets to any real point.
I found it utterly engaging --- I loved it!
It wants so badly to be profound, and while it is extremely touching and moving on some levels, on others it misfires completely.
"The November Man" will keep you entertained, especially if you're a spy thriller junkie like me.
"Sex Tape" is nothing more than a mindless way to spend an hour and a half --- not great, not totally awful.
James has done a great service with this doc --- it demands to be seen, and Roger's life to be appreciated.
Enough with the sight gags and wisecracks about her size, and her love of pies. Choose some other topic to make fun of --- preferably not one which insults our intelligence.
"Earth to Echo" is a flimsy excuse for a tribute to number 25 on AFI's 100 Years 100 Movies List.
Who knew that a spoof of romantic comedies could be so hilarious, and entertaining?

A shocking and disturbing look at higher education in the U.S., "Ivory Tower" does an excellent job exposing the many problems facing universities, and more importantly, students who wish to attend them.
The battle scenes are consistently too long, even though the special effects of the street fighting in Chicago and Hong Kong are awesome.

It appears the filmmakers had noble intentions in revealing the inequity of influence from wealthy donors, i.e., the Koch brothers, "Citizen Koch" is muddied in its attempt. It fails to deliver its intended message...wake up, America, or we're screwed!
Every bit as enjoyable as its predecessor, because, it doesn't take itself too seriously.
Though I completely understand the thought process behind the decision, there simply isn't enough action in "Part 1" to justify a separate movie.
"The Signal" is completely underwhelming --- not enough science in the fiction. And certainly not thrilling.
I loved the first "How to Train Your Dragon". But this movie is mired in lengthy oratories which come off as preachy and full of righteous indignation.
At least, for once, the fight scenes don't last forever. My favorite is the major battle between Caesar and Koba --- it's very well choreographed and terrifically exciting.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Love is Strange" is a richly rewarding film. Hopefully it will be remembered come Oscar season.
"Third Person" makes a valiant attempt at being a continuation of Haggis' love for storytelling and multi-layering, but it falls flat --- not having the panache necessary to keep it compelling.
"The Skeleton Twins" is a strong, solid film with nuanced performances by an eclectic cast. It could prove to be one of the best of the year.
Jane Hawking's inspirational love story of her life with Stephen is the stuff for which movies are made.
We aren't provided with enough emotional information and impact to make this believable.
Admittedly, there are a few stinky moments --- the engagement of Megan and Anthony --- their breakup --- the prom scene --- to name a few, but "Laggies" is still an enjoyable film.
A spectacle of outrageous proportions, Nolan's creativity has reached new levels with this latest achievement.
The screenplay is very suspenseful in parts, but that tension doesn't hold up throughout.
Quite amusing, and honestly endearing.
There will be much talk about many aspects of this film come Oscar season, and editing had better be on that list.
"Rosewater" is a triumph for Stewart.
A moving and haunting script --- also a funny one, at times.
"Fury" is an astonishingly detailed production about the realities of war.
Melfi has constructed a meaningful, touching and often hilarious screenplay. And by utilizing the exceptional talents of the entire cast, he has solidified his path in films.
The screenplay is lacking in conviction from any angle.
Without the well-honed, and not overly maudlin script, "Pride" would not have become the testament to support, commitment and love that it is.
"Birdman" is a very unusual movie-going experience. For that matter alone, it's worth a trip to the cinema.

It's not an easy task to make a decent mystery/thriller --- let alone one that was such a widely-read, popular book. But Fincher, Flynn and the rest of the crew were definitely geared up for the project --- with a formidable end result.
I don't believe "The Equalizer" will score Denzel another Oscar, but it's a terrific performance.
A dismal, inane and laughable screenplay.

Gandolfini is perfect, but he's really just playing a less classy version of Anthony Soprano. With this being his very last role, the fact that he's back playing a mobster is satisfying, but truly sad.

"Last Days in Vietnam" isn't just about the horrific mistakes that were made by the U.S. government. It ultimately unveils the untold acts of heroism performed by a select few to save many. It's a true testament to the human spirit.
Who knew that Simon has such a broad range, and can perform in such a serious manner? Brilliant ---
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There is nothing new here --- no startling revelations. It's been done before --- on TV --- and better.
For the moviegoers who are looking forward to the pairing of Duvall and Downey Jr. --- forget it! This script isn't worth their time or energy --- nor yours!
Driving around in a doorless minivan in LA --- so absurd --- they deserve a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Kill the Messenger" is an extremely powerful film --- and one that is so important historically.
Left me more perplexed than pleased.
An impossibly self-involved portrait of a union far more commonplace than its offspring seem to believe.
Missing no stops on the road from cloying to annoying, Harlem Aria has waited more than 10 years for domestic release. Maybe its destiny has been written.
Alternately rancid and ridiculous, strident and sickly sweet, Our Family Wedding offers plenty that's old, borrowed and blue; it's the something new that's missing.
In Peter Hanson's dishy documentary Tales From the Script, 46 screenwriters gab agreeably about the tribulations of their profession.
[A] stunning documentary.
movie_title: Fixer: The Taking of Ajmal Naqshbandi (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A nifty little chiller that balances its cold terrain with an unexpectedly warm heart.
Exit could be a new subgenre: the prankumentary.

Offered only hints of life away from the barre or of Sy's relationship with his coolly poised benefactress, viewers will see either a very fortunate young man or a beautiful protégé, dancing as fast as he can to please everyone but himself.
Intermittently beautiful but frustratingly leaden, Shutterbug labors ineffectually to promote authenticity over artifice.
Strains to wring tension from a tired premise and an airless script.
An exemplar of fresh-air filmmaking that addresses the devastating legacy of the drug thalidomide with acidic wit and grumpy honesty.
Pretty to look at but dismayingly obvious, as in the shot of a wall-mounted crucifix gazing sorrowfully down on an incestuous struggle.
Opens tentatively but ends confidently with a climax that's bloody enough to jolt but not enough to sicken -- a trick that too many directors have yet to master.
Epic in scope but intimate in theme, The Warlords heaves with spectacular battles and the relentless sway of self-interest over conscience.
Like many relationships, Breaking Upwards starts in bed and ends on the street. The journey in between, however, feels as new as anything a tiny budget and a boatload of talent could produce.
Despite marvelously moody visuals and a tantalizing setup, Pornography: A Thriller finally puzzles more than it pleases.
Purports to be a documentary about the American public school system. In reality, however, it's a bludgeoning rant against a single state.
A professionally executed farce of the yelling-family variety.
The director, Nicole Opper, makes space for the complexities of transracial adoption without forcing her film into a predetermined, inspirational box.
Sweats to wring laughs from overworked themes and underwhelming performances.
Tight and tender, this small family drama is so visually expressive that listening is always subordinate to looking.
Inept, immature and terminally irritating, Mo is the kind of persistent clown who only responds to a slap in the kisser; would that the film were as easy to banish.

By the time we reach the climactic karaoke smackdown, we have learned more about Freddy Kruegerâ(TM)s personal hygiene challenges -- and how to make a shockingly bad movie -- than we ever wanted to know.
This seductively fluid and tactile drama explores love and identity through the prism of the female body and the rights of its owner.
movie_title: Le Chant des Mariées (The Wedding Song) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Not just sobering; it's a full-on assault.
Packed with illuminating interviews and lyrical movement, Breath Made Visible portrays a woman with angels in her feet and innovation in her blood. Long may she rock.
A shaggy comedy with more heart than heft.
Philosophically ripe but cinematically undercooked.
Arranged in sections that range from merely interesting to downright horrifying, this provocative documentary suggests a system regulated by fear and motivated by the desire to control.
Sluggish, stylized and frequently washed in a bilious green tint, The Missing Person is yet oddly irresistible, its omnipresent anxiety like a musical chord that neither rises nor falls.
Well-intentioned but philosophically timid, For My Father wants to meditate on the moral reshuffling that can accompany imminent death.
movie_title: For My Father (Sof Shavua B'Tel Aviv) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Propelled by an eccentric cast of characters and increasingly seamy locations, Fix dashes headlong through Los Angeles with a little charm and a lot of verve.
In the engrossing, exasperating, exquisitely shot documentary Loot, a search for buried treasure becomes an unlikely trigger for emotional catharsis.
After a particularly brutal, attention-grabbing start, Breaking Point quickly devolves into a flavorless stew of murder, corruption, blackmail and baby tossing.
The narrative may flag, but the doomsday atmosphere and George Liddleâ(TM)s production design remain vivid until the final, blood-splattered reel.
Respectfully and without dramatization (the ideas are electric enough), the directors observe a cross section of articulate evangelicals and accompany a Christian group on a revealing trip to Israel.
Expertly weaving personal fears, family tensions and political action (the zabbaleen donâ(TM)t whine; they strive to modernize), Garbage Dreams records the tremblings of a culture at a crossroads.
One part hagiography and two parts psychotherapy.
[A] restrained and ethically nuanced documentary.
An asinine pileup of improbabilities.
According to Murder in Fashion, the real culprit in the murder of Gianni Versace was the aesthetic tyranny of gay culture.
This saga, set in Berlin, is more committed to its bloodletting than to any of its characters.
Horseshoe crabs scuttle like possessed Nazi helmets and a school of fish morphs from dreidel to disco ball, as if choreographed by Busby Berkeley.
This scarily convincing argument that the end, if not quite nigh, is at least foreseeable urges us to wake up and smell the highly enriched uranium.

However crassly delivered, Mr. Korine's warning against over-consumption is unambiguous: these savages are our future, our "true seed." The only surprise is that he didn't include a shot of one of them violating this film.
In roles that could have devolved into arias of melodrama, the cast never overplays its hand, fighting the omnipresent melancholy in small ways rather than large.
Deftly combining low-key romance and gentle humor, the director, Ella Lemhagen (working from Michael Druker's 2008 play), stares down prejudice with a nudge and a wink rather than a soapbox.
You may not believe it's possible to bore people to death with a film about risking your life, but The Wildest Dream comes shockingly close.
movie_title: The Wildest Dream: Conquest of Everest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Wavers between soapy and trite, though the setting for the trials - the fascinatingly medieval Tribunal of Palermo - lends the courtroom scenes a bulletproof dignity.
Despite a gratingly clichéd soundtrack and a violent climax that feels wholly unearned, "The Kid" has an awkward earnestness that's very endearing.
Alex Karpovsky, gives life and form to the invisible act of one brain sparking another, showcasing a connection as ineffable as creativity itself.
movie_title: Trust Us, This Is All Made Up (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film's explicit depictions of regional violence have upset some audiences, but there's no denying their impact: those butchered pigs are only the beginning.
A raunchy romantic comedy that, like its heroine, rarely has both feet on the ground.

Moving, mysterious and intellectually provocative, A Film Unfinished positions familiar Holocaust horrors (the R rating was unsuccessfully contested) within a philosophical commentary on the way we view images.

Aside from the difficulty of spoofing a saga that has always been winkingly aware of its own angsty excesses, there is the inadvisability of angering a tweeniverse whose emotional investment in the originals borders on pathological.
Filled with mythic style and magical thinking, Altiplano feeds the eyes but gives rations to the mind.
This eye-opening documentary reveals the mensch beneath the moolah, the ardent social reformer beneath the paisley-patterned shirts.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The spare, relentlessly controlled debut feature of the Mexican director Michel Franco, Daniel & Ana advances on minimal dialogue and with virtually no musical accompaniment.
An unusually restrained and genuinely eerie little movie perched at the intersection of faith, folklore and female puberty.

Filled with clear, bright images and moments of skewed genius, this delicate debut effortlessly evokes those languid summer doldrums, when even a rotting girlfriend is better than no girlfriend at all.
The South Korean director Hong Sang-soo unleashes yet another emotionally stunted antihero in Night and Day, a rambling study of male arrested development.
An enormously likable peculiarity, a shambling road trip that effortlessly marries a guileless tone to knowing observations.
Off-formula and on-point, the story's emotional jabs are all the more poignant for their unpredictability.
Has an old-fashioned sincerity that entertains without engaging.
Cares less about investigating a death than about vindicating an accused killer.
Sincere performances elevate an underdeveloped script and awkward filmmaking.
The mood of scrambling desperation can be exhausting, but the filmmaking is never less than exhilarating.
Strongly acted and beautifully photographed (by Virgil Mirano), "Spoken Word" is a quietly resonant family drama about the tug of old habits and the difficulties of escaping the past.
Runs 20 minutes too long and several rungs above the head of its target audience.
Looking as if it were devised on acid and executed on mushrooms, this imaginative debut feature from the Seattle artist and filmmaker David Russo finds meaning in cleaning and life in dead ends.
movie_title: The Immaculate Conception of Little Dizzle (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Technically innovative but narratively moribund.
Tries to pin down the alchemy that transports a film from reject bin to cult favorite.
Strains to accommodate its daft premise and pontificating lead.
The result is a lovers-on-the-lam blast of pure pulp escapism, so devoted to diversion that you probably won't even notice the corn.
Never forgetting the rush of the game, the directors regularly serve up fleet footage of the teamâ(TM)s highs and lows, allowing the rhythms of the field to set the filmâ(TM)s volatile beat.
movie_title: After The Cup: Sons Of Sakhnin United (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Placidly photographed and lacking in urgency, Survival shows us the living flailing at fate and the dead just flailing.
Perched at the intersection of psychological survey and serial-killer exposé, "Cropsey" loosens the girdle of the documentary form to accommodate much more than facts.
A must-see for coprophiliacs and spanking enthusiasts, The Human Centipede (First Sequence) may be the year's first mainstream fetish movie.
Clogged with court transcripts, medical records and repetitive (if moving) patient testimony, Burzynski tickles the mind only at the cost of trampling the eyes.
A brain-deadening collision of high concept and low standards.
Though infinitely classier -- and easier on the eyes -- than Cartel, the recent documentary exploring public education, this latest charter-school commercial is no less one-sided.
If Ken Loach and Roberto Benigni went into a bar, drank themselves into a stupor and emerged the next morning with a screenplay, it might look a lot like The Misfortunates.
Explores the limits of cultural isolation with ramshackle avidity.
This spasmodically entertaining documentary from Angela Ismailos chronicles her globe-trotting goal of interviewing 10 of her personal cinematic heroes.

Energized by neither music nor narration, and without the essential urgency of facts and figures, the result is a series of finely polished but relentlessly dull snapshots lapped by rising tides and melting permafrost.

Frantic from the get-go, this new crop of zombie bait barrels through shadowy hallways and fends off waxen, emaciated attackers with such hysterical speed it's impossible to know -- or care -- whose face has just been chomped.

As the body count climbs and a pair of bickering surveillance guys watch in jaded fascination, the director, Fouad Mikati, reveals himself to be far more competent with blunt trauma than subtle interaction.
A baffling journey to a pointless destination, The Contenders offers a suffocating wallow in the lives of the rich and miserable.
An unabashed celebration of geekitude, idealism and the will to win.
A muddled morality tale more interested in coming of age than getting of wisdom.
Easy on the eyes but brutal on the ears, The Perfect Sleep fuses Shakespearean tragedy and noir iconography into a strange, lovely, leaden ball of confusion.
More a designer frame for actors than nourishing entertainment.
In The Photograph, an unlikely friendship eases an old man's death and a young woman's life.
The Lodger is a spooky story ruined by lumpen dialogue, cloddish performances and a director and writer (David Ondaatje) oblivious to both.
Depending on your tolerance for relentless whimsy and unflagging eccentricity, The Toe Tactic will make you gurgle with delight or groan with exasperation.
Roberta Grossman's Blessed Is the Match: The Life and Death of Hannah Senesh documents courage, but steers clear of character.
movie_title: Blessed Is the Match: The Life and Death of Hannah Senesh (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Our City Dreams is a lyrical documentary about the intersection of location and imagination.
If you can get past the excruciating title, Life. Support. Music. is a blessedly nimble journey from loss to reclamation.
As far as I can tell, the only ability in short supply is acting.
An airless, fragmented feature that's been kicking around since 2007.
Daddies and daughters lend a wistful emotional core to Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li, an otherwise generic martial-arts movie with video-game credentials.
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Like an annoying new puppy, Sherman's Way just wants to run around in circles and lick your face. After a while, though, you kind of fall in love with it.
I suspect the movie's sound designers deserve some kind of an award: thanks to them, the damage one can inflict with small appliances and a giant grudge is all too clear.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The performances are across-the-board solid (most of the cast is theater-based).
Skills Like This gazes indulgently on 20-something aimlessness and the comfort of assigned roles. In Mr. Miranda's hands sloth can be more appealing than you might think.
So cheesy and so poorly acted that it should never have seen the light of day.
Gives you the creeps, the giggles and the groans in almost equal measure.
Thanks to sincere performances (most notably from Mr. Ritter and Eva Amurri as Charlie's upper-crust crush) and clever writing (by Peter Elkoff), the movie never becomes maudlin.
Shapes a standard prison-break drama into a metaphysical study of freedom and reparation.
Cool-headed, lighthearted and outrageously entertaining, Forbidden Lie$ is documentary-as-striptease.
A charmingly sentimental but ultimately pointless homage to the sci-fi classics of yesteryear.
A strange synergy of old and new, My Bloody Valentine 3D blends cutting-edge technology and old-school prosthetics to produce something both familiar and alien: gore you can believe in.
Art house meets grind house in Cargo 200, Alexey Balabanov's morbidly compelling thriller set in the Soviet Union.
In Bedtime Stories the pain of this artistic limbo is written all over Adam Sandler's character, a resentful hotel handyman named Skeeter.
Proof positive that a naked hottie and whiz-bang pacing can disguise gaping narrative cracks, Timecrimes makes sci-fi lemonade out of low-budget lemons.
Propelled by geysers of blood and tidal waves of neuroses, Tokyo Gore Police plumbs wounds both cultural and physical to deliver splatterific social satire.
In Delwende the African filmmaker S. Pierre Yameogo tackles social injustice in present-day Burkina Faso with grace, economy and exquisitely controlled anger.
Filming over four years and tracking several cases, the Brazilian director Jorge W. Atalla favors a fevered shooting style that's repetitious and disorienting but also effortlessly dramatic.
Choose Connor, a jaundiced look at political power and moral turpitude, draws you in by creeping you out.
In Delwende the African filmmaker S. Pierre Yameogo tackles social injustice in present-day Burkina Faso with grace, economy and exquisitely controlled anger.
Quarantine, yet another pseudo-documentary horror movie, delivers the heebie-jeebies with solid acting and perfectly calibrated shocks.
Dysfunction beguiles in Good Dick, a perverse romantic comedy whose coarse title belies its tender heart.
Morning Light is a sweepingly beautiful documentary unmoored by democratic intentions.
Without Daniel Craig's 007-enhanced profile, it's unlikely that Flashbacks of a Fool would have appeared anywhere except the Netflix queues of his most rabid fans.
A teenage comedy with an old-fogy scent.
Who Does She Think She Is? is an engaging documentary about the struggle to create art while nurturing life.
movie_title: Who Does She Think She Is? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's not a moment of warmth or ease in Ben X, Nic Balthazar's punishingly cacophonous debut.
Saving Marriage is an in-the-trenches, defiantly partisan and exuberantly big-hearted movie.
Stripping away centuries of civilization, The Matador confronts something primal in human nature, daring us to do the same.
God and Satan duke it out for the soul of a young girl in The Haunting of Molly Hartley, an unexpectedly cynical addition to the teen-scream genre.
Never begins to tap the talent at its disposal.
Eden is a picture so modest and minor-key that the emotional bruise it leaves may take days to develop.
Not even the august presence of Maximilian Schell can dispel the odor of fusty smut that clings to House of the Sleeping Beauties.
movie_title: Das Haus der Schlafenden Schönen (House of the Sleeping Beauties) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Plugging the same two actresses into different Sapphic scenarios may be a valid filmmaking strategy but it can be an extremely boring one.
While the director ogles his cast and busies himself with hackneyed visual metaphors, Antarctica wallows in casual lust and bored disaffection.
Fear(s) of the Dark is an animated anthology that tells its stories with an inventiveness that's seldom scary but never less than mesmerizing.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Directed by Hilla Medalia with exactly the right balance of musical theater and personal drama, After the Storm presents a touching affirmation of the healing power of right-brain stimulation.
The Pope's Toilet cloaks religious critique in the scrappy tempo of irremediable poverty and irrepressible enterprise.
movie_title: El Baño del Papa (The Pope's Toilet) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Crank: High Voltage, starring Jason Statham as a man with a machine instead of a heart, is boorish, bigoted and borderline pornographic.
Note to the writer Kelly Fremon: Is Ryden postgraduation or postmortem?
Mr. Dresen and his actors create an atmosphere of reckless vulnerability that's immediately compelling and artistically intriguing. We want to explore this relationship further.
An intrepid record of modern-day piracy and the high-stakes battle between commerce and ecological survival.
movie_title: At the Edge of the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Since not even 3-D can put your eyes out, our only hope is that this time, the title is a promise and not a tease.
Has a static, playlike tone exacerbated by stilted performances and meager production values.

Trafficking in irresponsible inferences and unsupported conclusions, the filmmaker Brent Leung offers himself as suave docent through a globe-trotting pseudo-investigation that should raise the hackles of anyone with even a glancing knowledge of the basic
In the press materials Mr. Butler informs us enthusiastically that the movie "has all the hallmarks of Neveldine's and Taylor's sick, yet genius minds." At least he's half right.
Filled with glancing light and happy faces, Marina of the Zabbaleen, fights hard to sweeten the misery of its surroundings.
Despite excellent stunt work and a too-brief appearance by Orlando Jones as an unflappable cop, the movie -- unlike Mr. Douglas's hairdo -- never rises above mediocrity.
A relentlessly upbeat vanity project destined for the Disney family archive.

Despite the film's sketchy aesthetic and barely animate lead, its tone is carefully contrived: I'll wager no one in your circle is as dryly funny or spontaneously surreal as Harmony's nonsupport group.

Thanks to an informative, buoyant tone and the director's own restless intelligence, the film preaches to the unconverted with passion, energy and graphics so clear that they would make Al Gore weep all over his PowerPoint.
Mr. Jaglom displays an endearing lack of cynicism but an equal lack of discipline.
More an infomercial than a movie, The Providence Effect is, at best, a well-earned tribute to one manâ(TM)s unwavering vision.
According to the press notes, pandorum means "Orbital Dysfunctional Syndrome"; whatever that is, by the end of the movie I was convinced I had caught it.
It recounts a deeply personal, highly subjective and inarguably thought-provoking story of one family's quest for a certain kind of peace.

Set among the mean streets and meaner people of downtown Los Angeles, this laughably clichéd dive into sexual masochism and hardscrabble survival replaces story with outline and characters with place holders.
Spirited, probing and frequently hilarious, it coasts on the fearless charm of its front man and the eye-opening candor of its interviewees.
A stunningly witless revival of the infamous British film series about a girls' boarding school.
Feels underwritten and overdressed.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: With a surrogate for every demographic and a heroine for every taste, Casi Divas jiggles and jokes its way around as many Mexican box-office bases as possible.
At once regretful and optimistic, frustrated and proud. Mr. Stone has shown us the way; now all we need is the will.
Mr. Dresen and his actors create an atmosphere of reckless vulnerability thatâ(TM)s immediately compelling and artistically intriguing. We want to explore this relationship further.
If you thrill to the sight of a preschool teacher bringing an investment banker to his knees, then Nursery University is for you.
This intricate and compelling documentary paints a saddening portrait of American politics.
Revue melds disparate images of Soviet life during the 1950s and '60s into a luminous time capsule of patriotic fervor and political fealty.
Might have been more effective with a little more honey and a lot less vinegar.
Enriched by Mutsuo Naganuma's velvety photography, the director's restrained emotional grammar is surprisingly affecting.
Hampered by a script that veers from infantile to ugly and a director who doesn't know when to say "cut."

At a time when horror is defined by limp Japanese retreads or punishing exercises in pure sadism, Drag Me to Hell has a tonic playfulness that's unabashedly retro, an indulgent return to Mr. Raimi's goofy, gooey roots.
Emboldened by alcohol and steeped in despair, the characters in Sugisball lunge for love but would settle for understanding.

Smart without being smart-alecky, Mr. Rosen's writing avoids the aggressive cleverness and gummy politics of many similarly themed movies, focusing instead on realistic dialogue and low-key interaction.
The Golden Boys is an object lesson in how to squander a seasoned cast, a charming premise and a breathtaking location.
"He's having an existential crisis," explains Sophie. Too bad it's not a very cinematic one.
Suffers from abusive close-ups, repetitive fight sequences and uninspired demon design.
Unfailingly modest and profoundly humane.
The tangled issue of illegal immigration gives Paraíso Travel its motivation, but thoughtful storytelling and committed performances give the movie its heart.
An aggressively hetero American male is seduced by a hot Colombian pickpocket in Sabor Tropical.
Hugh Dancy plays a Manhattan engineer who suffers from Asperger's syndrome in this charming romantic comedy.

The movie is a Trojan horse: an exceptionally well-made documentary that unfolds like a spy thriller, complete with bugged hotel rooms, clandestine derring-do and mysterious men in gray flannel suits.
This film is an affectionate, rollicking guide to the drive-in classics of Australian filmmaking from the 1970s and '80s.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: One of the more doltish entries in the torture subgenre.
Its wit and style, however, are thoroughly modern, as is a hilarious ending that leaves the sequel door wide open. And why not?
So different from the usual fare that it might have arrived from another galaxy.
Like the makers of the excellent high-school-based MTV reality series, "If You Really Knew Me," Ms. Abeles believes that benevolent intervention is an adult's most powerful tool.
A laudable if lightweight argument for broader minds and thicker skins.

This witless installment features the usual ultra-slow-motion mayhem and helpful freeze-frames to allow us to admire the extra dimension. Fans will not be happy, however, to learn that Ms. Jovovich is more decently clothed this time around.
Mr. Hanks performs with customary blankness and a woeful lack of chemistry with his hardworking co-star.

Though the enjoyable prickliness of the film's early scenes soon dissolves into cozy solutions, a sturdy supporting cast - even Ron Leibman's scenery-chewing turn as Laura's blowhard father is more amusing than annoying - balances the scales.

Anyone looking for the lowdown on haute cuisine will be sorely disappointed: devoid of emotion, context or narrative, the baffling avant-garde techniques and extreme politesse of the lab become oppressively dull.
Swerving from bland to brutal, endearingly coy to shockingly explicit, the Canadian import "Good Neighbors" finds pitch-black comedy among white-bread lives.
This fabulously inventive debut feature, written and directed by the British comedian Joe Cornish, never flags.
A gay tragedy in three acts and more than a dozen excellent songs, "House of Boys" conveys an emotional honesty that overrides its dated style.
The writer and director, Rashaad Ernesto Green, relies too often on gender clichés...
A deliciously warped wallow in misogyny, depravity and dead-eyed manipulation, "Cold Fish" charts the twisted alliance of two tropical-fish salesmen with baleful glee.
An exhausted pileup of rock-movie clichés, "The Perfect Age of Rock 'n' Roll" presents artistic self-destruction with the solemnity of a movie that has invented a spanking-new genre.
movie_title: The Perfect Age of Rock 'n' Roll (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Dipping in and out of luminous black and white, "Protektor" has a distancing glamour that prevents the story from digging in.

A creature feature of disappointing stupidity, Rise of the Planet of the Apes replaces the sociopolitical underpinnings of the original film and its sequels with a limp warning about the evils of animal testing.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Lively, swift, vibrantly colorful and for the most part wonderfully acted, the film is slyly aware of the daytime talk show as a vehicle for women's concerns.
Laid-back, observant and rather shady, it cares so little for your attention that you can't stop watching.
A droll and dusty portrait of a place where privacy is prized and boundaries respected.
A restrained, ripely atmospheric thriller that relies more on mood than on special effects.
A creaky parade of conspiracy and paranoia that collapses military brainwashing and suspected backward-masking in the recording industry into one indigestible lump.
The fights are unexciting and the brothers uncharismatic, yet the film finds a soft, soulful center...
Brilliant, bizarre, dazzling and utterly demented...
What they're after is clear from the film's gruesome prologue; what they look like is withheld until long after we have ceased to care.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An unusually delicate psychological thriller that favors suggestion over exposition.
Corinne's journey is riveting not because she seeks the divine, but because she finds herself.
A movie whose claims, if accurate, should give us all food for thought.
Continues the painful decline of a director who seems more nostalgic for past glories than excited about new ideas.
Characters need to be more than vehicles for making a point, and a genuinely heartfelt tone is only partial compensation for an inability to convey the complexity of ideas.
Insulting several nationalities and most of the filmgoing public, "Tied to a Chair" lurches through acting atrocities, continuity glitches and narrative gaps with grating insouciance.
"The Wave" feels overdetermined and ploddingly dramatized.
A love triangle with fangs but no bite, the German import "We Are the Night" is mostly infatuated with its own stylish excesses.
A cringingly awkward tale of sexual predation and female lunacy.
If there is a special hell for film critics, it probably has movies like "Love, Wedding, Marriage" on continuous rotation.
[A] weirdly engaging tale of banking and bad behavior...
The black heart of coal country - and, as the film shows, our national energy debate - has never seemed so in need of white knights.

Painfully perceptive and relentlessly raw, this intimate observation of a couple in extremis plays out with such subdued intensity that, by the end, audiences will very likely feel as wrung out as its embattled stars.
The Congolese writer and director Djo Tunda Wa Munga gives Viva Riva! a playful sensuality that goes a long way toward disguising formula.
Their honey has never looked so delicious. Or so precious.
movie_title: Queen Of The Sun: What are the Bees Telling Us? (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Genially simpleminded and more sweet than scary, Trollhunter never settles on a tone. Fairytale fantasy, supernatural comedy, serious horror? All are sampled, to the detriment of the whole.
This programmatic entry in the tykes-and-trophies genre has too much on its plate and not nearly enough on its mind.
A small film with a gigantic heart, The Lips casts a spell far greater than its modest narrative.
Shocks only with its candor and complete lack of dramatic manipulation.
A repellent comedy that's less fun than a parasite infection...
Neither hopeful nor hopeless, the story is about embracing heritage while striving for more, all the while trying not to step on the neck of your brother.
[The] moral outrage is magnificent, swelling from hushed to howling without the help of narration or posturing from the unfailingly dignified Ms. Peagler or her quietly dedicated lawyers.
This low-budget paean to indoor plumbing and rampant facial hair doesn't unfold so much as unravel.
"How are we going to get out of here?" Sarah squawks at one point, a question that Mr. Dourif ought to have asked his agent long before the cameras began to roll.
That it eventually -- if barely -- succeeds is due more to the resilience of its actors than to the discipline of its makers.
Though at times too determined to avoid dramatic highs and lows, "Little Girl" strikes gold in the casting of the 2-year-old Asia Crippa.
Exhibiting astonishing dexterity, Mr. Sono shapes all this trauma into a narrative that's completely coherent and surprisingly touching, never more so than in Yu's struggle toward sexual maturity.
"Silver Bullets" neither pleases the eye nor stimulates the mind.
Niccol, whose excellent 1997 film Gattaca revealed a similar obsession with human genetics, is an above-average filmmaker who may simply lack the daredevil recklessness a project like this requires.
What begins as an amusing fluff piece ("Daddy's messed up," mumbles one woozy subject after dropping his gurgling infant) slowly emerges as a compelling and often touching peek at punk paternity.
A shapeless rock-music caper that, like its deluded antihero, just doesn't know when to stop.

Seamlessly dovetailing style and subject, "Dragonslayer," a poetic and affectionate portrait of the professional skateboarder Josh Sandoval, known as Skreech, vivifies a subculture of random hedonism and future myopia.
Charming in a way that American romantic comedies have all but forgotten, Young Goethe in Love is by turns cute, campy and endearingly cliched.
Captured mostly in gorgeous black and white, "The Love We Make" is alternately trite, touching, funny and fascinating.

The best concert films achieve a marriage of sound and image that feels effortlessly harmonious, and in that regard "Inni," a musical portrait of the Icelandic band Sigur Ros, leaves most of its genre in the dust.
Undeniably courageous if frustratingly superficial.
As she learns the value of public schools and pickup trucks, her erstwhile friends in Philadelphia seem happy to be rid of her. By movie's end, you'll feel exactly the same.

This emotionally manipulative, heavily partial look at the purported link between autism and childhood immunization would much rather wallow in the distress of specific families than engage with the needs of the population at large.
Propelled by male rage but softened by Considine's big-hearted understanding of his characters, this bruising slice of urban life rewards our patience.
Comes at you like a horror movie before settling down into something quieter but equally skin crawling.
Comprising small, near-perfect scenes played out largely at dinner tables and on couches, "The Lie" wonders if it's possible to rewrite lives and remake choices.
Swirling with unease, its scenes set us up for a payoff that never materializes and strand its actors in a bitter present.
As we join throngs of excited citizens at a public vote-counting, their uninhibited zeal for the process only highlights the jaded cynicism that threatens to overwhelm our own.
Somehow the happy screams of children whirling above a neutered reactor sound a lot less comforting than they should.
Plumbing the roots of negative campaigning, Boogie Man shines a sickening spotlight on a thriving political strategy, suggesting that the devil may indeed have all the best tunes.
movie_title: Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: "Lads & Jockeys" conveys first-race terrors and last-place humiliation with indulgent thoroughness.
Cleaving to the sports-as-salvation playbook with more fastidiousness than creativity, "The Hammer" offers a sincere but wearyingly formulaic portrait of triumph over adversity.
Smart, wordy and sweetly sympathetic to lives lived online, "Sidewalls" coasts on Martín and Mariana's twin voice-overs, alternate musings on themselves and their city.
For those who care about the winning and losing of championship belts, the film's slow-motion attention to pugilistic style and powerhouse punches is thrillingly instructive.

The film leans almost exclusively on the focused performances of its two leads, who create a credibly barbed chemistry that goes a long way toward distracting us from the film's low-budget deficiencies.

The result is a movie that isn't crummy, exactly, just blah: when the freakiest teeth on screen belong not to one of Walt Conti's animatronically realized sharks but to a good-ol'-boy called Red, you know you have a problem.
The most terrifying aspect of Contagion, ultimately, is the plausibility of its premise. Meticulous and low-key, the film reminds us that disaster lies in the most mundane interactions.
The filmmakers seem unaware that they're beating a dead horse. As the uniformly annoying characters stumble around, screaming and cursing, we don't give a hoot for their survival.

In its compassionate, modest gaze, the real cost of distant political decisions is softly illuminated, as well as the shame of a country with little to offer its less fortunate young people than a ticket to a battlefield.
Eugenio Polgovsky's unvarnished portrait of the rural poor in modern-day Mexico.
Engrossing, poetic and often very funny, "Position," like its predecessors, uses the lens of a single family to view the tumult of an entire country.
Tasteful to a fault, "Berlin 36" turns real-life controversy into disappointingly tepid drama.
A film with nothing to please the eye and even less to excite the mind.
A melancholy poem to love, loss and the tug of tradition.
