As one bloody encounter treads on the heels of the next, all that remains is a tiny indie undone by its own vicious ambitions.
An offbeat romance fueled by pets and pithy aphorisms.
You may never have heard of the Kashmere Stage Band, but by the end of "Thunder Soul" you will wonder why.
[It] possesses all the right ingredients: an idealistic young lawyer, a corrupt corporate villain and a sympathetic victim. It just fails to assemble them into a compelling whole.
An even-tempered glimpse behind a very dark curtain.
movie_title: You Don't Like the Truth: 4 Days Inside Guantanamo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Drags us through miles of jungle and reams of stilted, soul-sucking dialogue.
This crackpot thriller from the usually competent Jim Sheridan leaves only one mystery unsolved: what on earth was he thinking?
Where the earlier film pulsed with precisely calibrated paranoia and distinctly drawn characters, this inarticulate replay unfolds as mechanistically as a video game.
It's all very stiff-upper-lip, when what the subject cries out for is a rant.
Though the story eventually develops some shading, Mr. Morrissey's enthusiasm for graphic novels is evident in every overstylized frame and underwritten conversation.
What emerges is a poignant commentary on the uneasy commingling of love and fame.
As a trippy, trifling memorial to a time before its eponymous club was a mini-mall and rave culture a woozy memory, "Limelight" delivers the messed-up goods.
Pointing the finger at neoliberalism, American drug laws and a general disinterest in "the extermination of the poor," Mr. Minn creates a scattered but thought-provoking diatribe.
A stringent street psychodrama in which brutality is an infection and every male is a carrier.
Anthony Burns's sweetly nostalgic re-creation of small-town Texas in the early 1980s.
No wonder Daniel wants Laura: I almost fell in love with her myself.
A sugary, aggressively anthropomorphized story of one avian interloper and a whole bunch of human obsessives.

Low key, low budget and low energy, this animated space odyssey from the writer and director Geoff Marslett accompanies three mismatched astronauts to the red planet and the search for new life forms.
Juggling love story, jewel heist, suicide and a hilarious 12-step meeting, Mr. Jaglom displays his usual loosey-goosey style and insider wit.
A thing of frigid beauty and twisted playfulness.
For all its many irritations, You Wont Miss Me has undeniable punch, a frayed energy that feels janglingly unstable.
Soulless, joyless and depressingly graceless, Alien Girl plays like an early Guy Ritchie knockoff without the jokes or Cockney accents.
Satan may not hate us, but the film's writer and director, James Felix McKenney, surely does.
Beautiful in its minimalism, Nenette is no antizoo rant but a melancholy meditation on captivity.
A 14th-century road movie with 21st-century cuss words.
This bizarre sort-of satire featuring insane characters doing incomprehensible things might be forgivable if it were even mildly amusing. It's not.
Shot in color but produced in edible, Oreo-toned black and white, A Useful Life transitions seamlessly from indoors to outdoors, from nostalgia to hope.
Patiently directed by Hans Petter Moland, Ulrik's journey back to life slowly draws you in.
Sniffing and licking as he goes, and pausing to rub his face vigorously with bioplastics, the director favors a peripatetic style that staves off boredom but is frustratingly shallow.
This bewildering collision of noir narration and purple paranoia may be long on atmosphere but is woefully short on sense.
An outsider tale of unforced rawness and lilting poignancy.
Had the curtain come down 10 minutes sooner, it would have done so with a satisfying thump instead of a soggy swish.
Though there is little here for an informed person to take issue with, the film's well-intentioned preachiness is unlikely to win over those who favor Genesis and denial over climate science.
Even those viewers who share the film's conviction that preparing a collection for New York Fashion Week is inherently fascinating may lose interest long before the final frock is fitted.
In a field becoming more crowded by the year, Family Affair emerges as one of its more complex and unsettling examples [of the dysfunctional childhood doc].
Not since Flashdance has a lobster dinner been seasoned with so much unspoken emotion.
Mostly, however, this dreary Antipodean curiosity is a yob-filled slog of hard-man posturing, all of it bathed in an oppressive testosterone funk. And I haven't even mentioned the hairy buttocks.

Among its achievements is the kind of comfortable, shaded acting we expect from seasoned professionals and a script (by the director, Joseph Infantolino) that almost scarily captures the cadences of whining white privilege.
Bizarre and beautiful, disturbing and droll.
movie_title: The Temptation of St. Tony (Püha Tõnu kiusamine) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Worthless as social commentary and clueless as a film.
Delivers a satisfying, sun-dappled fable about the kindness of strangers and the cruelty of peers.
Mr. Graham's economical style encourages multiple readings of each stop on a journey we all take sooner or later, whatever our sexual orientation.

A strange hybrid of personal journey, half-baked documentary and cleverly executed tease, S&Man (pronounced "Sandman") gets up close and personal with three of the more extreme makers of underground horror and fetish films.
Tries to coax laughs from characters so dated even Eddie Murphy would balk.
Swift and amusingly brainless, Hatchet II more than delivers on splatter expectations.
Tries to coax laughs from characters so dated even Eddie Murphy would balk.
A predictable yet poetic reflection on faith, hypocrisy and the weight of conscience.
We could not possibly care less.
By the time the killings start, it's clear that Ray Wright's screenplay is more interested in following formula than in breaking new ground.
Female-empowerment fantasy or just plain prurience, Grave is extremely efficient grindhouse.
Woven together by Jeff Malmberg -- if not seamlessly, then with illuminating patience -- these disparate strands honor an individual as unique as the miniature universe on which he depends.
An engrossing -- and profoundly distressing -- tale of random connection and specific revenge.

Cannily marketed as a collective experience, the Paranormal franchise works best in midnight screenings. The hunger for cold, dead chills is usually best indulged in the company of warm, living bodies.
Effortlessly compels. The ending may be pure sci-fi schmaltz, but it's schmaltz that this viewer, at least, could believe in.
Ms. Chastain digs deep. Surrendering to her character's smoky voice-over and disastrous judgment, the actress finds pockets of soul in a role that's part Jessica Rabbit, part Marilyn Monroe.
Like the best westerns, Red Hill is a stripped-down morality tale; like the best horror movies, its true monsters remain cloaked until the final reel.
Evokes a time when every love affair came with its own soundtrack, and every song seemed to be written only for us.
movie_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Blond, boyish and with an irrepressible faith in human adaptability, Mr. Lomborg is the anti-Gore.
Transforms a picture-postcard location and odd-couple narrative into a pretty, and pretty predictable, snooze.
movie_title: Letters to Father Jacob (Postia pappi Jaakobille) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Tempering the film's oppressive emotions, the cinematographer Zoë White's exquisite compositions charge leaden rain clouds and rustling branches with eerie life, and dusty indoor corners with shadowy secrets.
An unusually perceptive examination of fraternal rivalry and failed ambition.

By taking a playful approach to a deeply serious subject, [director Liz Canner] explores the link between female sexuality and corporate profits with a style that's as entertaining as it is revelatory.
Like a fledgling Will Ferrell, Mr. Ingram embraces his inner nerd with mouth permanently agape and hair sprouting like florets of burned broccoli. But this is Ms. Cattrall's movie all the way.
Spends rather too much time in the troubling company of Terry Brumfield, a barely mobile invalid who houses two full-grown African lions and their four cubs in a trailer in his backyard.
movie_title: The Elephant In The Living Room (2011)

movie_review_blurb: From its "once upon a time" beginning to the anticlimactic end, "Footprints" remains fatally lodged in La-La Land.
A defiantly unsentimental look at the complex codependency between a harried single mother and her severely autistic daughter.
Long on temptation and larded with violence, Princess gazes on its reckless heroine with avuncular fondness.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A based-on-real-life saga that turns bloody reality into bloodless drama.
The writer and director, Mark Goffman, sticks to a no-frills style that makes the film feel longer than its 1 hour 24 minutes.
Ryan Samul's cinematography and Jeff Grace's score pick up the slack, smoothly maintaining an unstable atmosphere of lurking horror.
Whether designed by nature or by little green men, they make you want to believe.
Like a Ken Loach drama stripped to bare bones, "The Arbor" springs to life in the bright bitterness of Dunbar's prose, showcased in alfresco performances of contentious scenes from the play.

Imagine spending an afternoon watching a bunch of vagrants putter around on an abandoned city lot, and you've pretty much nailed the viewing experience of "Earthwork," a painfully dull account of a year in the life of the Kansas crop artist Stan Herd.
More successful at conjuring atmosphere than at plot, "We Go Way Back" is nicely acted but frustratingly slight.
The result is a journey to prehistory that's simultaneously wondrous and tedious, profound and completely nuts -- which is to say, quintessential Herzog.
A dolorous debut from the Peruvian brothers Daniel and Diego Vega and an oblique reminder that one person's fantasy can be another's nightmare -- at least at first glance.

Against all reason, Byron's televangelist-led quest for clarity compels us to follow, the film's melting, naturalistic images softening the occasional scream of dialogue repeated beyond all necessity.
Makes a pedantic yet persuasive case for banishing meat and dairy from the dinner table.
Cuter than a basket of puppies licking a litter of kittens, "An Invisible Sign" is an excruciatingly whimsical collision of adult themes and kid-friendly aesthetic.

Merging old-fashioned comedy routines with up-to-the-minute politics - all of it enabled by fun-loving personalities and a gift for rousing original songs - the ladies emit a genuine warmth that reels audiences in.
I for one will never look at a blender the same way again.
"Kati With an I" transforms one teenager's particular story into a moving portrait of Anygirl, U.S.A.
Recounts a bright-burning life while leaving us mostly in the dark.
Circling wildly within the film's main set -- a stalled elevator car -- or hurtling up and down an empty shaft, Mr. Fujimoto's camera is as giddy as a tween at a Justin Bieber concert.
"Fat, Sick" may be no great shakes as a movie, but as an ad for Mr. Cross's wellness program its now-healthy heart is in the right place.
At heart an unlovely love story illuminated by sudden flares of violence, the film reeks of hopelessness and moral destitution, offering its lovers few means of escape.
Teasing and shrewd, "Rabbit à la Berlin" is a floppy-eared fable about the uneasy trade-offs between liberty and security.
movie_title: Rabbit a la Berlin (Królik po berlinsku) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Strip away the uninspired mythology, and I Am Number Four is just your average high school movie with below-average drama.
Unfolding in an impoverished neighborhood in Mexico City, this disturbing debut paints social decay with bold, elegant strokes and dizzying camera angles.
Exudes an amiably accessible vibe that softens the edges of its freewheeling explicitness.

Neeson's comforting intelligence (and a marvelous turn by Bruno Ganz as an ailing former member of the East German secret police), are not enough to prevent the film from choking on obviousness and directorial fumbling.
Ms. Uberoi's straight-shooting style is a perfect match for her salt-of-the-earth subject, a hard-working husband and father with more on his plate than most.
Lodged firmly in the "You go granny!" genre alongside wrinkled fluffery like Calendar Girls and the execrable Boynton Beach Club, The Over the Hill Band at least offers truth in advertising.
A droll Nietzschean fable that's fully aware of its lapses into absurdity.
Observing his subject both on and off medication (Mr. Winters says he is bipolar), Mr. Pasternak has produced a film that feels depressingly exploitative.
A disappointingly shallow story in which only the dead are named, and the living are reduced to stereotypes.
An extravagantly corny ode to the collapse of the Cleveland mafia in the 1970s.
Slams Christians against pagans with little love for either.
Immersed in the alien beauty of the Kazakh steppe, "The Gift to Stalin" moves slowly but engages thoroughly.
With neither zombies nor cannibals to hold our attention, Mr. Horgan relies on a single question: When society breaks down, how quickly does our humanity follow?
Screaming "vanity project" from every hackneyed frame, "Drawing With Chalk" is yet another example of midlife American males doing all they can to avoid acting their age.
As singular as its title, "I Travel Because I Have To, I Come Back Because I Love You" embraces road movie, personal journal and trancelike study of arcing grief.
movie_title: I Travel Because I Have to, I Come Back Because I Love You (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A touching chronicle of a dying culture harnessed to ambitions that remain very much alive.
The mantle of social relevance can be a heavy one, but "Trust," a smooth drama about a girl's seduction and rape by a middle-aged Internet predator, is neither preachy nor hysterically overreaching.
"Wrecked" is mostly free of dialogue - and, unfortunately, suspense.

Cradled in Damon's solidly reliable hands, even a movie as extravagantly silly as this one gains heft and credibility, an impressive accomplishment when you consider that the entire plot revolves around magic notebooks and spellbinding hats.
A warm, entertaining compendium of counterculture voices (including Jim Carroll and Amiri Baraka) and literary landmarks.
Like The Exorcism of Emily Rose ... Requiem is loosely based on the real-life story of a West German woman who died in 1976 after a series of failed exorcisms.
Presents immigrant lives with significantly more empathy than detail.

The Outsider, Nicholas Jarecki's starstruck documentary about the writer and director James Toback, is a tragically missed opportunity to illuminate one of the more unusual cinematic talents working today.
The movie's insistently playful tone and cheesy fantasy sequences ultimately work against its ambitions, undermining a story that seethes with abuse and sexual obsession.
A comedy about a suspected gay pedophile is something even Mel Brooks might balk at, but Say Uncle would have benefited from his ability to turn bad taste into good feature.
An affecting portrait of the impact of profound change on people with limited options.
Thomas Allen Harris's film offers a fascinating glimpse of the early campaigns of the African National Congress, and the way childhood memories can obscure larger truths.
Giddy, gossipy and endearingly unslick, Once in a Lifetime chronicles the rise and fall of the most famous soccer team in the United States with slapdash glee.
movie_title: Once in a Lifetime: The Extraordinary Story of the New York Cosmos (2006)

movie_review_blurb: With its contemplative tone and haunting images, The Color of Olives may be the most peaceful documentary ever to arrive from a war zone.
movie_title: The Color of Olives (El Color de los Olivos) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: For audiences exhausted by today's bloated extravaganzas, The World According to Shorts is an eclectic palate cleanser.
Filling our heads with pretty pictures and not much else, Darshan: The Embrace is likely to leave audiences enchanted but unenlightened.
... a dispiriting revenge fantasy engineered by three waspish Barbies against one disposable Ken.
From its plaintive title to its melancholy soundtrack, My Country, My Country is an appropriately mournful look at the chaos of Iraq under American occupation.
Without plot or incident, and with only the flimsiest of characterizations, Hamilton operates primarily on the level of suggestion and insinuation.
A rough Baltimore kid, armed only with a killer smile and hip-hop moves, falls for a classically trained dancer in another retread of Footloose.
Too infantile for tweens and too stagnant for tots, Zoom bleeds boredom from every frame.
In this English-language Dutch thriller, a 13-year-old girl and a young Afghan drug courier fall in love while fleeing his employers.
Disney's latest sports-underdog movie is the true story of a part-time bartender (Mark Wahlberg) who realizes his dream of playing for the Philadelphia Eagles.
Best viewed while sloshed, Beerfest is idiotic, tasteless and irrepressibly good-natured in other words, a frat-house classic.
A dithering but generous Spanish farce, Queens follows the coming nuptials of three gay couples by focusing on their overbearing mothers.
A polemic masquerading as a movie, Poster Boy unspools like a humorless lecture on right-wing homophobia.
A married therapist (Roger Rees) and his dominatrix (Geno Lechner) attempt a real-world romance with predictably strained results.
Everything old is new again in the latest film about the beloved pooch with the I.Q. of a grad student and the instincts of a boomerang.
Not even necrophilia and the imaginative deployment of leeches can relieve this exercise in unrelenting dullness.

Styled as a film noir -- possibly because the shoestring budget precluded adequate lighting -- the movie guides us through the events leading up to Mr. DeLay's indictment for illegal use of campaign contributions in the 2002 Texas Legislature elections.
movie_title: The Big Buy: Tom Delay's Stolen Congress (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Director Liz Mermin documents the hilarious, moving and sometimes fractious meeting of diametrically different cultures, one that has suffered unimaginable horrors and one that believes a good perm is the answer to everything.
Unpleasant, uncouth and painfully unfunny, Larry the Cable Guy attempts lowbrow humor with neither the wit of the Farrelly brothers nor the raunchy inventiveness of Keenen Ivory Wayans.
movie_title: Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Creative exhaustion haunts Ice Age: The Meltdown, as the characters from 2002's Ice Age face global warming and the submersion of their valley.
Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing and Charm School is a soggy, endless wallow in nostalgia and the healing power of very bad dancing.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The story of an unusual friendship, Simon tackles weighty social issues with quiet intelligence and low-key charm.
Set in and around the dockyards of Glasgow, On a Clear Day follows a laid-off shipbuilder who decides to fix his life by swimming the English Channel.
The Wild follows Samson the lion (voiced by Kiefer Sutherland) as he escapes from the zoo to rescue his cub who has stowed away on a ship bound for Africa.
The overheated telenovela La Mujer de Mi Hermano bubbles with incest, adultery, religion and homosexuality.
Sarah Watt's film follows a group of disparate and desperate characters over the course of one of the most depressing weekends in movie history.
The aptly named Standing Still, about postcollegiate 20-somethings, has the dramatic momentum of a daisy-picking toddler.
... Water is an exquisite film about the institutionalized oppression of an entire class of women and the way patriarchal imperatives inform religious belief.
With commendable literalness, the makers of the German soccer comedy Guys and Balls have settled on a title as cheerfully unsubtle as every one of the film's jokes.
Filmed in a covert, voyeuristic style, How I Killed a Saint successfully conveys the pervasive anxiety of a country teetering on the brink of civil war.
Robin Williams tricks us into believing he can control his inner maniac beyond the film's first 15 minutes; when he fails, any hopes of RV going off-formula are dashed.
Roger Rees abandons dignity though not his native English accent to play Nat Banks, the proud but impoverished owner of a decrepit Virginia farm.
Goal! The Dream Begins follows a young Mexican soccer whiz from Los Angeles to England and a tryout with Newcastle United.
movie_title: Goal! The Dream Begins (Goal!: The Impossible Dream) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Set to the death rattle of the British Empire in Africa, Wah-Wah observes the disintegration of the Compton family through the eyes of its young son, Ralph.
Not even a grumpy cameo by Burt Young and some lovely shots of the Brooklyn Bridge can save a movie as punch-drunk as its benighted protagonist.
... the appropriately named Mr. Dark has no use for actors as anything other than body-bag fillers.
David Turnley's sinuous black-and-white documentary about an open-air dance club on the outskirts of Havana places passion and rhythm before politics and history.
... A Cantor's Tale is more concerned with singing praises than with arguing over orthodoxies.
... Iraq for Sale has an us-versus-them sensibility that's extremely effective.
movie_title: Iraq for Sale: The War Profiteers (2006)

movie_review_blurb: ... the movie's good intentions are consistently undermined by its simplistic notion of redemption, and its inspirational thrust is diluted by an epilogue that suggests the program still has a ways to go in the life-altering department.
Stephen and Timothy Quay merge live-action and animation to create a tragic fantasy about a beautiful opera singer, a lovesick piano tuner and the mad scientist with plans for both of them.
A Rubik's Cube of shifting sexual orientation and elaborate sex fantasies, Sloppy Seconds gathers all the accouterments of soft pornography ... into a plot of stunning imbecility.
In the Australian outback, in the opal mining community of Coober Pedy, Rex Williamson (Vince Colosimo) hunts maniacally for the perfect stone while his family endures a life of dust and deprivation.
A moody thriller about an unhappily married couple, a remote cabin and a pair of homicidal crazies.
Nine years in the making and timeless in its observations, Highway Courtesans is an intimate look at some of the youngest practitioners of the worlds oldest profession.
Britain and India face off in National Lampoon's Van Wilder 2: The Rise of Taj, a strained attempt to transplant the American campus comedy to more uptight shores.
movie_title: Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj (Van Wilder 2) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The ghost of 1970s Argentina haunts 1980s Texas in this perceptive and beautifully acted drama from the Argentine director Julia Solomonoff.
Philippe Diaz's tumultuous documentary is a noble but failed attempt to explicate the tragedy of Sierra Leone's 11-year civil war.
With its retro look, cautionary theme and not-so-special effects, Automatons is a shameless ode to 1960s sci-fi and classic television shows.
The American actor Jefferson Mays is back in rouge and petticoats for Memoirs of My Nervous Illness, a punctilious account of madness and womb envy.
Paul Bojacks dour examination of unexamined lives is a slow-burning morality tale simmering with self-interest.
The film's few moments of hilarity are no less welcome for being completely unintended...
The Chinese director Zhang Yimou achieves a kind of operatic delirium, opening the floodgates of image and melodrama until the line between tragedy and black comedy is all but erased.
Alison Chernick's aptly-named documentary takes us aboard a Japanese whaling vessel to witness the filming of the artist Matthew Barney's film Drawing Restraint 9.
Glen Morgan's disastrous remake smothers terror beneath a blanket of unnecessary information, revealing too much and teasing too little.
Roberto Benigni's film is a scorching affront to Italians, Iraqis and the intelligence of movie audiences everywhere.
movie_title: La tigre e la neve (The Tiger and the Snow) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: I Love You, a bleak drama from the Croatian writer and director Dalibor Matanic, is an unusually perceptive scrutiny of absence and emptiness.
Ever Since the World Ended is a faux documentary with a twist, a rudimentary yet fascinating record of remembrance and reconstruction.
Aliens offer a cure for earthling ennui in From Other Worlds, a limp sci-fi comedy with fewer laughs than a meeting of Abductees Anonymous.
A pair of disaffected 17-year-olds are nudged toward adulthood in a movie that favors natural drift over artificial drama.
The horror movie workhorse Sarah Michelle Gellar is back to chill us with The Return, a rote thriller with an intriguingly frenetic shooting style.
An understated and disarmingly human tale of an all-girl band in the runup to the annual rock festival at the members' school.
Color of the Cross, a low-budget re-imagining of Christs final days, makes a big deal out of the relatively tame suggestion that Jesus was black.
Animated in name only, Everyone's Hero is the uninspired tale of Yankee Irving (Jake T. Austin), a 10-year-old baseball fanatic who finds himself in possession of Babe Ruth's stolen bat ...

Only Laura San Giacomo, as Morris's lonely daughter, Flo, transcends the staginess of the premise and the creakiness of Richard Marcus's screenplay to deliver a performance that feels remotely natural.
You've probably been to parties like this, even if you wish you hadn't: languid all-nighters filled with vaguely recognizable music and vaguely employed artists.
Two women reach out to each other from opposite sides of the socioeconomic divide in Jeffrey M. Togman's marvelously revealing documentary about the psychology of poverty.
A simple tale of beauty, the geek and the Internet, this Japanese romantic comedy follows the halting courtship of a 22-year-old nerd and his subway crush.

Ian Inaba assembles compelling evidence to support his claim that African-Americans -- who are traditionally more likely to vote Democratic -- are being deliberately and systematically excluded from the political process.
A what went wrong? documentary that succinctly and ruthlessly dissects the battle for Ohio in the months leading up to the 2004 presidential election.
Directed by Greg Coolidge with the flair of a training video, Employee of the Month turns work into a game and love into a sporting event.
This vigorous documentary offers a five-year record of 29-year-old Stephen Heywoods battle with A.L.S., or Lou Gehrigs disease.
Puzzlehead reveals the selfishness of creation with style, originality and the understanding that even a tin man can have a heart.
Two documentaries about the Palestinian writer and thinker Edward Said explore his life, his chronic alienation and his sympathy for the Palestinian cause.
movie_title: Out of Place: Memories of Edward Said (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Androgyny rules in Zerophilia, Martin Curland's audacious feature about a fictional chromosomal abnormality that wreaks havoc with one's genitals.
Like its progenitor, The Grudge 2 is filled with defective light bulbs, scummy bath water and camera work that makes even teenage flesh look mottled.
There's a tartness at the center of Sweet Land, Ali Selim's unabashedly sentimental tale of a mail-order bride and the community that eventually comes to accept her.
Saw III, with its barrage of grungy rooms, mortified flesh and elaborate torture, is a highly creative exercise in bloodletting, with a bleak view of human nature.
A hyperventilating account of the blood-drenched Miami drug culture in the 1970s and 80s.
Keir Moreanos muted yet moving documentary traces his fathers experience as a volunteer doctor in Vietnam.
movie_title: As the Call, So the Echo (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Form and content fight to the death in Wondrous Oblivion, Paul Morrison's defiantly gauzy tale of racial friction in 1960s England.
The Last Atomic Bomb takes a deeply affecting look at the bombing of Nagasaki and its aftermath as seen through the eyes of a 70-year-old survivor named Sakue Shimohira.
Depression, drugs and professional stasis commingle in The Magic Gloves, a limp urban comedy not nearly as whimsical as its title.
Two documentaries about the Palestinian writer and thinker Edward Said explore his life, his chronic alienation and his sympathy for the Palestinian cause.
Directors Kief Davidson and Richard Ladkani go underground themselves to expose a form of near-slavery instituted by the Spanish conquistadors more than four centuries ago.
On the surface, Hate Crime may seem like a movie about violence rooted in religious bigotry, but underneath it's a poorly disguised argument for vigilantism.
In Shakespeare Behind Bars, the most restricted people in society find freedom in performance and release in words.
Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter... and Spring may arrive cloaked in Buddhist theory but its premise is more Halloween than hallowed.
Oh, Antonio; as a human you are -- forgive me -- less than convincing, but as a marmalade pussycat in shiny black thigh-high boots you are absolutely sensational.
Super Size Me is, on one level, a cinematic stunt in the tradition of Michael Moore's populist, anti-corporate crusades.
'Spike Lee's love of New York, unlike Woody Allen's, has always been more tough than tender.'
'In a sublime collaboration, David Hare and Stephen Daldry have created a delicate atmosphere of inchoate sadness.'
'The Matrix grabs you by the eyeballs, hypnotizes you into a state of visual ecstasy, and doesn't much care if your brain is following or not.'
'What made the first film so satisfying -- the detailed creepiness of human enslavement by technology -- is barely touched on here.'
''Everything that has a beginning has an end,' says the tag line. Not in financial terms it doesn't.'
'Rich with meaning or a sublime prank, Dogville gets to you.'
'A valiant but doomed affair, as carefully constructed -- and ultimately as hollow -- as the Trojan Horse itself.'
'Gorgeously decadent, massively contrived, and gloriously superficial.'
'Brooks' preference is clear: wise Mexican earth mother trumps competitive American neurotic every time.'
'An invigorating, revealing movie about the transformative power of ideas.'
'Breathtakingly beautiful and menacingly primitive.'
'Above all, Cold Mountain is a story of women -- abandoned, starving, and learning to rely only on themselves and each other.'
'The personal is political' may be primarily associated with feminism, but it practically defines the Israeli filmmaker Danae Elon's fascinating journey into her past.
Thai director Pen-ek Ratanaruang's splatter comedy 6ixtynin9 rejoices in a plot as tricky as its spelling.
A beautifully designed and ambitious example of Korean cinema.
Goofy, bizarre, yet surprisingly coherent, The Calamari Wrestler veils sharp social commentary with irreverent humor and corny romance.
Absent the suspense and satirical thrust of its predecessor, The Stepford Wives is a star-studded, soft-centered piece of whimsy
Vital and delirious, The Saddest Music in the World hurtles along on twin tracks of vaudevillian humor and gleeful bad taste.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Misguided, miscast, and completely misconceived, the wretched King Arthur is one of the grittier, more earnest failures to appear this summer.
The genius of director Sam Raimi is to take the fantastic and make it believably, achingly human.
Warmhearted and defiantly unsentimental, "Grandma, a Thousand Times" gains lightness from Teta's tart observations ... and the director's stylistic sprightliness.
It demands a great deal of actors whose faces and bodies are, for a while at least, our only temporal coordinates. Yet all are off-the-charts remarkable.
Jackson's Hole
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The film's real pleasures are subterranean, hidden in fleeting glances and demurely loaded body language.
That Theron rises to the challenge is remarkable; the challenge for audiences will be to avoid confusing a great performance with a great movie.
Catwoman has nothing on its mind but random movement and the airing of every lipstick shade from Revlon's Fall collection
Everybody's Business: The Corporation unfolds a stunning catalog of corporate perfidy that will surprise all but the most informed viewer
An astonishing, mesmerizing film about a vanishing way of life
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: More daring, more unexpected, and more thoroughly alive than anything this stuffy genre has seen since Gosford Park
Konstantin Bojanovas depressing, uninvolving documentary follows six heroin addicts in his home town of Sofia, Bulgaria.
It's a sad day indeed when a movie's most memorable performance belongs to Scooby Doo's Matthew Lillard.
An orgy of color and movement, Hero's balletic but virtually bloodless violence harnesses the forces of nature in a thoroughly unique way.
We Don't Live Here Anymore is a thoughtful but dreary examination of narcissism, disconnection, and emotional dishonesty.
Open Water is terrifying on a purely primal level. In a fear-of-the-dark, monsters-under-the-bed way, it twangs nerves forgotten since childhood.
The Village is an enormous disappointment -- not because the ending is so banal, but because Shyamalan has become a director who no longer trusts his talent.
What's remarkable about Marston's filmmaking is his ability to present scenes of shocking defilement without a hint of gratuitousness.
There's another, more interesting movie lurking behind the pulp, glimpsed fleetingly in a stunningly-angled shot or a tantalizing line of dialogue.
It takes nerve to use dead children as apologists for adult misbehavior, but nerve is something novelist John Irving has never lacked.
The real beauty of "Metallica" is its understanding of a business, and a fan base, that provide no way to age gracefully while retaining musical credibility.
Though fans of the original may chafe at the altered ending, the new Candidate is a tight, high-strung political thriller in its own right.
Like its seductive protagonist, Intimate Strangers is a masterful tease.
Part rockumentary, part howl of outrage, Screamers is an invigorating and articulate film.
A disturbing yet compelling debut.
This eye-opening, often heartbreaking documentary about America's working poor tracks four low-wage workers in the Northeast and California.
This courageous documentary takes viewers to a small hillside community in Medellín where an illegal right-wing paramilitary group holds power.
The Danish filmmaker Jeppe Ronde's intriguing documentary presents a window into a strange and selfish obsession.
39 Pounds of Love presents a bracingly honest yet poetic portrait of a man refusing to be defined by the limitations of his body.
My Big Fat Independent Movie is a frenetic attempt to spoof every major art-house film of the last decade.
Based on a popular Japanese comic-book series, Initial D is a slick but silly affair unlikely to appeal to anyone over the age of 15.
Based on the testimony of more than 16,000 people, Pamela Yates's harrowing documentary chronicles 20 years of terror, brutality and repression.
A lighthearted comedy about the outing of a bride-to-be and her five-year relationship with her maid of honor.

With leads who strain to manage one facial expression between them, and a cinematographer shooting everything through the same steel-blue filter, Underworld: Evolution is a monotonous barrage of computer-generated fur and fangs.
The War on the War on Drugs is a lively and well-executed satire that sweetens its occasional truths with rebellious humor.
movie_title: The War on the War on Drugs (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The debut feature of the director Fanta Régina Nacro, The Night of Truth is a raw, Shakespearean fable that powerfully reflects the tragedy of countless civil conflicts.
Jonathan Hock's unwaveringly upbeat documentary follows the basketball sensation Sebastian Telfair as he chooses between the University of Louisville and the N.B.A.
Michèle Ohayon's documentary is a slyly insightful portrait of conflicting expectations in the search for the perfect partner.
Cool, mysterious and defiantly foreign, the mournful thriller Love plays out on the immigrant fringes of an indifferent New York City.
Startlingly direct, if unavoidably preachy, The Second Chance takes aim at Christianity's racial divide and the corporatization of faith.
The path of true love may not be smooth but it is predictable in Christmas in the Clouds, a wisp of a movie set in a Utah ski resort run by a Native American tribe.
As one of our most prominent and passionate advocates for Native American rights, John Trudell deserves more daring and objective scrutiny than this overly reverent tribute.
Plucking shamelessly on post-September 11 anxieties, Sorry, Haters follows the irrational involvement of a New York City cab driver and a disturbed fare.
Ultraviolet cleaves faithfully to its comic-book genealogy with a plot unobstructed by big words and images that rarely breach two dimensions. Ultrasilly.
Directed by Ari Taub with a naturalistic style and a nonpartisan eye, The Fallen finds its humanity in the dailiness of a soldier's life.
The Roost is a minimalist horror movie with more ambition than resources.
Emmanuel's Gift is a powerful story of political change almost smothered by contrivance.
A cold and moody psychodrama poised frustratingly on the border between novel and banal.
The movie presents a hopeful, if sugary, view of cultural dislocation.
Maysoon Pachachi's documentary is an on-the-fly diary of events and impressions into the challenges of extracting democracy from chaos.that offers insight
movie_title: Return to the Land of Wonders (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Bursting with gangsters, gambling and human weakness in general, Johnnie To's Throwdown is so strange and idiosyncratic that it's almost surreal.
Lutz Hachmeister and Michael Kloft's fascinating documentary provides a chilling glimpse inside the brilliant but toxic mind of Joseph Goebbels via his extensive diaries.
The late character actor Victor Argo stars in this melancholy, often surreal love letter to a post-September 11 New York City.
Raw, chaotic and engagingly eager, This Divided State juxtaposes candid interviews with scenes of unrest as Mr. Greenstreet rushes gamely from one hot spot to another.
Set in Los Angeles among a group of young people who dream of becoming famous, Undiscovered carries more than a whiff of the self-referential.
Lush, lurid and completely besotted with itself, Eternal is one of those movies normally found slinking around the ether of late-night cable television.
A silly-sweet, gay romantic comedy aimed primarily at teenage and college-age audiences.
Anyone who can compare Reagan's funeral to Weekend at Bernie's and John Kerry to an Ent, one of Tolkien's talking trees, deserves an audience on both sides of the aisle.
Even allowing for the burdens of low-budget filmmaking, Ethan Mao is little more than a revenge fantasy for anyone whose parents ever gave him or her a hard time.
Favoring literateness over melodrama, and psychological kinks over special effects, Usher delivers unexpected jabs of wry humor.
Everything about Steal Me, the new feature from the writer and director Melissa Painter, feels dangerously overripe.
Answering the Call is an emotional tribute to the thousands of regular citizens and emergency personnel who, on Sept. 11, 2001, responded to the worst disaster any of them had ever seen.
movie_title: Answering the Call: Ground Zero's Volunteers (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A monotonous female coming-of-age story about a simpleminded teenager in upstate New York who becomes infatuated with a Ratso-like drifter.
Garçon Stupide is an intriguing examination of alienation and dysfunction, tonally haunting rather than melodramatic.
Occupation: Dreamland presents a compelling study of composure and decency in the midst of overwhelming pointlessness.
Inspired by Chekhov's short stories, Three Days of Rain belongs to the now-familiar genre of overlapping tales of urban desperation.
A lively, sexy, insightful documentary about the musical style bachata, and its most prominent singer and songwriter, Luis Vargas.
This mockumentary, in which young African-American men reinvent themselves as a modern-day British Invasion-style band, is messy, unfunny and unforgivably dull.
Set in Berlin in 1942, Dennis Gansel's intensely beautiful film brings us inside Hitler's network of elite schools to groom young Germans for positions of power.
Emphasizing sameness over difference, this is the kind of film rarely seen by those likely to benefit most from its universal message.
Marrying small-screen formula to big-screen actors, Shoot on Sight is an earnest melodrama that struggles to surmount its good intentions.
A heartbreaking and meticulous documentary about life inside a blue-jeans factory in China, reveals more than we may care to know about the provenance of our most beloved item of clothing.
Room 314 cracks open the door of an anonymous hotel room where, at different times, five couples navigate critical moments in their relationships.
Never Back Down offers extreme fighting as the modern-day alternative to sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll.
Wetlands Preserved is a fond account of the rising, thriving and eventual closing of the TriBeCa club known as the Wetlands Preserve.
movie_title: Wetlands Preserved: The Story of an Activist Rock Club (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Flash Point plays like the last hurrah of a criminal underclass facing the inevitable shrinking of its bottom line.
movie_title: Dao huo xian (City Without Mercy) (Flash Point) (Fuse) (The Signal) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: War Made Easy: How Presidents & Pundits Keep Spinning Us to Death is a depressing look at political manipulation and news media compliance.
Directed, with visible earnestness, by Patricia Riggen, Under the Same Moon blunts the hard edges of immigration with a thick coating of preciousness.
A confused young artist is torn between his family and his future in Shelter, a sensitive romantic drama from the writer and director Jonah Markowitz.
A Four Letter Word is a surprisingly endearing romantic comedy that explores gay relationships with low-budget verve.
The flailing, protagonists of Backseat, while not exactly 40-year-old virgins, can have avoided that fate only by the tender mercies of women with low expectations.
Hats Off is a documentary tribute to the 93-year-old actress Mimi Weddell, one of those people for whom the word 'individual' seems especially apt.
If Nim's Island were anything but a children's movie, the casting genius who suggested Jodie Foster as a potential love interest for Gerard Butler would be looking for a new occupation.
A spoonful of fashion helps the feminism go down in Nana, a delightful pop fairy tale that speaks to young women in the language of sisterhood and self-direction.
Modest to a fault, the introverted family drama Tehilim circles an unsolved mystery and unresolved emotions.
The Dhamma Brothers offers a constructive alternative to the hopelessness of human warehousing.
This crude, rowdy movie is unexpectedly touching in its embrace of surfing as an escape from the stigma of poverty and broken homes.
For a film about erotomania, Prom Night is a curiously flaccid affair.
One of the sleaziest documentaries to arrive in a very long time, Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed is a conspiracy-theory rant masquerading as investigative inquiry.
A hair's breadth from hagiography, Scott Hicks's Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts is much like its subject: affable, quotable and emotionally guarded in the extreme.
movie_title: Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A women-behind-bars plot seething with lesbianism, incest, hanging and catfights -- on paper, at least, Four Minutes promises more fun than a Roger Corman marathon.

Without the King, Michael Skolnik's subtly perceptive documentary, avoids a tone of first-world outrage; leaning more toward understanding than blame, the film examines a country forced to choose between tradition and survival.
Young women find expression for more than their music in Girls Rock!, a jubilant documentary about a place where power chords and empowerment go hand in hand.
For a tale spiked with so much torment, Fugitive Pieces feels remarkably soothing.
Above all the movie has a heart, a mind and a gentleness of spirit that parents will welcome, while the frequent flights of fancy ensure that no child will be left behind.
Featuring exceptional people doing extraordinary things, Blindsight is one of those documentaries with the power to make you re-examine your entire life.
Awake is filled with risible medical behavior (the sterility of the operating room is repeatedly compromised) and a horizontal Mr. Christensen screaming variations on "Oh no, I can feel that!"
The documentary Billy the Kid presents the world according to a troubled teenager in Maine.
Part tribute, part musical mystery, 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris shines an overdue spotlight on a great who got away.
movie_title: 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As much the chronicle of an era as of a band, The Holy Modal Rounders ... Bound to Lose casts an affectionate eye on the kind of hedonism no one is meant to survive.
For his poetic fourth feature, Half Moon, Bahman Ghobadi returns to the desolation of the Kurdish borderlands and the enduring optimism of his people.
In Arranged two devout Brooklyn schoolteachers clutch hands across the religious divide as their respective families prepare to marry them off.
A brow-furrowing blend of child abuse and adult trauma, Andrew Klavan's screenplay sacrifices coherence for atmosphere at every turn.
There's not a single wrong note in Liberty Kid...
A colorful and confounding head trip, Opera Jawa is guaranteed to test the fortitude of all but the most adventurous viewer.
Chico Teixeira's languid, libidinous Alice's House is the best argument against marriage and motherhood to appear in many a year.
In the intriguingly layered documentary Orthodox Stance, a determined young boxer strives to prove that the laws of God and the laws of the ring need not be at odds.
Trailer Park Boys: The Movie is like a feature-length version of the television sitcom My Name Is Earl, only Canadian -- and not funny.
Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer, the team behind Meet the Spartans, prove that ridiculing other movies is much easier than making your own.
The Eye is the latest Western deconstruction of a successful Asian horror movie and it is louder and more literal than its inspiration.
Praying With Lior documents the extraordinary life of Lior Liebling, a rabbi's son with Down syndrome.
Custom designed for its smirking star (who is also an executive producer), this tasteless train wreck asks only that she preen and prance on cue.
The flesh is weak but the spirit is indestructible in Cover, a ham-fisted morality tale.
Three women converge on the road to self-awareness in Vivere, a moody drama from the German director Angelina Maccarone.
Men are men, and women are no end of sorry in Little Chenier, a steamy saga of jealousy and revenge set on a waterlogged spit of Louisiana land.

Eyes popping and mouths agape, Martin Lawrence and Raven-Symoné mug their way through College Road Trip as if it were a silent movie -- which, come to think of it, would have been a lot less irritating.
A dreary, interminable drama written and directed by Eva Aridjis, is exactly one-third of a good movie.
Male midlife crisis presents as pathological self-loathing in Meet Bill, an imperative to which the only sane response is: No thanks.
Adam Hootnick's Unsettled makes the political personal, drawing a scattershot yet intimate picture of a nation divided.
More amusing than tragic in its depiction of the band's infantile behavior.
A minor chiller and major downer from the talented Alexandre Aja.
Malcolm McDowell is thoroughly engaging in Never Apologize: A Personal Visit With Lindsay Anderson.
movie_title: Never Apologize: A Personal Visit With Lindsay Anderson (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Jack Brooks: Monster Slayer harks back to the drive-in classics of yesteryear with unapologetic nostalgia and undisguised affection.
Operating at the intersection of art and industrial engineering, Richard Serra is an informative if unanimated guide through Thinking on Your Feet.
movie_title: Richard Serra: Thinking on Your Feet (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Yet another documentary that everyone should see but most will not.

Jeremy Dean makes a valiant attempt to juxtapose past and present, but his goal is consistently undermined by an execution so muddled it's almost unwatchable...Even so, the film deserves to be seen, if only for its wealth of rare historical footage.
An adult fable told with childlike simplicity, Year of the Fish updates an ancient Chinese version of the Cinderella story with imagination, charm and just the right amount of sweetness.
Trace[s] influences and celebrate connections with tunes to make you tap and sway.
Onstage or in rehearsal, surrounded by familiars or alone with the camera, Ms. Bethnia is an expressive force of nature whose honeyed voice could lure sailors to their doom.
movie_title: Maria Bethania: Music is Perfume (Maria Bethania: Musica e Perfume) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Repurposing clichés as springboards to deeper issues...[director Springall] reminds us that ritual can ease reconciliation, and that sometimes even meat and dairy can get along.
movie_title: Morirse esta en Hebreo (My Mexican Shivah) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: How atrocious is the comedy Everybody Wants to Be Italian? Let me count the ways.
Had Jorge Ameer, the writer and director of The House of Adam, aimed for high-flying camp instead of low-rent earnestness, his movie might have stood a chance.
Modeled on noir and executed on acid, Able Danger is a paranoid fantasy of geek superheroics that lunges desperately for political relevance.
Irena Salina's astonishingly wide-ranging film is less depressing than galvanizing, an informed and heartfelt examination of the tug of war between public health and private interests.
The message may be clear -- suppress the past at your peril -- but the execution is a mess.
There's scant reward for sitting through Igor, an animated twist on the Frankenstein story that never sparks to life.
This overripe tale of innocence lost has become one of notoriety found.
A stunning introduction to a rare new talent.
movie_title: Bei yazi de nanhai (Taking Father Home) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Clueless, directionless and altogether pointless, America the Beautiful will outrage only those who have spent the last 50 years in suspended animation.
A dolorous comedy that leans heavily, if inoffensively, on ethnic stereotypes.

Weird, wicked and wonderfully perverse, Late Bloomer pulses with frigid energy. Watching it is like having your finger trapped in a light socket: no matter how much it hurts, you can't quite tear yourself away.

If the writer-director, Akihiko Shiota, sometimes strains too hard for mythic import, his patience is a gift. As Yuki watches a blind woman fashion an origami bird, the characters' connection to a simpler, collective past is evident in every perfect fold.
More tired than the fantasy it promotes, A Previous Engagement aims at middle-aged women with the subtlety of a pitch for bladder-control medication.
In The Memory Thief, a strange and melancholy journey to the heart of madness, a rootless young man finds meaning in the horrors of a stolen past.
Roger Spottiswoode directs with old-fashioned style, avoiding the saccharine with realistic depictions of a war-ravaged China (where he filmed) and a cast well versed in stiff-upper-lip.
A riotous blend of arterial spray and grindhouse glee.
Deceptively simple and threaded with gentle humor, Mukhsin paints the turmoil of puppy love on a canvas of family relationships as delightful as it is believable.
This is no splatter movie: spare, suspenseful and brilliantly invested in silence, Bryan Bertinoâ(TM)s debut feature unfolds in a slow crescendo of intimidation.
You don’t have to be a fan of African tunes to appreciate Jacques Sarasin’s heartfelt ode to Congolese music and its resilient practitioners.

Like a dog unleashed in a field full of rabbits, he chases one shard of "evidence" after another - a second gunman, a girl in a polka-dot dress --without bothering to arrange them in any coherent pattern.
movie_title: RFK Must Die: The Assassination of Bobby Kennedy (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Beauty in Trouble uses the changing moods of water as both metaphor and frame for the infinite adaptability of human emotions.
A cloying blend of Bollywood sentiment and Amélie whimsy, Nina's Heavenly Delights is a lesbian-foodie fairy tale that keeps its appetites well under control.
In To the Limit, Thomas and Alexander Huber run up rocks the way some of us run up credit cards -- rapidly, fearlessly and with little regard for consequences.
Gunnin' for That #1 Spot is an on-the-fly record of a memorable moment in basketball history.
This classy, heart-on-its-sleeve movie is packed with laudable life lessons and Depression-era trivia.

Adopting a confessional, direct-to-camera interview style for most of its running time, this unvarnished vérité documentary about teenage prostitutes in New York City resolutely resists the urge to dramatize. The heartbreaking stories are drama enough.
Everyone's sorry about something in this glum drama about the way repentance can do more damage than the sin that precedes it.

Has a dark desperation thatâ(TM)s morbidly compelling. But the movieâ(TM)s amoral momentum is fatally slowed by an acronym-heavy script and flimsy characterizations that offer fine actors...little to play.
Assembled without frills or fuss, A Man Named Pearl is as much a portrait of a small Southern town as of an unassuming black folk artist.
A Very British Gangster plays less like a documentary than an E! exposé of lowlife skulduggery.
A struggling anorexic and her physical opposite form an unlikely friendship in disFIGURED, a funny, awkward and often uncomfortable drama.
Back to Normandy is never less than an extraordinary journey through time, memory and the repercussions of a baffling, bygone crime.
Elsa & Fred is both a movie about love and a love letter to movies.
A seriously deranged dramedy about finding yourself through terrorism, Be My Oswald attempts high-wire artiness on a bargain-basement budget.
Filmed in real time during the freezing winter of 2000, Yiddish Theater: A Love Story tracks eight days in the failing life of the Yiddish Public Theater.
A jaunty mix of chanting, baking and spiritual uplift, How to Cook Your Life introduces us to the cooking classes of Edward Espe Brown, a twinkling Zen priest.
This latest recycling of foreign-grown frights shows less interest in horror than in healing.
Missing Victor Pellerin is an enigmatic and utterly compelling story of incinerated art, unbridled egos and exotic plants.
Self-consciously edgy and romantically limp.
In keeping its inflammatory subject matter at arm's length, Provoked does exactly the same to its audience.
Severance turns a corporate retreat in a Hungarian forest into a bloody game of whack-a-mole. (Team building and paintballing are so last year.)
The cannibals, coconuts and landlocked locations [of Dead Man's Chest] have been replaced by the high-seas high jinks that made the first film so enjoyable.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A documentary filled with immediacy but free of analysis, a fascinating but ultimately unenlightening record of [Palestine's] plight.
Allan King's wrenching record of five real deaths is a potent reminder of the fearful gap between fiction and reality.
With Bug, William Friedkin continues to be more fascinated by the evil inside our heads than the boogeyman outside.
Knowing but never jaded, Hollywood Dreams is driven by Ms. Frederick's no-boundaries commitment to her broken character, a performance that's as startling as it is touching.
A familiar underdog story told with unusual sensitivity, Davis Guggenheim's Gracie depicts the obstacles faced by a young girl who dreams of playing on her high school soccer team.
Dazzles and confuses with equal determination.
Filled with painfully awkward men with painfully bad haircuts, I'm Reed Fish exhibits less energy than a sloth on Seconal.
Surf's Up has a friendly, blue-collar vibe and some sly, low-key humor.
'A small house can accommodate hundreds of friends, but can't accommodate two enemies,' the doctor says ruefully, quoting an Arab proverb. Sadly, Blood and Tears is the proof.
movie_title: Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There was a time when movies like DOA: Dead or Alive lurked sheepishly at schoolboy height on video store shelves, spines straining to accommodate the charms of their actresses.
A Stephen King short story is adapted and brought to the screen in 1408, more psychological thriller than outright horror.
'What do you do when nothing is left?' is the question that drives The Real Dirt on Farmer John.
movie_title: The Real Dirt on Farmer John (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Over the G W follows a troubled brother and sister as they are committed to a New Jersey treatment center by their well-meaning parents.

Plodding but heartfelt, Something to Cheer About pays tribute to a time when basketball scholarships and professional opportunities were practically unknown. Back then, a player's only opportunity was to make history.
The Condemned is tailor-made for those who like their violence multifaceted and their women monosyllabic.
A hackneyed melodrama partly redeemed by a cast convinced that it's performing Tennessee Williams.
Tie Xi Qu: West of Tracks is an astonishingly intimate record of China's painful transition from state-run industry to a free market.
movie_title: Tie Xi Qu: West of Tracks (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The new prequel Hannibal Rising provides a back story that ought to have remained firmly in our imaginations.
Leaving no cliché unturned, Coffee Date provides cheesy music, chats about gaydar and the obligatory are-you-looking-at-mine? urinal scene.
Consistently smart and delicate as a spider web, Bridge to Terabithia is the kind of children's movie rarely seen nowadays.
Is the world ready for a flaming Nicolas Cage?
We may learn nothing new about the grasp of addiction, but the movie's lean 75 minutes is at least a genuinely fast track to oblivion.
Starter for Ten, an amiable, nostalgic British comedy from the director Tom Vaughan, tackles a lofty subject -- the allure of knowledge -- with down-to-earth charm.
The title may suggest a wildlife documentary, but The Cats of Mirikitani is entirely, vibrantly human.
Border Post is a profane and playful military drama about boredom, duty and the consequences of reckless lust.
Reeking of self-righteousness and moral reprimand, The Ultimate Gift is a hairball of good-for-you filmmaking.
By turns playful, sexy, tragic and contemplative, Flying is an addictive soap about sexuality and sisterhood.
movie_title: Flying: Confessions of a Free Woman (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A documentary grab bag of film clips, diary readings and desultory narration, A Journey of Dmitry Shostakovich peeks at the politics of this controversial composer.
Wholesome, eager entertainment that doesn't talk down.

The turtles themselves may look prettier, but are no smarter; torn irreparably from their countercultural roots, our superheroes on the half shell have been firmly co-opted by the industry their creators once sought to spoof.
Filled with labored exposition, stilted line readings and the most unconvincing romantic hookup since Michael Jackson and Lisa Marie Presley.
Imagine an entire film infected with hangdog sensibility, unrelieved by humor or narrative interest, and you have The Hawk Is Dying.
The rapper Ice Cube returns to the multiplex with Are We Done Yet? a feeble fable of better parenting through home improvement.
In Firehouse Dog a pampered Hollywood pooch trades his movie-star lifestyle for a run-down firehouse sadly in need of a mascot.
Ping Pong is probably the most extravagant celebration of a childhood game ever committed to film.
The lively hip-hop documentary Rock the Bells demands neither familiarity with the music nor a hankering for rhyme.
An uninvolving melodrama more suited to the small screen than to the large.
In a role that could easily have slipped into bitchy smugness, [actor] Magyar gives the character a self-deprecating charm that's enormously appealing.
Uninvolving and cliché-ridden (even shape-shifters, it seems, deserve a falling-in-love montage), Blood & Chocolate is Romeo and Juliet with fewer manners and more exotic dentition.
Uneasily straddling age groups and genres, Joshua is a highly effective family drama cloaked in the stale tropes of the demon-seed thriller.
What emerges is a complex portrait of a man who cares more for humanity than for his own children, often left to languish in orphanages while their father scoured bodies and minds.
An all-too-familiar wallow in urban woe and artfully photographed isolation.

Jose Riveraâ(TM)s highly improbable and sensationalized screenplay leaves its actors no room for authenticity. Marco Kreuzpaintner directs with commendable energy, but squanders Daniel Gottschalkâ(TM)s gold-dust-strewn images on hyperventilating voyeurism.

A campus comedy with a dirty mouth, an innocent heart and a surprisingly wise mind, Freshman Orientation uses identity politics as a road to romance and emotional maturity. The naked breasts are a bonus.
Somewhere between documentary and dramatization, fact and impression, Strange Culture molds one manâ(TM)s tragedy into an engrossing narrative experiment.
The Seeker feels passé and lacks a charismatic lead. Too bad Daniel Radcliffe is an only child.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A faux documentary grounded in ethnicity and mired in absurdity, Finishing the Game is a terrific idea still waiting to be fashioned into a real movie.
What happens when idealism becomes power? That question is the driving force of Jeremy Kagan's inert yet strangely compelling film Golda's Balcony.
In Naked Boys Singing! 10 grown men (including one natural redhead) go full monty while belting out show tunes and high-kicking like muscular Rockettes.
Though still a stranger to subtlety, Mr. Perry has learned to balance the obviousness of his setups with characters whose interactions feel genuine.
It's not easy to turn one of the most controversial events of the 20th century into a movie that makes your eyes roll, but O Jerusalem does this and worse.
Devised for minimum fuss and maximum tension, Trigger Man is the little thriller that could.
Bifurcated images, isolating the characters from their dreams and from one another, create a yearning atmosphere that pulls you in; like their director, you really want them to escape.
A bizarre psychological study of degeneration and dependency, The Living and the Dead is a horror movie only in the most literal sense.
Over the course of [its] sequels, the Saw franchise took a novel, if distasteful, idea and basically tortured it to death.
The pungent layers of narrative that make up Glass Lips may cross and collide -- and occasionally confuse -- but the intelligence behind them is clear.
There's a riveting story lurking inside Holly; It's just not the one the filmmakers want to tell.
Swift and stealthy P2 is a canny exploitation of one of the urban woman's greatest fears: the after-hours parking garage.
In I for India Sandhya Suri offers her family's immigrant experience as a springboard for questions of nationality and filial responsibility.
Suicide, infidelity, spousal abuse and arrested development are the building blocks of Park a wearisome comedy.
Eloquent and occasionally touching, Darkon is haphazardly photographed but unfailingly generous toward subjects who exhibit an astonishing degree of self-awareness.

Antonia explores cultural and sexual oppression with sensitivity and verve. The story may lack complexity, but it is loaded with irrepressible energy and a deep appreciation of female friendship. And that's always something to sing about.
...Ira & Abby radiates a breathless charm, due in no small part to Ms. Westfeldt's sharp dialogue and engagingly unmannered performance.
A coming-of-age tale so treacly it doesn't just tug your heartstrings, it attempts to glue them to your ribs.
Nostalgic as only a project steered by two former campers can be, Summercamp! is a riot of talent shows and campfires, canoeing and holistic clowning.
Setting the record straight literally and figuratively, In Search of Mozart is an adamantly linear, myth-busting stride through a prodigiously talented life.
Displaying more corn than is usually found at the North Pole, Arctic Tale documents the travails of a polar bear cub and a walrus pup as they struggle toward adulthood.
The Sugar Curtain is a pensive valentine to literacy programs and childhood idealism left in the ashes of broken families and an economically bifurcated society.
movie_title: The Sugar Curtain (El Telon de azucar) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Nice Bombs feels as sad and directionless as the country it documents.
Pretentious and inane, I Know Who Killed Me arouses unexpected sympathy for its embattled star.
In their no-frills documentary, Out of Status, Pia Sawhney and Sanjna N. Singh examine the actions of the Immigration and Naturalization Service after 9/11.
A Decalogue for special-ed students, The Ten leans too often toward the bizarre and the bewildering.
It takes a certain amount of genius to stage a derisive spoof of MTV's My Super Sweet 16 while enthusiastically aping the very materialism it promotes.
Captivity the movie has been thoroughly eclipsed by Captivity the marketing.

The lackluster story connects the clichés but leaves the characters isolated. Underdog may have been originally created to sell cereal for General Mills, but this latest incarnation couldn't sell Frisbees at a dog park.
A downtrodden schoolteacher, a disabled boy and a government agent suffering from an embarrassing itch are the unlikely heroes of Zebraman.
Like Douglas Sirk without the throw pillows, Sunflower is a shamelessly old-fashioned melodrama performed with such sincerity that resistance is futile.
Vividly impressionistic and delightfully curious.
A surreal nightmare of gleaming surfaces and razor-sharp edges, The Bothersome Man unfolds in a sterile city where nothing is quite as it seems.
What began as an oddball study of a jagged male friendship devolves into cliché and compromise.
Monty Lapica's film about the self-destructive behavior of a 17-year-old suffers from severe dramatic droop.
This film is like Ocean's Eleven if directed by Robin Hood and financed by Telemundo.
"10 Questions for the Dalai Lama" is a tedious title for an anything-but-tedious film that expertly merges the mystical and the mundane.
Horror without suspense is like sex without love: you can appreciate the technicalities, but ultimately there's no reason to care.
Yawningly directed by Jim Isaac, Skinwalkers is a slavering mess that buries its clunky addiction metaphor beneath a welter of genre clichés, all delivered in extra-slow motion.
"Red Hook Black" crawls forward by means of stilted conversations and vacuous exchanges.
Raising significant questions about the psychological effects of poverty on young children, this unsettlingly direct stab at atonement feels genuine.

Straight-shooting, hard-hitting and fuming with contempt for the tobacco industry, "Addiction Incorporated" would be almost too exhausting to watch were it not for the folksy charm of its star witness.

Proceeding with a strained quirkiness that infects much more than the names of its main characters, this first feature by Justin Reardon is a paean to the kind of narcissism that sucks the air out of every scene.
This disordered portrait seems heavily influenced by its equally jumbled setting.
How can you dislike a film that signals a killing with "Bang Bang" and a villain with "The Snake"?
So much effort; so little entertainment.
Beneath its calm, exquisitely detailed surface, "When Marnie Was There" bubbles with half-formed ideas and undeveloped themes.
Like its heroine, "I Believe in Unicorns" is faltering and undeveloped, but with a wiry core that belies its apparent uncertainty.

Offering few solutions beyond a single fair-trade fashion company, "The True Cost" - whose serene interludes compete with sickening recordings of Black Friday shopping riots and so-called clothing haul videos - stirs and saddens.
A hard-line thriller derailed by messy editing and narrative silliness.
Wrapping an existential question in the random rhythms of the road movie, "Doomsdays" comes at you sideways, its melancholy catching you off guard.
A troubling example of what can only be called a fertility thriller.
The wonder is that despite its obvious roots, District 9 feels staggeringly original.
Rambling, frustrating and wholly uninvolving, "The Face of an Angel" swarms with ideas that have no place to land.

Perceptive and compassionate, "Eden" recognizes how the thrill of artistic freedom can curdle in the heat of the marketplace and the demands of daily life. Yet the movie's refusal to foster regret, or have Paul repudiate his passion, is telling.

Marveling without questioning, the movie is content to package the phenomenon and coast on its feel-good wave. Yet, somewhere around the midpoint, I began to wonder who was most thrilled by all this fuss.
Nick might usurp most of the screen time, but it's Mr. Del Toro, face flickering from benevolent to vicious and body heaving with literal and symbolic weight, who seizes the film.
A damp-eyed comedy whose banal title isn't the only thing needing improvement.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This jingoistic war-at-sea movie, redeemed by neither narrative momentum nor fully formed characters, will test the patience of the most ardent military fanatic.
This deceptively simple documentary by Jean-François Caissy regards the turbulence of adolescence as a negotiation between risk and restraint.
Slow and steady, and with remarkable assuredness, Keith Miller's "Five Star" plays mean-streets drama in the lowest of keys.
Though based on a remarkable true story, this clichéd tear-jerker is barely interested in Marguerite's revolutionary teaching methods, focusing instead on the intensity of her connection to Marie.
One of the many irritants in this trite, well-intentioned lecture on tolerance: The audience is always several moves ahead of the script.
You won't be convinced that Spandau Ballet was the best band of the 1980s. Even if they did have the best bums.
movie_title: Soul Boys Of The Western World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This tenderly observed love story (by the director, Maxime Giroux) isn't about religion - or its lack - but about the attraction of difference and the undeniable need to feel alive.
With the reek of straight-to-video wafting from every frame, "Lovesick" astonishes most by its appearance in an actual theater.

The barnacle-encrusted plot, which pits little Prince Zhao (Bill Su Jiahang), the rightful heir to the emperor's throne, against his murderous older brother, Shing (Andy On), is dumbed down to the studs.
None of this is particularly cinematic ... but it is engaging, mainly because the stakes were so high and the statesmanship so delicate.
movie_title: The Other Man: F.W. de Klerk and the End of Apartheid (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film's potentially most affecting moments are too often smothered by the hackneyed characters and setups that surround them.
Ambulant corpses may be tramping all over our movie and television screens these days, but "Wyrmwood" has enough novelty - and more than enough energy - to best its minuscule budget.
At heart a dotty look at oldsters struggling to adapt to an unwelcoming modernity, "Shadows" has the bones of an anarchic sitcom.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Affected and slow, and more concerned with mood than plot, this moony first feature from Michael Johnson uses its Portland, Ore., setting as a canvas for mapping a course from isolation to companionship.

Balancing its abstract storytelling with commanding visuals (by the gifted cinematographer Ali Olcay Gözkaya), "Futuro Beach" explores liberation and reinvention, the tug of familiarity versus the allure of the foreign.
The sweat of three writers and the acting chops of Stephen Rea still don't come close to earning "Out of the Dark" a passing grade.
Documenting a lifetime spent gulling audiences and pursuing con men, the directors Justin Weinstein and Tyler Measom have produced a jaunty, jovial portrait with a surprising sting in its tail.
The swings from goofy to gory and jokey to tragic cancel one another out, and Mr. Diliberto's near-constant voice-over is irksome.
movie_title: The Mafia Kills Only in Summer (La Mafia Uccide solo d'Estate) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: These drifting, unresolved stories may lack dramatic punch, but Mr. Nikolic, who teaches film at the New School, draws lovely performances from his cosmopolitan cast and oodles of atmosphere from a spare piano-and-strings soundtrack.
A tiny, piercing study of dawning desperation that's all the more remarkable for being virtually silent.
A movie singularly lacking in rock-doc unpredictability and verve.
A frustratingly fragmented yet warmly intimate portrait of an evolving bond that frays but doesn't sever.

Onah - whose movie began life as his thesis project at New York University - seems more keen on showing how the tensions of immigration and gentrification have shaped the Lower East Side than on fashioning a credible thriller.
The light is menacing, the mood watchful and the action scenes have a crude, desperate energy that gets the job done.
There may be little to give you the collywobbles, but there's quite a lot to enjoy, with Ms. Morton heading the list.
Falling back repeatedly on in-your-face symbolism - especially with regard to the specter of decline - Mr. Salvadori seems content to idle in neutral.
Sadly, "24 Days" isn't nearly as involving as it should be.
This collection of eight mini-sermons falls flat.
Brimming with characters - many in near-identical military garb - and bristling with double crosses, this unnecessarily lengthy homage to resistance chooses breadth over depth at every turn.

Thankfully free of the usual triumph-of-the-will score, "Meru" is an ultrasmooth blend of conventional documentary techniques - the talking-head interview; the back-in-the-day photograph - and uncommon ambition.
A heartfelt documentary about the chemical industry's aggressive efforts to conceal the thousands of potentially toxic ingredients contained in everyday products.
Mr. Jones fashions an unfaltering encomium that's entirely free of the highfalutin monologues that might deter noncinephiles.
As drifting and dreamy as its searching heroine, "My Friend Victoria" takes a graceful but unsatisfying stroll through the life and longings of a young black woman in contemporary Paris.

A happy marriage of rudimentary conditions and highly sophisticated filmmaking, Eryk Rocha's passionate documentary "Sunday Ball" dives into an amateur soccer game in the Brazilian slums and barely comes up for air.
Rhythmically blending vintage recordings and live performances, "The Winding Stream" exudes a quirky warmth that counters its PBS-pledge-drive aura.

"Other People's Children" desperately wants to take a deep dive into a young woman's pain and the solace of artistic expression. For that to happen, though, would require much better actors and a much smarter script.
Defiantly amateurish yet never less than engaging, "Sweaty Betty" is a true oddity.
"Intruders," a distasteful thriller with a bludgeoning sensibility and little common sense, turns a cozy family home into a clockwork house of horrors.
Shatteringly stupid and repulsively misogynistic, "Martyrs" mashes revenge, torture and the supernatural into one solid, quasi-religious lump.
Directed by Ross Katz and filmed like an ad for erectile-dysfunction medication, The Choice is almost repellently synthetic.
More than anything, The Hurt Locker is a high-wire study of men at work, its lack of overt politics replaced by a revelatory central performance.
If you drink every time you're reminded of Monty Python's 1979 Judean jaunt, "Life of Brian," you might just make it through to the end.
A goofy horror movie with little to say and not a lot to see, "Ava's Possessions" sacrifices scares in favor of a rambling addiction metaphor that never finds an emotional rhythm.
Delivers a vibrant testimony of resilience under oppression.
movie_title: They Will Have to Kill Us First (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A master class on narrative pacing and carefully managed jolts.
Depressing in the extreme, "Creative Control" surfs its subject as if unaware of the possibilities.
A story that kicked off two years ago at a reasonable gallop has now slowed to barely a limp.
Bursting with so many fond and famous faces that you can imagine its subject swooning with delight - and then criticizing their makeup.

Even those who have spent the last 14 years pining for a sequel to "My Big Fat Greek Wedding" - by most accounts, the highest-grossing American romantic comedy - will rue that longing when they experience "My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2."
Dreamy and delicate, trite and oh so earnest, "The Summer of Sangaile" presents a soft-core frolic in teenage Sapphic bliss with the solemnity of a world-shattering event.
For all its bursts of violence and descending-guillotine sound effects, "#Horror" feels driven more by social commentary than by outright terror.
Whatever its flaws, "Heist" is to be commended for repeatedly finding ways to distract us from them.

I left this barbed portrait of a cracking-up comic with more than a little respect for its fearless director, Rick Alverson, and his trusting star, Gregg Turkington. You can't deny that they're a match made in heaven.

Pursuing his character's self-destructive, often tasteless agenda, Mr. Mills (drawing on his own experiences and doing triple duty as the director and screenwriter) gives a performance of rancid single-mindedness.
Dumb as dirt and just as generic, "Hitman: Agent 47" trades brains for bullets and characters for windup toys.
There's barely a whiz-bang punch line or smoothly executed setup to be found in a movie that longs to be a sparkling bedroom comedy and winds up a tortured, fizz-free farce.
Considering how aimless its screenplay, how lost its hero and how unglamorous its setting, Bob Byington's "7 Chinese Brothers" is remarkably appealing.
