This minimalist but deeply affecting morality play slowly tugs you in.
Brahms's "Cradle Song" might play at the beginning, but that doesn't mean anyone here has the slightest chance of sleeping.
If you've ever wondered what a breaking heart sounds like, it's right here in the futile warble of the last male of a species of songbird, singing for a mate that will never come.
Sludgy greens and smudged blacks assault the eyes, and crashing sound cues accompany every scare - dead giveaways of a director, Uli Edel, who trusts neither his audience nor his images.
Shockingly funny, weirdly touching ...
Feeding over-the-top language to underdeveloped characters, Deon Taylor's "Supremacy" dramatizes racism with an unvarying intensity that quickly becomes wearing.
Shockingly funny, weirdly touching ...
Funny and feisty, gritty and sometimes grim, this first feature from the photographer Elaine Constantine delivers a sweaty snapshot of a very specific time and place.
The rambling, uncertain tone engendered by Ms. Sichel's striving to align her Buddhist beliefs with the harsh realities of terminal illness also weakens her story's gravitational pull.

Watching Mr. Tillman as he cheerfully embraces sobriety to please his son, and is rebuffed by his former street pals for doing so, we see a poignant meditation on how our expectations of loved ones can become a burden that not everyone can carry.
The best sections reverberate with the power of Poe's words. As such, they serve as apt tributes to yarns that will always be more formidable on the page than on the screen.
A witty fusion of western, horror and comedy that gallops to its own beat.
A wearying loop of slug-snort-crash that leaves Ms. Silverman out on a ledge and the audience with no way to reach her.
As if all its artistic energy had been gobbled up by the fornication, "Love" has nothing left with which to build its characters or set them in motion.
John Nolan's old-school effects are wicked good, and Martijn van Broekhuizen's mossy photography is pleasingly sinister.

Filmed almost entirely inside the Pathway Home in California, a residential therapy center for veterans, this devastatingly raw documentary shows that for some the fighting may stop, but the suffering continues.
If, as many seem to believe, we are presiding over the possible annihilation of our species, then maybe we need a kick in the pants more than a reassuring hug.
Plagued by a rickety premise, generic sets and invaders who recall Doctor Who's Cybermen, "Alien Outpost" jabs its finger at the Iraq War with repetitive obviousness.
Even if, like me, you're a sucker for men with tossable hair and precision eyeliner, you can't help noticing that "The Devil's Violinist" is hysterical - and possibly historical - hooey.
The script is thoughtful, but its anger is diffuse, with laissez-faire capitalism and the problems of illegal immigrants and returning soldiers jostling for attention.
Seasoned actors are left to yell pointlessly at one another, while Beth and the zombie angle slowly decompose.
A punishing, predictable drama that's almost rescued by strong acting and good intentions.
The journey from page to screen may have battered Mr. Welch's novel, but its lamenting heart beats loud and clear.

Punishingly stylized, this marriage of comic-book panels and hard-boiled dialogue has a heaviness that can't be explained solely by its cynicism or lack of wit. It's a blunt instrument whose visual shadings far surpass the kill-or-be-killed storytelling.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The director, Christina Voros, adopts an educational approach that embraces the pleasure within the pain.
Dim in wits and lighting, "The Possession of Michael King" strains our eyes, spits on our intelligence and saps our generosity of spirit.
A tepid horror movie that runs out of ideas long before it runs out of victims.
An orphaned girl and a fatherless boy bridge opposing societies in "Patema Inverted," a delightful animated fable from Yasuhiro Yoshiura.

Temperate in tone but screaming with subtext, "Jamie Marks Is Dead" climbs above the current glut of supernaturally inclined entertainment by dint of a hushed unease that permeates almost every frame.
The movie's signature signage - "Abandon all hope, ye who enter here" - is the only instruction we really need.
Moves to the formulaic beats of the second-rate TV movie, albeit one cloaked in an ultra-glossy sheen.
Marrying American voices to Belgian animation, this candy-colored adventure has a harum-scarum energy that rarely flags.
movie_title: Thunder and the House of Magic (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Belle and Sebastian fans will be fully sated; everyone else might feel as if they'd consumed a meal consisting entirely of meringue.
With her dirty-blond curls and angelic smile, Helen is fully alive in a way that's all too rare on our movie screens. She's not out to shock or sicken; that's your problem, not hers.
A singularly focused and avant-garde talent, Ms. Streb bends the messy rush of risk to her indomitable will.
A lean, low-budget debut that taps into newlywed anxiety with subtle wit and no small amount of style.
Ms. Kirkland - a headstrong veteran performer who is nothing if not game - has proved that she can play this kind of role in her sleep. If only the movie around it were worthy of her efforts.

Together with the writer Simon Barrett, whose canny scripts flip and swerve at unexpected moments, Mr. Wingard is building a résumé that pays at least as much attention to character and story as it does to scares and body count.
You can imagine Mr. Smith and his collaborators rolling in the aisles at their own preposterousness. If you can find your inner 16-year-old, you might just join them.
"Dinosaur 13" may not be the best documentary, but as a scientific soap opera, it's a doozy.
For all its enthusiastic vulgarity and truly terrible punk rock, "We Are Mari Pepa" is a gently endearing portrait of four amiable Mexican teenagers feeling their way toward adulthood.
A balloon of cuteness that makes you yearn for a pin, "What If" is Saturday night comfort food for those who need to believe that even the most curdled among us can find a mate.
An extraordinary, almost indescribably personal reflection on life, love, suffering and impermanence.
Shot with a camera as excited as a squirrel-chasing dog, "Cheerleaders" has a girls-gone-wild energy and a twisted sense of humor.
A sneakily compelling, endlessly patient observation of three working-class families in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.
A vigorous companion piece to Peter Nicks's revealing 2012 documentary, "The Waiting Room," "Code Black" (the title describes the emergency room's saturation point) is a keening cri de coeur.
A devastating meditation on what can happen when a prescient thinker challenges corporate interests and the power of the state.
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A quaint labor of love blinkered by fidelity to an outdated text.
Avoiding intimacy with something close to terror, Gong-ju idles on the fringes of events as though reluctant to take up space. She knows that invisibility is probably her only friend.
Pitting good against evil with striking intelligence and a near-operatic commitment to extreme suffering, Ms. Gebbe neither mocks nor celebrates Tore's love for his God.
Unfolding in simple yet wonderfully expressive hand-drawn frames, the film's unsparingly observant plot depicts the slide into senility with empathy and imagination.
Mr. Khan displays a strong visual sense that makes pivotal scenes pop.
If the twisty finale underwhelms, Mr. Carreté's enigmatic style and textured images offer their own doomy rewards.
None of this is riveting, but the film's loose naturalism and strong acting - Chris Browning, as a liaison between the F.B.I. and the reservation, is especially enjoyable - are slyly seductive.
This second feature by the Mexican director Aarón Fernández is a delight.
Essentially, we're watching dead people refuse to lie down, yet the acting isn't terrible, and Scott Winig's photography is satisfyingly bleak and grimy.
Narratively and emotionally, this weirdly becalmed trifle by Maria Sole Tognazzi ends up almost exactly where it started.
Unfocused and repetitive, this feature-length commercial by Jeremy Snead uses a muddled timeline and bargain basement graphics to produce a horn-tooting, "Aren't games awesome?" tone.
As Momo conquers her fears, averts a tragedy and finally sees the beauty of her surroundings, the movie grabs your heart with the softest of hands.
A below-ground but slightly above average horror movie ...
It's all quite trying, like watching a depressed duck paddle around a muddy pond.
"The Almost Man" may be slight, but how many films can pack equal amounts of emotional nuance and inappropriately sprayed urine into just 75 minutes?
James Cameron upstages the ocean in "Deepsea Challenge 3D," a shallow vanity project that invites us to join him in marveling at his own daring.
An intermittently interesting but fatally clichéd comedy of personal and professional suicide.
"The Girl in the Photographs" is an unfortunate example of the expanse that can open between a movie's ambitions and its execution.
A gentle, melancholy drama so pale and tentative that its very colors appear washed away by grief.
For most of us, the mechanics of 3-D printers are as mystifying as the movements of galaxies - a knowledge gap that the documentary "Print the Legend" does absolutely nothing to address.
These random encounters, as well as brief interviews with band members ... effortlessly capture the bond between this former steel town's spirit and the ineluctable tug of Mr. Cocker's lyrics.
movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A sprightly horror movie about finding new purpose for old bones.
How miserable does your day have to be to transform the breeze from a pesticide spray into a blessing?
Directing with an old-fashioned tenderness toward his unassuming star, Ken Ochiai conjures a swan song to a waning art form and those who practice it.

Like one of those machines that can inhale a car and spit out a tidy cube of squashed components, "Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles" is a near-indigestible lump of clips and quips and snipped opinions.
movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Rising above a minuscule budget with ladles of charm and a tender poignancy, "Little Feet" is a quixotic poem to youthful resourcefulness.
The infuriatingly vague and downright strange story banishes the haunting delicacy of mood that Mr. Egoyan has conjured so successfully in the past.
"Song of the Sea" moves delicately but purposefully from pain to contentment and from anger to love.
There is something profoundly draining and suffocatingly incestuous about watching a film that's dedicated to watching a computer screen.
Interweaving multiple perspectives and three generations of family memories, Yael Reuveny's "Farewell Herr Schwarz" traces a Holocaust mystery with stumbling curiosity and endearing sincerity.
"Ode to My Father" may have slain them in South Korea, but its packaged pain and bullet-point structure are likely to leave Western audiences cold.
Modestly presented but emotionally ambitious - and with a lovely, low-key performance from Ms. Shelton - this immersive first feature gently reveals the void of an adulthood on autopilot.
Despite the kid-gloves sensibility, "Paddington" delivers a knockout blend of fluid animation and live action.

A slow, mesmeric slide into heartbreak and horror, "Medeas," the ravishing first feature from the Italian director Andrea Pallaoro, effortlessly conveys a family's disintegration with few words and even fewer miscalculations.
Evidencing more bullets than brains, "Vice" - a bit of ephemeral science-fiction twaddle directed by Brian A. Miller - has absolutely nothing to recommend it.
[The] screenplay ... plays down intellect in favor of corn and cliché.
A groaningly tedious survival story that will at least leave you with a renewed commitment to wearing sunscreen.
Though hardly immune to cliché ... this squirmy tale of dueling addictions gets points for skillful spikes of humor.
Commendably, Ms. Barker-Froyland resists the urge to tidy up loose ends. And if her leads remain locked in a romance-novel connection ... at least it's one in which the smart girl gets the boy.
Scenes flirt with cliché, yet the writing has spark (one very funny sequence cuts among radically different interpretations of the previous night's revelries), and Tim Naylor's photography is pretty.
The director, Todd Darling, is so busy fist-pumping for urban farming - and so dazzled by his granola heroes - that naysayers must be demeaned and denigrated.
As unoriginal as its title, David Hayter's "Wolves" is yet another hoary, hairy transformation narrative featuring lycanthropy as a metaphor for coming of age.
Sneakily compelling ...
movie_title: Levitated Mass: The Story of Michael Heizer's Monolithic Sculpture (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Forced to wait at least half an hour for the skeletal plot to kick in, we have plenty of time to notice the awkward dialogue and slapdash logic.
Normally, I would have no objection to being trapped in a car with John Cusack, but that was before I saw "Drive Hard."
Executed with considerably more polish than the crime at its center, "Fishing Without Nets" turns the hijacking drama into a morally murky contemplation of deprivation and desperation.
Composed of multiple layers - more than one of which might bring tears to your eyes - this shape-shifting documentary begins as one thing and ends as quite another.
Soft in tone and muted in color, "Waiting for August" is a child's-eye view of one family - among many in today's Romanian economy - rising to the challenge of living without parents.
If the movie's hilariously cruel treatment of the halt and the lame upsets you, you can enjoy the crisp cinematography, operatically repulsive effects and frequently witty dialogue.
movie_title: Dead Snow 2: Red vs. Dead (Død snø 2) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A forceful indictment of the United States government's surveillance and prosecution of computer hackers and journalists.
The setting is futuristic, but the themes are ancient in "Young Ones," Jake Paltrow's eccentric merger of frontier western and science-fiction gadgetry.
A deeply cynical movie masquerading as a complex moral dilemma, the Australian drama "Felony" proves only that skilled actors and slick photography can tart up even the most problematic script.

A smart, sly comedy about what its director, Will Bakke, calls "the power of platforms," "Believe Me" parodies the machinery of faith-based fund-raising with its heart on its sleeve and its jokes above the belt.
A documentary that purports to chronicle the sober and urgent work of those who ferret out human-rights abuses, but instead plays like a portrait of a rather glamorous marriage.
Shockingly flabby ...

Harboring few ambitions beyond knock-your-socks-off action sequences, this crafty revenge thriller delivers with so much style - and even some wit - that the lack of substance takes longer than it should to become problematic.
"Braddock America" pierces the skin.
A World War I fable that's as stiff as an Eton collar and as plodding as a draft horse.
Rough-hewed but naturally inspirational, "True Son" gains heft from its portrait of a city sharply segregated by race and income.
"Virunga" wrenches a startlingly lucid narrative from a sickening web of bribery, corruption and violence.
Filthy conversations abound, mostly with a handful of trash-talking students and a series of female characters apparently conjured from a frat-boy wish list.

We can't blame the actors. According to the publicity notes, Mr. Simpson sent them into the woods with limited information, then amused himself by scaring the bejesus out of them. If only he had done the same for the audience.
A thriller with so many viewpoints, feints and fake-outs that it swiftly disappears up its own URL.

Featuring the usual fractured visuals, generic victims and pinballing cameras - both hand-held and mounted on bike helmets - "Exists" nevertheless has an unusually dreamy opening and a few surprisingly entertaining tweaks.
A slow-motion explosion of anti-authoritarian rage.
The story strings pearls of performance on the flimsiest of plots.
Matteo Garrone's colorful and kinky exploration of what women want. And what men will do to give it to them.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The splatter is deployed cautiously and sometimes wittily, the story moving briskly from wishes granted to costs exacted ...
This feather-light French confection, written and directed by Paul Calori and Kostia Testut, addresses its dignity-of-work thesis with sweetness and heart.
Everyone ... works hard to transcend the artifice, and they deserve better. So, for that matter, do Simon & Garfunkel.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As with last year's "Lights Out," [Mr. Sandberg] proves a master of the flash-scare, a nifty choreographer of precipitous timing and striptease visuals. But he's also adroit with more leisurely horrors

Even artists as gifted as these two can only hitchhike so long on the charisma of household names like Mick Jagger and Michael Caine, and the dueling impressions that fuel the franchise have become effortful and repetitive.
This quirky, obsessive documentary is about so much more than broken keys and busted type wheels. It's really about how we create art.
Sometimes dreamy but mostly dissatisfying, "Walk With Me" offers no clarity for the curious.
Mr. Rosenbaum and his producer Jasin Cadic shape a narrative of professional insecurity and personal resilience.
Cramming several tons of plot into a one-pound screenplay, the three writers ... have little option but to condense. That said, Mr. Wingard's eye for a stylish image hasn't dimmed.
There is ... a great deal of moping.
Like the teenage girls who monopolize its attention, "Kill Me Please" is moody, lovely, preening and libidinous.
Painted in the broadest possible strokes, these ropy relationships agitate a movie that has neither a coherent point nor an authentic character.
The writers of "Rememory," Mark Palansky (who also directed) and Michael Vukadinovich, mash a fertile premise into sentimental mush.
The intimacy of the film's images and the surprising candor of its participants are disarming: Whatever your initial response, be prepared to re-evaluate.
Marrying fact and fiction, Jane Goldman's seamy screenplay is wildly overstuffed; but the director, Juan Carlos Medina, gives the music hall scenes a rowdy authenticity.

Shot with a dreamy fabulism that merges the gorgeous and the grotesque, "Indivisible," the third feature from Edoardo De Angelis, draws on a rich vein of Italian cinematic history to deliver an adventurous ode to freedom and sisterhood.

Equal parts disturbing and humorous, informative and bizarre, "Rat Film" is a brilliantly imaginative and formally experimental essay on how Baltimore has dealt with its rat problem and manipulated its black population.
[An] execrable remarriage comedy, one that's mystifyingly seeded with acting heavyweights.
Depressingly dull and terminally inarticulate.
A 14th-century farce that, given its comically credentialed players, ought to be a great deal funnier than it is.
"Circle" is an emotionally sterile lark, its wounds inflicted with brolly and bullwhip, a smirk and a shrug.

With a little more shading and originality, "13 Minutes" might have pushed beyond its familiar Nazi tropes to shape something more immediate and infinitely more potent: an ominous portrait of radicalization.

Its arguments range wide without going deep, but its factoids about the medical benefits of hanging out in a forest - and the cognitive costs of a noisy school or hospital - are fascinating and persuasive.
Weighed down by the worthiness of its intentions, "The Promise" is a big, barren wartime romance that approaches the Armenian genocide with too much calculation and not nearly enough heat.

Teeming with acts both heroic and reprehensible, John Ridley's wrenchingly humane documentary, "Let It Fall: Los Angeles 1982-1992," reveals the Los Angeles riots as the almost inevitable culmination of a decade of heightening racial tensions.
Dreary, derivative and flat-out dopey, this dragged-out torture tale will disappoint even those whose hearts race whenever they see a female character strapped to a bed.
Virtually a chamber piece with just two primary characters, the movie dives into the black arts with methodical restraint and escalating unease.
If the story is too tricky to realize its themes or welcome the impatient, it also contains enough empathy to humanize a character who's part man, part spiritual symbol.
Falling with a thud between two stools, it has neither the zip nor the zaniness of farce nor the airy vivacity of the best romantic comedies.
As quaint as the specters it works to expunge, "Another Evil" is an ultra-low-budget ghost story with an off-kilter sensibility that initially intrigues but ultimately fizzles.
What we're left with is a morality play in which three deeply deplorable people - and one surprising white knight - wrestle with class privilege, mental illness and extremely silly food.
Little more than an indulgent wallow in gustatory privilege. By the time the final meal is devoured, you'll be wanting nothing so much as an antacid.
The vein-popping mood is ultimately more exhausting than exciting.
Beyond simple nostalgia ... the appeal of this limp retread is difficult to discern.
Impressively lean and rigidly controlled, "The Survivalist" achieves, at times, the primitive allure of a silent movie.
Sweeter and soapier than we've come to expect from the Danish director Thomas Vinterberg, "The Commune" swaddles the pain of a disintegrating marriage in a good-natured cocoon of laughter and larks.
Without Lee's complicity in the triteness of his story - and Mr. Elliott's ability to sell it as a melancholy burden - this low-key feature by Brett Haley wouldn't be half as pleasurable.
A movie about large setbacks and small triumphs, and the grit that takes you from one to the other.

Sincere, sometimes brief performances - including those of John Leguizamo as a disabled veteran, and Julia Stiles as the bitter wife of Nelson's nemesis - lend necessary oomph to a narrative that can, at times, verge on sleepy.
A pointless gush of science-fiction bilge.
This chilly tale of violent secrets and unvoiced misery relies heavily on the skill of actors who seem to know that one false move could tip the whole enterprise into comedy.
"47 Meters Down" - despite a clever final section - struggles to extract tension from clamor and agitation.
The look is rough, the emotions always hovering near the surface. Yet, buoyed by Mr. Sharif's cheery personality, these can sometimes be defiantly upbeat.
"The Tiger Hunter" might balk at the harsher details of immigrant life, but it has a generosity of spirit that lifts everyone up.
The director elects ... to back away from the story's edgier, more unnerving possibilities in favor of something altogether more soggy and formless.
Nothing much happens in "Lucky," and then everything does.
Planting a flag firmly at the intersection of patriarchy, sexism and white supremacy, "The Rape of Recy Taylor" is a documentary of multiple layers and marvelous gumption.
Landing lightly on the loneliness of fame and the ravages of aging, "Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool" is a fond farewell to a distinctive talent.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This timorous tale sidesteps uncomfortable realities in favor of soothing whimsy and preordained uplift.
Even at a time of year when movie companies typically unload their dross, the sheer awfulness of Dito Montiel's "The Clapper" stands out.
Leisurely and deliberate, intelligent and casually cruel, "Have a Nice Day" is a stone-cold gangster thriller whose violence unfolds in passionless bursts.
movie_title: Have a Nice Day (Hao Ji Le) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: This blah trudge from cradle to stage will be catnip to his fans and Ambien to everyone else.
Ho-hum apparitions appear and disappear without a trace. Ms. Mirren and her representatives are probably hoping the movie will do likewise.
Four of the five live-action short films nominated for Oscars this year feel so weighty that the lone comedy comes as something of a relief.
Impressively photographed and perkily paced, Jason Filiatrault's story never droops quite as much as its lead character, injecting a welcome poignancy that tempers the cuteness.
If I can persuade just one of you to bypass its milquetoast masochism and watch the stratospherically superior "9 1/2 Weeks" instead, then I will have done my job.
A good-looking but overstuffed genre pileup that confuses as often as it compels.
A soggy string of Hallmark moments designed to interrogate the value of the objects we cherish, the movie is front-loaded with major stars and squelching with sentiment.

Suffused with sorcery and silvery light, "November," written and directed by Rainer Sarnet, is a bizarre Estonian love story - a mishmash of folklore, farm animals and scabrous fun - in which beauty and ugliness fight to the death.
A twisty thriller with horror-movie flourishes.
This parched Outback western, awash in noirish mannerisms and a sunstroke-inducing palette, harbors a robust social conscience beneath its hotbed of bribery and sex trafficking.
A tortured mystery dripping with pretentiousness.
An imbecilic misfire.
Small and stagy and claustrophobic, "Shining Moon" is visually rough yet oddly enticing in its experimental awkwardness.
movie_title: Shining Moon (El Destello de la Luna) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Rampling's pale, stricken countenance sets the tone of "Hannah" and dominates virtually every moment thereafter. By the end, we feel so wrung out it takes a second or two to realize that very little has happened.
Notable mainly for the beautifully organic performances of its two female leads.
Committing completely to Carl's wobbly perceptions, the filmmakers mire us in a hackneyed swamp of narrative uncertainty.
It's an entertainingly desperate joust, playing out beneath defiantly unattractive lighting.
Zvyagintsev ... uses a toxic marriage to paint a larger portrait of decay, dereliction and moral detachment.
Though disappointment and loneliness guide its conversations, the movie isn't bleak; it's a touching and tender commentary on the need to be seen and the desire to be heard.
This painstakingly paced thriller displays an intensity of purpose that makes it impossible to dismiss as well-executed trash.
To watch the magnetic Idris Elba trudge through a monumental dud like "The Mountain Between Us" is almost physically painful.
[Dr. Farmer's] quiet outrage over the widely-held assumption that it's futile to treat the global poor drives this story, which is finally as much about the triumph of a philosophy as of medicine.
A stiffly depressing portrait of toffee-nosed child abuse.
This exceptional life ... is smothered by a cloying fairy tale romance that turns every challenge the couple faces into a lark.
Becoming a decent person requires an awful lot of dying in "Happy Death Day," a snappy horror-comedy with a gentle romantic spine.
Mostly a frustrating jumble of surreal puzzle pieces that audiences will likely be uninterested in solving.

Despite Mr. Radcliffe's all-too-obvious dedication (his increasingly emaciated body, astonishingly, was not digitally enhanced), he can't rescue a screenplay (by Justin Monjo) that cares more about the condition of his flesh than the contents of his head.
A movie that panders not at all to Western sensibilities, giving few pointers on a theme beyond the fortifying power of faith. For some viewers, that will be plenty.
"God's Own Country" weaves a rough magic from Joshua James Richards's biting cinematography and the story's slow, unsteady arc from bitter to hopeful.
"All I See Is You" is halfway through before something resembling a plot kicks in, and even then this limp, shape-shifting psychodrama proves unable to sell it with anything approaching coherence.
Though not nearly as mindful or meaty as Mr. Miike's 2011 triumph, "13 Assassins," "Blade" is creatively gory fun.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "I have heart cancer," Ms. Hines's character says at one point in a vain attempt to halt her daughter's complaints. I think I know exactly what she meant.

"Mayhem" embraces its pulpy title with fighting-and-fornicating glee. Neither innovative nor particularly clever, the movie understands its mission and benefits from Mr. Yeun's unfailing air of basic decency.
A satirical scream of rage against patriarchal prerogatives, this feminist horror-comedy, written and directed by Ms. Palka, has a vicious edge that can stifle your laughter.

A dreary pileup of hard-luck monologues and run-down locations, Mark Webber's "Flesh and Blood" straddles the line between fact and fiction with exhausting earnestness and a fatal dearth of narrative.
The cinematography isn't the greatest, and the structure is hit or miss, but so what? In a movie this good natured, the heart is everything.
A twisty, small-town thriller that blooms in the shadows and shies from the light, "Sweet Virginia" marshals a relentlessly threatening mood from dangerous secrets and unpleasant surprises.
Often ravishing aesthetics and stylistic quirks act as soft restraints, keeping us watching despite a near-total absence of story and a thinly disguised attitude of male entitlement.
Opening an aperture into a process so ego-stripping that it feels unseemly to witness, "The Work" is enlightening yet also punishing.
The performances are desultory, the musical score bullying and the drama - aside from the game-changing placement of inconvenient shrubbery - as predictable as Tom senior's steadily sprouting beard.
In the background, Alexandre Desplat's swoony score piles on the sentiment, but it's all just empty calories; what this movie desperately needs is conflict.
There are some gnarly questions - of faith, love and self-worth, for starters - at the heart of "The Ticket," if only its makers had chosen to address them.
From blowup to makeup to uneasy détente, "My King" is repetitive yet oddly tremendous.
There's a very real possibility that watching "Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV" could result in brain addlement.
More than a fable about the clash of tradition and modernity, "Ixcanul" is finally a painful illustration of the ease with which those who have can prey on those who don't.
A numinous meditation on grief that's more likely to inspire laughter than tears.
Unlovely and uninvolving, "Level Up" is a running-man cocktail of brutality spiked with low-level humor.
Mr. Scott creates a disappointingly skeletal Frankenstein story that entertains efficiently but vacuously.
An ungainly yet strangely captivating oddity, "London Road" snags your attention from the get-go in the manner of any razor-edge experiment: By making you wonder, what on earth?
Though rife with implausibilities, "Transpecos" is fortified by strong acting and a location whose desolate beauty is a gift to Jeffrey Waldron's serene camera.
"Operation Avalanche" weaves well-known conspiracy theories into a goofily entertaining satire of youthful ambition co-opted as a tool of government intrigue.
You don't have to remember the gutter headlines inspired by its namesake to find the true-crime documentary "Amanda Knox" completely riveting.
The era's skinhead riots and striking workers - and Strummer's biting, pro-immigrant lyrics - are never more than window dressing in a movie that would rather scatter fairy dust than grit.
Dependably genuine, and suffused with Mr. Jaglom's increasingly mellow intelligence, this lighthearted backstage drama will feel to his fans like a gathering of familiars.

A strange, spiky movie that refuses to beg for our affection, "Little Sister," the fifth feature from Zach Clark, molds the classic homecoming drama into a quirky reconciliation between faith and family.
"Huntwatch" feels dismayingly one-sided. Yet as we hear of animals being skinned alive and see a bludgeoned pup linger in agony, any pro-hunt argument seems emphatically beside the point.
Trundling along on the drone of Ramsay's pseudo-hardboiled voice-over, "The Whole Truth" plays like an especially claustrophobic courtroom procedural, drably photographed and generically framed.
A grindhouse slog of unrelenting bad taste.
Spiked with dryly funny exchanges and lovingly shot by Eric Robbins on 35-millimeter film, "In a Valley of Violence" nevertheless feels exasperatingly two-dimensional.
Buckling beneath the weight of its director's ambitions, Yang Chao's "Crosscurrent" is spectacular to look at and a devil to decode.
Arranges a series of oblique, geographical vignettes into an unsettling mural of systemic damage.
If there's such a thing as an easygoing thriller, then "Hell or High Water" is it. The stakes may be steep, but the characters can seem more nonchalant than nervous.
Though too slight to be memorable, the gay romance "Front Cover" takes a gentle, thoughtful look at the intersection of ethnicity and sexuality.
It's shamelessly partial but also warmly pleasurable, partly because Mr. Linklater is an engaging and humble conversationalist who moves easily to the beat of his own soundtrack.
When she bounds onstage with a holler and a howl - and diction that nails every last word to the melody - it's clear she deserves that exclamation point in the title.

Viewers ... are unlikely to be more than marginally amused by its fair-to-middling acting, enervated plot and forcibly diverse group of drifting souls gathered on the fictional Greek island of Khronos.
Unfolding with a sincerity that dares you to roll your eyes, this warmhearted documentary by Louise Osmond wallows in its working-class roots like a horse in clover.
Muting the usual cacophony of manipulative musical cues and assaultive sound effects - for long stretches, the movie is almost hushed - Mr. Mikkelsen stirs claustrophobia into panic.

Unexpectedly, Mr. Efron has developed a sweet gift for highlighting the poignancy that undergirds his studmuffin persona; the women may lust after Teddy's body, but the movie relies mostly on his heart.
Our hero's quest ... never ignites, mostly because of Mr. Lee's acting deficits.
movie_title: Phantom Detective (Tamjung Hong Gil-dong: Sarajin Ma-eul) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Observing an unspeakable crime through a dreamy haze of adolescent confusion, the Israeli drama "Princess" turns a loving family home into an incubator of sexual curiosity.
Even if you don't recognize the majority of the unidentified clips assembled here, or the quotations that divide and guide them, the fascination they exert is all their own.
movie_title: The Thoughts That Once We Had (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film is an emotional black hole, its insufferably smug tricksters augmented by Mr. Harrelson ... as his character's identical twin. They never let us forget that their chief superpowers are glibness and ego.
A buoyant, if undisciplined comedy about foreign-raised South Korean teenagers getting in touch with their ethnic roots.
Much of this is funny and even perceptive about the nooks and crannies of adult sexual relationships. It's also very well acted ... But something feels off.

An odd-couple caper of staggering dopeyness that makes you long for the snap and sizzle of the buddy movies of the 1980s, "Central Intelligence" is a clean-out-the-fridge soup of celebrity cameos and C.I.A. confusion.
Patchily revelatory ...
Reaching across 15 years and multiple countries, "Les Cowboys" repurposes the narrative codes of the classic western to explore the complexities of a disrupted world.

Mr. Williams's decision to prioritize his subject's point of view feels frustratingly restrictive. Belaboring the cartoon connection, the director leaves the family struggles that enrich Mr. Suskind's 2014 book of the same title stubbornly veiled.
Toggling between the breathtaking Peruvian highlands and the busy clamor of Lima, "The Debt" places three very different lives on a collision course freighted with moral and financial complexity.

Even if it weren't cheap-looking and dreary, "Cell" would still be hobbled by an entertainment landscape already lousy with zombies, and a hive-mind premise that - at least metaphorically - has been all but realized.
Though Mr. Berlinger had final cut, it's hard to find a single moment here that would be out of place in a promotional video.
movie_title: Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Spackling over any copycat cracks with strong acting and fleet editing, "Lights Out" delivers minimalist frights in old-school ways.
Sprinting right out of the gate, the director, Yeon Sang-ho, dives gleefully into a sandbox of spilled brains and smug entitlement.
[The] screenplay ... amounts to little more than a string of flashy stunts before fizzling to a contrived close. For all its hints at imminent catastrophe, "Nerve" feels surprisingly tame.

Impossible to categorize, this stunningly original mix of the macabre and the magical combines comedy, tragedy, fantasy and love story into an utterly singular package that's beholden to no rules but its own.
All affect and no personality.
[An] elegantly unsettling documentary about the United States' reliance on aerial combat drones.
A sweet, shambling poem to the tenacity of hope and the sustaining power of friendship, "Hunter Gatherer" joins two luckless strivers on a picaresque journey to nowhere.
The lightness and winking quality that softened the slaughter are less evident in "John Wick: Chapter 2," an altogether more solemn affair weighed down by the philosophy that more is always more.
"I Am Jane Doe" coalesces into a steamroller of pain that squashes our ability to see beyond its wounded families.
The setup is commonplace, but the scenery is delicious, the dialogue refreshingly tart and the keen supporting cast frisky or affecting, as the occasion demands.
Might just charm you into submission.
The millions who died during this real-life tragedy deserve a stronger memorial than this one.
Drawing its energy from revenge and its jagged humor from a black well of contempt for the wealthy, the movie fashions a world in which the only likable characters are the crazy and the doomed.
Guided by the work of a handful of burr-like journalists, this dense and disturbing documentary dives into the regulatory quagmire of California water rights with more courage than hope.
Slapstick and sap vie for prominence in "Table 19," a comedy so lazy that it actually features someone falling off a log.

At times it plays like an extended skit on "The Daily Show"; yet its disorder also makes its insights - like how strongly the church's training sessions resemble acting classes - feel refreshingly organic.
An exceptionally classy-looking movie about deeply horrifying behavior.

Mr. Byrne - relying almost entirely on a doom-metal soundtrack, game performers and a grungy palette of oily browns and moldy greens - somehow whips his ingredients into an improbably taut man-versus-Satan showdown.
While "T2" might be middle-aged, it's very far from moribund, the despondent base notes shouldering a story of revenge and regret, amity and acceptance.

Touching on issues of artistic survival and the porous boundary between work and pleasure, Ms. Subrin, an accomplished visual artist and filmmaker, sifts addiction, celebrity and the plight of the aging actress into something rarefied yet real.
What hoists this bloody battiness above much of the scrappily low-budget horror pack is the smartness of its execution and the strength of the movie's central performance.
A fascination with posteriors - both human and feline - isn't the worst thing about "CHIPS," but it's up there.
Given the familiarity of its premise - a handful of survivors brave the aftermath of a deadly, rage-inducing virus - "Here Alone" is unexpectedly engaging.
Yes, it's a horror movie (the murder scenes suggest that the director has watched "Psycho" more than once), but even its most brutal acts pulse with inchoate sadness.
Adopting a meandering, free-flowing structure and woozily intimate photography, the director, Jenny Gage, and her husband, the cinematographer Tom Betterton, follow close and listen well.
Ugly to look at and even uglier to listen to, Joanna Arnow's whiny documentary "i hate myself :)" plays like an especially brutal exercise in self-analysis.
The movie's rough-and-tumble look works in its favor, and the occasional doldrums allow for reflection on the obstacles, military and otherwise, the women face daily.
The gently nostalgic mood and sleepy pacing effectively erase the movie's necessary edge.
A horror movie of such ineptitude that it invites sympathy for even its least gifted participants.
A depressing slog that could have been so much more, "Youth in Oregon" suggests that loving someone gives us the right to override their decisions.
[An] insipid and uninformative portrait of singularity and obsession.
"Planet Earth" might have made us tougher to impress, but "Seasons" has the advantage of its focus on a timeline, showing the gradual incursion of man into this earthly paradise.
[Its] strengths ... are undermined by a story that gives Seth an out and seems to suggest that we should forgive him. Not likely.
Ms. Magalhaes, a former dancer, uses her expressive eyes and graceful limbs to bring the intimacy and sensuality of her actions to vivid life.
This nostalgic nod to the Chinese magic-and-martial arts genre known as wuxia mixes love story and clan war with equal amounts of silliness and heart.
Staggeringly silly and visually disordered, this unfortunate misfire has been kicking around Europe and elsewhere for a couple of years under different titles, and it's easy to see why.
"The Hollow Point" limps to a close without fully rewarding the effort expended on its making.
Gruesome without being gory, "The Autopsy of Jane Doe" achieves real scares with a minimum of special effects.
Proving definitively that slapping Mr. Franco's scenery-eating grin on any old drivel doesn't guarantee entertainment, "Why Him?" is trite, crass and insultingly moronic.
In this achingly inept thriller, you will see Naomi Watts do what she can to sell a plot of such preposterousness that the derisory laughter around me began barely 20 minutes in.

Embracing a structure that implicitly acknowledges the complexity of the issue, Ms. Marson nevertheless contributes to the film's general fuzziness by failing to clarify the legal and moral guidelines that govern these kinds of prescriptions.
Despite solid acting (including John Cusack as a plainclothes detective), "Arsenal" is hobbled mainly by its director's histrionic tendencies.
Alternately sexy and silly, galvanic and gentle, "MA" is best enjoyed as a slide show of visual blessings and, sometimes, bafflements.

"Alone in Berlin" proceeds like a train crossing a plain. Without twists or turns, hills or valleys, its dramatic engine chugs reliably forward, delivering its cargo of World War II tragedy with bland efficiency.
"My Father Die" is a trashy jewel. As with the Rubens painting of Saturn devouring one of his sons that punctuates certain scenes, you kind of can't stop looking at it.
He still looks like a hard-boiled egg sitting on top of a fire hydrant.

Though thematically vague, thinly plotted and without a reliably sympathetic soul to cling to, the movie has a mutinous energy and an absurd, knockabout charm; even its violence is more quirky than brutal.

Mr. Franco broods and puzzles and vacillates. But he often seems abandoned by a director whose approach is so noncommittal and dramatically limp that it strands the actor, and his character, in a bland purgatory of conflicting motivations.
Light on plot yet heavy on chemistry, "Paris 05:59" is at times a little precious. But the two leads are so believably besotted that their occasional immaturity doesn't rankle.
movie_title: Paris 05:59: Théo & Hugo (Théo et Hugo dans le même bateau) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The characters don't have conversations so much as helpfully recite their back stories, and the long-buried secret is soon so obvious that the movie's last-act hysteria feels forced and a little ridiculous.
Stingingly attuned to the tension between long-term love and last-minute misgivings, "Between Us" makes a familiar situation feel remarkably fresh.
The whole film seems to be running in place.
This low-budget debut by Joshua Overbay cooks a surprising amount of tension from the barest minimum of ingredients.
Anyone looking for some idiosyncratic, visually stimulating entertainment this week could do worse than Where Is Where?
The film's kinky energy eventually wanes, the pileup of profanities losing its initial zing.
Looper is a self-consciously good-looking, profoundly silly movie that nevertheless comes off as high-minded.
Augmented by a trove of archival footage reaching back to the 1930s, Jesse Feldman's buoyant cinematography merges political history and sports mania into a triumphant timeline.
If wallowing in the creative hiccups of tortured scribblers is your moviegoing goal, there are much better options.
[Its] downfall was ensured by a leading lady who will always be more credible chasing zombies than the American dream.
Drippy sentiment and coarse political satire vie for control of "Butter," a two-faced sendup of heartland obsession that wants to have its toast and eat it too.
Arranged in a handful of clear, concise chapters, "Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare" turns an unwieldy, Medusa-headed topic into a convincingly humane argument for change.
movie_title: Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A low-budget horror anthology with segments both ghastly and moronic ...
Yes, child trafficking is horrific; but embedding your raise-the-alarm mission in a film this inept runs the risk of arousing more amusement than activism.

Arnold, a director of uncommon originality, attacks our very notion of what a costume drama should look like. The result is neither dainty nor remotely refined: It's an animalistic, mud-splattered howl of torment.
"In My Mother's Arms" takes a distressing snapshot of an ongoing struggle.

Though both actors deliver performances more credible than the plot that frames them, their authenticity only highlights the script's affection for improbable coincidences and an ending even Garry Marshall might consider too pat.
A vibrantly vulgar comedy that never hangs around to admire its own cleverness.
This remainder-bin horror movie is impossible to take seriously.
Though at times a tad worshipful, the film's tone is ultimately more awed than hagiographic, its commenters too cleareyed and candid to back away from negative publicity or public disenchantment.
A film that begins as a family quest but evolves into a gripping study of know-don't-tell reticence and the umbilical tie of a lost homeland.

This scattershot investigation of the effects of Internet pornography on female behavior only ruffles the surface of a complex issue, one that demands a much larger sample than three white, educated women.
Despite a welcome lack of Disneyfied sentimentality - no tears are solicited for banged-up young'uns - the film never acquires a rhythm.
Newlyweds are slaughtered, a child kidnapped and a suicide bombing foiled, all of it advanced by chunks of clumsy dialogue and embarrassingly labored acting.
Pairing a dull romance with an even duller sport (at least as represented here), this cliché-ridden vanity project is more suited to the ABC Family channel than to the inside of a movie theater.
Unfolding in awkward diner conversations and uncomfortable bedroom scenes, "Gut" has a cold, flat look that gives even a child's stuffed toy a sinister sheen.

Unable to shape these events into a dramatic structure, the director, Camilo Vila, resorts to a meandering tale of random indignities suffered by a lead so bland he comes across less as principled than as stupendously naïve.
A brutally uncompromising blast of outrage, Vibeke Lokkeberg's "Tears of Gaza" is less a documentary than a collage of suffering.
Dry as new bank notes and doggedly uncinematic, Simon Yin's "$upercapitalist" approaches the seamy side of international finance with a story as stale as the subprime meltdown.
Snapshots of greasy fries and slimy grills pump up the unsavory atmosphere, while Heather McIntosh's ominous, cello-driven score plucks our nerves and stirs our stomachs.
Blindingly gorgeous to look at and exceptionally well acted, at least by the women.
Mr. Weide and Ms. Tucker are ill served by a director who reduces the anti-wolf lobby to caricature and the debates over reintroducing wolves to the Northern Rockies to grossly biased clips.
This small sleeper delivers a surprising number of pleasingly putrid punch lines.
"Somewhere Between" presents an effortlessly moving but superficial profile of four bright Chinese girls and their adoptive American families.
Labeling a film grind house doesn't excuse soap-opera emoting and laughable dialogue.
The sports-as-savior theme is an old one, but this confident movie, alternately volatile and tender, coats its clichés in winningly natural performances and Enrique Aular's kinetic photography.
Even if you resist the film's claims of being based on one family's actual experiences, "The Possession" is eerily enjoyable pulp.
Swelling music and Kelsey Grammer's refined narration supply the appropriate sobriety, but the film is too intent on promoting the nobility of its cause to worry about engaging the uninitiated.

"The Tall Man" opens like a ghost story and closes with its feet firmly in the real world. Until then, Pascal Laugier's chilly little thriller manhandles our sympathies and gladdens our eyes in almost equal measure.
Filled with blind eyes and unspoken agreements, "Girl Model" opens a can of worms, then disdains to follow their slimy trails.
With slapstick smothering the scares, "[REC 3]" is further marred by a plot in which the muted Catholicism of its antecedents is turned up to full blast.
Moving from union hall to town hall, from brutal salary negotiations to contentious plans to create urban farms out of concrete wasteland, the film listens and moves on.
A swelling meditation on wounded hearts and rekindled hopes.
Unfolding in somber tones and among hard surfaces, Arbitrage has the slickness of new bank notes and the confidence of expensive tailoring.
Coming upon opportunities for depth or nuance, Ms. Jaye seems unsure how to proceed.
movie_title: The Right To Love: An American Family (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Despite on-point performances, the story is too pitted with holes and loose ends to permit the film a bump from meh to marvelous.
A zombie plague may have laid waste the world, but apparently supplies of black leather unitards have yet to be exhausted.
Exhaustive and exhausting, the new energy documentary "Switch" is so monotonous it makes "An Inconvenient Truth" look like "Armageddon."
A nifty little thriller that dances on the boundary between plausible and preposterous.
With marvelous discipline, Mr. Shapiro crams a wealth of material into a tight 77 minutes, smoothly communicating the group effort required to achieve the perfect shot.
A straightforward whatdunnit and a passionate slap in the face for a spineless EPA.
Ms. Anderson traces a tale of aggressive rezoning, multimillion-dollar development deals and racial displacement.
A gentle pairing of youthful idealism and tenacious hope.
movie_title: A Bottle in the Gaza Sea (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A narrow, albeit intriguing window into a technological revolt that deserves a more far-reaching film than this one.
Derivative and dorky, Storage 24 still entertains more often than it exasperates.
More than anything, "FrackNation" underscores the sheer complexity of a process that offers a financial lifeline to struggling farmers.
An awkward blend of anti-Semitic atrocities and identity-swapping absurdity, the World War II drama "My Best Enemy" struggles to find a convincing tone.

Reuben is a whiny and uncoordinated prodigal son. His constant chafing at himself and the world is the film's biggest problem; by the midway point we're all wishing him back in Finland where he belongs.
A granola ode to natural childbirth that makes you want to hop into a tub of warm water and start pushing.
movie_title: Birth Story: Ina May Gaskin and The Farm Midwives (2013)

movie_review_blurb: "Our School" observes the feinting of small-town officials in rural Transylvania as they try to duck a mandate to integrate Roma children into the regular school system.

Charmingly slight and casually confessional, this fond, fly-on-the-wall portrait by Sabine Lidl tags along with Ms. Goldin on a sentimental journey from Paris to Berlin, where longtime friends and lovers wait to supplement her candid reminiscences.
movie_title: Nan Goldin: I Remember Your Face (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Soulless and two-dimensional, Knife Fight is a black hole of disillusion and spin.
Driven by a combination of narrative economy and emotional expansiveness, Valérie Massadian's "Nana" is as difficult to pin down as the inner life of the tiny human at its center.
A dumb, dreary, let's-get-back-at-them slasher in which pulverized genitals pass for feminist critique.
Combines lecture, farce and soapy sentiment in a single misshapen package.
movie_title: La chispa de la vida (As Luck Would Have It) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Gliding from intimate to surreal, from aurally disjunctive to visually seductive, "Rubberband" is a languorous ballad of sadness and disappointment.
movie_title: A Rubberband Is An Unlikely Instrument (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Vividly depicting the indignities of the flesh, "Porfirio" offers a harshly sensual portrait of a man imprisoned by paralysis and the callousness of the state.
A derivative horror movie with highfalutin pretensions.
Compellingly illuminates how the monsters among us leave more than corpses in their wake.
A Canadian nonthriller that plays like a heavily sedated hybrid of "Taken" and "Not Without My Daughter" ...
Though the film eventually caves to sentiment and stereotype, its alert performances and muted rhythms offer much to enjoy in the interim.
This well-acted debut feature from Michael Connors (a former Army captain) is too limited in ambition and scope to satisfy our expectations.
The bulk of the material is confusing at best and laughable at worst.

Visually stunning but manipulative in the extreme - try not to roll your eyes as the various family members miss one another by inches - The Impossible nevertheless contains two of the year's best performances.
"Jack & Diane" offers a glaring example of a writer and director, Bradley Rust Gray, unable to trust in the simple strength of his material.
A simmering drama powered by fully drawn characters and fine performances.
Brown ... translates a collage of experiences - some desperate, some hopeful, all tragic - into a first-person commentary on the malign reverberations of war.
Low-key and low-tech, "Lunch" coasts on the earned wisdom of pros who know how to work a room.
Has an atavistic pulse, evoking a decaying society where elevators fail and bus drivers cower behind mesh grills.
A story that, though sickly fascinating, is as crudely rendered as its images.
A well-meaning but inexpertly dramatized account of the roundup of 13,000 Parisian Jews in the summer of 1942.
"Generation P" delivers a brave, head-spinning commentary on the potency of advertising and the seduction of the soul.
Quiet, simple and soaked in sorrow, "Hitler's Children" takes a stripped-down approach to an emotionally sophisticated subject.
The sisters' struggle for autonomy (they opened Amsterdam's only independent brothel until they were forced out by organized crime) reveals a touching commitment to mutual survival.
A wry, mournful study of midlife crisis ...
This brisk reimagining of the 1984 slasher "Silent Night, Deadly Night" delivers the seasonal goods with admirable efficiency and not a little wit.

Bathed in the flamingo colors and Caribbean rhythms of its location, this deeply personal debut from the writer and director Mariette Monpierre develops with a lingering attention to sensation and sound.
Making the most of its likable leads, the script (by Ms. Kenig and Dana Dimant) maintains an amused, nonjudgmental tone ...
Equal parts temper and tenderness, lust and incaution, "Heleno" is short on specifics but long on impression.
The film presents an often sharp commentary on dueling beliefs and idiocies that unfolds in lush pastel hues and distinctively retro drawings.
[A] layered, intermittently fascinating documentary ...
A patient chamber piece about the emotional bruises left by poverty and neglect.
If we must talk trash, Mr. Irons - assisted by a scientist or two and Vangelis's doomy score - is an inspired choice of guide.
Infinitely less than the sum of its parts, Antonino D'Ambrosio's "Let Fury Have the Hour" crams 50 thoughtful artists into a disappointingly muddled film.
[A] grating round robin of connubial dysfunction and romantic disappointment.
Though Mr. Yang paints a colorful portrait of a country grappling with new freedoms, his real triumph is a moving and complex love triangle that will configure and reconfigure into adulthood.
Mr. Slater valiantly tries to appear turned on by his leading lady's shimmying midsection, but he might as well be watching a performing dog for all the heat mustered between them.

Baxter may not be the most accomplished filmmaker, but he's on the side of the angels here and his determination to give the locals a voice denied them by major media coverage lends his film momentum and heart.
Unexpectedly flouting its doomy title, "Last Days Here" invests the standard, washed-up rock-star tale with surprising sweetness.
At least 30 minutes and several scams too long, the plot passes from amusing to confounding long before the final double-cross.
[The directors] cede narrative structure to their interview subjects, which may fulfill some goal of objectivity but cheats the viewer of depth or a clear point of view.

Frayed-looking performance film alternates with cuddly home movies and the director's theatrical interventions, but the couple's willingness to bare flesh only heightens the overall feeling of artifice.
movie_title: The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye (2012)

movie_review_blurb: In the crumbling passion of a once hot-to-trot couple (a perfect Kristen Wiig and Jon Hamm), [it] locates a jagged heart that no amount of zingers can surpass.
Almost all of the film's remarkably static scenes reveal too little and confuse too much.
Here, dreams and reality rub shoulders, and redemption seems as distant as peace itself.
Donaldson ... seems to have lost all talent for pacing.
If making a decent movie required only good intentions, then "Pray for Japan" would be off and running.
Within its tight 87 minutes, not a lot happens, unless you count the saving of a life.
Like the bloodied placards brandished by demonstrators outside women's health clinics, the film communicates in the language of guilt and fear.
There is something appealingly messy about "Come On Eileen," the first feature from Finola Geraghty and one of the few to face alcoholism from a female point of view...
By the time the mirror ball finally spins, we have long since lost interest.
A shimmering exploration of romantic obsession and the tension between fitting in and flying free.

If the 20-odd seconds of blank screen squatting pointlessly amid the opening credits aren't enough warning that you're in for some seriously sluggish storytelling, then the adoption of a snail as one of the central motifs should drive the point home.
[It] has a gentle oddness as unforced as its performances and as inoffensive as its dialogue.
Watching "God Save My Shoes," Julie Benasra's blithely blinkered documentary, is like gorging on empty calories: flavorful, diverting and with a slightly nauseating aftertaste.
It's potent stuff, delving into pornography, incest, murder and mutilation in the company of alienated men and unhappy, sometimes cruel women.
A sad chronicle of absent fathers and messed-up mothers, drugs as currency and violence as the period at the end of every argument.
This distressing infiltration of a family of young boys by a charismatic psychopath rewards with a stylistic talent that feels entirely new.
Ms. Seyfried belongs to a stable of blank-faced, saucer-eyed beauties whose limited appeal may conquer the small screen but so far has failed to tame the large.
An immersive look at the power of archaic traditions to sabotage a transitioning culture.
Unsurprisingly, the finished product plays like a pumped-up recruitment commercial deemed fit for feature length and multiplex viewing.
What we need is for the writer and director, David Pomes, to wallow less in aimless dialogue and lowlife sordidness. What we need is a point.
To fresh eyes, Corman's World may feel more like a meal; to the rest of us, it's merely a glance at the menu.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Mr. Miyazaki smooshes fantasy and history into a pastel-pretty yarn as irresistible as his feminism.

Really, how slovenly is it to use invisible aliens? If you're going to tease us with nothing but pinwheels of light for three-quarters of the film, you'd better have one heck of a reveal up your sleeve.
Finally less compelling for its random details of multiple brutalities than for its chilling portrait of a country irretrievably rotting from within.
This irreverent classic earns its cult status by brilliantly timed performances and a script as funny as it is observant.
movie_title: Le Père Noël est une Ordure (1982)

movie_review_blurb: Maudlin and ham-fisted, The Iron Lady is cinematic scrap metal.
Ed Wood would have been proud.
movie_title: Codependent Lesbian Space Alien Seeks Same (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Though speckled here and there with uneasy comedy, "Toll Booth" is a psychological pressure cooker that could blow its lid at any moment.

In place of emotional stakes, we get gleaming, stylized, occasionally slow-motion violence, filmed in such extreme close-ups and cramped spaces that it's impossible to differentiate gunman and victim.
Charmingly low-key, the British coming-of-age drama "Albatross" offsets slack plotting with creative casting and sensitive performances.
While occasionally unpleasant, the film never crosses the line from bearably chilling to unbearably gruesome, keeping its characters credible and its events explicable.
The film's title may draw you in, but it's the texture that keeps you watching.
As the camera skitters spastically around its troubled schlub, the film becomes a muddy, minimalist moan of desperation.

So entertaining are the characters that you may leave the theater before realizing that the film's specters might emanate from somewhere much closer -- much, much closer -- than the haunted history of a Connecticut hotel.
Feels more like a free-market sales pitch than like a critical look at one weapon in the poverty-fighting arsenal that may or may not offer long-term hope.
movie_title: Bonsai People: The Vision of Muhammad Yunus (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An earnest experiment in don't-ask-don't-tell drama as indebted to shirtlessness as to iambic pentameter.
A portentous, rather creepy documentary that masks its lack of historical context with an atmosphere of accumulating threat.
Devoid of charisma or a third dimension, these contrived characters - whether dissolute or doltish, shrill or sheepish - rarely engage.
While Mr. Irelan and a few of the supporting players have some solid moments (the entire cast consists of nonprofessionals), the general vibe is too stilted to convince.
Pablum tarted up with tennis racquets, "16-Love" is, in a sense, the perfect movie for teenagers: you can text and tweet to your heart's content and never miss a thing.
While it's hard to concentrate on systemic problems when faced with the rotting teeth of an adorable Vietnamese orphan, it's those very problems that require our most intense scrutiny.
Even were it not so delightful, Damsels in Distress, set at a fictional upper-crust college, would deserve a watch for its dialogue alone.
Too lifeless for Lifetime and too inept to do justice to its source material...
"The Oregonian" teases us with horror and amnesia-mystery conventions without sealing the deal either way.
A beautifully filmed and patiently explained assessment of a proposal to build five hydroelectric dams in the Patagonia region of Chile.
[It] suggests only that ferreting out new ways to inflict pain requires more imagination than anyone on hand realized.
Cevin Soling and David Hilbert's offbeat meditation on human nature and academic hubris.
A tiresome roundelay of lies, lust and leaping paranoia.
Like the romance it portrays, Seeking a Friend for the End of the World is brief, sweet, funny and sad.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This one is for Hank Williams fanatics only, and Mr. Thomas puts a dark and subtle sheen on a disappointingly watery script.
Relaxed performances and pillow-soft photography compensate somewhat for the story's narrow ambitions, but they're not enough to invigorate a movie that clearly would rather charm than challenge.
Blessed with natural performances and brisk pacing, this unusual little movie would like us to know just one thing: Passion is fine, but a pal is priceless.
The film weaves a spell as inchoate as Margot's discontent.
This screeching exposé from Asif Akbar serves neither the viewer nor its embattled subject.
As scrappy and passionate as the actions it documents, "United in Anger: A History of Act Up" delivers a living tribute to a movement spawned by death and despair.
movie_title: United in Anger: A History of ACT UP (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Mr. Sun straddles ancient and modern, tranquillity and turmoil, with equal sureness.
Tom Shu-Yu Lin tackles death, divorce, loneliness and first love with the eye of a painter and the heart of a child.

"The Imposter" is slippery, manipulative, unstable and smoothly confounding. It's also one of the most entertaining documentaries to appear since "Exit Through the Gift Shop," a film similarly obsessed with role playing and deception.
They should have known that a levitating De Niro was simply a séance too far.
The film's sweetness is endearing but too featherweight to engage.

Perhaps it's all that armor, or that even the estimable Mr. Wang seems exhausted by the film's dolorous themes, but it's tough to care about characters who spend most of their lives obsessing over the violent deaths of others.
A provocative look at what can happen when corporate power takes aim at independent film.
An ostensible romantic comedy that's really just a grating portrait of an irredeemable jerk.
By the end you may not be a fan of her music, but it's hard not to root for her rebirth.
For all the stellar intentions; revelatory evidence; and thoughtful, wall-to-wall interviewees, this frustratingly overstuffed documentary indulges more in spraying buckshot than stalking a target.
A riveting portrait of young men in shock and in mourning as the tragedy stirs feelings that have long lain dormant.
Like the Upper East Side penthouse in which it unfolds, the documentary "Unraveled" is cool and elegant, echoing with spaces for our imaginations to fill.
Roiling with jealousy, suicide and latent lesbian urges, "The Moth Diaries" dances on the border between hallucination and reality without fully committing to either.
Mr. Grubin may fumble two romances and several pivotal scenes, but the energy of the streets remains safe in his hands.

To experience "Chimpanzee," the latest piece of gorgeously shot pablum from Disneynature, is to endure an orgy of cuteness pasted over some of the most asinine narration ever to ruin a wildlife movie.

Replete with eye-roll-inducing contrivances and heavy-handed symbolism - both lovers share dreams of their teeth falling out - this arrested-development comedy panders to the work-averse by taking easy aim at ambitious careerists.

More grounded in simple observation than in fanciful theories, this effortlessly engaging story of sudden tragedy and halting recovery wisely focuses on the facts and leaves the wonder to the audience.
A good-looking but passionless affair that remains stubbornly aloof from its audience.

The wonder of Black's performance here is its empathy and balance: inasmuch as he can disappear into any role, he dissolves into this one with no hint of mocking remove. It's a beautiful thing to see.
Unfolding in New England over four vibrantly represented seasons, "Feelings" is a small-scale wonder.
The film has a bare-bones look that only intensifies its nearly painful sincerity.
Stuffed with secrets and characters who can't wait to betray one another, the film offers no one to root for except Mother, whose perverted family values at least remain consistent.
Even at a lean 73 minutes, this flimsy road movie feels at least 43 minutes too long.
A powerfully atmospheric blend of ghostly encounters, horrific situations and missing-persons mysteries from the Philippine director Yam Laranas.
Moments of insight flare like fireflies and disappear, whether from underfinancing or overambition is unclear.
Charging from one beating to another, wrenching diminishing returns from drunken camera angles and cat-and-mouse games, Mr. Jardin makes Vincent's predicament as hollow as a sustained scream.
Hysteria, a disappointingly limp ode to the invention of the vibrator, plays like a Merchant Ivory Production of Portnoy's Complaint.

Though not much to look at, these brief glimpses of soul-and-soil connection - a sheepherder watching his lambs gambol, a young resident explaining how a favorite mountain nurtures prayer - unfold with heartfelt simplicity.

[Jackson's] doleful revenant is in almost every scene, and this hardworking actor seems to know that the film around him should be a light-footed caper instead of a grim noir with a side order of deviance.
Generating suspense without blowing the special-effects budget, Mr. Sanchez paints an intimate portrait of a tormented personality.
Close-ups of a needle penetrating gnarled toes and a mutant slathered in what I choose to believe is bittersweet chocolate make as much sense as the scary drawings of angry vulvas hiding in a drawer.
We are left with a naked portrait of successful self-analysis, of a man reaching backward for the strength to move forward.
Poised on the brink of sexual awareness and the waning of the Cultural Revolution, an 11-year-old boy struggles to interpret the signals from his changing body and an increasingly confusing world.
Magnificent in its thoroughness and nuance, this dense, multifaceted study of Somali piracy really needs to settle down.
Revealing little that a moderately informed viewer will not already know, the film shies away from the outrage and bare-knuckle journalism that this shameful topic deserves.
For all the shooting, knifing and nattering about sleeper cells, the film feels weirdly static and terminally tired.
A cool, kinky tale of sudden bereavement, sexual adventure and hard-won hope.
Trying to gather too much into his net, Mr. Stewart gets a little lost, but his bottom line could not be clearer: When the oceans die, so do we.
A muddled supernatural thriller that fails to capitalize on either its horrific prologue or eerie location.
Plays like a publicity stunt for its secular stars.
A documentary that presents the sexual exploitation of young women as a systemic cancer that feeds on public misconception as much as male appetites.
Messy in parts and at least 15 minutes too long, "Personal Tailor" is also cunningly acted and lushly photographed (by Zhao Xiaoshi) in dazzling candy-bright colors.
Mr. Kaufman's talent can be debated, but his love for his job is stamped on every garish, oozy frame.
Filled with sappy dialogue and screeching strings, "Truth" is a puerile excavation of secrets and sickness.
A tedious wallow in female damage and the indulgence of same ...
"Loves Her Gun" is one of the most soothing examinations of fear you're ever likely to see.
A soft-centered child's-eye view of alienation, toughened by fine acting and Hélène Louvart's full-bodied photography.
Before our eyes, Laura's lengthening limbs and deepening introspection become the point of a movie that begins with a child and ends with a young woman.
Had Mr. Croudins focused more on Mitch's desire to distance himself from a wrong-side-of-the-tracks upbringing - and less on ticking genre boxes - his movie could only have been the better for it.

Dredging up horror movie favorites like random nosebleeds, a traumatized priest and a mama-to-be with a yen for raw meat, Matt Bettinelli-Olpin and Tyler Gillett direct with competence but a dispiriting lack of originality.
A sparking, gossipy soap opera that's riddled with emotion and stuffed with strong characters.
This challenging and mesmerizing documentary captures horror and joy with the same gorgeous dispassion.
movie_title: Aatsinki: The Story Of Arctic Cowboys (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Tapping into the near-universal desire for reinvention, Mr. O'Keefe gives us a well-worn story that somehow avoids glaring clichés or forced melodrama.
Ms. Sevigny is the unsteady center of a movie that uses awkward silences, cryptic dialogue and self-consciously arty images to signify emotional limbo.
Though the developing bond between the two men - one of whom is virtually nonverbal - is credible and even touching, the storytelling is too oblique to reel you in.
