movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Louis Zamperini's life would make a great movie, if only somebody knew how to make it.
Cumberbatch refines his Sherlock Holmes routine and carries a rousing movie about how English cryptographers cracked Germany's military code and shortened World War II.
It wants to make big statements about America and do it in a quiet voice, and is about class distinctions and the assumed privileges that money brings with it.
The "Hobbit" trilogy started slowly and ended with a rush, heroes and villians fighting it out over a mountain of gold. What kid of any age can resist that?
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The talking heads, Long and Rossum, go on and on in a relationship drama that plays with time and fails.
This set-up could be played as farce or satire or some pleasing combination of the two, but writer-director Roberto Ando, adapting his novel for the screen, chooses a formal, arm's length approach.
A documentary on the Deepwater Horizon oil spill of 2010 shows that nothing has changed except the oil is still in the ocean and the lives of those who live closest to the spill are much worse.
Jones stars and directs in a powerful western with Oscar-worthy performances by himself and Swank.
If you like pelicans -- and what's not to like? -- you'll like this documentary.
I've read the novel and seen the movie twice, and I've given up worrying about the plot. It doesn't matter.
Neeson used his newfound box-office clout to get "A Walk Among the Tombstones" made, and he's the best reason to see it.
It tosses out a lot of information and doesn't pull it into a compelling movie.
A beautiful, heartbreaking documentary.

"Palo Alto" is "Fast Times at Ridgemont High" without the wit; "River's Edge" without the depth. It's like reading a first novel by a talented writer who has something to say but isn't yet sure how to say it.
An amiable documentary about a shy-guy redhead in Scotland raises some important questions in a low-key amusing way.

Favreau's a big man who knows how to wield a chef's knife and shoots the food truck scenes with a hectic good nature that's infectious. There's no message beyond the obvious -- a good sandwich can solve a lot of problems.
What's best about "Belle" is the performance of Ebatha-Raw.
The potentially huge audience for "Million Dollar Arm" deserves a better movie, less derivative and cynical and more like something real. What a concept.
There's a sketchy, uneven quality that keeps it from taking off. Scenes are unbalanced and end abruptly and the movie comes to a logical end twice and keeps going.
A straightforward documentary about the history of dams in America and the recent movement to remove expensive, outdated dams that impede fish passage.
The connections between African Americans, Jews and Italians could maybe be explored in a different, better movie, one that doesn't have Sharon Stone in it.
For those not driven off by a Mad Libs collection of "emotional tension," "gloomy plot," "grieving parents" and "modern Romania," "Child's Pose" is thrilling.
The last in a trilogy about a French novelist and his three lady friends in New York is as light and relaxing as a summer evening.
A fascinating and frustrating film ...
Gyllenhaal is impressive in a weirdly original thriller from Villeneuve that trips over its many legs at the finish.
When all is revealed in "The Best Offer," the appropriate reaction is that of a frustrated auctioneer: "That's it? That's all you've got?"

It's exciting to see how Will Ferrell and Adam McKay took all the good will they built up in the first movie and pushed it to the limits of sanity in search of laughs without playing it safe and stupid like so many comedy sequels.
Oscar-bait, through and through.
"The Armstrong Lie" feels like wheel-spinning, outraged that Armstrong lied not only to millions of people but to Gibney and then not pushing the evidence to the finish line.
A nice movie about a nice guy.
Some of the performances -- Mitchell, Fischler and especially Lucas -- are lively, but Barr never gets under Kerouac's skin to show the pain of an artist who can't hold his life together.
How could a movie with all that talent be so awful?

It's all beautifully photographed in medium depth and edited in a way that's both erotic and shallow, and would be nothing more than a Lifetime movie without a knockout performance by Robin Weigert as Abby.

It's an unusual experience -- I kept waiting for what felt like an extended prologue to end and the movie to start -- but once it settles in, you're off on a cultural time-trip without a guide or a net.
There's magic in the music and the men and women who make it. Maybe they put Mavis Staples at the end because nobody could follow her.
Woodley and Elgort, who played sister and brother in "Divergent," have the unforced chemistry that happens so often when opposites attract.
Ai comes across as highly intelligent, weary, extremely wary of outsiders but with a puckish sense of humor.
O'Connell is a force, tough and tender, and Mendelsohn matches him in a stirring English prison drama.
Gandolfini's last screen performance and another great one from Tom Hardy are the highlights of a crime thriller from Lehane, the author of "Gone Baby Gone" and "Mystic River."
A movie that raises questions about creativity and mental illness in a celebrity culture.
Duplass and Moss are great as a couple that goes away for a weekend to find what's lost and find something else entirely.
The road to "The Giver" was paved with good intentions -- and potholes deep enough to bury it.
Watching Michel Gondry's new movie "Mood Indigo" is like being force-fed mounds of parfait by a gang of ice-skating mice.
Revolutionary in its approach and quietly transformational in the way of all great art; experiencing it will change you.
Move over, Liam Neeson. There's an unlikely new action hero on the Euro-American market.
"Venus in Fur" is about the mysterious games men and women play, and Seigner and Amalric are up to it.
Just think back to everything that was funny in "21 Jump Street." It's exactly the same.
Director David L. Lewis has done his homework and turned up some gems ...
movie_title: The Pleasures Of Being Out Of Step (2014)

movie_review_blurb: My advice is to go with someone whose opinion you respect; you might not like it, but you're sure to have a lively discussion.
"Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" is a showcase for Serkis and the mo-cap wizards. The apes go marching, one by one.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Short, depressing, beautifully acted ...
In a complete reversal from "Once," it's the story, not the songs, that carries "Begin Again."
Its low-key, easy pace and refusal to put extra emphasis on anything gives the real emotions more power when they do arrive.
Hollywood insider Shep Gordon is a raconteur and an all-around great guy, according to him and Myers, who directed a documentary about his pal.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "The Rover" is bleak and gorgeous and has a soulful center thanks to Pearce.
It's called "Filth." Who says there's no truth in advertising?
It's to Schwartz's credit that Dunne and the other actors bring new life to a familiar story.
If it was a real con artist, it would be led away in handcuffs. Nice try, almost got away with it, but not quite.
The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel" is a movie title that reviews itself.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Teens trapped at the wilderness camp from hell act out in violent ways in a well-intentioned expose that steps on its message.

The tone -- deadpan, wistful, silly but never stupid -- is just right and puts "What We Do in the Shadows" next to "This Is Spinal Tap" as a mockumentary that shows its subjects as human -- in this case, inhuman -- in their hopes and fears.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A documentary about the National Lampoon does its best to capture the glory days.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A talky take on the Apple co-founder, structured around three product launches.
"Bridge of Spies" is a smart thriller anchored by two actors whose different backgrounds and styles fit together as firmly as pieces in a puzzle.
An even-handed overview of a tumultuous time in U.S. history.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Freeheld" isn't bad -- with that kind of source material and topline acting talent it almost couldn't be -- but it could have been much more than it is.
Director Denis Villenueve knows how to tease out the suspense, setting a scene early and holding it until the squirming starts, then a moment longer.
What makes "The Martian" work is Damon.
"The Walk" is the rare movie that improves as goes along, shedding its cliches and getting down to what matters.

The dialogue flies past in strings of cliches and emotional beats that don't land, and the underlying message about love and work, work and love is so retrograde that it makes "Prada" seem empowering.
Bill Murray's making broad, sloppy comedies again. That sounds like great news for fans who grew up on "Meatballs" and "Stripes." It's not.
It's fun to watch "The New Girlfriend" the way it's fun to drink a glass of Champagne, and about as memorable.
"The Visit" is not a head-scratcher, like so many of Shyamalan's movies. It's more of a shoulder-shrug. That's it? That's all you've got?
Rather than explore and embrace the contradictions within Jobs ("he had the focus of a monk but none of the empathy" is the best he can do), Gibney puts the hammer down.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Kwapis stages everything like a sitcom, has no sense of pace, and buries the theme of late-life friendship under a haze of sentiment and trail dust. "A Walk in the Woods" could be called "I Need a Walker to Get to the Woods." It's a good walk spoiled.
An update on the wonderful screwball comedy tradition led by a dazzling performance by Gerwig.
"No Escape" is xenophobic claptrap of the highest order.
The finished movie looks cheap and slapped-together, like the crew was in a hurry to get the shot before the cops showed up and starting asking for permits.
A coming-of-age movie from a woman's perspective that deals with sex in a frank, graphic way that is never salacious or prurient.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's overlong and sanitized but succeeds in presenting an important part of contemporary American culture to a mainstream audience.
Ritchie wants to have it both ways, to make James Bond and "Get Smart." It doesn't work.

Maguire nails Fischer's cockiness, his Brooklyn accent, and the way his eyes dart everywhere before locking in on the only thing that interests him, the chess board. He misses by making Fischer's mental problems too overtly crazy.
Loach is 79 and has said this could be his last feature. It's a fine way to end a singular career, on top and in the pocket.
A journalism movie draws the wrong conclusions about a famous journalism scandal.

Gavron is blessed with a talented cast that's fully invested in the project. Duff and Carter transform what could be cliched roles while Gleeson and Whishaw make the men more than one-dimensional villians.
A surprisingly subtle take on aging and the changing roles in a relationship.
The experience of watching "Carol" is like being pulled into a different place, real and not real, like the best movies, like being in love.

It just doesn't work. The pacing is off, there's no tension, the connections don't stick, all that talk leads to a lot of bloody action but no payoffs since the talk meant nothing and the characters that were saying it weren't memorable.
A movie about the financial crisis that tells the truth in a most entertaining way.
I liked it, once I gave in to its charms and chose to ignore its shortcomings.

The documentary is really just an extension of the book, with clips from the movies and commentary by the directors. That's more than enough, although I would have liked a little more on Truffaut's life and career.
Redmayne and Vikander give powerhouse performances in a languid adaptation of Ebershoff's novel.
The formula, more than the Force, was with Abrams. He was wise enough not to mess with it.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There's all sorts of splashing and sloshing and spearing and shouting of ultra-polite commands -- everyone, no matter how much they hate each other, unfailingly uses the honorific "Mister" -- but nothing clicks.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A 3-D, sexually explicit movie filmed in France by a provocative director using inexperienced actors -- what could go wrong?

Hanks found an amiable raconteur in Solomon, now 90 but sharp and focused on the business that was his life. A collection of Solomon's confidants sing his praises and get misty about how much fun they had in the old days.
movie_title: All Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's Pixar Lite, acceptable family entertainment that's nowhere near the quality of "Inside Out" or "The Incredibles."
Hardy plays two roles and knocks himself out.
It's surprising proof that iconic franchises that started in the 1970s can be revived in all the right ways. "Star Wars" fans, take note.
Cranston seizes a starring role as blacklisted writer Dalton Trumbo.
"The Hunger Games" is over. Bring on "Star Wars."
Steinmark's life doesn't give a filmmaker much to work with, and writer-director Angelo Pizzo makes the least of it.
What happened in Chile really was a triumph of the human spirit, as cliched as it is to write that sentence. The miners deserved a better movie, but that's not how it works.
A special experience, a movie that matters.
It's "Thunderball" without the light touch and the boring underwater scenes. Not bad, no need to wake Roger Moore from his mid-morning nap and bring him out of retirement, but not special.
Those who dismiss Lee as a strident polemicist should take another look: "Chi-Raq" makes its points with a sharp wit and downright goofy humor.

Ronan is a fresh new star whose performance as an Irish immigrant in the 1950s is one of the best of the year.
Alvarez ... gets some impressive work out of his young actors, particularly Michael Angarano as John Wayne and Ezra Miller and Tye Sheridan as rebellious prisoners.
This is the best movie of 2015 so far, an action masterpiece.
It's sometimes effective, sometimes manipulative, contrasting life and death with a man holding a card that spells out how he's supposed to look when he pretends to die.
Just when you think all the great rock and roll stories have been told, along comes "Lambert & Stamp," about two guys from different sides of the tracks who guided The Who to guitar-smashing glory.

Witherspoon and Vergara have charisma to spare and the potential for an oil-and-water chemistry that could have worked, but director Anne Fletcher didn't guide them anywhere and writers David Feeney and John Quiantance gave them nothing to work with.

An indie comedy that gets by on the charm of its actors -- Nick Kroll, Rose Byrne and Bobby Canavale -- while asking nothing of its audience and doing nothing more than providing a pleasant 90-minute extension of Kroll's brand into movies.
"The Salt of the Earth" presents not just a passing of time through one man's remarkable life but a change of perspective.
Crowe is a commanding lead actor who could have made it into something special if he'd stayed out of his own way. Maybe he should have stayed home. You should.

There's no tension and never a moment where it feels like anything is at stake. Longo is guilty; Finkel will get his story and get on with his life. It's all about them, not what happened to an innocent family.

"Downton Abbey" has more action in 10 minutes than "Effie Gray" does in two hours.
A committed Pacino and a crack supporting cast can't save a maudlin story about a rock star trying to connect with his estranged son and his better nature.
As for the plot, there is one. As for the acting, it's there in the sense that actors are onscreen moving around and saying words that don't make sense.
Cooper is game but not fierce or conflicted enough; Lawrence doesn't get deep enough to pull anyone along on her spiral into madness.
Deneuve presides over everything as the regal head of the family and national treasure of her country. She's reserved, acting more with her eyes, taking everything in.
"Get Hard" is not challenging its audience; it's pandering to it and trying to get away with weak material.

Boorman is 82; "Queen and Country" is being called his final film in a career that included "Point Blank," "Deliverance" and "Excalibur." If this really is it, congratulations -- and regrets that Bill Rohan didn't appear in a few more movies.

"The Gift" is a low-budget, high-reward thriller and a confident first feature from a talented filmmaker.
Neeson sells it the way he sells everything: with total conviction and a physical grace that belies his big frame.
At the heart of "Iris" is love, between Iris and the camera, Maysles and his subject, and Iris and Carl. They nailed it, this crazy life, and they're still getting a kick out of it.
"Good Kill" deserves credit for framing these important issues in a credible, visually challenging drama, but writer-director Andrew Niccol doesn't take his material anywhere interesting.
Provocative and heartbreaking.
Soggy romantic comedy set in Hawaii that looks like it's been in the sun too long.
Ruffalo gives another in a string of great performances, this time as a loving father with bipolar disorder.

If all the vulgarity and cheap shots were excised the movie would only be 30 minutes long. Filmmakers often shoot tamer versions of the same scene for TV; "Vacation" must have required separate scripts.

It clocks in at less than two hours, only about half of that taken up with a mix of models, computer-generated effects and various other explosions and loud noises. The other half is people saying and doing stupid things.

It's a sad story, and Asif Kapadia's documentary tells it without narration or commentary. Instead there's a brilliantly edited succession of interviews and performances and news footage that glides through her charmed, doomed life.

It's very meta and only mildly interesting. The actors are attractive, the countryside moreso. The plot is silly and threadbare; when tragedy does strike, it has about as much impact as a summer shower.

If "Magic Mike XXL" were an "Ocean's Eleven" movie, it would be "Ocean's Twelve," the boring one in the middle before they wrapped it up on a higher note. There's no need for "Magic Mike" to go there -- twice is one too many.
"A Little Chaos" could have used a lot more of it.
The laughs stop about halfway through, and the 79-minute running time feels about right. One night in a house with these two couples is enough.
"Me and Earl" is smart and appealing, but it spends way too much effort saying "I'm not like that" when it really is.

movie_review_blurb: It's an exciting experience, dazzling and entertaining and thought-provoking.
That this is a documentary, this family lived in New York for decades in almost complete separation from its neighbors, is astonishing.

A quirky comedy that knows where it's going and gets there in due time.
There's an inherent lack of energy in the later years that sucks some of the tension out of the movie, but the overall effect is often entralling and never less than interesting.
At least five years late and a few million brain cells short.

Maybe it's too early to say MacFarlane can't make a movie. He's still young, he's compulsively creative. He'll keep getting more chances. He could figure it out, but I don't think I want to watch him try.
"I'll See You in My Dreams" takes its time getting to unexpected places and makes you glad to follow along.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Finding out about The Comedian, Rorschach and Jon is all great. Yet, there's no human (non-superhero) to root for, so I didn't care if their version of Earth went up in smoke.

Trust me. You must skip the first 20 minutes, and it would be a good idea to leave 10 minutes early as well. Then you've seen a great, intense action flick.

This is the classic 'How come I never heard of this movie?" One day you are watching TV, and New in Town pops on and nothing makes sense. You wonder how you missed hearing about this film in the theater.
The film is jolted into hopes and dreams and more importantly, escaping a blah life. But you can just sense there is something else. After all, this film isn't called 'Frank and April Move to Paris.'
Just like the winter in the movie, the film feels long. The story is amazing, but surprisingly, in the hands of Zwick the film never felt that way.

It's a well-crafted character, stuck in a bad movie, which is a back-handed compliment considering Eastwood produced and directed as well. Now it's time for a PBR and a cigarette. Man, Walt is influential.

The original is at least kitschy fun. So rent that before you even think about spending $40 for the family to see this.

Does director Ron Howard have a style? It's almost like he's a chameleon director, able to craft a variety of projects and do them all very well. But perhaps this also stops him from making unequivocally great films.
Winslet and Kross do making an exciting couple but then Fiennes keeps showing up in the first half. Man, he can really be a buzz kill sometimes.
Biggie lived a HUGE life in only 24 years, but this film has two hours and never sells me. Isn't selling what Sean 'Puffy' Combs is supposed to be an expert at?

Going to a scary movie is kind of like a first date. Your palms get sweaty, you're consistently nervous, and you're just hoping for something unexpected to happen. It's a love/hate thing, and so is this movie.
I once saw an exhibit at an art museum that was a separate room where the noise and light would increase until you couldn't take it anymore. Similar feeling here.
It knows what it is, almost mindless and totally kick-arse. In fact, it's my favorite of the Crankporter flicks.
Little girls will be bored with this insanely fake financial world and Dad's you don't need this movie to remind you to spend time with your kids, right?
It's a well-crafted, good-looking film, and I love the names involved ... it's just not exciting enough.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Just like Up, the first 20 minutes is the best part, and that's about where the comparisons stop. They had the pieces in place for The Proposal but it slowly fell apart.
The opening sequence of Up sits in silence, telling the story of Carl and Ellie and is so overfilled with emotion, tears fell at the end of this beginning.
There is a lull toward the end, where you almost become as exhausted as the boys on the trip. But (and I rarely say this) thank goodness for those end credits.
We finally get to see the full, destructive power of Skynet. And while it looks great, the story around it sure falls flat.
There isn't nearly as much comedy as you would expect based on the previews. There's nothing wrong with that, except the created void isn't really filled with anything, and that ending is just bad.
There is such a fine line between stalk and courtship (in this film), and he normally falls on the stalking side. But he also does yoga, so I guess that makes it all right.
Here's my recommendation, don't let this be your kid's first scary movie, especially in the 3D, which is the only way to see this beautiful, hypnotic film.
I wouldn't quite say love, but this film is really likeable. Whether you want to call it a bromance, or guy love ... it's just a good time at the movies.
What Christopher Nolan did for the Batman franchise, J.J. Abrams has done for Star Trek.
A failed romance is just one reason this is a flat, sloppy film. But still, Wolverine and those claws give us just enough action to keep us mildly interested.
Melodrama makes its way into this film on occasion (like with the flashbacks), and that separates it from greatness.

It just feels like cheating. This is the exact footage used in the "Planet Earth" series. I even miss the full Disney treatment. No cute names given to the animals? How will you sell more stuffed animals?

Antimatter and crosses. Science and religion. Angels and demons. You'll never guess, but it's more of a gray area than black and white. And for many of us, it's as close to Vatican City as we're going to get.
Bryan Singer makes this movie possible, filled with great suspense and amazing actors. This film is on my short list as one of the year's best.

All of the dots fit together very nicely and this journey is one I would take again in a second. Though I was hoping for tears of joy at the end and I didn't get it. But I was close.
I checked, The Opposite of Funny Movie and Awful Film were available for titles, but Disaster Movie works absolutely perfect.
Films like The Hangover and Superbad have proven that you don't need a big budget and lavish sets to make people laugh. For a comedy, Year One feels dated.
Malkovich plus Pitt is perfection. In fact, I wish the film could have focused on just the two of them.
This can't be what women want to watch. A film written, directed and starring all women completely misses the mark of embracing strong powerful independent women.
With the focus on odd and again, obvious twists and turns there wasn't enough time to sit back and watch two of the greatest actors of our time.
It should have been a comedic version of Quantum Leap or Sixth Sense, but instead we get a boring, unbelievable potential romance between Gervais and Leoni.

Sex, choking, the Messiah ... It doesn't have the impact you'd think with those things as the key subjects. It should have gone darker, otherwise Choke just runs out of breath.

The humor is based on a transsexual and killing a dog. That's not enough, especially when there was all of Celebridum to make fun of.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It will (and should) make some people uncomfortable, but more importantly it's a unique film experience and that is something difficult to pull off.
I haven't made a list, but this has to be one of the best high school/coming-of-age/romantic/comedy films of the past decade.

I wanted to be left bawling like a little baby, this story has that potential. But when Ben gets distracted with Emily, so does the entire film. We almost forget Ben is on a focused (albeit depressed) journey.
It's a flat, lifeless story with a flat, lifeless lead. Humans are flawed, humans are beautiful, the Earth is dying ... it really feels like we've been here before.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

This is really about a man who gave his life to a movement. Everyone knows about the tragic end of JFK and MLK. More people need to know Harvey Milk's story.
If for some reason you hate the song, 'Somewhere Over the Rainbow' you must avoid this film. Otherwise, it's a crowd pleaser, especially the fairytale-like first half

The bleached blond hair, the self-tanning and the hearing aid all create one of the most memorable characters of the year. Plus, there is a surprising amount of subtle humor.

movie_review_blurb: A little too long, way too many characters and a pretty good ending sums up Ritchie's latest bombastic ode to the ugly side of London.
The real reason to see the film though? Craig Robinson as Delaney. He's good in 'The Office,' he's great here.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, Sally Hawkins does an amazing job, but she also plays a type of person that the majority of us can't stand. It's beyond Poppy's positive outlook.
It's always good, never great. Then we're suddenly forced to remember this is all (potentially) real and not just a Shakespearean play about a kid with a daddy complex.
It goes a hint beyond average. With that said, I can't wait for the next, because it appears they have finally shed the revenge and we can see what else our Blond Bond can do with the famous role.
I said the first film is a teenage boy's wet dream. This sequel is just masturbation.
I love Michael Cera, just not this time.
Public Enemies isn't my No. 1 of the year, but it's close. Even more powerful than Depp is the way Mann controls this film's look and feel.
Feels like we're watching Mr. Rogers run a country. Freeman's Mandela smiles politely and wants everyone to be his neighbor. While that may be real, Eastwood never makes it seem interesting
This movie feels exactly like watching your friend play the greatest video game ever. It looks pretty, but eventually gets boring.
Hugh Grant and Carrie Bradshaw (yeah, I know) go to the woods. It's by the numbers, harmless and almost without charm.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Jason Reitman may just have the greatest, albeit mainstream, start any director has ever known. It's another crowd-pleasing, great film.
It's complicated. Oh wait, no it's not. This film is a classic example of rich people's problems.
Waking up hurts. Most of us have been there before. Firth is used to playing the reserved, slightly nerdy characters who don't quite fit in, but now he's also given an extreme weight to carry.
Director Rob Marshall knows how to put on a show, but that's just it. It's only a show. This film is all about the individual performances.
Sherlock Holmes is back. I wish I could say this is the thrill ride of the season. But it's just--a ride of the season.
An old man screams at Anna and Declan to kiss over and over again. It feels like something that should be against the law instead of endearing.
Ideally, Ledger's Joker from The Dark Knight would have been his last performance. Once again Gilliam has made a movie probably only he can truly understand or find very interesting.
This is Blunt's chance to follow in the footsteps of Gwenyth Paltrow, Anne Hathaway and Keira Knightley in becoming a leading lady in a period piece.
It's like they tried to accomplish everything, but ended up forgetting to have a purpose.
Without a second viewing I'm actually not sure if talking about it will simply drive me nuts or impress me more. I'm leaning toward nuts.
There is no one I would rather have play an overweight drunk. Bridges nails it.
This is a powerful war film that never needs to enter the battlefield for you to be fully absorbed.
Out of the 8 characters that could save the world, I wished 7 would just die and get the apocalypse over with.
This is a made for TV movie. This is also the best made for TV movie I have seen in recent memory. Plus, Portland looks great.
I'm as shocked as you are, but 'Dear John' isn't awful, until a plot twist makes you simply stop caring.
You're going to like half of the fluff, but it's ultimately very forgettable.
It is great to be in Scorsese's hands after almost two months of average films.
Watching Ronald McDonald shoot up a city is just one of the thrills in this year's Oscar nominated shorts.
This is Kevin Smith's laziest effort. Instead of an homage, he just made a bad buddy cop flick.
Lower your expectations, because Tim Burton has created a great canvas, just not a great film.
Crispin Glover steals the show in a movie with good self-awareness, and enough laughs to make the price of admission worthwhile.
It seems we're stuck in the middle with Miley. She's not ready to be a dramatic lead, and her core audience will be bored with this typical Sparks story.
After a slow start, this becomes a really good adventure flick. There aren't many laughs, but the father-son, and son-dragon relationship will appeal to everyone.
Three average action sequences aren't enough to save this film from the weak story and bad dialogue. At least 'release the kraken' is my favorite new euphemism.
A terrible plot can't stop Carell and Fey from being my new favorite fake married couple. I demand they rejoin forces on the big screen at least every two years.
With comedians Chris Rock, Martin Lawrence and Tracy Morgan on board, it's surprising they give the best moments to James Marsden.
Sure it's a bad film, but what makes it worse is the ending, which is the worst of the year.
There are 15 magical minutes where you are laughing with the movie. Otherwise, you're laughing at.
Everybody's fine. So is this movie. Fine and forgettable.
So we've got a paper cut and a phone call, and a romance that never feels as big as the movie tries to make it seem.
We're stuck on the ledge, waiting to see if Paul will jump. Painful, but good.
Borat feels like a story, Brüno comes off more as sketches, very funny sketches. It's like an R-rated Daily Show.
This is the worst version of Can't Hardly Wait imaginable. Denis shouldn't hang out with Beth. Beth shouldn't give Denis the time of day.
Sure we don't have much time for Hagrid, Tom Riddle's memories, or a Half-Blood Prince, but it's not so bad because we have teenagers in love. That only sounds condescending, I swear.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: They really try to entertain with split cameras, a great narrator's voice, songs and a classic rainy night moment. This is a great film about how you remember a relationship.
Sandler has great self-awareness and lets us laugh with him, at him and on occasion feel for a rich, spoiled superstar.
Hugh Dancy carries this movie on his back, otherwise it could have easily ended up on the Lifetime channel.
This is my favorite bad movie of the summer. And yes, I realize that's a backhanded compliment. Yo Joe.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a really solid date movie that should give everyone a little something of what they are looking for.
Away We Go should get it's due when they are handing out awards at the end of the year. I loved it. And now I'm ready to have babies. Wife, you reading this?
It's an original idea that loses its way, or simply becomes an action flick, your choice.
The only thing that works in this film is Zach Gilford, otherwise it feels like a bad mashup of two screenplays, with a terrible life lesson.
Tension, twists, humor, and it's constant. This is the best adult 'Once Upon a Time' I can think of.
It's a small story about Woodstock. I didn't think that was possible. Lee's got the look down, but the story doesn't totally captivate, and the music is almost not present.
It fails at everything it attempts to do. There's simply no point for it to exist.
Funny and painful. And no, I don't mean painfully funny. Watching a man make poor decision after poor decision is always a tough sell for a comedy, but this one gets it right.

Adult comedy normally means sex, drugs and lots of F-bombs. Not this time around. Sure, we might not bust a gut like Damon did getting ready for the role, but there should always be a smile on your face.
Wondering what it would be like if Juno never got pregnant and two awkward high school kids fall in love, but then you combine that with a best friend demon who eats guys?
Train wreck. Car wreck. Plane wreck. Boat wreck. Please tell me you've picked up on the common theme here people.
Psychic spies. Jedi warriors. Clooney delivers big time, but the story could have been better.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's no heart, and I don't put it simply on the visuals that almost look real at times. Amazing 3D is the only thing this dark version does really well.
It's a sob story. Precious consumes you completely. Her narration is simple, sometimes broken, and gives you a glimpse of an absolutely awful life. It's a tough sell, but a good movie.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Ensembles are tough, but I now feel safer in Richard Kurtis' hands than any other director, especially when he brings along a pile of British talent.
This is a dramatic, slow moving Mad Max with a kid along for the awful ride. It's a survival tale, and The Road should be seen for those who want to keep carrying the fire.
If you want to see Larry David limp around and see his view of 'the glass is probably covered with diseases so who cares if it's half empty or half full,' then go along for this ride.
We all want Big Mike to be saved from the life so many are stuck with. I'm simply shocked Bullock was up to the task of doing the saving. Yes, it appears I was blindsided.

If you like ghost stories you're going to want to get in line and hold on (to whoever is sitting next to you). Each night brings a new kind of chill to the mix. Just thinking of 'Night 20' makes me nervous all over again.
It's not a kid's movie. It's not a movie for kids. It's a movie made from the mindset of a child, and it's a job well done.
Simply rent Silence of the Lambs and Falling Down, then mash them together and maybe you'll have what this movie was trying to achieve. Maybe.
I wasn't entertained, I just wanted out of the supposed cold.
'Love Happens' actually uses a slow clap in a serious way to bring this movie home.
I'm not going to talk about the twist that happens 40 minutes into the film. You can probably find other critics who will try and kill the twist for you, but not me.
Wes Anderson can tell a tale, and now he has proved a family can appreciate him as well.
The camera techniques used actually give the audience just a hint of what it must be like to live with a fully aware mind, and one working eye.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Moore's mere presence becomes politicizing, but this film attempts to make people realize the health of people in this country should have nothing to do with income and politics.
The entire film has three repetitive jokes: Dewey cut his brother in half, Dewey can't smell, and he's going to take drugs. So it's kind of amazing how well the film works.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cell phones, the Internet, '80s fashion and '70s style are all thrown together for a winning combination.
Don't get me wrong, I love these films. But they really are just mindless action movies -- just done INCREDIBLY well.
The film is formulaic and the plot is barely connected together. But it moves along quickly and there's the occasional smile.
There was just enough connection between Claire Danes and Charlie Cox that happily ever after is exactly what I wanted.
Treat yourself to the Donald Sutherland version, plus, his perm is more frightening than anything that happens in Invasion.
Even though the melodrama gets ratcheted up at the end, there were plenty of moments I found myself cheering for the Champ.
First off, you have to like complainers, otherwise Adam Goldberg will drive you nuts.
Comedians like Will Ferrell, Jack Black and Ben Stiller can get away with lesser material because just looking at them can elicit laughs. Dan Fogler is not in that category.
When the score (from the original) is the best part of this retelling, perhaps it's best we don't celebrate Halloween this year.
...painfully uncool one-liners, a flat performance from Clive Owen, a disgusting job by Paul Giamatti and a plot that reveals itself to be idiotic.
Christian Bale had me in the first few seconds when he started limping toward the window
we're stuck with Amy Poehler telling us she's an alcoholic and an unaware Susan Sarandon watching two men act like idiots, which unfortunately isn't funny at all.
It's a quality film, but all the truly emotional moments come from watching and listening to the soldiers, which doesn't really happen until the very end.
The switch is flipped so quickly by Erica that I didn't root for her vengeance, I felt sorry for her.
We barely get a line from Mr. Burns, Moe, Lou and the rest of the bunch, but following Homer J. Simpson is not a bad way to spend an hour and a half of your summer.
This is my favorite David Cronenberg film to date.
Sydney helps a group of geeks with the most mundane tasks, such as tying shoes, and waking up and there isn't one ounce of believability in the journey.
Apparently someone out there thought it would be a good idea to capitalize on American's love for penguins AND gross-out comedies.
The majority of the film is filled with arguing, betrayal and fear with a twinge of hope.
This is a brilliant, personal film.
...Jamie Foxx leading his team of experts into uncharted territory, which then leads to the longest, best action sequence of the year.
Even though the film looks beautiful there are things that rubbed me the wrong way.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The technical prowess of Wes Anderson is still top-notch, with the best example being the train showcasing all of the characters at the end.
A killer voice-over by Tom Wilkinson sets the tone for this dramatic thriller, and you're willing to go on the journey even if you don't understand it all the time.
Betrayal, war, love triangles and most importantly, Cate Blanchett proves to be able to capture strength, anger and sadness better...
It's a roller coaster, mainly because a good scene is typically followed by a bad one. For every thrill, there is a melodramatic moment that just doesn't work.
I was done when there was a needless scene abusing a woman. And the ending was on the verge of interesting, until it came down to one little punch.
Ben Affleck creates an authentic tone for the city of Boston, and then he gets great performances out of Casey Affleck, Ed Harris and the rest of the cast.
It attempts to take a Three's A Company situation and mix it together with a widower trying to raise three children. This is not cool.
It feels familiar, even Washington's performance of real-life Frank Lucas feels like something we've seen before.
The most intriguing parts of this film are contained in the voice-over montage in the beginning and a surprise ending, leaving a lot of filler in the middle.
Catherine Zeta-Jones controls the kitchen, but can't control my attention.
The film works best for me when they are making fun of the racial climate of the 1960s.
They could have focused more on the similarities of best friends and a gay couple. Instead, they just try to offend everyone in sight and then act sorry at the end.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Jim Carrey tries his best, but the film never gets psychologically creepy, never makes the viewer question what is fiction, what is reality, and most importantly what the number 23 is all about.
I can only assume a bike wreck is much more gruesome than a car accident. Luckily, I have never seen one, but after watching Wild Hogs, I can imagine.
The look and feel of this historic battle is perfect for the virtual backgrounds and obscene violence. Again, trust me on the violence.
Maybe because it focused on swimming, and didn't really capture the drama of the sport, it came off like a TV movie. It even borrowed from Dead Poets Society with an 'Oh Captain, My Captain' moment.
The main problem is Reign Over Me always skirts around the issue instead of tackling it head on. Depression and loss are hell, and hopefully friends can be there to bring you out of it.
It was a great decision to animate this feature film. The great decisions end there. Unfortunately, TMNT doesn't spend nearly enough time having fun.
Blades of Glory doesn't get the gold, in fact, I think they just miss out on the bronze.
A baby being left on the doorstep of an orphanage has been done many times, yet Meet the Robinsons makes it feel new again, and not just because of the fantastic 3-D technology.
In the beginning, the film had me with an absolutely amazing intro song. I was dying laughing, but after that ran out, I was just dying.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It jumps from typical action one-liners to political discussions about Abu Ghraib. I mean, you can't have a character named Swagger and expect me to take you seriously.
Disturbia takes it's time setting up the thrills and Shia LaBeouf actually acts like a high schooler.
As soon as it's over, you start forgetting about it. It's not a bad movie, it's just fine.
Director Mike White is really good at creating an uneasy feeling in a normal setting. But the question remains, do you want him to?
The film even attempts to make moral judgments about how watching a fight to the death is wrong, which ends up alienating anybody that sat their butt down in the theater in the first place.
Since Lucky You overdid the poker cliches to death, let me end with one of my favorites: 'You got to know when to hold'em, know when to fold'em.' It seems this film never learned that lesson.
The infected just seem to bite, spit blood, scream and repeat a little too much.
It should be good. It's got a well-known, talented cast from top to bottom and the subject of ex-boyfriends is limitless. Instead it has the feel of a straight-to-DVD failure.
There's a nagging feeling of dad trying to rush the family on a vacation. If you hurry this much, you're bound to miss something and that keeps the Potter films away from greatness.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As someone engaged, I felt they disrespected what marriage can and should mean. And most importantly, I'm offended at their attempt at cringe-worthy humor.
One of the best and simplest ideas for a film in a long time. It's too bad the ending doesn't compare with the rest of the film, but still a good time.
Most of the discussions of food come off like an animated Frasier episode, which shouldn't have broad enough appeal.
I was actually nervous with all the gunfire and near misses. But then it kept happening over and over again. So instead of being involved, I studied the action sequences.
Angelina Jolie continues to prove her acting is worth more discussion than her personal life. It's not always fun to watch, but it's an important piece of work.
I can't believe I'm going to say it, but this film is as busy as a bee.
This movie isn't about logic, faith or family, and doesn't have many laughs except when baboons carry things -- that's always funny. It's just mindless summer popcorn.
I think a character like Nancy Drew can still work in today's pop culture world, but unfortunately the film doesn't believe in her enough.
These actors have the characters they play down pat, and as long as they come up with some reason to pull off a heist, I'll be watching.
I was prepared to bash another penguin movie for hopping on the bandwagon, but this one adds enough for me to put those worries to rest.
There is always something to smile about and identify with. If you're a slacker, condescending or extremely hormonal this film has someone for you to worship.
Both sequels to the original film are confusing and long. But the third does improve on the second, because at least something happens.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The problem with this film is that after a quick, fun beginning they repeat a similar journey from the first film. Except this time, Shrek and Artie argue instead of Shrek and Fiona.
When Jessica Alba was at the MTV Movie Awards she called Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer the best family/comedy of the summer. That alone should spell disaster for a superhero film.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Having the talent of Laura Linney and Philip Seymour Hoffman isn't enough.
It attempts to conquer social, political and military all in the same film, but it doesn't knock any of them out of the park.
The problem comes when we realize it's a Tommy Lee Jones film and the title is more than just a random coincidence. It's a really good film that was almost great.
Will Smith shows some promise trying to find a cure for a horrific virus, but somehow the plot becomes Shrek, Bob Marley and God trying to save the world.
It captures pure terror. It's horrific. That's horror plus terrific. It's almost impossible for a film like this to be lumped into the same category as...
If Day-Lewis isn't front and center, the film drags with themes such as oil vs. religion, and greed is always around...
It's the closest a film has ever gotten to a roller-coaster ride. It will definitely nauseate, it feels claustrophobic, there are sudden scares, and it also peaks too early.
This is Colin Farrell's best work in years and proof that Woody Allen is an old dog, and these are new tricks.
There are only a few moments that feel genuine and allow Katherine Heigel to smile. 27 Dresses is chock-full of cheese and eventually runs out of material.
For all the unnatural setup, it's amazing that the performances come off so naturally.
Charlie Bartlett is a poor man's Rushmore. There is a great film waiting to be made about psychiatry, anti-depressants and our youth, but this isn't it.
Period comedies are a tough act to swallow for some, but if you are on the fence at all, please make sure Miss Pettigrew lives for more than just one day."
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It isn't bad, but it can't find a rhythm between being based on a true, ugly story and trying to be a fun bank heist film.
Here's what I hoped for: someone to root for, someone to root against, an inspiring coach, some eye candy and, of course, training montages. I got what I wanted.
It has some decent eye candy, but overall this film is bluffing if they think it's a great, intelligent blackjack film. I know I just used a poker term, but I doubt 21 would have noticed.
The film does stand on it's own two feet, thanks mainly to Norton who should have demanded having Banner run a little more, and Hulk smash a little less.
It's a great idea. A silent, unknown killing machine knocking people off while a science teacher tries to figure out why. But it just didn't work.
You do get to see Ferrell's ball sack, which might be a draw for some, but otherwise it's a mess. Ferrell and Reilly bicker and it should be better.
I am still comfortable believing Myers is a comic genius, but it's no where to be seen here.
Simply put, this film is borrowed/created from Fight Club and The Matrix. It's a poor man's, but it's not that far off from those great films.
Will Smith, Fourth of July, superhero. It all seems to add up to a great combination. But they only made half a film.
I wanted more unearthed footage. But if you are looking for a tribute to the man, you won't find anything better.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you can turn off your mind, and I know that is pretty easy for most of us, then you'll get a kick out of this 3D journey.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Hellboy is it's own world. That is a compliment and also the problem. Director Guillermo del Toro has envisioned a fantastic looking world, but it's just a vision.
This is entertainment, not a movie. And as entertainment goes, Mamma Mia! belts it out of the park.
I say this with a smile from ear to ear, there is too much of a good thing. The Dark Knight is the best adult superhero film of all time.
Zodiac does a great job of showing three different paths (reporter, cop, cartoonist) in trying to capture a serial killer.
This is a movie theater experience. It needs to be seen at night, with a big screen and lots of friends.
The makers of Shaun of the Dead have done it again. This time they have combined a classic cop-buddy movie with a quaint town in England, and yes, laughs definitely ensue.

It is like a buffet. You look at the cast and trailers and you just start drooling over all the options. But they just overdid it, stuffing you with filler, and the juicy part of the film didn't start until it was halfway through.
It is a teenage boy's wet dream. The girls are insanely hot, the lead is awkward/funny and the action sequences are top notch.
The comic-duo of Jonah Hill and Michael Cera reminded me of an immature, foul-mouthed Laurel & Hardy.
Right from the beginning when Juno is chugging away on Sunny D, we want to see watch she will say and do next.
Saving the world became secondary to the power of holding hands. There is an amazing amount of life and humanity throughout and a quality message to boot.
X-Files: I Want to Believe %u2014 it's almost like a mantra that Chris Carter is trying to get the audience to hear. Say it enough times and they will believe. Well, that's not the case.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If your perfect weekend is Nascar and country music, with barely any political discussion, then this is your cup of tea ... I mean bottle of beer.

Dear fictional character Rick O'Connell, you can't roll your eyes about a magic knife being the only thing to kill a raised-from-the-dead emperor if you've already lived through two other unreal adventures.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: I laughed out loud once, yet I am giving this film a positive review. There's something magical about a G-rated film that attempts to capture life, death and a little bit of magic.
This is not the future of films, but it is a future, especially for the action genre.
Director Todd Haynes takes an artistic leap, I just don't want to catch all of the finished product.
Noah Baumbach is the king of dysfunction. We constantly see films about war, love, aliens, so why no films about how insanely uncomfortable family can be with one another?
It has a chance to be a real crowd pleaser, but unfortunately it zeros in on its core audience, which is 8- to 12-year-old girls
Sam Elliott shows up as a cowboy, who would normally be a pick-me-up, but with Golden Compass I just wanted to find my direction home.
...This leads to one of the best romances of the year. The problem comes when an older Briony attempts to atone for her misdeeds.
There is a chance I have simply outgrown Alvin, Simon and Theodore. But I can still recognize a quality film and this isn't it.
This isn't so much a film about picking up the pieces after a tragedy, but instead an extended story of the pieces that fell...
The two young boys are definitely the highlight of the film. Their friendship is truly felt, which makes the tragedy that befalls Hassan all the more powerful.
The difference here is that film audiences are used to blood. So some of the chilling effect is lost...
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The dialogue zings and pops whether you are trying to keep up with Hanks and Hoffman as they exchange one-liners or trying to fully understand the foreign affairs...
If you desperately need to escape the house this holiday season, avoid this treasure and see something else.
It was Irish overkill. There didn't seem to be a chronological plan with the letters, so poor Holly is just forced to sit and wait to hear from her dead husband.
This is the perfect example of what can happen when a producer/director/writer doesn't have to answer to anyone. Coppola makes an artistic mess.
Showcasing the history is done with care and purpose, but I wanted more. I wanted more time between Washington and Forest Whitaker. I wanted more...
At one point Morgan Freeman's character shouts, 'This was supposed to be fun.' I couldn't agree more.
Pineapple Express is a mess, but a wonderful one. It's not the ultimate movie about pot that I was expecting, instead it's a great ordinary-man action movie.
Burstein's goal was to film an authentic senior year of high school. Instead she showed that it's almost an impossibility.
Tropic Thunder is the biggest comedy of the year. It's also the funniest ... attack humor at it's best.
It's is like that bottle of wine that makes you feel like you paid too much for what you got.
If you're stuck, In Bruges doesn't seem to be a bad place to be.
Anna Faris might just be the lightest comedic heavyweight.
Unfortunately, this is a broad family comedy that depends on odd sound effects (zonks! splat!) during every scene...
Cars, babes and guns. Stop, that's enough to entertain. It should have been an overly violent, comical Mario Kart. This is not a remake, this is a title take.
There are definitely enough moments where you are shocked into laughter that allow this sequel to be, as opposed to not being at all.
They have billed Star Wars: The Clone Wars as the untold story. If only the untelling of the told could now be done.
This ensemble piece works if you know Los Angeles. After all, it's very possible for a homeless kid, pot-smoking Realtor, young model and a number of perverts to cross paths in that town.
There isn't an enjoyable character in the bunch of this tragedy that constantly spirals downward.
It is supposed to be a raucous ride of laughter, but it's thin on one important aspect: the jokes.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Comedy is difficult, but it seems like Mad Money didn't even try. It's very hard to find the jokes.
The pratfalls and naked jokes don't eek out enough humor, and Wilson's Fish never becomes someone you can truly root for.
Should I be having this much fun watching an 11-year-old destroy her competition? You know what, I think the answer is yes.
Is there anything more stereo-typical than straight guys locked in a mutual dare? Well, here the stakes couldn't be higher, or funnier.
We all know Freddy Krueger (whether we've seen this franchise or not) so we're miles ahead of these static teenage characters, and just waited for them to catch up.
It's absolutely average. That's not exactly what you are looking for when your subject is about a man on a ledge.
It's such an extraordinary true story and 'Red Tails' turns it into something extra ordinary (in other words, really really ordinary).
When I was twelve, I remember thinking, hoping and praying for the trapped whales. 'Big Miracle' does just enough to bring those feelings back.
The found footage element keeps geting in the way of a good teenage superhero film.
Back and forth. Back and forth. There's not much plot for Daniel Radcliffe, so he tip-toes around looking for scares that don't add up.
The best film of 2012. Too soon? Yeah, you're right. But this film is more than just Neeson killing wolves.
It's a fantastic minimalist action film where you actually get to see what is happening.
Any sign of cutting-edge 3D effects are gone in this sequel. Now we just have Dwayne Johnson pec popping, and squabbling with Michael Caine in this forgettable adventure.
It really feels like Denzel Washington owns the place and Ryan Reynolds holds his own. Plus, the action is like a Bourne little brother.
A documentary OR an action/drama honoring the missions of our Navy SEALs could have been good. But instead of OR, they tried AND. It fails.
The only thing worthwhile is seeing Portland (the filming location) on the big screen. It proves this landscape would be good for a thriller/horror, just not this one.
They barely care about the story, but there's enough funny people involved to make 'Wanderlust' worthwhile.
If they would have just had more crazy Cage, and a faster 'Crank'-style film, it could have worked.
The more I think about this film, the more upset I get.
Arthur may not be perfect, but he cares. The same can be said for the film. 'Arthur Christmas' is full of just enough holiday cheer.
I don't think you'll feel 'happily ever after' when the film ends, but you'll be pleased enough by its magic.
I'm as surprised as you that this film could end up being the funniest of 2012.
Mindless fun isn't exactly what I was hoping for with 'The Lorax,' but that's what you get.
The party won't stop, even though you want it to.
I understand John Carter likes being on Mars (superpowers + hot, intelligent princess). I just don't want to be there with him.
After three months of films in 2012, 'Friends with Kids' is the best.
It feels weird to say, 'I liked it,' but I know deep down, in places that feel uncomfortable, I loved it.
It's like this film almost sneaks up on you as you're watching it. At first it's just quirky/cute, but it becomes much more. Mark Duplass gives his best performance.
This is the most fun I have ever had watching a horror film.
Will Ferrell took a chance with this one, and I'm glad he did. It's played 90 percent straight, and that other 10 percent is odd and hilarious.
I liked everything about this film except for the ending. I loved that part.
I wonder what 2012 film will have the sixth best action sequence. 'The Raid' will own the top five spots in a landslide. What a great action flick.
A really fun date movie until every couple has to break up and try to get back together.
This film feels like a quality straight to DVD flick. 'The Three Stooges' is not as painful as I thought it would be.
Efron's kind of handsome is more pretty than rugged. Don't worry. The geniuses behind 'The Lucky One' know how to solve that problem. He's got scruff.
I didn't read the book. While the film is entertaining enough, I never felt drawn in to this new world.
Wow. This is now my favorite film of 2011. It is beautiful to look at and a great nod to the nostalgia of cinema from a true master.
I loved watching George Clooney's character interact with everyone. I didn't care about the finished result, just the process.
Growing up, I loved the Muppets. This film is a great chance for a new generation to fall for them as well.
It's an adult movie that will make you not want to touch any adults when it's over.
'Higher Ground' proves faith can be on display in a film, but that doesn't automatically mean it's worth watching.
It's a nice way to say goodbye to the summer of R-rated comedies.
I don't know how she does it. Wait, yes I do. I just don't care.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's rare to feel such a unique tone with such an ordinary idea. Gosling, Brooks and 'A Real Hero' all shine in this great film.
There is heart here, but that's only during the closing credits when we see a glimpse of the true story.
Immediately one of my favorite baseball films, as well as one of my favorite Pitt performances. Only time will tell if I can delete 'one of' from those sentences.
Watching this movie feels like sitting next to a kid, and watching him play a video game, knowing it will never be your turn to have fun.
It's one of the better films you'll see this year even if you won't necessarily like what you'll see from these characters who are trying to run our country.
Life is hard. Cancer is hard. Relationships are hard. Family is hard. '50/50' managed to find the power in all of those things and give us plenty of laughs so we're not simply in a ball crying.
If anything, it feels like 'What's Your Number?' is the worst version of what 'Bridesmaids' could have been. It just doesn't heart, and every joke feels completely forced and obvious.
'Dream House' attempts to answer a question no one was asking. How long can a twist ending last? After the reveal, it's just a weird waste of time.
Perhaps in the hands other another director, this film about obsessive birders would have felt truly obsessive. Instead, it's simply nice.
It's a requel (prequel + remake). Same pattern, different characters. Unfortunately, it doesn't do anything better than John Carpenter's vision.
Eventually when the action ending shows up, I thought, "I could play that video game." Otherwise, 'Immortals' is a waste.
One of the last lines by Al Pacino in the film is, "Burn this." I agree.
It falls short of 'Rango,' 'Kung Fu Panda 2' and 'Winnie the Pooh,' but not by a lot. It's fast, entertaining, and funny.
Whatever momentum the third film had in this series, it's gone. Once again, it's an average soap opera.
Ugh. Nothing makes sense, it's not funny and the 3D is worthless.
Even though the film unravels, the performances by Michael Shannon and Jessica Chastain make this film worth it.
The protection of the individual at the sake of our society always kills me. But, what are you going to do? Throw money at it. No really, throw some money at 'Margin Call,' it's worth it.
There are colorful moments in 'The Rum Diary,' but they don't jell together. It feels more like a 1st episode than a movie.
It didn't have me rethinking history, but for those two hours, it was entertaining enough. I don't know if that will be enough for Emmerich and this "What if?"
This is the driest comedy farce in all the land. It fits very nicely in Stillman's catalog.
It is not pure joy, but instead authentic young love in a difficult situation. It's definitely worth seeing.
It's like an art-house 'Human Centipede.' While it hints at some interesting ideas, it just comes down to a crazy doctor.
While there are some interesting visuals, the lack of story and emotion doom this film.
Yes, it feels familiar, but they keep finding a way to make me nervous/scared.
Thank goodness for NPH. His appearance wakes up the film and makes things fun for a while.
Performances by DiCaprio, Hammer and Dench make this Eastwood film worth your two-plus hours.
It is like a less funny 'Office Space' with bigger stakes. The fun becomes a little ordinary, but the likeability of the cast keeps it entertaining.
This is a quality creepy drama. There is power in the subject, and absolute power in the performances of Olsen and Hawkes.
'Warrior' makes you cheer, sweat, laugh and in a completely shocking twist, cry just a little bit.
This proves we don't need a remake of 'Slap Shot.' Funny and violent, 'Goon' is a very good sports movie.
The wacky comedy is not enough to enjoy watching this crumbling relationship. I finally feel the Apatow length.
The story within a story, which is kind of within another story, but really about ALL of the stories isn't something that is worth your time.
This film captures some of the greatest images you'll see on the big screen this year.
Rockwell and Walken are at their best in this violent tale. What more could you possibly want?
Unfortunately, this franchise has finally seemed to run its course. There are less quality scares, and now a story that almost doesn't matter.
Are we sure this isn't a TV pilot that accidentally ended up on the big screen?
As the saying goes, you've got to shake 22 Bond films, before the 23rd is stirred to perfection. Without a doubt, this is the best James Bond movie.
As a new father you can fully trust me when I say things like 'Wreck-It Ralph' is fun for the whole family, even though my family won't find that out for another five years.
With 'Cloud Atlas' you'll play connect the dots, and potentially feel like a kid, remembering what it is like to be amazed at what you are seeing on the big screen.
It's always odd walking away from an average film, realizing there are plenty of flaws, and still kind of liking it. That's the case with 'Chasing Mavericks.'
I rolled my eyes, laughed at, and laughed with this film. I was entertained. It's a sloppy enjoyable mess, and the most fun I had watching a 'Twilight' movie.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While Spielberg captures a time, Day-Lewis captures another brilliant performance, and some of the supporting actors may capture Oscar nominations, the film didn't capture my soul the way I was hoping.
While this might not be what we expect from a film about The Master of Suspense, it's oddly a fun romp, with Helen Mirren eventually stealing the show.
The completely obvious comparison to the mobster world and our American economic system is a welcome, straight-forward surprise for storytelling.
Arnold Schwarzenegger gets knocked down, and slowly gets back up again in a film that is a rental at best.
Mike Birbiglia showcases the mindset of a comedian trying to find his voice, and the film has a surprising amount of heart.
The whole film is mild until the end. You won't believe it, but it's also not worth believing.
While the idea of giving fairy tale stars Hansel and Gretel the R-rated bloody adult treatment sounds like a good idea to me, it turns out it's only good in theory.
Dwayne 'The Rock' Johnson isn't an 'ordinary man.' That's why he has a nickname and looks like a real-life superhero. That's just one problem with this film.
This film has everything you want out of an epic adventure, even though you've seem almost all of it before.
Better than 'Project X' and 'The Hangover Part II,' worse than 'The Hangover' and 'Superbad.' So yeah, it's average.
It's the funniest superhero film, and it doesn't feel like it's pandering. That's the power of Downey, Jr. and now Shane Black.
It's definitely a fun action movie, but I'm ready for these films to boldly go in their own direction, instead of hanging on to the originals.
Perhaps we were wrong to complain about the repetitive nature of 'The Hangover Part II.' At least there were funny moments. This is a slow action film, with only a few amusing parts.
While it gives you your fix, it doesn't put Superman back on top of our cinematic superheroes.
While it's nothing ground-breaking, 'Monsters University' is really, really nice once it gets past the idea of Mike and Sully being at odds.
The 'Before' trilogy is a vacation for me. I am taken away, and it is never for long enough. I genuinely feel lucky to have these movies.
I would happily watch it again, which is something I rarely say about horror films.
Because of his brilliant standup comedy, I find myself rooting for Hart. I hope he will have the chance to star in a film that is worthy of him. 'Ride Along' isn't that opportunity.
I am completely fine with Pine giving us more Jack Ryan in the future. Hopefully they can find a new script or go back to one of the Tom Clancy novels for an interesting story.
Almost everything is bland pregnancy humor that's been done to death in other films. I don't know why this movie exists.
On paper it's a good comedic pairing, but that's it. About 45 minutes into the film, I realized I was trying to laugh, instead of the film making me laugh.
While definitely odd, I'm surprised about the lack of magic, heart-warming feelings in this film.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The drama becomes engulfed by too much 'melo' during Sister's story. You're better off listening on your own to the fantastic Motown sounds the film is based on.
The look of the film is great, and the anti-bullying message works. This would be a fantastic introduction to scary movies for the kids.
They want it to be 'Seven' meets 'Sherlock Holmes' and you can tell Cusack is into it. Unfortunately the plot is ridiculous and the murder-mystery is boring.
It's a blockbuster that manages to please with intelligence and fun. Whedon makes it look easy.
It's filled with moments that don't really matter, especially when dealing with the fishing business.
This is Anderson being Anderson. I'm quite happy with that. It's realistic imagination overload.
When you have the chance to see this film in August, pull the damn trigger.
Is vomit ever a good thing? 'Madagascar 3: Europe's Most Wanted' is cinematic vomit, and that's a compliment.
Jane Fonda's hippy offers nothing but a chance for Catherine Keener's uptight New Yorker to bicker with. What a flat film.
'Prometheus' could be starting something great. While it looks amazing, the jury is out on whether it ends up reminding me of 'The Matrix Reloaded' more than anything else.
It's an odd epic that has moments, but nothing that will stand the test of time.
After an amusing start, this film seems to forget it's a pot comedy.
It doesn't expose stupidity. That's what Cohen has done absolutely wonderfully in the past with his other characters. Now he's just acting stupid, with only some funny results.
That dazzling red hair outshines any story that 'Brave' attempts to tell.
We've seen Carell be mopey before. In fact, I say we declare him King of the Mopes!
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's small, but not simple. There are three shocking dramatic twists that feel completely earned.
While it feels a little messy, they get enough things right (like Garfield's Peter Parker).
One of the best performances by a child actor, in a movie that feels wonderfully created by that child.
Everything is supposed to be a farce, but it plays out like a boring drama. This film makes 'Midnight in Paris' all the more impressive.
It's better than the first, mainly due to the over-the-top beginning and end. That middle hour takes a while.
Pointless 3D, and with the way the story was told, there were no surprises. It does however feature the most horrific suicide I've watched on film.
This is a drama (not comedy) that is probably the most honest portrayal of therapy on film. If you are old, see this movie.

Getting a few chuckles and one or two laugh out loud moments is not enough, especially when Ferrell and Galifianakis could make fun of our actual political system, instead of this truly fictitious one.
Whether you call this a reboot, extension, evolution or a spin-off, I'm thrilled with where this franchise can go.
Who knew dance could save Miami? Beyond the dancing (which is good), the story seems created for a 5th grader.
I wish I could call the plot about a dodo bird 'whimsical,' but there just wasn't enough laughs from these 'Pirates.'
The only thing the cast seemed to care about it trying to make you laugh. It worked for me, especially having a happy Vince Vaughn.
Though this one is better than the first two, this is now my least favorite trilogy.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The look of the sci-fi universe, and good action sequences make up for the near pointless plot.
The belief that one man can become a symbol for something greater will continue to drive people to this trilogy for years to come.
Everything about this film feels like a pretty good reworking of 'The Family Guy.' Unfortunately the last quarter of the film forgets it is a comedy.
It's a good behind-the-scenes film that becomes a little ordinary in the end. Loved Matthew McConaughey, though I'm not convinced he knew the cameras were rolling.
Stone gets down and dirty with some pot and plenty of violence. I had a lot of fun, I just wish Lively's voiceover didn't exist throughout the film.
The degree of difficulty is very high with this uncomfortable comedy. I cringed with laughter throughout.
Paul Rudd screams Portland in a good way, but the annoying sisters take their toll and nearly ruin my Rudd buzz.
Even for those looking for crazy fun, I think they'll be disappointed with how serious, and how much of Lincoln's life is actually included in this mashup.
An insane start, including Morgan Freeman as our narrator, gives way to boredom and standard repetitive action.
It took a bunch of second-string actors too young to get a role in 'The Expendables' and put them in a very average cops and robbers flick.
Silence is golden. Actually, in this case silence is silver, just like Clooney's salt and pepper hair.
This is the best of the romantic comedy genre since '(500) Days of Summer.'
Don't get me wrong, there are moments, but Rodriguez found a way to make extreme violence boring.
The reason to see it: the awesome 3D. The reason not to see it: everything else.
At this point, it looks like it's up to you whether you want to believe or not. Phoenix's trainwreck of a life and the "why" becomes a discussion for another time.
It's a cat and mouse game where we are stuck rooting for the cat even though it killed and raped thousands of mice.
While funny, it spends a lot of the time remembering/imitating great 80's high school flicks and ultimately doesn't live up to them.
It's a good concept with five strangers stuck in an elevator with bad things happening. Unfortunately, the devil is included every step of the way.
Remember when everyone liked Matt Damon AND Ben Affleck? Well, if 'Gone Baby Gone' didn't convince you to get back on the Affleck Express, 'The Town' will.
When the ending feels more like 'Dan in Real Life' you know Oliver Stone and Michael Douglas went wrong somewhere in this sequel.
I know I could tell you to 'accept' or 'like' or 'friend' this movie. Instead, I'm just going to tell you to go see it.
It's not about a horse, it's jockey, or it's trainer. It's about a horse owner. Instead of honoring the greatest race horse ever, they try to find an underdog story with Diane Lane's help.
Our public schools are failing. That's not a shock right? While children are our future, I wanted a little more solutions and inspiration from this documentary.
It's indie-Bateman against Hollywood-Aniston. And for the most part, Bateman wins. It's shocking an idea this absurd can work, but it's funny and charming.
This film quickly moves to the top of the list of 'Most Purposeless Use of 3D' beating out 'The Last Airbender' and 'Clash of the Titans' with ease.
This franchise nails something that most horror films overlook -- the anticipation of the scare.
Damon breathes some life in to this boring film, but he's only in one-third.
I don't get the entertainment of having someone's lower intestines spill on the floor if we're never asked to understand, relate, care or even laugh about the person involved.
This 'based on a true story' delivers the lies our society was forced to gobble up, and showcases two people who were 'right' and right in the middle of it.
It's borrowed and blue. The homage to 'Superman' gets old and the film is only slightly better (and very similar to) 'Despicable Me.' Anything original tends to fall flat.
An idea and cast that should be great doesn't have enough laughs to get through all of the annoyance.
Too many times we're stuck watching fake TV news or other people react to the action, instead of hanging with Washington and Pine.
What IS the story with 'Morning Glory'? No seriously, you need to pick one.
Of all characters, Dobby (at one point the Jar Jar Binks of the Harry Potter World) steals the show.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Crowe proves he can still play an ordinary man and after a slow burn, this film picks up the pace for an insanely exciting finish.
Being stuck with James Franco is well worth it and the film manages to stay hopeful despite the situation.
The Millennium Trilogy follows a similar pattern as The Matrix Trilogy, and that's not a compliment.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: After a slow start, it has just enough Disney charm to entertain the children (of course) as well as the parents.
There's the attempt with some R-rated wacky comedy and also tear inducing sadness. The film doesn't earn either, but the two leads and their lack of clothing make this a passable romantic comedy.
While the action is good, the movie isn't as cool as it thinks. If you replace Bruce Willis with Gene Hackman, then you have a hit on your hands about these 'old' agents.
