It's as if von Trier is incapable of nuance, declaring every action, every thought and thematic observation, with on-the-nose bluntness.

As pretentious and provocative as he is personally invested, von Trier remains an attention-seeking eccentric who might be seeking a kind of agonized attempt at atonement. Or maybe he's once again laughing derisively at his audience and critics.

By the time you emerge from The Raid 2's mind-boggling, show-stopping and utterly exhausting succession of brawls, gun battles, car chases and martial arts showdowns, you'll feel as bruised and battered as Iko Uwais' inexpressive character Rama.

While there are hints of interesting ideas lurking along the narrative's periphery, the implausible leaps in logic, inept plotting and sloppy sense of time and scope defeat any opportunity for impact.
... it's nice to dream, and Jodorwosky certainly offers up a wondrous image of what might have been.
Imagining what if can be fun, especially when you consider the talent and vision the cult director envisioned for Herbert's interstellar epic.
Nick Hornby's novels have produced two terrific examples of the genre: High Fidelity and About A Boy. Unfortunately, this latest adaptation is strictly a minor league affair.
As incredible as the photographs are and as intriguing as Maier's background is, the film left me feeling uneasy about the manner in which her life and work is being exploited.
Walking With the Enemy is one of those cinematic conundrums critics face: encountering a should-be-told story in a should-be-avoided movie.
Equal parts ingenious, muddled, exciting and predictable, Godzilla ultimately seems at war with itself, wanting to deliver thematic substance and artistic wit but beholden to big budget expectations.
Knight's script is taut and tense, ramping up the emotional stress and parceling out details and complications with a surgeon's skill.
...the essential difference between Favreau's low-budget debut Swingers and this back-to-basics passion project is, ironically enough, hunger.

Oh, what could have been. While Disney seems to understand that girl power can mean big box office (see Frozen), they still seem unable to fashion female characters that boast true complexity, agency and independence.
It's the kind of movie where no one behaves like a real person ought to and a lot of the plot doesn't make sense but you can't help but be pulled into its eerie, off-kilter web of menace.

Colorful residents, nifty archival footage and narration by actor Sean Bean, who grew up less than 30 miles from Ashbourne, help provide context for Baxter's energetic exploration of what may be the oldest ongoing sports rivalry on Earth.
Comparisons to Harold Ramis' beloved and profoundly humane Groundhog Day are misguided. Edge of Tomorrow doesn't have a humanistic pixel in its digitally bloated body.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly it's punch-your-face loud.

Majestic in its ability to dwell in silence, this is a film that sticks with you long after the lights come up. And like the work of Ingmar Bergman, it's unafraid to shoulder the full weight of a tragic past on a defiantly uncertain future.
The story doesn't dot every i or cross every t, but it certainly makes every ridiculously sinister turn stick.
It zigs when you expect it to zag.
What makes most of Knocked Up work is its ability to squeeze big laughs out of real-world situations.
Candler's plotting is predictable and her characters should be substantially deepened, but her ability to capture the rage of male adolescence and the numbness of grief is nothing less than superb.
...just as Sabotage settles into any kind of character groove, it devolves into more generic action, more silly shocks and a twist ending that's as anti-climactic as it is nonsensical.

Reeves' deliberately charts a queasy path toward disaster rather than indulging in the moronic fist-pumping kineticism of Michael Bay. When was the last time you saw an action film that inspired a desire for peaceful coexistence?
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Like Gene Hackman in The Royal Tenenbaums, Fiennes seems both in sync and immune to Anderson's fastidious nature. It's a tour-de-force performance that should earn an Oscar nomination but will most likely be overlooked in favor of more sober portrayals.
A moody, atmospheric study in paranoia and tension.

If nothing else, director Jim Mickle should be commended for his subversive attempt to turn his slow-burn cannibal horror flick into a moody meditation on matriarchal power and the uncompromising demands of tradition.

[Redford] brings both physicality and emotion to the role, subtly shifting from anger to surprise to despair. It's a completely naturalistic performance, stripped of ego or artifice, and you often forget you're watching a Hollywood icon.
The odd-couple road movie is well-trod territory, so it's a welcome surprise to see it handled as intelligently, deftly and movingly as it is in Stephen Frears' Philomena.
The 71-year-old Scorsese is in full-on gonzo mode here, giddily leering over every tacky, morally bankrupt act of decadence. But eventually the film's three hours exhaust rather than enlighten.

It's one thing to repurpose a story into something of your own, but to abandon its intent in service of a unrecognizable plot and muddled message leads to the question: Why call it The Secret Life of Walter Mitty at all?
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: If Mud isn't the best movie of this young year, it's certainly the most instantly satisfying.
If you're not moved and angered by what you see in Blackfish, your heart is made of harder stuff than mine.
It glorifies these soldiers, much as Zack Snyder canonized the Spartans in 300, as cartoon symbols of American heroism.

Jonze is reaching for something profoundly sincere with his fourth film, presenting a highly entertaining meditation on love. It seduces you - much like its protagonist is seduced by Johansson's exquisitely smoky voice.
The Hurt Locker is not a conventional approach to wartime heroics but rather a penetrating and harrowing examination of war's unrelenting damage on the human psyche.

While it's obvious he means well - Berg clearly reveres these soldiers - he doesn't seem all that interested in depicting who they were as men. Heck, Die Hard's John McClane was a more fully sketched character than any of these real-life action heroes.
As unapologetically entertaining as Boyle's winking tale about fate is, it brings with it recognition of India's worst social ills.
[The Departed] showcases Scorsese's trademark themes of sin, betrayal and redemption. It's a carefully calibrated and detailed film that takes its time establishing the characters' complex histories.
Instead of being a subversive action flick about the callous indifference of a growing corporate hegemony, it seems like the product of one.

Farhadi not only has a gift for complicated and elegantly crafted human drama, he understands the way people think and feel, the way they make choices and are forced to live with the consequences of those choices.
The Lego Movie's desire to inveigh against social conformity turns into a plea for collectivism. It's a message that will inevitably send the blood pressures of FOX News pundits through the roof.
Composed with all the subtlety of a jack-hammer, this over-narrated fantasy seems incapable of grandeur or magic, reducing its ideas, visuals and performances to kitsch.

On paper, the complications sound like plot points in a melodramatic soap opera. But under Farhadi's direction and in his cast's more-than-capable hands, this knotty family drama never feels false or manipulative.
It's Titanic meets Gladiator, but not as good as either. If you don't have time to read the rest of the review, that should do you just fine.
It's Titanic meets Gladiator but not as good as either. If you don't have time to read the rest of the review, that should do you just fine.
Miyazaki's animation is as exquisitely wondrous as ever. But it's curious that he feels so much for a man who seemed to feel so little.
Cusack and De Niro never quite embarrass themselves, but the material is clearly beneath their talents.
It may not always treat psychology with the sophistication it deserves, but it at least acknowledges that it's an imperfect method of personal understanding.

Adorned with all the adolescent fetishes of his previous films, its stop-action animation world suits Anderson, allowing him to create the perfect playground for his deadpan sense of humor and relentless examination of familial anxiety.
There's no doubt that Anderson is an inventive filmmaker bursting with ideas. The problem is that he hasn't found a powerful story to contain them.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: ... this black comedy wannabe ends up plucking at the heartstrings when it should be going for the jugular.
Whenever the comedy loses steam and the emoting gets too much, the movie queues up another indie-emo-fueled montage to fill the emotional gaps. What would Zach Braff be without the Shins?
A fitting showcase for Philip Seymour Hoffman's tousled talents ... and a sad epitaph of a title for one of Hollywood's most talented character actors.
Linklater sculpts drama out of time, demonstrating that the fleeting moments we experience day in and day out are actually telling the story of our lives.

Mitchell reshapes tried-and-true scare conventions - teens in peril, a relentless malevolent force, jarring soundtrack - into an unexpectedly unique creepfest. And his riffs on sex and adulthood are refreshing in their allegorical complexity.
None of this would work without Williams' painfully authentic performance. She plays Wendy as a gentle but self-possessed young woman who combats despair and fear with solemn defiance.

The message here is convincingly clear: corporate America is involved in an elaborate and extravagantly funded game of three-card monty, playing the public for the suckers they are all-too willing to be.
There's a fine line between clever and smug, and Szifrón rides that line hard, reveling in the brutality and explosive emotions on display.
The mayhem is clever but, functionally, Whedon is serving Disney's branding schemes first and his story and characters second.

The practical effects and stunts give it the kind of bone-jarring, visceral impact that most Hollywood and Marvel superhero movies have largely abandoned. By comparison, The Avengers: Age Of Ultron, seems unconvincingly cartoonish.
...isn't funny enough to play as a straight comedy nor dark enough to resonate as a black comedy, but should be commended for sticking with its ballsy plot twist.

Shouldn't a magical destination be, well, magical? Instead of leaving our jaws agape in wonder, Tomorrowland's architecture looks like a cross between Disney's Epcot Center and a high-end shopping mall.
That Sugar Film's message is one well worth hearing, there are better, more informed messengers out there.
It's first-rate filmmaking in service of subtlety-free, second-rate storytelling. You never for a moment doubt where Southpaw is heading, but, ultimately, it's Gyllenhaal that makes you care.
Despite the best prosthetic penis joke probably ever, Patrick Brice's fitfully funny indie still doesn't deliver the awkward sex comedy Gen-Xers deserve.
The Wolfpack is what happens when a filmmaker of limited talent gets the scoop of a lifetime.

On one hand, it's energetically directed, well-acted, and reasonably smart. On the other, it's infected by a kind of hipster racism, where the black and female co-stars exist to make a young white male with no actual problems feel better about himself.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If your superhero movie is 101 minutes long and it takes 75 minutes before the bad guy shows up, something is seriously wrong with your script. Just sayin'.
Essentially a senior-citizen version of Holmes fan fiction, McKellen makes the movie worth watching. Too bad the final caper doesn't match his dedication to character.

A heartfelt portrait of self-questioning genius and a thinking man's version of bromance. It asks provocative questions about the nature of conversation while engaging in equally provocative conversations. Wallace probably would have hated it.

It doesn't work, but I'm impressed with how hard it tries. There's an infectious sincerity to both the writing and the acting that elevates what is otherwise a messy mashup of tone, style, and storytelling.

Stupid. But not in a good way. Just plain, insufferably stupid. The movie objectifies the women in exactly the same way the villains do. In a summer that saw the rise of Imperator Furiosa, I'm sorry, this just won't do.
Good intentions do not a good movie make. And it's sad to say, but Johnson was far more convincing in 50 Shades of Grey.

..certainly better directed than many low-budget scare flicks, but it inevitably comes off as secondhand, a mildly entertaining, if clumsy, mix of eeriness and chuckles that arrests Shyamalan's cinematic decline but certainly doesn't reverse it.
It cribs from just about everything Martin Scorsese has ever done in the genre - but without any of the complicated morality, stylistic artistry, or seductive panache..
Let's face it: This is what 3-D IMAX theaters are for. If ever you wanted to know just how small and insignificant you are when facing the full force of the natural world then this is your film.
Revenge of the Sith is far from a great film but it easily trumps its two predecessors.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: As a window into our country's right-wing attitudes about emerging democracies, the film is particularly timely.

What would you ask your maker if you had the chance? Has humanity earned the right to live? Prometheus' first 40 minutes are a banquet of juicy themes, speculations and inquiries that are ultimately left to rot on the table.

...occasionally nails its grizzled '70s tough guy shtick but mostly it delivers a tired jumble of sloppy genre cliches, stupid character choices, and unnecessary action sequences. Neeson is clearly punching below his weight class.
With a sharper, more satirical script, it might have worked. Which is to really say Chappie kind of sucks.

We actually start to care about these ridiculous characters because, like the rest of us, they're just trying to survive the inanities of everyday life ... and keep the carpets free of unsightly gore stains.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Kingsman is entertaining in its way and occasionally clever, but also relentlessly smug and sexist.
McDonagh isn't always successful at juggling his disparate impulses, leaving his film to tonally lurch from one scene to the next. But damned if he shouldn't be praised for trying.
Life Itself is at its most compelling when it tackles Siskel and Ebert's contentious professional marriage. Their rivalry is a fascinating stew of insecurity, resentment, respect, and co-dependence.
A modest, slow-burn screenplay that's more about revealing its central characters than spinning a compelling yarn, which is certainly no sin.
... how do you miss including a reference to The Beatles' "I Am The Walrus?" There's not even a passing "coo-coo-ca-choo."
Liam Neeson has spent so many years bringing class and gravitas to otherwise undeserving films (ahem, the Taken series) that it's nice to see him in a movie more befitting his talents.
Schechter's adaptation feels more cautiously reverent than inspired, denying Life of Crime of snap, style, and, most importantly, a sense of danger.
Coogan and Brydon are locked into a routine that reliably amuses but, perhaps, one they have mastered too well to examine their own privilege.
One wonders what might've been, had Johnson allowed his stars the freedom to riff off rather than merely recite his pain-by-numbers script.
Gone Girl isn't as wicked as it should be or thinks it is. Fincher is becoming the go-to guy for middlebrow, beach-towel novel adaptations.
Director David Dobkin really wants you to hug your dad. And you can feel that insistent desire for almost every minute of The Judge's too-long 140-minute running time.
That it comes as close as it does to successful satire is either a testament to Simien's talents or an indication of how starved cinema is for socially relevant comedy.
Despite Iñárritu's tin ear for humor, inaccurate views of New York theater, and blatantly petty grievances, Birdman not only engages, it occasionally compels.
Why can't the bad guys hit even one dwarf? This second chapter improves on most of its predecessor's shortcomings but suffers from the fact that it cannot stand on its own as a movie.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Much as Nolan's characters often fail to reconcile their grandest desires, so, too, does Interstellar fall short, particularly in its trying-to-have-it-all finale. But, damn, if we shouldn't applaud Nolan for aiming big.
Unfortunately, despite Rosewater's earnest and intelligent approach, it remains a shallow treatment of a topic that deserves much more.
The movie is leaden and uneventful, clearly marking time for Part 2 to deliver the big action set pieces and the dramatic consequences of Katniss' choices.
The film is dour and lumbering, with only a handful of rousing scenes to justify the blatantly financial choice to split the novel into two films.
Not only is Horrible Bosses 2 uninterested in satirizing our country's desperate state of economic uncertainty, it isn't even interested in having any horrible bosses in it.
Witherspoon, who clearly saw the project as an opportunity to redefine her career, is refreshingly and respectably raw but hardly revelatory.
For all Wahlberg's self-flagellating, we never really understand his suicidal petulance. He's an ennui-soaked brat.
If a movie could have a jutting jaw and steely eyes Unbroken would be the prototype.
What is the price of getting what we wished for? Are we happier for getting it? In this case, the singing and dancing answer is, thankfully, yes.
There's little in the way of dramatic fireworks or intimate epiphanies. The emotional messiness is just too schematic and neat, suggesting theatrical rather than real-world inspirations.
Moore's performance is exquisitely nuanced - the only thing worth remembering about this otherwise tone-deaf weepie.

Anyone who knows Leigh's method wouldn't be surprised that Mr. Turner is more of an intuitive collage than a faithful dramatization of reality. It's a fascinating, mostly plotless examination of one man's tortured artistic process.
A pervading sense of "who gives a sh-t" permeates the whole affair. I can't recall the last time I heard a sound mix this bad in a major motion picture.

A slick and nightmarish descent into a world where corporate justice rewards those who do whatever it takes to get ahead. It's more than fitting that this horror show of American capitalism opened on Halloween .
The Nightmare Before Christmas cleverly refashions its yuletide characters into Edward Gorey refugees.
The story doesn't dot every 'i' and cross every 't' - but it certainly makes every ridiculously sinister turn stick.

Krokidas is a cunningly inventive director, making his shoestring production look 10 times its budget. And the cast is terrific. But without a stronger contextual frame his film is little more than an intriguing footnote to story of The Beats.
There are better ways to spend your evening. Perhaps there's some laundry to be done?
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: ...more of an energetic and affectionate sketch than a revealing portrait of this oversized personality, but one has to wonder if the woman who celebrated glittering surfaces would have wanted it any other way.
movie_title: Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has To Travel (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's always a pleasure to see a movie give attention to the ideas and visions of its characters, but the drama is, at times, a little too dry and earnest to hit Dangerous Liaisons heights.
You will not see a better-looking film this year. But you will undoubtedly see better films.

Jarecki makes clear that all our efforts and investments in fighting the War on Drugs haven't yielded any real success, only ruined lives, families and communities. There comes a point in any war where it becomes important to ask: Is it worth it?

... the dynamic on-the-fly scenes of danger and chummy stationhouse camaraderie are slowly peeled away to reveal a fascinating and multigenerational portrait of loss, resiliency, frustration and regret.
...buried beneath the bloated 2-hour and 46-minute run time of The Hobbit is as an entertaining two-hour movie...
Django is infectiously rousing and exuberantly subversive. Say what you will about his insensitivities, nothing in Tarantino's approach is condescending or pretentious.

Predictable plot twists and chase scenes ensue in a stylish but otherwise old-school thriller. But the events of last week encourage deeper reflection on what we seek from the violence that is so casually depicted in today's movies.
The jokes are few and far between, and the scenes inside the car lack the imagination and spontaneity a more comically attuned director would otherwise bring.
God save us from boomer nostalgia and its endless idealization of the '60s.
Not Fade Away is intimate, episodic and achingly poignant. It's also woefully insubstantial. Chase has created less of a dramatic narrative and more of an awkwardly paced, formulaic collage.
Gangster Squad, I have seen The Untouchables and you, sir, are no Untouchables. But you may be the most violent episode of Dragnet ever.

Bayona has the uncanny ability to put viewers in the moment, allowing them to vividly experience the family's struggles. But for all his formidable skills and artistic vision, his compassion is distressingly myopic.
As each contrivance piles it becomes clear that the filmmakers are just padding an otherwise sporadic and unmotivated series of jolts.
Candis demonstrates a practiced hand in his direction, keeping the pace brisk and the tension taut. But there's no getting around the meandering and highly formulaic script.
Welcome to the latest in WTF cinema, the kind of movie that critics love, general audiences loathe and cinephiles puzzle over.
...this deceptively simple film makes clear that death, real death, the kind we all face and most art refuses to address honestly, is relentless and unsentimental.

Not content to simply present a twisty thriller, Soderbergh pulls off a series of dramatic sleights of hand, undermining genre expectations and keeping the audience continually off-balance, wondering where his crazed yarn will go next.
Viola Davis suffers the greatest indignity, literally playing a magic Negro who holds down two jobs; one as a housekeeper and the other as a supernatural librarian. Both serve white people.
Loud, insultingly low-concept, and irony-free... today may be the perfect day to take Die Hard out back and put a bullet in its head.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Hoss' outstanding performance is a deep well of subtle yet unmistakable motives and reactions.

A movie made solely to land a healthy weekend box office then move on to the global market for a return on its investment. As a business strategy, it makes sense. As an instance if cinema, it's a bit depressing.
When is a phone call from your dead friend more than just bizarre? When it's made on a hot dog. It's a hopeless mess. But, at least, for its first half, a very entertaining mess.
Can we spare some sympathy or hope for the children of villains, even if they too show signs of their parents' evil? Lore provides no easy answers.

...Inept and self-congratulatory. It's an eyeliner-and-bad-special-effects face off, with the Cullen family and their runway model pals voguing against Aro and his heavily robed, superpowered minions.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It has that jangly soundtracked, Sundance smell about it, never imposing enough style or taking enough risks to fully distinguish itself, but offering just enough of a unique voice to get by.
This is a movie that embraces the fullness of English eloquence and dares the audience to keep up.
[A] handsome and discriminating historical drama.
Anderson's latest effort is like an Instagram photo - a nostalgic snapshot that seems to be of different time and place but is really the twee affectation of a world that never existed.

Merida comes off as a slightly more enlightened version of Jasmine, the discontented princess in Aladdin. And though she doesn't need a handsome young prince to make her whole, she ultimately learns that mother (as a stand-in for father) knows best.

Strange as it may sound, Magic Mike's male stripper money shots are less a celebration of Tatum and company's impressive pecs and abs and more the jaded reflections of an artist who's lost faith in his career choices.
When Zeitlin zeroes in on the father and daughter, Beasts of the Southern Wild sucks us in and makes us care.

Though the canvass is bigger, the cast more assured and the action pieces more impressive - The Joker's embrace of violence and chaos cut closer to the bone. Nothing here feels as spontaneous or as dangerous as Ledger's lip-smacking performance.
Things start off promising, but, by the time the final reel rolls, Winterbottom's too-detached style seems to be willfully wallowing in oversimplified misery.
For fans, Journeys is like that box set of uneven rarities that they simply must own. For casual friends, it's 90 minutes in good company. For the rest - ho-hum.
Instead of creating complex, three-dimensional human beings, "Hope Springs" infantilizes the emotions and life experiences of older Americans.
While the results are mostly entertaining, this is the weakest and least thrilling addition to the Bourne series.
It's clear that Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix has left the dewy-eyed awe of childhood magic and entered the brooding angst of adolescent powerlessness.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: From a visual standpoint, ParaNorman has set the bar for stop-action animation.
Watching Jackie fill cart after Walmart cart with crap the family doesn't need is to witness the new millennium's version of Marie Antoinette.
Oz remains a calculated studio endeavor, filled with awkward shifts between simple-minded humor, gooey sentimentality, lavish effect sequences and move-it-along storytelling.
It earns its hour-and-a-half of thrills honestly, with good solid storytelling and filmmaking. It's amazing how rare that is these days.
End of Watch earns a helluva lot of goodwill through the incredible chemistry of Gyllenhaal and Pena.
Audiences who like to see bullets rip through eyeballs and cheeks will undoubtedly be delighted.
Anderson's style is clearly epic in scope, but his narrative approach is ambiguous, opaque and chillingly detached.
The dreamlike visual approach makes for undeniably good cinema but as a meaningful examination of why Detroit unraveled, what it's facing, and where it might go, it's woefully inadequate portraiture.
So close to being a great movie is Looper that I want to go back in time and chat with writer-director Rian Johnson about the parts of the film that come up short.
The question isn't how such a ham-fisted, clichéd and, frankly, stupefyingly simple-minded film got made. The question is: How did it recruit such a talented cast into its union-bashing ranks?
There are a few chuckles along the way (mainly sight gags involving butter), but the commentary is obvious and toothless.
Affleck impresses with the thematic sophistication of his vision. He is a man who truly believes in the redemptive powers of cinema.
It's about what you'd expect from the filmmaker whose first feature, In Bruges, featured a coke-addled dwarf pontificating about the impending race riots to a pair of Belgian hookers.

Men play women. Women play men. Blacks play whites. An Asian plays a freckled Victorian. Bad accents flourish. And Hugo Weaving, whether he's a he, she, or ridiculous hoodoo leprechaun, is always the villain.
There's also a fine line between meditative and just plain pokey ... It's only the charisma and passion of the film's performers that carries us to the end.
At 50 years old, James Bond has matured in the best sense of the word.
Smart and sweet, Robot and Frank feels familiar while you're watching it yet consistently finds ways to catch you off-guard.
Stoker may drip with juicy primal urges, suspense and demented behavior, but it offers very little logic or substance to soak up.
Polley expertly navigates the emotional states of her characters, constantly surprising and challenging our expectations about who will say what and what will happen next.
There's something depressing about the fact that The Croods could probably be watched by an audience anywhere in the world without subtitles and they wouldn't miss a thing.
Thankfully, Ratatouille never relies on pop-culture references or crass satire to get laughs. It creates comedy on its own terms.

As a film critic who has spent too many summers viewing mediocre misfires and uninspired reinterpretations of TV shows, comic books and cult classics, it's immensely satisfying to recommend something as breathtakingly glorious as WALL-E.
Though his politics are unmistakably left, the documentarian's targets are almost exclusively the powerful and his work is fueled by optimism rather than cynicism.

Prince Avalanche isn't quite the character study it seems to want to be. Green sometimes bobbles the tone and focus, lurching from deadpan comedy to self-indulgent navel-gazing to underplayed ghost story.
Though Blue Jasmine has a tendency to hammer away at its themes, it at least shows that Allen still has a few interesting ideas floating around behind his horn-rimmed glasses.
Green takes this familiar story of accidental bromance and subtly inserts metaphors about loss and regeneration.

It looks and feels impressive, and actually seems to be about something other than explosions ... but is undone by a script that bludgeons its audience with all the subtly of a grenade to the face - which, in fact, happens to one of the film's characters.
Wright and Pegg's rickety and ridiculous mash-up of narrative elements is actually a sophisticated attempt to grapple with real emotions and ideas.
...bears all the extravagant style perfectionist filmmaker Wai can muster, but suffers from a sketchy biography that lurches along.

When Still Mine's title reflects the sincerity and adoration we witness between two very private people - rather than a declaration of ownership - McGowan's movie is worthy of the wonderful cast he's attracted.

The directorial instincts of Villeneuve lean toward the lurid, though he seems to think he's making a grand and brooding statement about the human condition. Prisoners is a compelling but unpleasant film, captive to its own schlocky hubris.
Awkwardly shifting between drama and humor, this therapy sitcom is schematically plotted, hitting all its dramatic mile markers at just the right moment, rendering everything neat and predictable.
A manically paced, profoundly affectionate and highly entertaining prequel to a cultural touchstone.
Teeth-clenchingly intense and gloriously immersive. Cuarón demonstrates that cellphone screens and tricked-out home theaters are no match for his big-screen artistry.

Will Richie regain his moral compass? Can our young turk turn the tables on his scheming mentor? If you're hoping for a surprise answer to any of these questions, then you are watching the wrong movie.
No matter how elaborately you trick out the shot, watching actors type on computer keyboards just isn't all that dramatic; even if they're typing really, really hard and really, really fast.
McQueen imbues his film with undeniable artistry and intellectual rigor, but startlingly little passion. You will be angered, horrified and moved by what you witness, but you will not be challenged.

Cormac McCarthy's manly grade of nihilism, pseudo-biblical prose and extreme acts of violence fill a plot-driven story that shows startlingly little interest in plot, character development or exposition.
Ender's Game, for all its glossy special effects and laudable wartime moral questioning, lacks a fundamental sense of thrills.
Reeves distinguishes himself behind the camera. The fight scenes are exciting and plentiful, acting as a showcase for both Hu Chen's formidable talents and Yuen Wo-ping's inventive choreography.
Imagine if Michael Haneke's Time of the Wolf had been penned by Stephanie Meyer and you'll get an inkling of what How I Live Now is attempting to pull off.
Although his latest film, Howl's Moving Castle, features astonishing imagery, it's a less complete package than Spirited Away or its predecessor, Princess Mononoke.
Gloriously gothic and deliciously creepy.
Kung Fu Panda is hugely entertaining, gorgeously animated and expertly cast, with Jack Black and Dustin Hoffman doing some of their best work in recent memory (no joke).
More a recap and appendix to the Paradise Lost trilogy... one can't help but feel that the celebrities involved needed this document of their efforts to appease their vanity.
When Death is your narrator, your movie had better have something profound to say about the precariousness of life or, at the very least, display some satiric wit. The Book Thief does neither.
While much of film is subversively amusing (though rarely laugh-out-loud funny), Johnson's depiction of high school bullying is disturbingly realistic, without ever crossing into hyperbole.
Though the short and breezy film is predictably clever, occasionally brilliant and unfailingly entertaining it still feels very much like an elongated episode.

More loyal to the classic show than the first film, Scooby-Doo finds his live-action niche in the highly entertaining sequel.
Never Die Alone succeeds only in being so bad that, as the final scenes roll, it is very funny, albeit unintentionally so.
An entirely forgettable action film. There is nothing new about it, the action feels similar to a Universal stunt show and you've forgotten it before the exit.
John Hamburg's remake of Something About Mary offers more of Ben Stiller's tiresome shtick.
Charlize Theron goes from very pretty to pretty scary in the jarring feature debut from director Patty Jenkins.
An expertly crafted film with several of the year's top performances.
Peter Webber exhibits unique skill in his feature film debut thanks to an excellent cast and the beautiful camerawork of Eduardo Serra.
With better direction and a better-suited leading man, this really could have worked.
An old fashioned grade B action pic at heart, Hidalgo tries too hard to be an important epic.
The Punisher is a shame, an example of a good story turned to crap.
Like the unkillable villain Broken Lizard parodies, the guys don't seem to realize when it's time to lay themselves to rest.
If your kid has recently suffered brain damage or undergone a frontal lobotomy, they probably still won't be fooled by this cookie-cutting, lifeless drudge.
These days, we rarely see realism portrayed so effectively on screen.
As kung fu films go, this is one of the best I've ever seen.
William H. Macy is the ultimate loser and Alec Baldwin is an old school casino boss in director Wayne Kramer's near-perfect feature debut.
Charlie Kaufman and Michel Gondry's second collaboration is a mind-melting, dramatic masterpiece.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The story's length, lack of sets, music, or a focused story combine to make one of the most excruciatingly dull cinematic experiences I can remember.
The Ladykillers is filled with laughs, great characters and a twisted, black tale that stands the test of time 50 years after it was first conceived.
Starsky knows exactly what it is and has fun with it.
An attempt at a Christopher Guest-style mockumentary minus the biting satire and wit.
Young Adam is entertaining and rewarding if you have the patience.
A very original, funny and highly accurate dissection of the teen girl world.
Let's put an end to the whole creepy scraggly-haired little girl looking through the tops of her eyes and making groaning sounds thing. This has to stop now.
Maria Full of Grace is an important and powerful film. It serves both to educate and tell the story of a very strong-willed and thick-skinned female character.
Not necessarily better, but just a different and equally impressive take on a great film.
AVP works in those few shining moments when the monsters are allowed to do their own thing.
Those willing to commit themselves, sit back, and take in all the film can offer should find the experience very rewarding.
Paparazzi is every bit as brainless as its previews would indicate.
A smart story, good direction, great chemistry, and some pretty exciting tennis to boot.
Enough originality, clever set-ups and witty humor to keep anyone entertained.
A positively brilliant comedy.
Friday Night Lights is a disappointment in the end because it could have been so much more.
A mildly entertaining film that will slip from most minds shortly after the closing credits.
If this movie offends or shocks you, then the past couple seasons of South Park will kill you.
An exceptional concept with questionable execution.
The Grudge is not the worst film of the year, but that's about the biggest compliment I can give it.
It's not Payne's best work, but even a lesser piece by Alexander Payne far exceeds just about anything else out there.
Too imbalanced to sustain the interest of most audience members through its entire 95 minutes.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Not a perfect film, but it provides enough excitement and intrigue to keep the popcorn crowds well entertained and glued to their seats for future Bourne adventures.
I, Robot is the summer's best action movie so far. It proves that you don't necessarily need to detach your brain in order to walk into a big budget summer blockbuster.
If one good thing can come out of this film, it's that this should provide an everlasting blueprint for what not to do with a comic book film.
At once both hysterical and stomach turning, Morgan Spurlock's documentary about living on fast food is a poignant achievement.
Of the twelve shorts, there's really only three that are good and a few that are passable. The other half are uninteresting, poor, and at times, incredibly painful to watch.
Desperately pleading for our laughs, Shrek 2 offers a small dose of the original's fun spirit with none of its heart.
The laughs are abundant for the first half, but then a plot and some tastelessly out of place jokes bog down what might have been a classic comedy.
One of the more bizarre and original characters in recent memory, Napoleon provides some great laughs despite an uneven story that often loses steam.
Hanks' Navorsky character is compelling, we care about him, and we become interested in a situation most of us would stop at nothing to avoid.
In the tradition of the greatest sports comedies of all time, Dodgeball is a blast and an instant classic.
A hit and miss comedy that's never terrible and never great.
Michael Moore's new documentary is more ranting and raving than effective filmmaking.
Spider-Man 2 is, on the whole, a success.
De-Lovely is worth a rental if only to learn more about Porter's wonderful music and to see two very fine performances from Kline and Judd.
The Clearing delves into deeper issues of failed ambitions and lost hopes than the simple survival plotlines of most thrillers...
Quite possibly the most boring tale of bad to the bone British thugs I can remember.

Swords, sorcerers, archery and mysticism rule in this big, silly popcorn adventure.
Will Ferrell headlines a great comedy cast in a story that is as ridiculous as it is hysterical.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: One of the best love stories of recent years.
A simply stellar, electric, musical biopic that joins the best ever made.
A sweet story can't overcome a seriously flawed film.
The film is unfortunately uneven, with great moments followed by not-so-great moments.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The anchor of Twilight is the nuanced, understated performance of Kristen Stewart.

You heard it here first: Year One is the best prehistoric comedy of 2009.

As usual, characters end up in an escalating series of preposterous events and zany hijinks that, while being occasionally amusing, aren't much different from watching your average humdrum situational TV comedy.
Like a bad roller coaster. It sure is fun getting to the top, but everything else is a letdown and you walk away feeling a little ripped off.
A smart, dark, sleazy breath of fresh air...

movie_review_blurb: For such a talented cast Baby Mama unfortunately misses the mark.

Cox rocks and Apatow's streak continues in this spot-on biopic parody.

movie_review_blurb: Paris Can Wait is more fitting for the Food Network than a feature film. And even then, cooking shows have better editing etiquette, story structure and emotional appeal than this half-baked entree.

movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In Holland, the silver screen has its youngest and best Spider-Man yet. He's juvenile, irresponsible and amateur. He's a kid. And you feel for him, since we've all experienced the social pressures of school.

In Campillo we have a filmmaker easily able to bend narrative to his will, to make the act of telling stories with moving pictures fresh again, and who is also fascinated with the physical properties of his medium. It's a potent mix.

If The Ultimate Gift really wanted to embrace a powerful Christian message, it would've made Jason's ordeal truly threatening and genuinely transformative.
A familiar clash between old and new is rendered fresh and alive, with an edge of menace that slowly gets under your skin.
More often than not, the red balloon appears as a silent, benevolent witness to ethereal moments that [director] Hou has taken great care to capture.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's not the whole, rough-edged film that appeals most, but the individual moments that feel exactly right, accumulating to form a lasting impression.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Like its protagonist, Richard Linklater's A Scanner Darkly suffers from a schizoid identity crisis.
It's an effortlessly charming ensemble, and Klapisch's characters (most of them anyway) reveal depths of feeling that compensate for the film's lightweight tone and too-long running time.
A tenacious survival tale in which passionate lovers are held apart by outmoded traditions. How they overcome obstacles to happiness is what makes the film so dramatically engaging.

None of this is fun to report from a critic's perspective. I'm a Shyamalan fan who greatly admires what he's trying to do, but Shyamalan's desperate desire to be the next Steven Spielberg has grown painful to witness.
They say you can't go home again, but writer-director Kevin Smith didn't get the memo.
It's flawed but no less fascinating for its mood of simmering tension on the fringes of the American dream.
It casts a spell of compassionate humanity with a gently healing effect.
Subject matter dominates over filmmaking craft in Rachel Boynton's somewhat sloppy but otherwise riveting documentary.
A so-called 'science-fiction fantasy' about an epic trip to our planet, another epic journey away from it, and Herzog's musings on the implacable dominance of nature.
This is one of those deliriously unhinged movies that looks, feels and sounds genuinely insane, for all the right artistic reasons.
You can't blame Crossover for being comfortable with its own clichés. It's so blatantly formulaic that it actually grows on you if you don't dismiss it in the first five minutes.

It's a modest triumph of unflattering realism, proving yet again that a camera, a few good actors, the right material and a sensitive director are all you need to illuminate any particular aspect of humanity.

[Hollywoodland] holds interest as a whodunit that's refreshingly compassionate toward the fates of its characters. Warts and all, they're likable dreamers in a town where dreams don't always come true.
As a breathtaking follow-up to 2003's Ong-Bak: Thai Warrior, it's a whole lotta fun.
Despite some weaknesses, The Black Dahlia remains curiously fascinating.
As a sad yet joyful celebration of cultural exchange, Riding Alone plays like a small miracle, unfolding in a world as it ought to be.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The painstaking authenticity and appealing cast of Flyboys can't overcome the cloyingly formulaic nature of its story.
A rambling road movie with noble intentions and an excess of speechifying.
In 90 captivating minutes, Laura Poitras' extraordinary documentary My Country, My Country gives you a greater understanding of the situation in Iraq than you'd get from 100 hours of Fox News or CNN.
This indulgently puerile waste of time plows ahead with pointless mayhem masquerading as 'art.'
Bordering on camp and loaded with lesbian undertones, this wretched drama plays like a high-school horror flick that trades monsters and mayhem for an overdose of force-fed cruelty.
Conversations with God is a bad film about good things that many people will find enlightening. Its message is admirable, its filmmaking as bland as a communion wafer.
If you've ever been fascinated by a large and complex construction site, Juan Carlos Rulfo's oddly affecting documentary may offer a kind of blue-collar bliss.

What could have been a turning point was instead a footnote of Irish cinema, seen now to be a presciently accurate assessment of Ireland's turbulent national character at a pivotal time of transition.
If you're on this movie's wavelength, you may find yourself unexpectedly moved by its cumulative effect.
Despite its best intentions, Holly never achieves the dramatic clarity it needs to put its human suffering into galvanizing perspective.
The Sasquatch Gang may not fully qualify as an undiscovered gem, but it's got some dynamite all its own.
The movie's convoluted hide-and-seek plot also demands a White House break-in that makes about as much sense as subprime mortgage rates.
The film's father-son friction grows occasionally repetitious, but it springs from a sensitive, well-written melodrama that earns its emotions with tender sincerity.

The play's power has been diluted by questionable editing, an overload of blandly stylized violence and the conspicuous suspicion that this whole thing is the predictable result of catering to base commercial instincts.
This is powerful stuff.
Even casual horror buffs have seen it all before.
Summer Love feels more like a haphazard assembly of loose-knit components, jumbled together with obvious affinity for all varieties of a distinctly American genre.
Watching this impeccably crafted melodrama, you feel grateful for a veteran filmmaker who serves a gripping story with a confident efficiency that's lean, mean and focused like a laser.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In a remarkably assured, no-frills feature debut, Brazilian documentarian Chico Teixeira draws a vivid portrait of marital and familial dysfunction.
Helvetica is one of those rare films in which the exploration of a specific topic leads to expanding horizons of perception.
If nothing else, it's a welcomed alternative to the more straightforward and serious film that Spielberg is likely to deliver.
CJ7 is wildly entertaining at times, but when it comes to telling an actual story, Chow could use some tutoring from the clever folks at Pixar.

Too serious for comedy and too improbable to achieve much impact as social melodrama, it works best as a showcase for its actors, all of whom bring more depth to the material than it achieves on its own.
Under the Same Moon combines all the elements of an old-fashioned tear-jerker with the low-key, low-budget intelligence of a carefully crafted indie film.

Gabarski's low-budget realism is nicely matched to a deceptively stolid performance by Faithfull, who combines infinitely subtle expressions with the smoky, still-sexy voice that made her famous as a '60s pop songbird.

Bahrani blurs the line between New York reality and fiction so effectively that his scripted films feel vibrantly authentic, as if Bahrani had simply discovered his characters and allowed their lives to proceed with a minimum of directorial intrusion.
Hey, at least you don't have to ask what it's about, right?
What you get, in the end, is a pair of fine performances (from Thurman and Wood) and a technically well-made film that arrives at a foregone conclusion.
There are moments in City of Men that feel so vividly accurate that you may find yourself ducking from the gunfire.
This is an indie film in the genuine spirit of the word (not some studio-subsidized boutique product), showing compassion while following its own course of low-key redemption.

What compelled Kapur to film half the movie through scrims, curtains, screens and arches? How can you appreciate human drama when you're constantly being distracted by the 16th-century equivalent of Architectural Digest?
As always, Buscemi masters his portrayal of needy desperation, but he still makes Les admirable for his capacity to go with the flow.
Fay Grim makes giddy sense to a point, but Hartley seems trapped in a bubble of his own, failing to let us in on a joke that would be funnier if its punch line weren't so quirkily obscure.
Takes a light-and-lively approach to the local population, consisting of transplanted oddballs and stubborn survivors drawn to the Sea's calm, sunny environs and isolated, crime-free lifestyle.
movie_title: Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea (2004)

movie_review_blurb: [Director] Bekmambetov is a reckless and juvenile storyteller with a regrettable knack for empty spectacle.
Walking to Werner flirts with becoming an ordeal.
If you're getting the impression that Dynamite Warrior is insanely plotted for deliberate hilarity, you're right.

As observers we can project our own fantasies onto Ben's, and [director] Ellis enhances this dreamy effect with low-budget ingenuity, like cleverly executing location changes in the same unbroken shot.
Anything but comforting. With its depiction of bestial behavior and shocking wartime violence, it's the kind of film that polarizes viewers through the raw power of its imagery.
Unlike other recent films about the plight of Africa, Bamako channels its outrage more directly, yet with greater subtlety, by recruiting real-life witnesses to Africa's economic crises.
It's an exercise in hero worship that couldn't be more justified, even though Wiesenthal would have been modestly embarrassed by the honor.
movie_title: I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life And Legacy Of Simon Wiesenthal (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As poet of heartbreak, Shinkai could be accused of treacly mush (the voice-overs are a bit florid, and the saccharine piano score doesn't help), but he's got a delicate touch with sentiment that will have receptive viewers reaching for a Kleenex.
movie_title: Byôsoku 5 senchimêtoru (5 Centimeters per Second) (A Chain of Short Stories about Their Distance) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As timeless as the human condition.
A pathological case study disguised as a romantic melodrama.
It's a must-see for curious cinephiles, but otherwise a drag.
It's obviously more fun to watch Czech Dream than it was to experience the deception firsthand.

It's an eyes-wide-open account of tenacity and triumph for parents and children alike. Considering the dramatic rise in the number of children born with autism, it's a film that everyone should see and appreciate.
An irresistible Japanese import, Hula Girls is a crowd-pleaser so comfortable with its own clichÃ (C)s that it goes down smoother than a mai tai on Maui.
It thoughtfully illuminates a seemingly unsolvable problem while proving that one person really can make a difference.
If you're receptive to its challenge, you'll find little miracles from start to finish.
When it works, it works like a charm.
Anyone can grasp the issues explored in Jonroy's comedy, and occasional missteps are easily forgiven when something new (along with a feast of great-looking food) is being brought to the table.
As close to a masterpiece as any film you're likely to see this year.
As an acting showcase -- the supporting roles are as rich as the leads -- Georgia Rule is undeniably one of the year's best American dramedies.
There are so many quiet, understated miracles unfolding in Clean that all you can do is watch in awe and amazement.

It really is reprehensible and disgusting, not only because we've seen far too many sociopaths in movies over the past 20 years, but because it deals with horrid clichés and presents them as something indie-hip and morally provocative.

The film seems unnecessarily vague on a rational level, but it's spot-on as a psychological study of a twinlike sibling relationship, and the ways in which memory can suppress trauma and soothe a mourning soul.
Deeply compassionate and frequently amusing, qualifying as a minor miracle of humanely observant filmmaking.
[The movie] manages to eradicate any meaningful subtleties that are present in Kate DiCamillo's 2001 Newberry Award-winning children's book.
Hints of greatness are subverted by frenetic plotting and sensory overload.
movie_title: A Tree of Palme (Parumu no Ki) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Great to look at, but it's more silly than profound.
Schorr's award-winning film may be a bit on the slight side to some tastes, but it's a journey well worth taking.
Implausibility and banality join forces to turn dot the i into the kind of pretentious, pseudo-clever claptrap that most wanna-be directors get out of their system during film school.
Miller's many fans are likely to hail this as a masterpiece. Rarely has an artist in one medium been so loyally served by another.
Until it careers into cacophony ... it's a lot of fun.
A sick, twisted, deliriously entertaining horror thriller that rivals The Texas Chainsaw Massacre for sheer, relentless intensity.
Hal Hartley's 'fake sci-fi movie about the way we live now' is a misfire, suggesting occasional winks of satire while taking itself so seriously that you're left wondering when to laugh.
We have to settle for good intentions and bad writing.
Every viewing of Los Olvidados offers further proof of its perfection.
The Minutemen were influential then and now, and We Jam Econo is a valentine to the band and D. Boon's memory. They're immortal now, and that's as it should be.
movie_title: We Jam Econo: The Story of the Minutemen (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A lame exercise, delivering shameless thrills at the expense of logic and genuine suspense.
Achieves an unlikely but ultimately successful blend of blunt-force comedy and desperate investigation.
By any standard it's impressive anime; as a feature debut it's a remarkable achievement.
movie_title: The Place Promised in Our Early Days (2004)

movie_review_blurb: You're unaware of the film's power until the ending (well-earned and happy) hits you with an unexpected well of emotion.
movie_title: The Two of Us (Le vieil homme et l'enfant) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some giddy humor and a soundtrack of '70s Top-40 hits, this is 'entertainment' for sociopaths, occasionally effective but impossible to recommend with a clear conscience.
Performed in a series of devastating duets, it's so mature and authentic that it feels like an alien presence in the current (i.e. shallow) movie landscape.
Wretched excuse for a horror flick.
The vision of Intimate Stories is amusingly warm-hearted without being cloying or sentimental; the landscape may be harsh, but the performances are inviting.
It's refreshing to see a PG-13 horror film that aims for good old-fashioned spookiness.
It's an offbeat romance that defies easy labeling, recommendable as a film buff's pleasure and a semi-audacious art-house curio.
The only thing missing is an anime sequence, but the whole thing's a big cartoon anyway.
Given its complex array of fact, fiction, location, character and atmosphere, Millennium Actress is almost unimaginable in any other medium.

If you're in synch with its heartbeat, and with Reygadas' tendency to pursue visual detours that intensify the film's sensual impact, this is a remarkable first effort that is equal parts disturbing, bold, mysterious and primal.
A satisfying story that's greater than the sum of its parts.
Looks good, sounds good and delivers what most Dirty Dancing fans are likely to expect.
How often do you come across a soothing, unassuming film as gentle as this?
movie_title: Monsieur Ibrahim et les fleurs du Coran (Monsieur Ibrahim) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Serves as worthy tribute to a true original, an 'artist's artist' for whom life itself was a singular mode of expression.
While it functions independently as a sad, ultimately moving portrait of a deeply codependent couple, the film also emerges as the most richly resonant of The Trilogy.
Boosted by Morel's subtly hilarious, hangdog performance, the film offers a cunning blend of door-slamming farce and whimsical marital love story.
Like love itself, Reconstruction works on an irrational, off-kilter plane, filled with elation, regret and elusive second chances.
Sharp, fast-paced and eminently logical.
Robot Stories has the look and feel of an above-average student film, but Pak's potential promises better things to come.
Impeccably well-crafted, kid-friendly and downright cuddly.
Has moments of raw, unflinching power.
Aimed squarely at a samurai-literate audience, and its appeal beyond that is probably limited.
It's junk, but it's fun junk, and its target audience won't be disappointed.
It's a humid, rough-edged epic that occasionally finds startling beauty amid devastating carnage.
Its intentions aren't as clear as they should be, but it's clearly the work of a deep-thinking artist with a fearful concern for a future in which the nature of humanity is entirely uncertain.
It's no Bull Durham, but it certainly gives Major League a run for its money.
An undisciplined mess.

A well-intentioned but flawed British drama that presents a sexual relationship between a sixtysome-thing widow and a much-younger man, then sidesteps nearly all the issues it's pretending to address.

Apart from Park's impressive but ultimately hollow style (his images are impeccably composed and visually inventive), Lady Vengeance is still an exercise in wretched excess (though less extreme than its predecessors).
Like any roller-coaster ride, it may make you queasy, but you'll never be bored.
No matter where you stand, This Divided State has a patriotic, galvanizing effect.
If you don't choke up at least once during the dogs' engaging adventure, you obviously prefer cats.
If [Director] Bekmambetov had any skill in actually telling a story, his kitchen-sink trilogy would be something to celebrate. It presently qualifies as a dubious achievement.
With ravenous alligators and lions on the prowl, Duma delivers familiar adventure, but Ballard refuses to cater to cuteness.
... a technically impressive but altogether listless revenge tale ...
It falls short of vintage Lumet while playing to his strengths as an actor's director who's built a career on themes of moral ambivalence.

Crafting plot through dynamic use of London locations and a magnificent embassy set designed by Vincent Korda, Reed and venerable cinematographer Georges Périnal set a fascinating, multilayered stage for Phil's dilemma.
If you dare to see it, prepare for a challenge.
Slither is a movie only true horror buffs can love. Its greatest strength is that it never aspires to be anything more than it is: 96 minutes of good laughs and retro-splatter.
Movies like Evil entertain us by serving sweet revenge on a platter, and director Mikael Håfström manipulates emotions more intelligently than most.
The Final Destination movies may be pointless and crass, but they play on that fascination with malicious efficiency, and 3 is no exception.
Argento's film is arguably exploitative, but its real-life horrors are effectively authentic.
movie_title: The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The only civilized response to this display of abject ignorance, hatred and bigotry is one of anguished despair, but Levin's film enlightens as much as it enrages.
This upright and thoughtful film boasts a level of quality and noble purpose that Hollywood has all but abandoned.

Approaching potentially unpleasant subject matter with humor, intelligence and deep compassion for its flawed yet infinitely human characters, Take My Eyes is almost certain to rank as one of the year's best films.
movie_title: Te doy mis ojos (Take My Eyes) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: In its own quiet, revealing fashion, Berman's film explores the folly and faith that characterized much of Black Bear's early existence.
Here's a 'steamy' soap opera that's never very steamy, and if you set your expectations low, this movie is only too happy to meet them.

Rich in perceptive details, Albou's film has drawn favorable comparison to the work of Claire Denis (The Intruder, Friday Night), and both directors share a sensual sensitivity to their characters' inner lives.
The courtroom scenes have a lively immediacy matched by the fiery efficiency of Ngassa and Ntuba.
As a musical fever dream of paradise lost, The Lost City is a flawed success, boasting just enough truth and admirable purpose to justify the hazards of Garcia's passion.

The film's escalation of tension is almost unbearable, and Mifune erupts with a ferocity that's as righteous as it is ultimately tragic, for Kobayashi refuses to soften the film's devastating imbalance of power.
A rigorous, labor-intensive viewing experience, but there's something to be said for its unadorned purity.
A portrait of rural America as beautiful as it is bizarre.
A sequel for seekers, What the Bleep!? Down the Rabbit Hole is a lightning rod for skeptics and believers alike.
movie_title: What the Bleep!? Down the Rabbit Hole (2006)

movie_review_blurb: With Naked in Ashes, Los Angeles-based filmmaker Paula Fouce manages a dubious feat of underachievement: She's made a documentary about Hindu mystics that's only marginally enlightening about its subject matter.
For an exquisite taste of sensory cinema, look no further.
We've seen this cautionary tale before, and the outcome, while chilling from an ethical perspective, is almost a foregone conclusion.
Transporter 2 is franchise hackwork, easily dismissed but adequately enjoyable.
Hallström specializes in tales of pent-up longing and hesitant reconciliation, but this cinematic Hallmark card is too prettified and predictable for his reliably delicate touch.
Decleir is so commanding in the role that it's easy to dismiss the film's generic trappings.
movie_title: De zaak Alzheimer (The Memory of a Killer) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Even the title is lame, but it does convey the movie's overall effect: numbing and toxic.
Has both novelty and back-to-basics ingenuity in its favor, along with memorable characters and the deft combination of gory shocks and comic relief that's essential to the genre.
Offers the most realistic approximation of a moon visit that Earthbound mortals have ever seen.
movie_title: Magnificent Desolation: Walking on the Moon 3D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A riveting BBC documentary that illuminates the character of that nation.
With an exclamation point suggesting the collegial equivalent of Beatlemania, Zizek! is a movie made by a groupie too enamored of her subject to make a satisfying film about him.
The movie forces you into primal alertness, its effectiveness enhanced by exceptional casting and escalating tension that plays on your emotions.
It's not a great film, but The Red Orchestra pays honorable tribute to these little-known resistance fighters, and that makes it worthwhile.
With its mind-numbing excess of digital imagery and lack of compensatory storytelling, MirrorMask suggests that something of Gaiman's is getting lost in translation.
With subject matter so potentially intense, it's a ho-hum thriller with a predictable outcome.
Like a cultivated orchid, the delicate product of careful attention and an appreciation for fleeting beauty.
You'll be hard-pressed to find a shred of the perverse ingenuity that made Saw so effectively unnerving.
It's no wonder Schlöndorff favors close-ups; with Mattes on screen, The Ninth Day gets right to its emotional core.
It's more thoughtfully conceived than most of what passes for filmmaking these days.
While it's rattling your nerves, Pulse leaves your brain wanting more.
If you don't mind a bit of treacle in your cinematic cultural-exchange program, The Overture will warm you inside and out.
While familial subplots, schoolyard showdowns and a climactic sea storm feel somewhat detached from the narrative, the deep sense of longing that underlies this sweet-natured tale rings true.
Morris explores the reality of Abu Ghraib with a visceral intensity that straightforward reportage could never allow.
It's just three gifted filmmakers with vision to spare, daring you to go to their extremes.

Bertino relies too heavily on occasionally nonsensical terror tricks that every horror buff has seen a million times since John Carpenter's Halloween set the standard for domestic fright-night mayhem.
By the time its third story kicked in, "In Another Country" lost me.
It's a feast for fans of the genre and a guaranteed ordeal for everyone else.
A Rorschach test of our own responses to the intimate drama unfolding before us.
Plenty of Northwest indie cred doesn't stop "The Men of Dodge City" from being an endurance test.

"Room 237" is an act of uncommon devotion to cinema, embracing the notion that movies are best defined by what happens to us as we watch them - how our own beliefs and experiences dictate our interpretation of what we've seen and heard.
"The Sapphires" feels like a movie you've already seen, but it's nonetheless thoroughly enjoyable, like a pop song that's no less infectious when you know every word.

Visually and sonically hypnotic, it's an intensely sensory blend of internal monologue and unsettling mystery, draped over a thin skeleton of plot approached so obliquely that it seems almost inconsequential.
Cruelty, bloodletting and death are evident throughout (frequently occurring just outside the frame), and Griffith's laudable discretion actually intensifies their impact.
This pleasant, unassuming little comedy manages to overcome its many potential shortcomings.
Hoult and Palmer carry "Warm Bodies" with a delightful conviction their characters' forbidden, "Romeo and Juliet"-like bond can be played like other movie romances, albeit with an obvious twist.
Being an appealing, shallow goof-off can wear thin, and Shore seems incapable of carrying a movie, even when it's a 90-minute knock-off like this.
It is numbingly bland, homogenized and deflated by an utter lack of original wit or charm. Worst of all, it is subtly but conspicuously condescending to its target audience.
movie_title: A Kid in King Arthur's Court (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Algrant's desire to reunite father and son through music is admirable, but "Greetings from Tim Buckley" is too meandering and ethereal to have any lasting impact.
Oh, gee, have I given too much away? Is there something in this lyrical narrative that can't be detected in the first five minutes?
3 Ninjas was a surprising box-office hit with the Saturday matinee family crowd, earning the highest cost-to-profit ratio of that year and instantly mandating this all-too-unnecessary sequel.
After being subjected to disturbing scenes of abject cruelty, rape and torture, my reactions shifted from squeamish revulsion to a reluctant yet growing appreciation for Kim's thematic ambition.
To the slim degree that it qualifies as a comedy, House Arrest is a comedy with rank amateur pathos, and it's totally out of touch with its own superficially treated emotions.
If you're looking for a 96-minute jolt of joy, look no further than this uplifting, well-made documentary ...
For all of its transgender drama, "Laurence Anyways" remains a love story, pure but not so simple.
Frodo Baggins as a psycho-killer? Why not?
With credits that include such garbage as Hot Dog... The Movie, director and former hockey player Peter Markle displays an utter lack of comic sensibility.

If you focus on its fascinating subject matter and the dramatic revelations presented here with irrefutable impact, "Free the Mind" qualifies as a pioneering inquiry at the outermost boundaries of neuroscience.
They may be short on humor, but they compassionately illuminate the state of our world, our frailties and foibles, and our capacity to survive the challenges that life throws at our feet.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films 2013: Live Action (2013)

movie_review_blurb: By the time it fades to black, "Gangster Squad" has squandered most of its early promise.
Despite its amped-up energy, the film never quite lives up to the promise of its earlier scenes.
Formulaic to a fault and painfully unfunny...
As Mexican drug cartels continue their deadly campaigns of narco-terrorism, it quickly becomes clear why Charlie Minn's film is titled "Murder Capital of the World."

"Ultrasonic" recalls better indie films like "Pi" and "Primer," but there's just not enough story to stretch over 90 minutes, resulting in several scenes that feel like filler, propelled by Rao's good but occasionally too-intrusive electronica score.
With his angular features and intense gaze, Lie is utterly convincing as an intellectual in the process of repairing his damaged life.
As comedies go, it's as dry as bleached bones in the desert, but you can't blame Vigalondo for taking another shot at cleverness.
"The Color Wheel" partially recalls the scathing audacity of "The Graduate" some 45 years ago.
The plot is clever yet breathtakingly simple, the action is relentless but logical, and the lead role is tailor-made for Hollywood's A-list action stars.
Great idea, lousy execution: "Iron Sky" boasts one of the zaniest premises in recent memory, and somehow manages to squander most of its potential.
Each in its own way, these shorts are masterworks that will stand the test of time.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films 2013: Animation (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An affectionate but somewhat haphazard documentary about Forman's life and work.
movie_title: Milos Forman: Co te nezabije... (Milos Forman: What doesn't kill you...) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's some boldly unconventional creativity happening here, but it's coming from the subject, not the filmmaker.
movie_title: Apocalypse: A Bill Callahan Tour Film (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Its anemic plot is almost nonexistent, and there's not enough substance to support Kim's languid style, resulting in a too-relaxed, 93-minute feature ...
It's hardly original (and Max von Sydow is wasted in brief scenes as Kane's father), but "Solomon Kane" is worthy of big-screen appreciation.
"Vulgaria" is certainly crude, but most of its amusing vulgarity is discreetly held off screen.
This quietly affecting indie film, about a Middle East war vet and the 10-year-old boy he takes under his wing, gently pulls the heartstrings while making dramatic missteps along the way.
A thoughtful bridging of a cultural divide.
Six mostly engaging fairy tales are digitally rendered with silhouetted characters performing in front of vivid, colorful backgrounds.
A forgettable film.
Compared with Weerasethakul's acclaimed features, it feels cobbled together and improvised, which for the most part it was.
IMAX 3D turns a slightly above-average "wuxia" ("martial hero" action thriller) into an epic extravaganza.
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: If you can overlook its shortcomings and focus on the information it provides, you may find it enlightening.
movie_title: People V. The State of Illusion (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The film is little more than a well-oiled machine that serves a strictly limited function, but like a precision timepiece, it is a thing to marvel at, even under close scrutiny.
A riotously enjoyable locomotive of action, Speed is driven by a premise of such crystalline purity that its ridiculousness becomes part of the fun.
Landis relies on routine action -- and cameos by such noted filmmakers as George Lucas, John Singleton, Martha Coolidge and others -- to hide the fact that there's no engine under his movie's hood.
The film benefits greatly from the use of three totally authentic ship replicas, but the real thing -- as presented in the PBS series about Columbus -- is still much more inspiring.
Bakshi's world is typically subversive, anti-nostalgic and, at times, a brilliantly conceived grafting of two and three dimensions. Unfortunately, its ingenuity matrix seems to have short-circuited.
League wants you to laugh more than anything else, and Hanks makes sure that you will.

I've never been a big fan of technique that calls attention to itself, but Wong's frenetic blend of slow motion, pixilation, rushing backgrounds and frozen foregrounds (or vice versa) is as integral to this movie as its bubbly story and characters.
Like Quentin Tarantino, Besson has a singular style and directorial sensibility that keeps you watching.

It's a good thing this breezy animated adventure lasts only slightly more than 70 minutes. Children will no doubt enjoy its simple tale, but would probably grow restless if it went on for a minute longer.
Bergman, who made The Freshman and Honeymoon in Vegas, provides quotable one-liners for everyone (especially Rhames), and a bevy of strippers lend colorful albeit stereotypically ditzy support.
Despite its best intentions, Father Hood is destined to become leftovers in the video store.
The film's entire cast and crew prove up to the task, and there's something both comfortably old-fashioned and blazingly contemporary about Aaron Sorkin's screenplay.
There's nothing wrong with The Gun in Betty Lou's Handbag that isn't wrong with about a thousand other commercially homogenized comedies of its kind.
movie_title: The Gun in Betty Lou's Handbag (1992)

movie_review_blurb: By the time Donner crowds his climactic poker game with a bevy of veteran Western character actors, decades of movie tradition have been reduced to window dressing, and Maverick leaves you hungry for the real thing.
Dafoe completely inhabits the character, appearing in virtually every scene and developing a fascinating psychological profile.
For connoisseurs of the bizarre, House's revival is long overdue.

Seeing the film twice reveals two completely different viewer perspectives -- a kind of "before and after" syndrome -- and like any good film The Crying Game grows richer as it sinks into your thoughts.
Hocus Pocus remains a delightful family comedy, spooky but never scary as it romps its merry way through the graveyard.
The film is so effective because Rudy is never seen as mock-heroic, and he's never lifted toward unrealistic achievement. He simply does the very best he can.
Antonia's Line is a Dutch treat that unfolds like a generous novel, surrounding you with its indelible sense of time, place and character.
If you have any inexplicable desire to see Car 54, take this advice: wait for its imminent release on video, and then consider renting something else instead.
Ultimately the viewer is left in the same bind as the filmmakers: wishing we'd been able to follow Naoki's apprenticeship to its traditional conclusion and beyond.
Simply put, absolutely none of it works. The movie utterly fails to set a foundation for its dark fantasy, effectively turning every character into a moron.

A powerful portrait of emotional endurance, propelled by the outstanding performances of Bassett and Fishburne, both of whom lend a crucial dimension to the gradual redundancies of Kate Lanier's otherwise insightful screenplay.

movie_review_blurb: For those who would question Crichton's motives, Levinson and Attanasio haven't let men off the hook.

It's miraculous casting, and the Australian Davis -- for my money the finest actress around, bar none -- is simply uncanny in her command of East Coast gentility combined with razor-sharp timing and comedic expression.

Jurassic Park is an astonishing success in one sense and one sense only: It is the monster of all monster movies, guaranteed to challenge weak bladders, flutter heartbeats and win automatic Oscars for the [tech crew].
With Eastwood as Kincaid and Meryl Streep as Francesca, this carefully observant love story turns Waller's pop-lit passion into screen art.
While drawing superb performances from her young leads, Holland has masterfully contrasted the garden -- a place where melodic robins seem almost conversant -- with the dread of Misselthwaite.

It's impossible to say whether Dave will play as wonderfully over the decades as it does right now, but this smooth-as-silk comedy could not be more timely, or connect more hopefully with our current national consciousness.

The fact that so much money was lavished on such a thick-headed project represents the height of fiscal ineptitude, but this is the kind of roller-coaster ride for which eager audiences will gladly check their brains at the turnstiles, so go figure.
"André Gregory: Before and After Dinner," is an insightful documentary/love letter directed by Gregory's second wife, Cindy Kleine, who married Gregory when she was 39 and he was 63.
movie_title: André Gregory: Before and After Dinner (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Sometimes it feels like you're rattling around in the fever-dreaming brain of the animator. It's glorious.
Ryder and Hawke bring crucial authenticity to their roles with effortless appeal. You'll find yourself wanting more of these characters than the movie gives you.
Johnson's savvy authority ensures that "Rewind This!" will leave many film-and-video lovers begging for more.

Romero himself is the film's highlight, appearing relaxed and funny in an entertaining interview.

movie_review_blurb: What you get, above all, is some enchanting flashes of classic Miyazaki and the nagging sense that something essential is missing.
