movie_title: The City of Lost Children (La Cité des Enfants Perdus) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: This is Allen's movie debut, and it's easy to see why his show is a ratings smash. There's an effortless quality to his humor, but it's also got a quietly urgent edge to it.
A flawed but essential film for its target audience.
You know the drill: A small group of unsuspecting adventurers wanders into danger, and not all of them will get out alive.
Unfortunately, the highlights are sporadic.
Ellis has broken every rule and emerged triumphant, creating a dark, cynical vision of problematic futures made bearable by an undying glimmer of hope for humankind.

A sci-fi thriller with no special effects, a cast of four and a single location used with Hitchcockian economy, Timecrimes boasts the kind of smart, resourceful filmmaking that champions ingenuity over spectacle.

Allen brings such conviction to the part that it's almost possible to look past the gaps in Mark's development. In the end, you may not buy each step he takes, but you respect Allen's attempt to make the effort seem genuine.
Considering its five-year production history, Late Bloomer is a regrettably scattershot affair.
It's a bit too convenient to credit Philibert's film with Proustian significance, but this particular remembrance has been constructed with similar profundity.

Long, masterfully executed shots accompanied by minimal dialogue and a richly expressive soundtrack; subdued performances punctuated by violent bursts of emotion; and a confident trust in the combination of stark realism and unadorned melodrama.

In adapting his novel and subsequent stage play, first-time writer-director Nic Balthazar seems more intent on impressing World of Warcraft gamers than honestly exploring the inner life of the mildly autistic boy at the center of his story.
Like the has-been it celebrates, this gentle comedy wears out its welcome by embracing mediocrity.

In telling the story of globe-trotting evangelist Arthur Blessitt, director Matthew Crouch allows Christian priorities to gloss over details that a more objective filmmaker would consider essential.
movie_title: The Cross(The Cross: The Arthur Blessitt Story) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Subtract Campbell from this movie's idiot-friendly equation and you've got just about any dimwitted horror comedy that's gone straight to video.

You couldn't ask for a less ponderous, more rollicking time.

Another delightful exploration of well-chosen subject matter that's more richly fascinating than you might first expect.
As an actor and now as a promising first-time director, Keaton's keen instincts serve him well.
Making a polished feature debut after directing shorts at the American Film Institute, Jordanian-born, American-educated Matalqa demonstrates a subtle touch with a well-chosen cast.

The stop-motion animated world of $9.99 is a marvel to behold.

A moving portrait of homelessness that's honest, respectful, heartbreaking yet warmhearted, and brimming with humanity.
movie_title: Great Speeches from a Dying World (2009)

There are simply too many marvels to tally.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A richly satisfying film that compassionately probes the human heart while preserving its elusive mysteries.

movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Although it glosses over a few relevant details, Trumbo also functions as a passionate defense of truth from a writer who embodied all of the virtues that America claims to value.

movie_title: The Girl Who Leapt Through Time (2007)

movie_title: Queen Of The Sun: What are the Bees Telling Us? (2011)

rasinski is sort of a low-grade Jimmy Stewart as a comic/dramatic actor. He's also, obviously now, a director other actors are delighted to work for.

It's all watchable to those of us in the Skeptics Tribe. I tacked on an extra half star to the star rating for this solely because of my outsized affection for a glorious section in the middle that I enjoyed as I have few other Star Wars side journeys.

movie_review_blurb: I prefer when it's witty and funny to when it's being melodramatic.
It took 35 years for a sequel to be made to Blade Runner. But it's a great movie sequel that dishonors no one -- least of all the audience.

This gimmicky serial-killer thriller is pretty laughable, despite the gruesome subject matter and its graphic, often nauseating gore.
The film doesn't go nearly as far in exploring its central concept as it could have, but much of this material is in extremely poor taste.
Foxx's spectacular, eerily accurate performance as Charles makes what would have been a rather sketchy movie better.
Passable, lightweight entertainment.
Payne and screenwriter partner Jim Taylor aren't afraid to let their characters look and act foolish, which is one of the reasons they feel so real.
It's hard to say which is worse in Christmas With the Kranks -- the lame attempts at humor or the even more lame attempts at sentimentality.
Filled with cringe-inducing, laughter-provoking moments, including more deliciously overripe performances than any single movie can possibly contain.
While some of the camera work is interesting, the film's mid-to-low budget is betrayed by the surprisingly shoddy makeup work.
It is a brave personal statement.
Nonsensical plotting, equally silly character interaction and groan-inducing dialogue.
Carrey, who plays three roles, his over-the-top turn here is actually appropriate for a change. But the young performers manage to hold their own with him.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: At its best when the title character is flying. When that character is on the ground, the film isn't nearly as successful.
The work of a filmmaker who's simply trying too hard, a filmmaker who's clearly straining to be funny, heartwarming and more than a little bit quirky.
[Bale's] haunted, sunken-eyed look will stay with you for days.
Strains credibility.
The deadpan nature of the film's humor is refreshing, and the cast seems to be having a blast.

Here's a film that manages to tell its tale without pandering, without cheap melodrama, without gimmicks and without big-name stars. Instead, it simply develops its characters and lets the drama unfold naturally.
This messy action-horror film is by far the most unpleasant, most unwatchable movie in what's already been a pretty sketchy trilogy.
For most of its two-hour running time, it's a pretty solid action yarn that echoes both the swordsman epics of Akira Kurosawa, as well as some of the Clint Eastwood Spaghetti Westerns.
movie_title: Warriors of Heaven and Earth (Tian di ying xiong) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This would-be wartime epic romance is so intent on setting a dream-like atmosphere that it fails to develop either the situation or characters in a convincing fashion.

If you can withstand the initial burst of salty language and severe dysfunction, there's a certain joy in seeing these characters get their just deserts. And not to give too much away, at least a couple of them do.
While the material itself has promise (it's an adaptation of Anne Holm's best-selling novel), this drama fumbles and stumbles its way to a resolution that's far too easy.
The lack of a really sympathetic or interesting main character makes the film version a bit of an endurance test.

With improved production values also come high expectations, especially in terms of storytelling. So when the plotting and a few of the performances are just so-so, it's hard not to think of the film as at least a bit of a disappointment.
The film will probably wring a few tears from even the most cynical, hard-hearted moviegoer.
The second time around around, none of this is nearly as fresh or lively.
It's presented well and doesn't feature anything like Moore's increasingly off-putting brand of sarcastic humor.
While this remake of the 2000 Japanese horror hit Ju-On gets the atmosphere right, its plotting is often eye-rolling silly.
A fine little film, filled with some astonishingly beautiful moments and some insights into the South American way of life.
Has an emotional honesty -- sometimes brutally so -- and real-life comic sensibilities that make it akin to television's late, lamented Freaks and Geeks.
If you're given the choice between seeing National Lampoon's Gold Diggers and death, you'd be wise to choose death.
Predictable and lacking any sort of edge.
A shallow melodrama that seems more suited to daytime television or one of those Lifetime cable network movies.
For the most part, such risky maneuvers work and give the whole picture a refreshing, unique feel.
Spy Captain may be an acquired taste. But for those who have an appreciation for old pulp serials and classic sci-fi, it's a real treat.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The two leads do elevate the material, especially Bettany, who has a winning presence. He may not be as charming as Hugh Grant, but he's considerably more believable in this part.
Takes a good premise -- one that's based on real-life events -- and turns it into a tired and overly familiar sitcom.
Wastes the talents of some very good actors.
You'd be able to laugh the whole thing off if it weren't so mean-spirited at times.
The film deserves to be seen, and its concepts deserve to be discussed in an open forum.
An artfully directed, well-acted bore.
Grows increasingly ludicrous over the course of its nearly two-hour running time, to the point where it almost appears to become a comedy.
It's executed poorly, with a lack of energy and spark.
If your pulse isn't pounding, maybe you need to check to see if you have one.
This film has some of the more astonishing scenes of individual combat in recent memory, even rivaling the superhero action sequences in Spider-Man 2.
This British drama gets increasingly lurid as it goes. And its handling of risque material is sensationalistic, even exploitative.
Suspect Zero is so derivative that it even has the audacity to rip off the credits style of Se7en.
The performances by the leads go a long way to make this believable. And there's no denying their chemistry.
The pacing is slack, and the increased level of blood and guts seems like a desperate move. And most of the special effects (especially the CGI work) are really shoddy.
This is Sayles' least coherent and certainly least satisfying film in quite some time.
It's frequently laugh-out-loud funny and surprisingly scary.
The performances are solid, and the film is just different enough to please open-minded audiences.
The whole thing would be pretty painful if not for the presence of Gong, who makes some of it watchable.
All the philosophical chattering here starts to become wearying. But the action scenes help, and there's no denying how dazzling the animation is.
Much of the material here doesn't translate well from book to film.
The film is extremely hit-and-miss.
Let's just say a lot has been lost in the translation.
A punchier script with more quips certainly would have helped Baptists become more than merely a mild diversion, and maybe more than just a local sensation.
An overreaching satire that even Lee's biggest fans will find disappointing.
It's simply repulsive and terribly unfunny.
A too-familiar tale.
While the twists at the end are a little more predictable here than in the first film, it's still an assured work, especially considering that it comes from a first-time director.
Given [the editing and jittery camera work], it's hard to know exactly how to feel about the film. Fortunately, the story is just compelling enough, its performances convincing enough, to help.
If it's possible, each successive Hilary Duff film seems to become more formulaic than the one before... just as each has become more predictable and treacly.
The film does have some very memorable moments. And Sanada's convincing performance as the world-weary former man of action certainly helps.
Going Upriver is talky, slow-moving and surprisingly superficial, more like a campaign informercial.
movie_title: Going Upriver: The Long War of John Kerry (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This overly busy deep-sea comedy throws in so many gags that it almost forgets to tell a story.
This satirical period piece settles for being mildly diverting and only sporadically amusing.
It's hard to come down too hard on this well-intentioned drama, as cornball and manipulative as it is at times.
A very well-assembled piece.
It does have Depp to buoy it up just long enough to keep audience interest alive until the film gets to the meat of the story -- the action.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Neither as shocking nor as enlightening as it obviously intends to be -- or as it believes itself to be.
The movie sometimes feels as if it's at odds with itself.

In a lot of ways, this film has what many of us wanted out of the third Matrix movie but didn't get: action, but with brains and actual characterization and without the ponderous, pseudo-spiritual mumbo-jumbo.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Goes awry from the minute it steps out of the cartoon world into the real one.
Seems set on making fun of Italians in the most heavy-handed manner possible.
Curiously, this weepy drama seems a little flatter, less involving, than it should. Especially with a cast like this.
Even though some of the situations and characterizations might seem extreme, the storytelling doesn't feel contrived. Again, it feels real.
The pacing's off in places as well, and the movie is flabby and lightweight, feeling every bit as long as its 130 minutes. But the performances are quite good.
This charming little holiday comedy is the movie equivalent of comfort food.
There's little real emotional investment here, despite the Wachowski Brothers' efforts to convince us otherwise.
Though some of Scott's editing decisions in this new version are questionable -- one even violates continuity -- he has left the film's most suspenseful and chilling moments intact.
Downbeat but surprisingly moving drama.
Clearly designed to appeal to fans of both the Indian and American houses of filmmaking. Unfortunately, it's so inept that it may appeal to neither.
Director Vladimir Michalek and screenwriter Jiri Hubac manage to strike a good balance between the comic and dramatic story elements, and the story isn't quite as predictable as you might think.

In the Cut manages to answer a question only a few of us were asking, and even fewer really wanted to know -- can a serial-killer movie be insufferably pretentious? Now we know. The answer is yes -- and how!
It's eminently forgettable and does represent Mouse House storytelling at its most formulaic, but it's still better than a great deal of what passes for animated entertainment these days.
Though some of Scott's editing decisions in this new version are questionable -- one even violates continuity -- he has left the film's most suspenseful and chilling moments intact.
Wonderland represents another low-rung on the downward descent of actor Val Kilmer.
Both Bacri and Dequenne are surprisingly effective in their performances and manage to sell us on their chemistry.
[An] excruciatingly unfunny live-action comedy.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: If you're not at least a little bit moved by some of the more heart-rending stories told here, you might need to have your (metaphorical) heart checked.
movie_title: Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The overwhelmingly dark tone and bleak subject matter make this one of the most difficult-to-watch films in recent memory.
One of the more effective recent feature films about the newsgathering process, even if it doesn't quite meet the standard set in 1976 by All the President's Men.
Even the weakest of these movies is head-and-shoulders above the vast majority of films churned out these days.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: As tempting as it is to describe the level of humor in Don't Tempt Me as hellish, that's probably giving the movie more credit than it deserves. Although describing anything in this dark comedy as heavenly is even more of a stretch.
movie_title: Sin noticias de Dios (Don't Tempt Me) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: While it's true that this 2000 romantic comedy is basically a Teutonic riff on the 1985 John Cusack comedy The Sure Thing, In July still has just enough twists and turns and is just light enough on its feet to stand on its own.
Keaton really is terrific, and her elegant Erica is one of the most endearingly sweet screen characters to come along in quite some time.
Stuck On You is endearingly goofy, and in many ways, it could be the sweetest, most affectionate film the Farrellys have ever done.

The peculiar story 'structure' and pacing may test the patience of those expecting a more traditional cinematic story, but those who can understand what director Gus Van Sant is trying to do here won't be disappointed.
Memo to Macaulay Culkin: When your latest cinematic 'comeback' attempt is a film like Party Monster, maybe remaining in career limbo wasn't such a bad idea.
Probably won't be of much interest to those outside of its target audience.
Gorlin supposedly based this material on some of his own experiences in Israel, but it still seems overly familiar.
The Weather Underground does as fine a job of getting into the heads of its subjects as any documentary in recent memory.
The only thing that separates Honey from cinematic turkeydom -- just barely -- is the dancing and the hip-hop/R&B soundtrack. Unless you're a fan of those, you're better off avoiding this one.
Despite some imaginative designs, The Haunted Mansion just sort of lies there, as if -- like some of its characters -- it is waiting to be roused from eternal slumber.

Though some of the content is questionable -- especially the whole 'brujo,' or American Indian witch, subplot -- the film is well-paced. And Howard does a nice job of keeping us in suspense about what's going to happen next.
For those who can take the constant assault on their senses and sensibilities, this grimy, unsavory movie is also one of the funnier holiday comedies to come along.
No film in recent memory has cried out this much to be mocked.
There's some powerful, thought-provoking material here that deserves considerably better treatment.
The film makes a convincing case that the seemingly antiquated play may actually be more relevant today than ever before. Who would have guessed?
The songs that are being lip-synched in The Singing Detective are in tune and on key, but very little else is in this nearly unwatchable musical-fantasy, based on the 1986 BBC television miniseries.

The plot is very familiar here, and despite his best efforts, Cruise seems very out of place. Yet Ed Zwick's direction is effective (much of that due to the spectacular visuals). And the supporting cast is terrific.
It's so full of cliches and pointless digressions that whatever it's trying to convey gets lost in a hurry.
Neither character comes off too well.
This is a thought-provoking film, and it features one of the best acting ensembles in awhile -- even by Sayles' standards.
While Buffalo Soldiers has its moments, it stumbles along the way and fumbles the ending.
Duplex plays out like a greatest-hits medley of films by its director, Danny DeVito. Which might not be so bad if he had a full body of films to draw from, rather than just a handful.
This adaptation of Frances Mayes' largely autobiographical best-seller is so predictable, so familiar, so episodic that it seems to belong on the small screen.
A B-movie that seems to be well aware of what it is.
It's so slowly paced, so flat-footed that it fails to engage on any level. Even for all but the most eager-to-please of audiences.
As every bit hard to watch as it is to turn away from. And that's really saying something.
The film tells its story in the flattest manner possible, a story that could have been fascinating and enthralling.
The victims of the crimes described in Senorita Extraviada cry out for justice. Just as their stories cry out for a more-focused, less superficial documentary than this one.
With Lost in Translation, director Sofia Coppola makes a serious bid to claim her last name for herself.
This filmed travelogue, a cinematic one-man's-diary -- or whatever you care to call it -- never really gives a reason for the audience to care about its subjects or its central thesis.
The film is full of shaky camera work, quick edits and supposedly arty touches.
It doesn't feel nearly as stale as you might think. In fact, many of its points about co-dependence and the meaning of commitment are constructive.
Two hours on the dot, feels more like two years.
Secondhand Lions doesn't have to do much to win us over.
Despite the intriguing premise, the filmmakers have chosen to concentrate their attention on gory action rather than characterizations and coherent storytelling.
[The] film is so sullen that it's more painful than a three-day family reunion with all of your least-favorite relatives.
Rogozhkin makes nearly all of his points with surprising subtlety.
This B-movie revels in its silliness, doing so with smarter humor than you'd expect.
If not for some odd, R-rated tendencies (such as strong profanity), this sappy, inconsequential character piece would seem more like something that should have shown up on the Lifetime cable channel.

This ineffectual, touchy-feely drama - essentially a Lifetime cable-channel movie with better production values and a name cast - is trying to pass itself off as quasi-feminist rhetoric, when it does as much as it possibly can to undercut those messages.
From start to finish, this documentary on the water-based board sport is filled with 'How did they do that?' moments.
One of the sweetest, most appealing comedies to come along in quite some time, and much of that can be attributed to Black, who reveals a considerably more tender side here.
For each silly gag or joke that works in Scary Movie 3, there are at least 10 more that don't.
The fact that the people responsible for this 1970s-period drama have made something so reprehensibly phony out of a true story makes you want to slap them silly.

The filmmakers claim they've tried to make something that will appeal to audiences outside of the usual LDS-film demographic -- yet it's filled with jokes and references that will only make sense to that audience.

It's not as if we really need another reminder about the importance of education. But it's still nice to see something like To Be and to Have, which manages to impart that message with subtlety and more than a little poignancy.
movie_title: To Be and to Have (Etre et Avoir) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A film with better intentions than execution.
It's safe to say that Leone has never in his career made anything as goofy -- or as sweet -- as this comedy.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the Midlands (2003)

movie_review_blurb: For audiences with an open mind -- and more than just a little tolerance for different opinions -- there are at least a few moments here worth watching.
A jewel of a film.

This dramatic thriller wastes some good performances, some snappy dialogue and some surprisingly tense pacing by falling back on some conveniently convoluted plotting and unlikely character development.
While Blanchett's performance as the title character is terrific, the film undercuts her at nearly every turn.
Fairly predictable and doesn't really feel either authentic or genuine.
A lame re-do of the 1974 cult classic that lacks not only the gritty and grim 'charm' of the first film, but also features little in the way of shocks, thrills or chills.
You may pull a muscle trying not to cringe as such long-time screen veterans as Shirley Jones, Cloris Leachman and Frank Gorshin embarrass themselves with over-the-top performances.
A nonsensical vanity project for singer Bob Dylan that wastes the talents of a lot of folks who should have known better.
While this material isn't necessarily up to the standards of Kurosawa's best work, it does warrant at least a look.
You could simply make a 90-minute-long film of dogs running around and it would be better than Good Boy! Much better, in fact.
One of the funnier comedies to come down the road in quite some time, and this sharply observant film also has surprising warmth and heart.
An adrenaline-fueled thrill ride that will satisfy even the most carnage-crazed action fan.
Most of the film is devoted to the central character, and thanks to Frot, she's a most likable heroine.

The film's ruminations about the meaning of terrorism and efforts to deal with it really resonate in the post-9/11 world. That makes this already-tense film all the more chilling and all the more memorable.
movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Fascinating and, at times, surprisingly moving.
To its credit, this one has its share of magical moments, even if they don't quite hit the highs of the Disney version.
This is nothing more than a lurid return to '70s blaxploitation.
When the best you can say about a sequel to a bad movie is that it's a tiny bit better, there are definite problems.
Probably the Coens' best since O Brother. It's certainly their most consistently entertaining film since then.

Does have a few things going for it, including some effectively dramatic plot points, as well as some unexpected twists.
The film's somewhat light-hearted tone is wholly inappropriate in what is, in essence, a story of sexual predators.
The film is rather unbelievable, even though it's based on real-life tales of the Vichy Milice.
It's hard to argue with any film that features so much footage of Chaplin at his best.
movie_title: Charlie: The Life and Art of Charles Chaplin (2004)

There is nothing really new or particularly insightful here, and even though Acts is at least watchable, it begins to fade from memory almost immediately.
The pairing of Carrey and Winslet may sound like a stretch, but both make it work with terrific performances.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: One of the scarier horror films to come along in quite some time.

Despite the efforts of both lead actors, as well as some rather contrived screenwriting by Alison Tilson, the romantic pairing of the somewhat effeminate Tsunashima and somewhat masculine Collette isn't really that believable.
[Depp's] amusingly idiosyncratic, yet surprisingly complex, performance goes a long way toward redeeming this otherwise sketchy film.
This supposed action-comedy is so staggeringly unfunny, unoriginal and uninspired that its title should have been Agent Cody Banks 2: Contractually Obligated Sequel.
The whole thing feels a bit scattered.

You don't exactly expect brilliance from a remake of a '70s action thriller, especially when the remake stars a professional wrestler. But Walking Tall still manages to exceed any and all expectations regarding its dumbness.
The constant winking at the audience does get a little tiresome, but for the most part, the film is a fun and thrilling action piece.
There is considerable charm and heart here.
There's quite a bit of the seen-it, done-it syndrome here.
It turns out Garner is a natural comedian with real presence. And, ultimately, her convincing performance is what makes 13 Going on 30 watchable.
Good Bye, Lenin! does a better job of summarizing the politics and recent history of Eastern Europe than you might think could be crammed into a movie that runs less than two hours.
A rich character piece with more than a few chuckle-worthy moments.
The Son takes forever to get going. And while that is a deliberate move by the filmmakers, Belgium's Dardenne brothers, it's still a problem.
Dull.
Things go as predictably as you'd expect, with the film simply meandering from one cabaret musical number to another before it finally gets around to the big showdown.
A brainless revenge-thriller that thinks it is smarter and more clever than it actually is.

Those who enjoyed the first Kill Bill will be surprised and entertained by this sequel, which nicely wraps up all the loose ends that were left dangling. At least when it's not assaulting your sensibilities.
There's no denying the subject matter is compelling, and the heightened sense of tension goes a long way toward redeeming the film.
It's possibly the laziest, lamest comedy to come along in awhile.
Raunchy but surprisingly warm and funny.
This flat-footed, tongue-in-cheek fantasy never really manages to garner more than a chuckle, despite its amusing premise, and at least a couple of promising gags.
It's a rather listless and self-involved documentary.
Thanks to Sharif's performance, this French-language import is made quite watchable.
movie_title: Monsieur Ibrahim et les fleurs du Coran (Monsieur Ibrahim) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A lot like love itself: sometimes messy, sometimes sweet, sometimes bittersweet, sometimes even painful.
It's nothing new to see a film that is better in concept than execution, or a film that wastes a talented cast. Sadly, The Reckoning does both.
The filmmakers would have been better off with a more direct, linear story line that might have allowed for some real character development.
The filmmaker misses too many opportunities by focusing too much on himself.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Drier and dustier than just about any academic-history text out there.
Amusing enough to please those looking for something silly, goofy and fun.
This is very different from what the Broken Lizard comedy team has done before. Refreshingly, so.
Garai is so wooden that she elicits more snickers from audiences than anything else.
Lazy and aimless.
To say that Theron's is an astonishing performance is something of an understatement.

The makers of this highly flawed science-fiction thriller have filled it with interesting concepts. Unfortunately, the majority of those have been executed so poorly that the whole thing becomes laughable.
Macy has played this kind of lovable-loser character so many times that he seems to be coasting.
Hamburg stoops to cheap toilet humor and dumb slapstick rather than exploring his characters.
Torque actually manages to outdumb such similarly brain-dead films as The Fast and the Furious (and its sequel) and Biker Boyz.
Surprisingly routine and listless.
It's as if in trying to tell an actual story the filmmakers have taken a large step backward.
It doesn't even live up to the low standards of the mid-'80s Breakin' dance movies.
The film seems to lose its way about midway through.
This comedy-drama is more of the formulaic, predictable and lightweight fluff [Moore's] been making all along.
Stickler has to be resourceful to tell this tale, and her storytelling methods are competent.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's refreshing that nearly all the tears here have been well-earned, with material that feels all too real, all too vivid and all the more moving as a result.
It features some of the most anguishing moments of any movie this year.

The performances ... are the saving grace for this sullen dramatic thriller, making it watchable, even when co-screenwriter/director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu does everything he can to sabotage their efforts.
Surprisingly mean-spirited, unfunny and features possibly the most annoying ensemble of child actors in recent memory.
Gives further proof of the eroding skills of filmmaker John Woo, for whom Paycheck is surely a career low.
A Civil War melodrama that never really has the emotional heft -- the oomph, if you will -- that audiences will expect.
Sentimental, even a bit treacly, but it's also appealing and full of warmth. And it's probably [Burton's] best film.
For those who are patient, there are quite a few things to admire, including the performances and the film's ambitious, audacious storytelling conceits.
Thuddingly unfunny.
This really is nothing new, and the cliched dialogue and one-note characterizations may have you wishing Altman had decided to make a documentary instead.
One of those rare movie sequels that's actually better than its predecessor.

Does have its share of very powerful moments, and it boasts some strong performances. Whether audience members will be able to concentrate on them amid the ultra-realistic and excruciating violence, however, is questionable.
Playing such a conflicted character isn't easy, but Neeson is up to it. And his convincing performance ensures that the film is watchable even when its main character is unlikable.
May be just interesting enough to hold the interest of most audiences.
Not only fascinating, it's important.
movie_title: The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Not only does this surprisingly warm and funny -- and well-acted -- comedy-drama stand head and shoulders above the most recent crop of LDS features, it's a film that may appeal to moviegoers outside its obvious target audience.
Much more tense and thrilling than most Hollywood thrillers.
Considering all the talented people involved with Welcome to Mooseport -- including a great cast -- you can't help but wish it were funnier. Even just a little bit.
It's a blast, thank you very much.
Inept in nearly every phase of filmmaking, the film's pace is lumbering, there's a shocking lack of authenticity and its messages are mixed at best.
If you didn't know better -- and if such things were even possible with a film like this -- you'd swear the filmmakers and cast of EuroTrip were simply making things up as they went along.

The performances are flat and lifeless (Cusick may look the part, but he has no real charisma), and even Christopher Plummer, as narrator, is less than lively, reading in an all too reverent monotone, suggesting even he's having a hard time staying awake.
Sandler and Barrymore somehow manage to make the picture work at least some of the time, but you will no doubt wish the material were better -- or at least higher minded.

If you have an open mind, and an appreciation of film animation, you will surely enjoy the film's clever gags, as well as the sensational blending of cel animation and computer-enhanced backgrounds and action.
Surprisingly lowbrow and hopelessly contrived.
Does at least make you want to find out more about Venezuelan politics -- as well as U.S. foreign policy regarding the country, so on that score it succeeds.
A stirring sports drama.
Cinematically, this is as aloof and clinical as a film can get.
This bit of fluff is unlikely to appeal to anyone outside of its obvious, intended target audience.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: There's no denying the film has its share of fascinating moments -- or that, on whole, it has a lasting power, especially its bleak, sucker-punch ending.
movie_title: Kandahar: Le soleil derrière la lune (2001)

movie_review_blurb: It's done so well ... that it's hard to know whom to really single out for praise here.
It's also a better -- no, make that far better -- movie than nearly everything else that's currently in theaters.
The movie takes 150 minutes to tell what should have been a 90-minute story.
Yet another 'buddy' or 'Odd Couple' cop movie that isn't particularly groundbreaking or memorable.

Strip it of its historical trappings, and Amistad is really just another courtroom drama -- a particularly manipulative one to boot.
This computer-animated comedy is much smarter than you'd be led to believe.
Superbly cast and well-acted.
Powerful and finely acted.
The film does become a fascinating portrait of the talented but mercurial Kinski.

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, all what we get is a movie version of Stern's show.
Logic is definitely not the strong suit of Pitch Black. But then, neither is consistent characterization, smart dialogue, originality, subtlety or any of the other benchmarks of quality filmmaking.
OK, this recycling thing has gotten way out of hand. Paper and aluminum products are one thing, but rehashing old movie ideas isn't going to help the environment in any way.
Talky and uneven but often funny romantic comedy.
Despite showing that she has a talent for writing clever dialogue, Jenkins quickly loses control over the story's direction.
We have seen Martin Scorsese's gangster films, and Abel Ferrara, you are no Martin Scorsese.
It has a life of its own, thanks to Wong's over-the-top blend of John Woo-like violence and almost surreal humor.

movie_review_blurb: This is one of the most gut-wrenching thrillers in recent memory, and it features a real sucker-punch ending.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Mortensen is very convincing as Nikolai, and his Russian accent is impeccable.
The few thrills it does have are outweighed by its rather dumb plotting and an overly familiar sense of style.
This is some of Brolin's best work to date, though the film still belongs to Bardem and Jones, whose low-key mannerisms are well-suited to the Coens' sensibilities.
Leans a little too heavily on the dumb, lowbrow stuff. And by the time it tries to redeem itself and its characters, it's nearly too late.
It is pretty talk-heavy, and a couple of performances are embarrassingly bad.
In the end, I Served the King of England is doomed to fail by comparison. Ironically, they are comparisons that the film itself keeps making.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Body of Lies nearly goes too far. As it is, this heavily political thriller becomes too serious and much too dark at times, and it doesn't seem to be serious enough when it really counts.
[Knightley's] credible performance is definitely one of the best things about this handsome looking-but-inconsistent biographical drama.
It's a bit too heady for its own good. And it doesn't help that the film is aloof and cold; it isn't exactly what you'd call enthralling.
[Fleder's] directorial bungling puts a terrible burden on the appealing cast.
It's refreshing to see a political documentary that's not just boosterism or political propaganda. If anything, this is an argument for 'cleaner' campaigning.
movie_title: Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [Harris's] performance as the usually quiet but quick-to-action gunman is terrific, and he's smart enough to leave much of the narration duties and such to the soft-spoken Mortensen.
Everybody deserves better than The Secret Life of Bees. That includes the filmmakers, the cast, the crew, the audience ... you name it.
Flash of Genius takes an uninteresting idea -- on the surface, at least -- and actually makes it even less interesting than it already would be.
It's very powerful but disturbing stuff.
Obviously the real star here is the artwork, which was spearheaded by director/lead animator Hayao Miyazaki.
The film remains an acquired taste at best.
Is it supposed to be funny, tragic or what? Even the characters don't seem too sure.
The film is filled mostly with talking-head interviews and very one-sided reporting. So it's lucky that these are subjects that are extremely topical right now, and are of interest as a result.

The plotting is a bit convoluted, and it relies on your knowledge of the earlier film. Still, it doesn't really get in the way of the action, which is why people pay to see these movies in the first place.
To be fair, the film is not horrible nor is it completely unwatchable. But it is mediocre.
There are some good performances. And it's definitely nothing like what we've come to expect from Claude Chabrol, a filmmaker who's been called the French Alfred Hitchcock.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: For the most part, the British comedy-drama Happy-Go-Lucky lives up to its title.
Role Models is about as irresponsible and as irreverent as a movie comedy can be.
It doesn't come like a full-length, filmed history lesson at all. In fact, it's a pretty fascinating, sometimes disturbing tale about the emotional and physical toll of combat.
Those with stronger sensibilities might enjoy themselves.
The comedy-drama not only boasts what might be [Hathaway's] best big-screen performance, it's one of the best things she's appeared in so far.
Zack and Miri Make a Porno offers more proof that Kevin Smith may have lost it. Whatever 'it' that he ever had in the first place.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There are parts of the film that are far more horrifying than anything the makers of the Saw features and other gruesome terrors could ever imagine.
While it probably won't appeal to a much wider audience than the one it already has, it does have a likable cast and a lot of energy.

Whatever points Pride and Glory was trying to make have been buried beneath layers of clumsy, good-vs.-bad posturings and peppered with R-rated language that's clearly supposed to remind us of films like The Departed.

Trouble the Water is probably the best of the films made on the subject. That's because the film concentrates on a few specific stories rather than trying to provide a comprehensive examination of its subject matter.
The material is thought-provoking and features some very good performances.
A big-budgeted bust that could prove to be an embarrassment to at least a few of the bigger-name actors in its cast.

This goofy, sporadically amusing satire is a career bounce-back of sorts. While [director Levinson] is not completely back on his game here, at least the film might make us forget about 2006's disastrous Man of the Year.
These days, even employing the traditional, 2-D cel style of animation seems like a quaint notion.
It may have been four years since the HBO television series Sex and the City halted production of original episodes, but the characters and material are still not ready for their big-screen close-up.
Is the whole thing preposterous? Yes. Is it a bit familiar and predictable? Possibly. Is it corny? OK, yes, a little bit. But again, it's fun and doesn't require too much thought.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's not as overwhelmingly dark and depressing as might be expected. Control is not particularly sunny, but there is some well-timed humor and it's well-acted.
Fred Claus wants to be both naughty and nice -- and still get some sort of present.

Director Ridley Scott and screenwriter Steve Zaillian try to develop each character equally, though it's really Washington's charismatic crook who holds our interest. That's not meant to slight Crowe, who's fine as well.
Kohn takes [risks] in this convoluted but fascinating documentary -- and most of those choices pay off.
Screenwriter/director Goran Dukic can't quite decide on a tone. The film is at times lighthearted, almost effervescent, and then it's so dark that it becomes depressingly bleak.
Unfortunately, the second half of the movie gets pretty messy, and the sudden tonal shifts (things go from light comedy to dark drama) are a bit jarring.

This digitally animated feature is not a great movie, but it is colorful, imaginative and solid entertainment. In many respects, it's more educational and more exciting than it is laugh-out-loud funny.
It's hopelessly and ridiculously contrived. There are things here that make some of the plotting in your average Scooby-Doo episode seem more plausible.
This Israeli-made drama is perhaps too overtly political for its own good.
Screenwriter Thomas Lemmer and director Alex LeMay appear to have some sort of agenda or ax to grind.

Director Gillespie and screenwriter Nancy Oliver keep the tone pretty light for about the first two-thirds of the film, though it does take a rather dramatic turn toward the end. And for the most part, it works.
Whether you will enjoy this movie depends on your tolerance for Anderson's unique sensibilities.
Dan in Real Life is a pretty warm, genuine comedy that succeeds, at least in part, because of some gutsy casting choices.
Given all the early furor about the film's NC-17 rating and its much-discussed sex scenes, Lust, Caution seems curiously sedate and unexciting.
It's certainly not terrible, but why the filmmakers didn't just ship it straight to video or cable is anyone's guess.
This fact-based drama pulls off a fairly tricky feat -- it's touching, thoughtful, sad, funny, sweet and ultimately redemptive -- and all at once.
While you might not agree with all -- or any -- of the movie's conclusions, there's no denying that it's effective and often intelligent filmmaking.
movie_title: For the Bible Tells Me So (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fascinating but unsettling.
Misses more comic targets than it hits.
Those who agree with its sentiments likely felt that way going into the movie. And the film is so talk-heavy and strident that it becomes overwhelming and a bit of a bore.
Though the filmmakers probably believe it becomes some sort of female-empowerment vehicle in the end, it's really just another thriller that relishes in the victimization of women.
Smith is, as always, a likable hero, and his unforced performance is definitely a saving grace.
There is one surprise -- it's not as eye-gougingly awful as you might expect. It's simply mediocre and immediately forgettable.
While you can appreciate what the choir and the film are trying to say, too often they get bogged down in trying to spread that message. They also take themselves a little too seriously at times.
This mediocre film that is heavy on computer-generated imagery adds up to little more than the Yawn-icles of Narnia.
The rather limited outcast-comedy premise is already tapped out. So this painfully unfunny film seems considerably longer than its scant 90-minute running time.
Hitman was based on a video game, which tells you everything to know about this film. Well, that and the fact that it was originally conceived as a vehicle for Vin Diesel.
It's a messy, ultimately depressing horror film that feels like an overlong episode of TV's The Outer Limits or The Twilight Zone.
Those who loved the Clash or Strummer will be enthralled throughout.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The performances are surprisingly lackluster. Witherspoon practically sleepwalks through the whole thing, as does Gyllenhaal.
It's well-acted but also a bit long and will probably be of less interest to those who aren't already fans of Dylan or his music.
There are some enchanting aspects in Enchanted -- the most enchanting being Amy Adams.
The film has major story construction problems, somehow managing to be overlong yet sketchy.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Bella turns out to be a clumsy message movie, one that leaves a lingering bad taste, whatever your beliefs regarding its highly divisive subject, abortion.
While the cagey old pro does manage to hold our interest throughout, Law badly flounders in the sort of vehicle that seems tailor-made for him.
Darfur Now does one thing other documentaries on the region in western Sudan haven't done so far: It offers hope that something substantive may be done about the Darfur genocide.
The film has just enough charm to win over at least a few in the audience, even if it's not quite as wondrous as its title might have you believe.
Amir Bar-Lev's feature-filmmaking debut is easily one of the most fascinating documentaries you'll see all year.
All the digital bells and whistles in the world can't conceal how hollow the movie is at its core or make us forget about its storytelling and dialogue deficiencies.
So ridiculous and sappy that it defies the best efforts of a pretty good cast.
The filmmakers have tried to expand the original source material by adding more characters to the mix. But as a result, it actually feels character-thin and a little sketchy.
Conflicted but well-acted.
It takes forever for the film to even get to the start of the baseball season. But once it does, it's pretty engaging.

A painfully unfunny and mean-spirited comedy, in which Billy Bob Thornton simply plays the same acerbic jerk character he's been playing since Bad Santa, and jockish Seann William Scott tries to pass himself off as a former high school loser.
Three of the comic segments in The Ten are sort of funny. Three others are just so-so. And the remaining four are just dumb, painfully unfunny and/or downright crude.
Those who don't need all that graphic content to be jolted and unnerved may find a few things to like here.
[Shane] Meadows' fictionalized version of these events is at least as vivid -- and at times as hard to watch -- as some of Ken Loach's more stark dramas.
Like the best art, documentary films can provoke strong emotions -- and The Devil Came on Horseback is definitely provocative.

Despite some quality performances, from both Foster and her co-star, Terrence Howard, The Brave One is every bit as ludicrous and every bit as wrong-headed and distasteful as those other [vigilante] films.

There is something perversely appealing about this film. Maybe it's the way Interview astutely comments on celebrities and our perceptions of them, as well as questioning the sincerity and truthfulness of the media.
The cast is very good. The chemistry between Duris and Morante smolders, while Luchini makes a convincing, bungling aristocrat.
It's about time to say that Heder's 15 minutes of fame have run out. He's simply regurgitating the same one-note, doofus shtick he's been milking since Napoleon Dynamite, and it's gotten tiresome.
For those who can stand the nonstop assault on their sensibilities, it's delightfully trashy, albeit irresponsible.
By making the film more graphic, Zombie has also made it considerably less scary and effective than Carpenter's version.
Kong has more humor, more drama and more humanity than all of the summer's top 10 movies combined and even delivers some sly commentary on how out of whack American priorities have become.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Ghosts of Cite Soleil is a curiously unfocused, rambling film that never really settles on exactly what it wants to say or exactly which stories it wants to tell.
The film almost overwhelms the audience with information, throwing out so many facts and figures, and so much footage, that it's all hard to process.
In the more sensational and gruesome aspects, the film fails miserably, getting more ridiculous and unbelievable as it goes along.
It's clear that Balls of Fury is trying to be dumb-funny... But Balls of Fury -- is much dumber than it is funny.
The underwater parts of Eye of the Dolphin are kind of pretty. Unfortunately, the rest of this waterlogged drama is pretty ugly.
The luxuriously paced period drama is nearly three hours long and feels every bit of it.

This tense character piece offers proof that Hollywood can still make a good, traditional Western, rather than emulating the revisionist Westerns that have followed in the wake of Clint Eastwood's 1993 Academy Award-winner Unforgiven.
Well-acted and reasonably engaging period piece. And it suggests Keira Knightley is at her best when she's in "costume dramas" such as this.
In the process of trying to provide audiences with a serious inspirational message, the makers of Return With Honor eventually turn this earnest but misguided film into an unintentional comedy.
movie_title: Return With Honor: A Missionary Homecoming (The Return) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Sydney White is actually one of the better Amanda Bynes vehicles. Yes, it is silly, and there's more sexually suggestive humor than you might prefer. But there's also some charm to it all.
The film is really at its best when it's dealing with the dysfunctional father-daughter relationship. Douglas and Wood's believable character dynamic certainly helps.
Despite all the film's plentiful talk, it never feels overplotted or convoluted ... or really all that talky. In fact, it's a rather taut, well-plotted and directed feature.
This is pretty heady stuff, and it's constantly enthralling, particularly for something that has to use so much second-hand information.
This dramatic crime-thriller never lives up to that potential. In fact, it's considerably less than the sum of its parts.

Screenwriter John Hodge and director David Cunningham's adaptation seems all too derivative of Star Wars, Harry Potter and The Lord of the Rings, and it takes itself more seriously than any of those -- much too seriously.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Alan Arkin has the enviable ability of making nearly everything he's in watchable. Sadly, Raising Flagg sorely tests that ability.
This is a film that can't quite decide if it wants to be a show-business spoof, a romantic comedy or an embarrassment comedy along the lines of HBO's Curb Your Enthusiasm.
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Milarepa is surprisingly flat and unexciting.
Chuck actually goes much further and becomes more sexually crude than Apatow's work, and its attempts to become redemptively cute are way too saccharine.
The Jane Austen Book Club simply doesn't know when to shut up. That's true -- for the movie as a whole and for the characters.

The self-indulgent 12:08 East of Bucharest certainly takes its time getting to the point. In fact, the first third of this film could have been trimmed without much damage. And this Romanian comedy-drama is only an hour and a half in length.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The whole movie [feels] like it was designed to be a nearly two-hour counterpoint to the nightly news.
Overly familiar, and at nearly two hours overstays its welcome by a good 15 or 20 minutes.
Almost overwhelmingly dark and downbeat, which nearly makes the whole thing unwatchable.
Muddled, overlong.
An enthralling documentary.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Far too often these days, documentary filmmakers try to push their own political agendas on audiences by ridiculing those who have different views from their own. Happily, that's not the case with Anthem.
An involving character piece and mystery/thriller, albeit a tad slow.

The Heartbreak Kid, not only reunites [the Farrelly bros.] with Mary star Ben Stiller, it also restores -- and arguably ups -- the raunchiness. So much so, in fact, that it becomes exceedingly uncomfortable and grotesque.
It's pretty good-natured, sweet and rather goofy.
Man From Plains is ho-hum and uninvolving, which is a surprise, considering the seeming wealth of material.
The movie version of The Kite Runner succeeds in at least one respect: It does make you want to check out the source material to see what has been glossed over.

Despite the number in its title, this odd but sometimes entertaining documentary/docudrama hybrid looks at seven defendants who were accused of organizing the protests and orchestrating the resulting mayhem.
Laid-back actor Reeves is thoroughly unconvincing, and so is the film as a direct result.
The Ruins offers further proof that what works on the printed page doesn't necessarily work on the big screen.
It's hard to feel anything but frosty sentiments towards this melodrama, a rather chilly adaptation of Stewart O'Nan's well-regarded novel.
There are some thrilling sequences, but it's equally groan-inducing as well.
The film does have its sweetly appealing moments as well. And the cast is good.
As far as recent concert films are concerned, Shine a Light fits neatly between the U2 3D and the Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert movie.
It's surprisingly, refreshingly effective at times, and it is old-fashioned in several respects.

Bag Boy, the latest film produced and released by the once-proud National Lampoon organization, was shot and set in Utah. Thankfully, it won't be seen by enough audiences to damage the state's reputation.
Like a seriously troubled gambling addict, 21 shows its hand too early and then stays at the table too long for its own good.
While [Pegg] gets some mileage out of this sketchy material, he's undermined by story and character problems, as well as the limp, uninspired direction of actor-turned-filmmaker David Schwimmer.
The Iraq war drama has its share of very effective, subtle moments but then follows them up with some crushingly heavy-handed commentary.
While there is still some questionable humor, and there are some tasteless sexual references, the film is very sweet and recalls the cultily adored 1980 hit My Bodyguard in almost all the right ways.

The movie is so overly familiar, and its take on the dysfunctional family dynamics is so unoriginal, that the whole thing might as well have been titled Generic Bleak Sundance Film Festival Drama No. 500.
Surprisingly, the movie is not terrible. In fact, it's watchable -- if you can stand the sight of people pummeling each other.

Unlike some recent 'torture-porn' movies, this film leaves the most reprehensible moments unseen (much of the violence is overheard). However, all that shows is that a film can be somewhat restrained and subtle and still be in bad taste.
George A. Romero's Diary of the Dead proves there's still some life left in the veteran filmmaker's long-running, zombie-movie series.
This inconsistent but sporadically entertaining comedy-drama does feel a little clinical and icy, though eventually it does warm up a bit. The good cast certainly helps.
It's doubtful whether even a dream team of Hollywood's best and brightest creative minds could have come up with a tale that's more fascinating or more inspirational than Blindsight.
The real 'trick' or feat that's successfully performed by The Counterfeiters is making us care about a character who, on the surface at least, isn't particularly likable or sympathetic.
This could be the single dumbest movie to be released yet this year, which is no small feat. It's definitely the worst thing Al Pacino has been involved with in quite some time.
The ensemble drama has some modest charms, which includes a surprising, old-fashioned sweetness and interpretation of romance.
The shame here is, it's not a terrible movie. It's just pretty amateurish in terms of the direction and some of the performances.
It's a well-acted piece that finds a unique way to discuss the fortunes of soldiers and their families during times of war.
An uneasy mix of Baby Mama, My Big Fat Greek Wedding and a few of Woody Allen's domestic comedies, and is even messier than that makes it sound.

On whole, this fantasy adventure does feature more action and is more exciting, arguably, than its predecessor, the 2005 film adaptation of C.S. Lewis's Chronicles of Narnia book, The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There's something really enjoyable about seeing a group of 70-something, 80-something and 90-something amateurs performing with the energy of people who are half -- or even a quarter -- of their age.
The Visitor may not have any big names in its cast, but it certainly makes up for that by having a lot of character.
Despite the presence of some likable, funny people, it's a painfully unfunny romantic comedy that makes you dislike those same people intensely.
Those who are patient will be rewarded with an engaging cast and the type of rousing ending that makes it worthwhile.
At two-plus hours, Speed Racer really isn't longer than your average NASCAR race or an extended road-rally event. It just feels like it is.

It seems irresponsible, if not downright stupid, for the makers of any movie to call their feature Flawless. But the most current film to sport that risky title has a number of serious storytelling flaws.
Overly familiar and predictable. Its debts to both When Harry Met Sally and My Best Friend's Wedding are considerable.
This exciting, enthralling action-thriller is certainly the best comic book-based movie since the second Spider-Man film.
The jokes that actually work successfully in Harold & Kumar Escape From Guantanamo Bay are the same ones that worked in its predecessor
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While to many audiences it might seem bizarre and out there, it's perversely watchable.
The only reason it works as well as it does -- or that it even works at all -- is because of its star, former SNL head writer Tina Fey, who's really turning into an endearing comic performer.
Features some very big laughs and is considerably sweeter than the trailers would make it seem.
While some of this material was drawn from Chinese legends, it still feels a bit half-hearted and as if it was cobbled together from bits of other movies.
Despite a few bits of low-key humor and some cheeky bits, the mostly charming film is actually meant to be taken seriously. And there are some poignant, surprisingly tender moments.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! is by far the best of the recent movie features that were based on late author and artist Theodor Seuss Geisel's beloved children's books.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This comedy is a painful and disingenuous attempt to turn the formerly hard-partying, R-rated comedian Martin Lawrence into a cuddly, family-friendly film star.
As usual, the yearly compilation of Oscar-nominated, shorts cartoons is a mixed bag.
[Dominic Fine's] camera captures beautiful Ugandan locations -- and some equally beautiful character moments. The film ends on a surprisingly upbeat note.
It's not completely awful. But it lacks the necessary suspense and the only thing that really holds it together are the performances.
This charmless, mediocre romantic comedy with supernatural overtones is nearly laughless.
U2 3D is the next best thing to being at one of the group's shows, and a ticket will cost you about a tenth as much.
For a good two hours, the drama is pretty riveting stuff. A seemingly hasty, rushed and ridiculous finale does end things on a particularly unsatisfying note, though.
This science-fiction/thriller is smart enough to wrap things up quickly. At less than 90 minutes, it's a lean, mean monster movie -- even if it's gimmicky filmmaking makes it an acquired taste.
Calling 27 Dresses predictable is putting it mildly. From the opening scene, it's painfully obvious exactly where the film is going and how everything is going to turn out.

Billy may come off as an odd duck, but he's not mean or too peculiar. Actually, he's pretty likable, which is why you'll probably find yourself rooting for him to get the girl and to be happy for a change.
One of the most challenging films in the recent memory...However, it's definitely worth it to stick with the film.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Features a few decent chills and has a distinctive tone and look.
...filled with laugh-out-loud gags, witty dialogue and geniune emotion.
It's the cast that really makes it work
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This fact-based drama is well-intentioned but gets a little bogged down in the details.
Those with strong stomachs will find this darkly comic piece is not just a bloody mess. Instead, it's bloody good fun.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A mostly amusing film that features smart performances and even-smarter dialogue.
Reilly is likably goofy, which goes a long way to redeeming the film.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An at-times grueling, dysfunctional family comedy-drama that is not for the emotionally squeamish.
P.S. I Love You commits several cinematic blunders, but the biggest one may be its attempt to turn Hilary Swank into a romantic lead.
Director Rob Reiner and screenwriter Justin Zackham's tale gets a little too caught up in the various shenanigans Edward and Carter get into.
We've seen most -- if not all -- of this done before, and done much better, in both the first film as well as the Indiana Jones movies.
The film works on multiple levels: as a history lesson, as a primer on Middle Eastern politics and as an artist biography.
Untraceable? Unappetizing is more like it - or perhaps unrealistic, unconvincing and/or unexciting.
These are characters the feel believable and are engaging.
Ultimately, we're not really interested in seeing whether there are any happy endings for any of these people.
A lot of actresses might have shrunk from the challenge of matching her performance, but McDormand is terrific. And her British accent is subtle enough to work.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [Anamaria Marinca's] convincing performance as the clearly conflicted Otilia holds our interest throughout the film.

It's the three leads who really make this material work. Lange is very sympathetic and relatable as Arvilla, while Bates injects some needed humor. And Allen is pitch-perfect as usual, as the film's moral center of sorts.

This '70s-period sports comedy is only funny about half of the time and seems like an uneasy film hybrid. Half the time it's trying to be a Will Ferrell vehicle, and half the time it's trying to rip off of earlier, better movies.
This overstuffed bit of fluff can't muster much in the way of excitement. It offers a yawn-inducing, sketchy and fairly questionable version of historical events.
Waste[s] the talents of a very good supporting cast and has so few laughs in it that it almost defies categorization as a comedy.
Screenwriter/director Tamara Jenkins (Slums of Beverly Hills) is smart enough not to try to redeem any of these people - at least not in the traditional, cinematic sense.
While there are a few goofy moments, it turns much too serious about midway through and loses a lot of the initial good will as a result.
It's not nearly as funny as its premise would suggest, and the movie even becomes a little dull when it tries to make a few points about the differences between commercialism and art.

Those who can withstand the verbal assault on their sensibilities will be rewarded. The film features some very good performances, as well as an interesting take on the morality and mental strain of being a killer.
It certainly helps that he has a very good cast. Reynolds has chemistry with all three female co-stars, while Breslin and an uncredited Kevin Kline steal scenes.
It's Christensen's lumberlike performance and some really dumb plotting and dialogue that the film will probably be remembered for most.

The best fantasy movie to come along in a while. Spiderwick is miles better than the yawn-inducing adaptation of "The Golden Compass." It's smart, thrilling and funny, and it even features a good message about the importance of family.
In several respects, Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show is a better documentary than it is a comedy concert film.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It was bad enough when Martin Lawrence humiliated himself in such noxious comedy hits as Big Momma's House, National Security and Wild Hogs.
This charmless romantic comedy-adventure is pretty dumb -- dumber even than the recent National Treasure sequel, if that's possible.
This action/suspense-thriller is hopelessly convoluted and contrived. The filmmakers are clearly trying to duplicate the style and feel vastly superior television series 24.

This one is not just a series of personal, one-sided attacks, as Moore's film seemed to be. Instead, filmmaker Charles Ferguson uses interviews with former Bush administration officials, journalists, former soldiers and others to make his case.
The movie packs a powerful, emotional punch, and it resonates strongly, especially considering the continuing unrest in the Middle East.
It's complex and fascinating. It also has a real ring of truth to it.

Make no mistake about it, Panic has some merits. It's unlike anything currently being done in the animation realm. Unfortunately, it lacks the playfulness and endearing qualities of its clay-animated kin...
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's just enough over-the-top action in this revenge-thriller. In fact, the action is enough to right this vehicle even when the plotting gets a little sketchy or convoluted.
Obviously, the dark nature of the story will turn off some audiences. But the film will appeal to those who love the thriller genre...
The Back-up Plan wants to be cute. But more often it settles for being cutesy. And more often still, it's off-puttingly crude.
The one real problem is the rambling narrative and some too-intrusive voiceover narration. (Brosnan is fine, but frankly, the pictures do a better job of speaking for themselves anyway.)
Screenwriter/director Conor McPherson keeps switching directions. And eventually, this zigging and zagging becomes tiresome.
The humor is more subtle than you'd think. And we wouldn't mind seeing more of this type of thing from both Duchovny and Moore.
Director Niels Arden Oplev and two credited screenwriters have trouble resolving all of this and putting a somewhat happier spin on the story and characters at the end.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Say what you will about the subtler European style of humor not translating overseas, at least it's more tolerable than this sort of over-the-top nincompoopery.
The final segment is as cliched and as predictable as any of the many films that have chronicled the rise and fall of well-known musical figures.
The film could have benefited from a more straightforward style of story telling and not co-screenwriter/director Marco Bellocchio's gimmicky, almost fantasy-like stylings.
