movie_review_blurb: While the performers do what they can with the material, we've seen this premise done too many times, especially recently.
Refreshingly, Mouret also shows that marital infidelity is not without serious repercussions.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: You should probably turn your "brain wattage" down in order to enjoy this silly science-fiction thriller.
That the movie manages to avoid some of the customary cliches and formulaic machinations of the sports drama genre makes the film rewarding, as do the performances by its mostly fresh-faced cast.
The oddness is sort of refreshing.
A nice antidote to the action-comes-first style of filmmaking that dominates movies this time of year.
The plotting here is so convoluted and so far-fetched that it makes the conspiracy elements in the National Treasure movies look plausible by comparison.
There's nothing really appealing or funny about these people or the predicaments in which they find themselves.
This flaky French import can't stick to one story and can't find a way to resolve its myriad story lines in the proper fashion.
It probably wouldn't work at all without [Caine]. He's so charismatic and so watchable that we can forgive the film's occasional lapses in logic and storytelling.
When it works, it's well. When it doesn't, it seems unfocused and nearly loses our interest.
If you cut the extraneous parts of Love n' Dancing -- you know, all the ones except for the dancing scenes -- it might not be a half-bad movie.
Much of it is done so clumsily that the characters verge on becoming caricatures.
Battle for Terra shows that you need more than computer-generated graphics to make a quality animated movie these days.
While it might not be as much of a cinematic train wreck as 2006's X-Men: The Land Stand, it's not quite the rousing, spectacular summer movie season opener we were hoping for, either.

This romantic comedy/fantasy goes exactly where we expect it to go. (And that can't be considered a serious plot 'spoiler'. Anyone who's ever seen a movie fantasy will be able to predict this film's ending.)
No other movie (documentary or feature film) has featured as many "wow!" moments as this one does in quite some time.
This Trek is an exciting, constantly entertaining feature that helps kick off this year's summer movie season in spectacular fantasy.
Watching talented, funny people like Zachary Levi, David Cross and Wendie Malick go from one demeaning and painfully stupid situation to the next is excruciating.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie does satisfy the cravings for a smarter sci-fi movie and does have some rewarding aspects.
As film starts taking itself more and more seriously, it becomes less fun and more formulaic and tiresome.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: At 160 minutes, it's too long. And this isn't exactly brainy fare. If you think too hard about this dopey science-fiction thriller, you'll surely find fault with its physics and similarly sketchy plotting.

Surprisingly sexual in nature, and not just because it seems so concerned with the sex practices of the elderly. There's too much of that sort of material here and not nearly enough of the stuff we really want to see.
Filmmakers usually mature over time. Jared Hess, on the other hand, appears to be getting more juvenile.
There's a lot to like here. The film looks beautiful, and Alexandre Desplat's score is suitably moody.
The film may remind some of the low-key and decidedly quirky comedies by the Coen brothers. And not just because George Clooney is one of its featured performers.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's an incoherent, would-be martial-arts epic with only a handful of action sequences in its favor.
A more accurate title for The Fourth Kind would be Close Encounters of the Worst Kind.
It's an unengaging, dull adaptation that has nothing really new to say in regards to the already-much-told tale.
Just when you thought you'd seen everything that could possibly be done with vampires, along comes something like Thirst.
You can't really argue with a film that tells us we should be good to one another, celebrates the importance of family and suggests we should live our lives to the fullest.
Its plotting leans more toward silly, soap opera-ish machinations, and while Banderas is as charming as ever, there are a couple of crucial bits of miscasting.

The release of the movie within only a couple of months of his death seems a little bit like a cashing-in move, and it is eerie to see Jackson again so soon. Still, fans of him and his music will find a lot to like here.

The adaptation of Darren Shan's best-selling book series is confused muddle of a movie. The filmmakers can't decide on whether they want it to be a comedy, a horror, a coming-of-age tale, a good-vs.-evil parable or a combination of all of those things.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film's penchant for dorky nostalgia -- especially '70s and '80s-era music -- quickly becomes irritating. It deserves a real tongue-lashing for trying to re-introduce the inexplicable Mr. Mister hit "Kyrie" into the American consciousness.
This animated adaptation of the Japanese comics characters and concepts appears to have been cobbled together from parts of other, better movies.

Swank makes it look easier than it probably should be. She's equally charming and vulnerable, which were evidently a couple of the traits of the real-life Earhart. And that's a good thing, because the film often sputters, sways and wobbles...
It's a faithful but occasionally downbeat fantasy-drama. And it really looks great.
One of the few fresh breaths of air out there, cinematically. This well-acted ensemble piece argues in favor of free speech without becoming too heavy-handed and ponderous.

This follow-up is a little more spotty and unfocused than the first film. That we're this interested in their further exploits has more to do with their goofiness than it does with the quality of footage editing, assembly and such.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Attempts by director Chris Weitz and screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg to inject more humor and lighten the tone go horribly awry. (The supposedly "serious" dialogue is funnier than any of their pop-culture references and such.)

Nothing in Mo'Nique's previous film and television work could have prepared us for this performance. The actress (real name, Monique Imes) usually plays goofy, clownish types, and this is definitely not that at all.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Obviously, it's not really a pleasant cinematic experience, despite the quality of its filmmaking and performances. It's worthwhile for its character development and its examination of morality and survival behavior, though.
The acting ensemble is good, top to bottom. Clooney might be playing a thinly veiled version of himself here, but he's well-matched with Farmiga, who brings some needed warmth and sex appeal.
McKay's blustery but believable performance is one of the more memorable supporting turns in any film this year.
A grueling, unpleasant exercise in cinematic sadism.
This digital world feels like a video game environment and, in the 3-D format at least, begins to create visual overload. The film's performances are also very inconsistent.
The absence of any really likable characters in the film is troublesome. Over the course of the movie, we become less interested in finding out what happens to any of these people.
Of course, there are a few unfortunate moments -- such as some character stereotyping and a couple of silly crass jokes. But it's also tune-filled and fun, and it's very well animated.
Crude unfolds like a pretty good legal thriller. Which, when you really think about it, is what this documentary feature is.

[Modine] seems too tentative and blase to work as the film's lead. Especially since he's paired with the vibrant Scott. She definitely deserves a chance to work again, with someone as committed to film chemistry as she clearly was.
Eastwood's direction seems unsure and tentative, and the inclusion of a pop song -- the overbearing "Colorblind" -- is an obvious attempt to sell a few soundtrack discs.
Co-screenwriter/director Oren Moverman slowly peels back the layers to the characters, with the game cast helping considerably in that regard.
If a film that's as over-the-top violent and gory as Ninja Assassin can't get an NC-17 rating from the Motion Picture Association of America's ratings board, it's unlikely any film will.
At least Luis Guzman and Dax Shepard were smart enough to avoid being credited for their roles in it.

This is certainly the funniest animated feature so far this year, as well as one of the most sly ones to boot. (But be warned that it's not really a kids movie. There is some potentially upsetting material and imagery.)
Five Minutes of Heaven is actually 75 minutes worth of buildup to an ending that's much more fizzle than sizzle.
Planet 51 doesn't have enough plot for a 10-minute animated short, much less a 90-minute feature. And unfortunately, what it does have plenty of is crude, lowest-common denominator humor.

In what is her first but certainly not last starring role, Mulligan is so natural that you wonder why it took filmmakers so long to give her a role this substantive. The 20-something is sure to be on the mind of Oscar and other awards voters.
Yes, this feel-good sports/biographical drama is predictable and by-the-numbers. Yet for the most part, this cinematic "comfort food" goes down pretty well.
The movie feels tentative and strained. It's one of the bigger cinematic disappointments of late.
The film is pretty superficial in its reporting and is by-the-numbers in its storytelling. If the subjects weren't interesting, the movie would be a complete snore.
When the film works, it works really well. It certainly doesn't hurt that it features Owen, an actor who's capable of making almost anything watchable.
A confused, contrived mess that would be laughable if it weren't so noxious and mean-spirited.
For all its flaws and despite the limiting premise, this music-themed drama works better than it should.

Francis Ford Coppola has never been the most subtle or unpretentious of filmmakers. But if anything, he's gotten even more self-indulgent and stuffy ever since he set his sights and cameras on Europe and South America.
If anything, the story elements are overly familiar and too predictable.

The movie is surprisingly dry and flavorless. It certainly doesn't help that filmmaker Jeffrey Levy-Hinte put this collection of footage together without any narration and with a bare minimum of narrative captions.
Beltran tries to give this flimsy nonsense some weight, but Brits McNulty and Pattinson's attempts at a Spanish accent are woeful.
The only thing that prevents the entire thing from becoming an unpleasant mess is Zahn, an often comic character actor who has an endearing goofiness to him and to his performances.
In the final 30 or so minutes it turns deadly serious, which is about the only time this mess gets any laughs.
Extract won't win [Judge] any new converts, obviously. But when the film gets laughs they're fairly healthy ones.
It will likely test the limits of some viewers, though those with patience may find a few things to like. There's definitely no shortage of ideas, that's for sure.
A very good cast of actors gets more mileage out of this material than they probably should have.
It's a confused muddle, and as a result, the film never really finds its footing -- and it never seems to have any narrative momentum.
There's something surprisingly perceptive about the way the film looks at male relationships and friendships.

This politically savvy, satirical piece deserves to be seen by as many people as possible. The way the film shows governmental 'war rooms' as being beset by petty, personal conflicts is positively enlightening.
What switches Post Grad from the ranks of the merely mediocre films to the lower rungs of really awful ones is its misuse of a lot of talented and funny people.
It's a brightly colored headache of a movie with lowbrow humor and obnoxious characters that will be just as much of an irritant to children as it is to their parents.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's talky, foul-mouthed, over-the-top and probably too long by at least a half hour. However, those who enjoy Tarantino's brand of off-the-wall filmmaking and those who can withstand this film's constant assault on their sensibilities will be just fine.
While it's pretty effervescent for the first hour, things really take a dire turn toward the end. The whole thing nearly becomes undone at that point.
You certainly hope that the humility Mike Tyson is showing these days is genuine and not just an act.
It's debatable whether the real Woodstock was as messy as Taking Woodstock, which re-creates parts of that now-legendary 1969 music festival experience.
Miyazaki fans who are expecting the deeper themes in this may be disappointed. And as good as it looks, it's not career defining work, it's only merely good.
It tries to be equal parts snark and snarl - think Mean Girls meets Carrie. But it's unsuccessful at doing either of those things well.
[It] wouldn't work at all without the very talented Giamatti. He has to portray a person with a soul, as well as a soulless one, and make us believe that's the case. He does so, perfectly.
For some, fashion might not seem like exciting material, but director R.J. Cutler is able to create some genuine suspense and tension, as the days and hours count down to the "close" of the issue.
The movie is honest about the way it depicts family relationships and racial prejudices. A believable and fresh-faced cast also helps in that regard.
The only really funny moments in Couples Retreat are bits that were clearly ad-libbed by the film's stars, Vince Vaughn and Jon Favreau.
Moreau's nuanced turn as the title character ensures that the film is not a complete loss. She's very convincing, especially when there arise some questions regarding her mental stability.
It's hard to watch this movie without feeling a little depressed and despondent about the future of mankind and its home.
It goes to show what a good cast can do with certain types of material.

The handsome-looking period drama takes material that could have been portrayed in lurid and sensationalistic detail but instead portrays it with real sensitivity and class, without going too far in showing a passionate romantic relationship.
Zombieland is, as they say in the entertainment industry, "all killer and no filler."
Director Steven Soderbergh tries too hard to force his tone on the material. There's already enough goofiness here.
Even if you don't agree with his assertions regarding economic theory and social politics, it still holds some interest.
If you didn't know any better, you'd swear that both the cast and crew of Surrogates were trying to make the worst movie possible.
The sloppiness is almost in keeping with the experimental styles of guitar playing that are featured in the movie. A few bits of brilliance shine through the messier moments.
[Siegel's] directorial debut has a real ring of truth to it, and benefits from having a terrific cast. Thanks to Oswalt, we like Paul more than we probably should.
It does take awhile for the plot to really kick into gear. Yet the discussion of terrorist morality is interesting, and there are some very tense sequences.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, the main character of this unfunny comedy is never endearing, he's just an irritant. So we're not all that interested in his personal and professional plights.
While there are a few select highlights, it's nothing new and is certainly nothing exceptional or noteworthy.
The filmmaking itself is pretty much by the numbers...But there's some genuine tension as the competition field narrows.
A cliche-ridden, treacly drama that trivializes the bereavement process while it makes romance look easy and like a foregone conclusion.
There's some food for thought to be gleaned from the film. It suggests a few small changes in our everyday lives that could make a big difference.
Blitz's dialogue is often clever, and the young cast members impress, particularly relative newcomers Thompson and Kendrick.
Producer/star Sacha Baron Cohen keeps trying to mine humor from the same type of jokes. And in terms of story structure, it's pretty much the same movie as its predecessor.
The filmmaking here is so incompetent and laughably awful that it recalls the work of schlockmeister Ed Wood.

It boasts some strong performances. Irish character actor Brendan Gleeson steals the show as the appropriately named Alastor 'Mad-Eye' Moody, and the three young leads show increasing confidence in front of the camera (especially Grint).
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Zathura really is what the television ads and movie trailers make it out to be -- Jumanji in Space. Though better and more exciting than that probably makes it sound.

The fact that director Joe Wright and screenwriter Deborah Moggach have managed to get so much of Austen's novel into a film that runs just a little longer than two hours is nothing short of miraculous.
It seems a little disinterested and distracted, even aloof and a bit cold.
One of those stories so incredible that even the most creative Hollywood screenwriters couldn't have come up with it.
To say that States of Grace takes some unexpected turns is to understate. But it also provides a lot of food for thought.
The film itself feels a little boring and tedious.
This fact-based drama has much to say about the current state of journalism -- especially television journalism -- and the obligation of news media to challenge and criticize governmental actions.

This digitally animated feature is not quite as funny as we may have hoped. But it does have a peculiar, goofy sweetness to it, and the sheer inventiveness of the whole thing makes it pretty enjoyable.
An ugly-looking movie with even uglier attempts at humor.
It's the surprising but effective payoff to Don Justo's journey that has the most emotional pull, which is due in no small part to newcomer Benedicti's performance.
Effective, albeit sometimes too-aloof, drama.
While Greenberg is amiable enough, he certainly doesn't have the charisma needed to play the leading man in this romantic comedy.
If anything, this blood-spattered, stomach-churning sequel to last year's serial-killer thriller is even more moronic, more overplotted and more convoluted.
As played by Cage, David is such a hapless nebbish that he's actually much more unlikable and unsympathetic than he should be.
Unfortunately, the Piersons can be so unpleasant that watching them misbehave in Taveuni becomes a chore.
Makes the mistake of thinking it's a lot funnier and a lot more clever than it actually is.
What really sells Walk the Line is the believable chemistry between the two leads.
The Ice Harvest is supposed to be a thriller with dark comic elements, but the movie stops being entertaining fairly early on, and none of its characters is even remotely likable.
[M]ost of the attempts at humor are painfully unfunny.

The remake of the 1968 hit comedy 'Yours, Mine & Ours' is pretty much the same movie as the 2003 remake of 'Cheaper by the Dozen,' with Dennis Quaid taking Steve Martin's place as the family patriarch and butt of several painfully unfunny, slapstick gags.
The film will probably be too much for the majority of audiences. As for hard-core horror fans, they may become a little restless themselves during the first half of the film.
All too often Spielberg seems to be more concerned with creating striking visuals than with building tension and genuine suspense.
Though Stroman directed the stage version, she is the wrong choice for this adaptation.
This half-hearted, obviously obligatory sequel feels labored and twice as long as it really is.
As it turns out, the furor and hubbub about the ratings squabbles over Where the Truth Lies may have just been a smokescreen to cover up the film's storytelling deficiencies.
Green Street Hooligans loses any credibility it might have had the minute it tries to pass off Elijah Wood as a tough guy.
It's his heavy-handed and often ludicrous plotting that is the film's downfall.
The film ping-pongs between wacky comedy and heavy drama, and it is so heavy on plot and character that it takes on a sitcomlike quality.

There's been a slight change in character focus, and those who receive the spotlight this time around are more interesting and compelling. But the technical aspects of the filmmaking aren't quite as good.
movie_title: The Work and the Glory II: American Zion (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Not all of the stories on display here are as relevant or interesting as others.
As expected, whether you find any of this funny depends on your tolerance for outrageously and politically incorrect humor.
The off-kilter humor is a welcome contrast, and the performances are strong, particularly by Baek as the increasingly unhinged patsy.
It's more yawn-inspiring than awe-inspiring, especially for those who haven't read the book.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This aloof, often cold drama may be too cerebral for its own good, as it fails to explain some of its more mystical elements.
A morality thriller filled with heavy-handed allusions to the betrayal of Judas Iscariot.

This all-too-predictable comedy-drama of misunderstandings, which was featured in the 2001 Sundance Film Festival and has been in limbo up until now, is not much different from a typical television movie made for the Lifetime cable channel.
Those who are not as knowledgeable about the subject may still enjoy the movie, which is given a boost by each of the profiled dancers having a good sense of humor.
but the filmmakers feel compelled to turn it into a be-all, end-all piece with a history lesson of the sport that feels curiously incomplete and superficial.
It's frustrating to see these filmmakers continually lobbing softball questions at their subjects.
This family drama wants to do nothing more than tell a story that will make audiences feel good about themselves and about the world in general. Which makes it a refreshing change of pace.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's disappointing to see a movie start off as subtly and restrained as North Country only to get progressively more heavy-handed in its second hour.
This one is more headache-inducing than mind-blowing.

At times this stop-motion animated feature is grotesque, even a bit creepy and scary (it's probably a bit much for really young ones). But it's just as often achingly sweet, and features some grand, sweeping romantic notions.
While there's no denying that Park has strong visual skills, his content so far is in appalling bad taste.
The documentary is effective, though at times it's a challenge to watch.
movie_title: Shake Hands with the Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The whole package is as entertaining as it is educational.
movie_title: Magnificent Desolation: Walking on the Moon 3D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Sometimes muddled and confusing but beautiful-looking follow-up effort.
The film tries to do too many different things at the same time, and the jumbling of goofy comedy and heavy drama doesn't work very well.
This comedy-drama takes a few unexpected dramatic turns and actually manages to say a few things about the peculiar charms of the South without becoming too patronizing or cloyingly phony.
It's as if two completely different movies got spliced together in the editing room, or in the projection booth.
It might not seem quite so awful, even reprehensible, if it didn't waste a pretty good cast, or if it didn't trot out that ultimate poor-taste cliche, a child in peril.
Life is watchable due in no small part to [Redford and Freeman].
As much as audience members will want to laugh it off the screen, it even defies that much enthusiasm.
The subject is a fascinating one, and the film is worth watching just to see how impressive Wexler's career has been.
Ecuadoran filmmaker Sebastian Cordero certainly has style to burn and has some intriguing opinions on the news media, though he could have left out some of the more melodramatic plot elements.
You would hardly expect Laura Linney, Tom Wilkinson and Campbell Scott to appear in such a transparent rip-off of The Exorcist.
Fortunately, most of the jabs are generally good-natured, and the cast is pretty likable.
[W]hile it has a handful of solid laughs, just as many of the film's gags fall flat.
A fuzzy and ultimately unrewarding psychological thriller.
The film manages to turn potentially interesting characters into caricatures and potentially heady material into soap-opera melodrama.
The real pity is that the film could have made its points without being so insufferably preachy and ponderous.

Mrs. Henderson Presents does present opportunities for Dench to point her nose in the air. But then the film loses track of her character to an extent and begins concentrating on others that are less interesting.
Offers further proof that a film really can get by on the charms of its stars.
That the film works as well as it does -- or at all -- is largely due to the old-fashioned appeal of the story and its likable cast.

Unlike the game, this gore-heavy and moronic science-fiction thriller doesn't feature a player-control aspect. So there's no way to skip past the early dull moments, or to end the game -- er, movie -- early.
Maybe Andrew Wagner was hoping they would be endearingly human, but instead they come off as annoying, hardly the type of people we want to be stuck with for an hour and a half.
The cat-and-mouse game that Ledda and especially Vincke play is fun to watch.
movie_title: De zaak Alzheimer (The Memory of a Killer) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This quirky comedy-drama ... features enough style, laughs and genuine warmth to help it overcome some storytelling deficiencies.
While the film goes off in a million different directions, it eventually winds up going nowhere.
The real star here is the Chinese landscape, which is lush and inviting. Cinematographer Jean-Marie Dreujou and his crews have done a good job of capturing its beauty.
movie_title: Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Tony Scott goes so over the top with attention-deficit quirks -- quick-cut scene editing, shaky-cam photography, washed-out color schemes, blaring soundtrack music -- that his films have become a chore to watch.
A lot of the humor is forced and unfunny.

At least this impromptu beach 'fashion show' is more watchable than the rest of the movie, which eventually turns into an improbable adventure-thriller filled with groan-inducing dialogue and equally groan-inducing performances.
In its own sneaky way, the film cleverly manages to examine the meaning of loneliness while looking at dysfunctional-family dynamics, but without becoming too overwhelming or too heavy-handed.
The one thing the film does have going for it is Pacino. But only his most die-hard fans will want to stick it out.
In Her Shoes demonstrates that it's possible to make something fresh and enjoyable out of the most formulaic material.
Treadwell emerges as a compelling figure, even when his childlike babbling at the bears sounds like the sound of the affirmations offered by the Stuart Smalley character on TV's Saturday Night Live.
With the story lines streamlined and compressed, the whole thing doesn't have nearly the emotional heft it probably should.
Clearly the filmmakers are trying to make The Baxter look old-fashioned. But there's a modern smugness and superiority that undermines that attempt.
One of the most visually stunning, imaginative fantasies in recent memory.

This material cobbles together elements of Westerns, space epics, new-age mysticism and even zombie-horror films. And it's to the credit of screenwriter/director Joss Whedon that it all feels cohesive, coherent and believable.
This is some of Cronenberg's strongest work since his 1983 adaptation of Stephen King's The Dead Zone.

There's more cleverness, ingenuity and creativity displayed in the first five minutes of the animated comedy Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit than there has been in most of this year's live-action features combined.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, the film tries to say too much, and as a result ends up saying nothing. Also, this G-rated film contains scenes of animal attacks that are much too intense for young audiences.
It serves as a sad reminder about just how much Reiner's filmmaking skills have eroded in the past decade or so.
It's watchable and is occasionally entertaining, but there's very much a split personality here.
Unfortunately, this too-dour film can't decide whether it wants to be a comedy or a drama. As a result, it doesn't really work as either.
Like its source material, Athol Fugard's novel, the film is a moving, thought-provoking examination of decency and responsibility.
The film is less than two hours long but feels considerably longer, thanks to a few drawn-out scenes and some clunky character drama.
Its stuffy, private-school scenes nearly turn the whole thing into The Dead Pugilist's Society, but this Swedish import does have its chilling moments.
Where the first Ice Age was low-key, this one is more frantic. And this time around the material is cruder, more lowbrow than it needs to be.
It's as if, in trying to emulate the style of stuffy documentarian Ken Burns, Wilmott made something that actually makes Burns' films seem livelier.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Basic Instinct 2 is basically the same movie as its predecessor. Only there's no Michael Douglas. And the setting has changed from the United States to Europe.
The film is an overwrought mess that you'd almost swear was a parody if you didn't know better.

As much a mystery as it is a suspense-thriller, this bank-heist film combines elements from both Dog Day Afternoon and The Usual Suspects. And as odd as that may sound, the experiment works most of the time.
This documentary feature is more concerned with telling us about Trudell's many exploits than with telling us about the man. As a result, it feels superficial, and the tone is much too reverential.
There are some fine performances, as well as a surprising, well-earned and emotional pay-off that comes at the end.
unlike [in Fahrenheit 9/11, Why We Fight lets its subjects do the talking; there's no constant narrative presence like in Moore's film. And as a result, it's considerably more persuasive.
Relies heavily on dumb slapstick, including a few tasteless, low-brow moments.
The film is generally likable and pretty good-natured, but its proclivity for crude jokes and dumb slapstick eventually bring it down.
V for Vendetta is a thought-provoking, suspenseful thriller set in the near future, as the American empire is in ruins and sees a fascist version of England as the new world leader.
Every bit as laid-back and genial as the musician is himself.
The film's hit-to-miss joke ratio isn't as favorable as you might wish.
What redeems this film somewhat are its plentiful dancing scenes and a charismatic lead performance by Antonio Banderas as Pierre Dulaine, a former professional dancer.

This revenge-thriller is ridiculously overplotted, with delusions of Tarantino glibness. It's also a little too pleased with itself; the filmmakers obviously think it's smarter and more clever than it actually is.

This documentary makes you wonder what our nation's schools would be like if educators had all the resources they need and deserve . . . and if students here had as much individual instruction as they need and deserve.
The headier aspects and New Wave stylings do make it worthwhile.
The plotting is too obvious, too contrived and too convenient.
That RV has any laughs at all is nothing short of miraculous.
American Gun arrives in theaters too late to really make a difference or say anything new on the subject of school shootings.
It's the first movie in some time actually lives up to its family-friendly billing.
For those who can stomach the concept, United 93 does have its effective moments, especially the riveting final 20 or so minutes.
Unfortunately, the Bring It On formula has already been imitated so many times that it's become tired.
A film that manages to be intelligent without being boring, making it one of the better music documentaries in recent memory.
Ben Affleck's little brother does have a likable quality, and his character eventually warms up.
Depp really does his best (or perhaps that should be his worst) to make his character unappealing and unlikable.
One of the few movies where its sentimentality actually works in its favor.
Friends With Money comes to an all-too-easy, sitcom-like conclusion.
To employ terminology that might be used by Simon Cowell, the brutally honest American Idol judge, American Dreamz is bloody awful.
The Sentinel is nearly suspense-free, and it's galling to watch Sutherland take a back seat to the aging Michael Douglas.
Does build steam as it goes, though the somewhat slow pacing works against it.
The film's notions about the importance of free speech and the proliferation of ideas are obviously important -- it's a message that needs to be spread in our own uncertain times.
The jokes too often miss their targets, and there's more of a reliance on innuendo and bathroom humor than there should be.
Scary Movie 4 has about as many laughs as the two previous Scary Movies combined. Faint praise, of course, as those films had maybe four or five laughs between them.
A smart, funny and often perceptive work that bodes well for the future career of screenwriter/director Jason Reitman.
Adam & Steve does distinguish itself from its fellow gay comedies -- in exactly one way: It's possibly the most low-brow of the lot.
This British import is a good-natured comedy featuring several laugh-out-loud sequences.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: ... skillfully made trash.
The latest remake of the much-filmed Disney concept The Shaggy Dog tries to mine humor from animal testing, which should tell you everything you need to know about this one.
To get any enjoyment out of The Pink Panther, you have to forget that Peter Sellers ever played Inspector Jacques Clouseau.

The film perhaps tries a bit too hard for its own good, as the filmmakers also try to steer a few scenes in a comic direction when they shouldn't. And it gets all gooey and sentimental at the end when it shouldn't.

Like the 1920 Indian motorcycle that Munro races, the film sputters a bit as it starts out. But it slowly gains speed and momentum, earning a kinship to David Lynch's similarly winning and low-key film The Straight Story (1999).
Something New is nothing new. It's just the latest spin on cliched romantic comedies about struggles faced by racially mixed couples.
... one of the smarter films out right now.
This charmless comic fantasy is a major disappointment.
The material in the film itself doesn't quite bomb, though it doesn't really kill either.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The New World is pretty as a postcard.
Let's just hope that Final Destination 3 really is the final entry in this successful but intellectually bankrupt horror franchise.
... a smart, sexy picture that makes an ideal star vehicle for Irish actor Jonathan Rhys Meyers.
Filmmakers Cory and Todd Edwards are novices, which may explain why they settle for the easiest type of humor, parody, but they're not very successful at it.

Unlike the opera, this version of the tale features no mystical elements and comes off as horribly contrived. What's more, director Kevin Reynolds' sluggish pacing makes the film feels twice as long as it really is.
Queen Latifah's film career has been marked by a series of big, brassy, bold performances, which is one of the reasons Last Holiday proves to be such a frustrating experience.

Ang Lee takes his time developing the characters and situations, making the proceedings credible. And Rodrigo Prieto's photography captures the magnificent Wyoming settings by emphasizing natural beauty, as well as the feeling of remoteness and isolation.
What saves Nine Lives is a first-rate cast, which includes Oscar-winning actresses Sissy Spacek and Holly Hunter.

The film provides a valuable glimpse into the religious practices of ultra-Orthodox Jews living in Jerusalem. But it's also a cleverly plotted film, which, refreshingly, also features a few welcome comic elements.
It is an important film, especially given the racial and ethnic strife that's only worsened around the world as a result of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
Breakfast on Pluto has its tongue lodged so firmly in its cheek that it nearly chokes on it.
Similarities between Glory Road and Remember the Titans (2000) are purely intentional.

The filmmakers have taken the source material -- Arthur Golden's best-selling novel -- and turned it into a glossy Hollywood production with the overripe melodrama you'd expect from a television soap opera, not a supposed epic drama.
Though it's supposed to be a suspense-thriller, Firewall is suspense-free short on thrills.
It's a uniquely unappetizing combination of unfunny material and unfunny performances.

This already controversial drama is yet another anti-American screed from Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier, who's become more than a little tiresome with all his cinematic bashing of the United States and its political policies.
A cinematic concoction that almost defies description or genre classification.
This is no-frills filmmaking and may be a little talky, but it's also very well-made, powerful stuff, and it should be seen by anyone who has questions about the American justice system.
Deep Sea 3D doesn't go any deeper than the ocean floor . . . but that's pretty deep.
Aquamarine film is not a completely noxious or painful experience, though it's rather juvenile and has a cornball sense of humor that is squarely aimed at its obvious target demographic.
16 Blocks only gets more ludicrous and contrived as it goes along.
Much of the all-ages, all-races appeal of comedian Dave Chappelle comes from his ability to mix both high-brow and low-brow elements into his humor.
On the upside, however, that first hour is followed by a two-hour roller coaster ride that climaxes with a breathtaking finale atop the Empire State Building in New York City.
Those who are patient will find the film quite effective in its look at the world's sense of heightened paranoia, by examining the notion that, in today's society, no one is safe... even at home.
Melancholia leans heavily toward propaganda, but the movie is well done, albeit almost overwhelmingly dark.
The film has the unmistakable imprint of [Lars] von Trier, with its heavy-handed tirade, masquerading as satire, assailing what he perceives to be America's obsessions with guns and violence.

The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada features some solid, if not spectacular, performances, as well as a bizarre and dark sense of humor -- which come in handy when the film starts meandering and runs out of steam.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: You could laugh off the film's more over-the-top aspects -- including the performances and its quasi-Quentin Tarantino dialogue -- if it didn't treat women and children with such brutality and contempt.
A little judicious editing might have made it more effective.
The film also has a distinctly sitcom-like quality and is poorly paced, like an overlong episode of Will & Grace.
Director Carroll Ballard makes only one type of movie -- family adventures that feature some sort of wildlife. To his credit, however, he does them pretty well.
Roth's ham-fisted approach here suggests that he is trying to stage his own version of Clint Eastwood's overrated, Oscar-nominated Mystic River.

The human co-stars are considerably less interesting [than the dogs], and that's the biggest problem with this outdoor adventure drama, which spends too much time with the humans and not enough with the considerably more watchable animals.
It's full of enough contrived and ludicrous soap opera-type plotting to make Huffman's TV series, Desperate Housewives, seem restrained and realistic.
Though it is skillfully made and well-acted, it's also exploitative and nauseating.

Director Peter Hyams and his cast seem determined to play this hokum with a straight face, except for Ben Kingsley, who is clearly trying to give the worst performance possible -- it's almost as if he's begging Hyams to cut his scenes out of the movie.
Simply befuddling.
What little humor Sahara has is forced, and of the goofy, 'buddy-film' shenanigans variety.
As longtime Red Sox fans themselves, the Farrellys obviously sweated getting all the little details right. And this is certainly the least crude and most gentle movie they've been associated with.
There are simply too many people populating this comedy-drama, which keeps introducing more and more story elements until there isn't enough time to sufficiently tie them all up.
Those who are patient enough to stick it out will be charmed.

Allen may be the stand-out, but the others do hold their own. She and Costner have terrific chemistry, and each of the four actresses playing Terry's daughters are strong (in particular, Wood continues to impress).
It certainly benefits from the presence of Ganz, the veteran German character actor who portrays Hitler.

It's not always easy to watch, and it's certainly not for the easily offended. But visually, there's much to enjoy, especially the striking black-and-white imagery offset with periodic, selective bits of colors.
Uses a folktale or parable to impart its message about the simple pleasures in life, and it's the telling of that story that makes it watchable and worthwhile.
It's not an unpleasant movie, just a confused, sometimes frustrating one.
Amusing -- but only in spurts.
This follow-up to the surprising 2000 comedy hit is so deprived of charm and so full of shrill, forced humor that it may make fans of the original forget why they enjoyed it.

Unfortunately, just when the film really starts to explore an idea, it moves on to the next one. And the bit about how the adult-film industry has changed since the 1970s was done more effectively in the fictional Boogie Nights.
Compelling, fascinating stuff.
Stumbles and falls every time the movie isn't on the ice. And come to think of it, it does a good deal of stumbling and falling when it is on the ice.
There's a lot to admire in Moolaade, including the way in which the filmmakers lay out the premise and necessary story details within the first 10 or 15 minutes.
An exciting adventure film with handsome, state-of-the-art animation.
Weird horror isn't as rewarding as scary or creepy, and The Ring Two is definitely one of the bigger disappointments of late.
Walks the line between being just creepy enough to be interesting and being completely disturbing.
movie_title: In the Realms of the Unreal (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Try to imagine Woody Allen mounting a production of Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman, and you'll have some idea of what King of the Corner is like.
Unfortunately, it's not awful in the sort of way that allows it to be dumb fun, nor does it provide any scares or laughs, intentional or otherwise, that might make it watchable.
Too often the movie defies description as a comedy.
Give Winter Solstice some credit for taking an unexpected route.
Unfortunately, Bullock's much-ballyhooed performance verges on cartoonish, and worse, she's paired with Fraser, who couldn't be more inanimate if he was cast as a brick wall.
The new remake of House of Wax proves it's actually possible for a movie to get dumber as it goes along.
Kingdom of Heaven has the nasty habit of quickly killing off its most interesting and compelling characters, those in whom the film invests time and tries to develop.

Parts of the movie are luridly enthralling, and its ugliness is strangely appealing (at least to people with a high tolerance for such things). Yet it pushes too many buttons and is filled with so many false endings that eventually it becomes tiresome.
Of the many mistakes Duchovny makes, perhaps the worst is his criminal underuse of Leoni (his real-life spouse), who's about the only thing the film has going for it.
[A] modestly amusing and at times very clever movie.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This dim-witted action-thriller might go down better if its presidential-assassination storyline weren't in such bad taste and if its attitude weren't so misogynistic -- and if its attempts at humor were more than lame one-liners.
The stories in Brothels are quite moving, and the film sheds light on a part of the world that is rarely seen anywhere.
Dust to Glory needed an editor - or at least a better one; someone who might have helped this documentary focus on one or two stories rather than trying to tell a dozen or more.
There are some pretty tense moments, the plot does keep you guessing and the performances are effective, especially the somewhat enigmatic character played by Kidman.
Angelo Pizzo's screenplay is rife with the expected sports and gamesmanship cliches, and he and Anspaugh take forever just to get to the game action, which is the only really worthwhile material.
If anything, this Hustle is more frantic, more frenetic, more cartoonish - and more enjoyable - than filmmaker Stephen Chow's previous film, Shaolin Soccer.
This winning low-key British yarn is told with real creativity and succeeds by developing characters and situations in an original way.
Ultimately turns out to be more fascinating as eye candy than as a story.
This is the kind of material you expect to find in a Lifetime cable-channel movie.
Handsome production values, solid ensemble performances and explorations of Far Eastern civilization.
It's the lack of sentiment at the right time that proves to be the film's undoing.
There is a certain audience for whom such cinematic comfort food will be welcome, and the film's stars are likable enough to at least ensure that it's watchable.
The plotting in this 2002 French drama really isn't any more deep than your typical soap opera.
Its plot is pretty much standard-issue. But the action is spectacular enough to allow the audience to overlook that problem.
This thinly scripted but brilliantly animated comedy feels as clunky and mechanical as its characters.

Even if the material is terribly formulaic and derivative, it's still such a simple, by-the-numbers romantic comedy that only a Herculean effort could mess it up. And the filmmakers have managed to do exactly that.
Arguably the best, most consistent movie Clint Eastwood has made since his Oscar-winning Western Unforgiven in 1992.
Cheadle brings a needed intensity to the film; his character's fear and compassion are quite vivid.
The film is filled with hilariously bad performances, expository dialogue and production values that suggest it could have been a low-budget film-school project.

There is also a plot twist that comes about two-thirds in, which is supposed to be shocking, but is actually one of the least-surprising, least-scary 'surprises' in recent memory. It may provoke more laughter than chills.

The humor is typified by the painfully unfunny recurring gag that has a bobble-head doll of Satchel Paige (voiced by Tracy Morgan) giving life and love advice to Nick. The late baseball great deserves better than that -- and so do audiences.
For those who can stand the ultra-violent content, there's something almost enthralling about the film -- until it falls apart in the final 20 minutes.
Like Hero, this one is almost nonstop action, and fans of martial-arts films will surely love it just as much.
As distasteful as the concept may be, it's approached with surprising sensitivity and taste.
[Not] a very appealing viewing experience.
Grace's dry, deadpan delivery and put-upon routine makes several sequences funnier than they probably should be, and he has believable chemistry with both Quaid and Johansson.

The film comes to what seems like a logical stopping point -- and then continues for another 30 minutes to a conclusion that only muddles its messages. In the end, what could have been a decent little sports drama is bloated and overlong.
Features performances by such masters of the form as Buddy Guy, Solomon Burke, B.B. King. But the movie doesn't depend on your knowledge of them or their works.
The simplicity of Postmen in the Mountains is much of the film's charm.
movie_title: Postmen in the Mountains (Nashan naren nagou) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Seems more intent on getting the musical numbers right than telling the story.

While most of Rosenstrasse is set in World War II, there are present-day, flash-forward sequences that are considerably less involving. Actually, they're so dull that they drag the entire movie to a screeching halt.
As with other live-action films inspired by Saturday-morning cartoons, this family-friendly comedy just isn't animated enough.
The explorations of the strained father-son dynamic and a message about redemption are well-done.

In the end, the two halves of the movie feel as if they are forced together, leaving messes that Tennant and screenwriter Kevin Bisch never really clean up.
It's clear that writer-director Niels Mueller has some delusions about making the next Taxi Driver, but nothing here has the sheer visceral impact of that film.
The music is lovely, as is the never-rushed pacing. Add to that Jugnot's very low-key lead performance, and you've got a formula to overcome even the film's most problematic moments.
Guerrilla is so dull that it almost makes you wonder what was all the fuss about the Symbionese Liberation Army.
movie_title: Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It was a bad decision to pair Rai with Australian actor Henderson, who comes up a little short in the charisma department. Darcy is supposed to be abrasive at first, but here he's just dull.
As much fun as it is to see Pacino chew some Shakespearean scenery, both the role and the movie could have used a more likable actor.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It seems unsure of exactly what it's trying to say, as if its focus was changed by the studio to make it more audience-friendly.
Essentially the same move Schwarzenegger made with his supposedly family-friendly comedy Kindergarten Cop, only The Pacifier is even dumber and considerably more crass.
Has its tongue lodged so firmly in its cheek that it practically chokes on it.
This on-again, off-again horror movie is a mess -- quite literally.
The film -- and its characters -- are full of quirks. But it tries a little too hard, especially where the quirks are concerned.
What really makes the film watchable is yet another terrific lead performance by Javier Bardem, an actor who only gets better with age.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The primary irritant here is Perry, whose performance is the cinematic equivalent of listening to fingernails scrape a chalkboard for two hours.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's little more than a collection of cliches about the Deep South, alcoholism and the literary arts.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

Its amateurish elements often betray the relatively low budget, and there's also a serious lack of energy.
Manages to overcome the sense of its being overly familiar.

It turns out to be a pleasant surprise, never taking itself too seriously and with some fairly tense and creepy moments.
Little of it works, and frankly, the film alternates between being dull and being almost campy fun.
At its best when it's sending up '50s-era Hollywood and it's at its worst when trying to make a serious point.
To paraphrase Lloyd Bentsen's now-infamous diss of fellow vice-presidential candidate Dan Quayle in 1988: We know Eddie Murphy. Nick Cannon, you're no Eddie Murphy.
The film's jokes just aren't that funny.
Has a few enlightening moments but has just as many that are tedious.
There's plenty of material here, but co-screenwriter/director Jacques Audiard feels compelled to throw in a couple of go-nowhere subplots.
movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arrêté (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This material brings out the worst instincts in director Rob Cohen.
This Russian-made thriller is seriously lacking energy, which is surprising considering the material.
It's one of the best sports documentaries to come along since 1994's Hoop Dreams and is among this still-young year's best films.
To be honest, the whole thing looks a bit like an episode of television's Power Rangers.
It works all right as sort of cinematic comfort food.

The ties that bind this drama's often-smug and off-putting characters are contrived, and the plotting rarely goes deeper than soap opera surface. And that's a shame, considering the caliber of its cast.
If you can turn off your brain, The Island is one of the more enjoyable movies this summer.
The term 'terrible' not only describes what happens to the characters, it also describes the brain-numbing sensation of having to sit through this movie.
It's an oddly affecting piece that manages to say something about isolation and loneliness in its own peculiar way.
movie_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005)

movie_review_blurb: If you can stand the assault on your senses, you may discover that there's a good message underneath (one about not excluding people based on supposed 'handicaps'), and Thornton gets off some very funny one-liners.

Apres Vous ... is less peculiar but considerably more contrived, more forced than Girl on the Bridge.

Mixes sappy sentiment with crude R-rated sexual material, which makes for a sweet-and-salty movie snack.
Fans of the television show will find a lot to like here. So will fans of the Broken Lizard comedy troupe.
The atmosphere conveyed is possibly too vivid. By the time the movie is over, you'll probably feel the need to take a shower just to scrub off the lingering, psychic grime.
This drama, which was bankrolled by the people behind the international Operation Smile program, has the best of intentions. But it's so painfully earnest that it becomes insufferable.
Overstuffed with characters and contrivances.

Some of the plotting borders on ludicrous, and newcomer Nguyen is pretty much charisma-free.

Admittedly, some may find the movie's pacing a bit self-indulgent and its sense of humor more than a little odd, but this rewarding, cinematic voyage of self-discovery also provides some real food for thought.
It takes an extremely open mind and a strong constitution to stomach a lot of this.

This film manages to sustain its laughs for the entire film, and when it takes the expected turn toward sweetness and sentimentality, it does so with such forcefulness, with such conviction, that you believe in it.
Obviously, this one is not for all tastes, but it is an impressive showing for Argentine filmmaker Martel, who's managed to do Almodovar-type material every bit as well as her mentor.
While a few of the film's more preposterous story elements do remain glaring, Red Eye is nonetheless enjoyable and exciting, something more than merely a guilty pleasure.

Unless you find filmed walking interesting, or unless you're in tune with Van Sant and his unique storytelling quirks, this drama -- loosely based on the last days of the late Kurt Cobain -- quickly becomes an interminable bore.
Surprisingly dull.
When the movie finally does show what the troops went through and how the raid itself was pulled off, it's exciting, enthralling stuff. If only there was more of that. . . .
More of a suspense thriller than a supernatural thriller. But it's just not thrilling enough.
This is not a glossy drama filled with pretty-looking people. Instead, it's a revenge-thriller and is one of the ugliest, nastiest movies in recent memory.
Whatever points screenwriter/director Attal is trying to make about relationship envy get lost as the marital conflicts become more contrived and shrill.
Deuce Bigalow: European Gigolo gets less funny as it goes along. Considering that this alleged comedy wasn't funny to begin with, that's actually quite an accomplishment.
Competent, surprisingly cohesive and coherent and it does its best to tell all sides of the story.
This insipid motor sports drama is not only shockingly inept in terms of storytelling, it's also one of the cheapest looking movies in recent memory.

Leaden and dull.
It's gone through Hollywood 'creative processing' at least one time too many.

In many ways this unambitious but heartfelt drama comes as a welcome breath of fresh air, especially now, when theaters are filled with dark and dreary features, the kind of heartless, soulless Hollywood constructs that glut the summer each year.
The turns that each of these stories take are hardly surprising, and most of co-screenwriters Elizabeth Chandler and Delia Ephron's attempts at humor fall flat.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

As frustrating and overbearing as parts of the film are, the inability to pin it down completely does makes it all the more watchable.
When The Longest Yard is about football, it's not too bad. Unfortunately, the rest of the movie is.
This is easily the best, most accomplished film Araki has done to date.
Heavy on jokes and light on story. Surprisingly, that turns out to be in its favor.
Overcoming the handicap of an overt, writerly device, Allen crafts a warm comedy and a painful tragedy right before our eyes.
Just as stuntwomen have to do, Double Dare pulls its punches.

movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Unleashed is easily [Li's] best, most consistently exciting film in quite some time.

Lopez is no help with a performance that is so cutesy, so one-note, that she could have phoned it in.
Newcomer Berry is not only able to hold her own with her more experienced co-stars, but she's the real standout here.

This imaginative but silly and headache-inducing adventure film was created largely by Racer Maximillian Rodriguez, the young son of filmmaker Robert Rodriguez. And it should have been left in his subconscious.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The quirkiness does get a little tiresome, even though director Kim Ki-duk and cinematographer Jang Seung-beck are able to capture some eerily beautiful images.
Morris continually drives home the same point, about the inhumanity and cruelty of child labor. Needless to say, it gets redundant and starts feeling wearying and monotonous.
It's almost as if screenwriter/director Marco Bellocchio wants to exorcise personal demons rather than entertain.
movie_title: L' Ora di Religione (Il Sorriso di Mia Madre) (The Religion Hour) (My Mother's Smile) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Spielberg, whose previous alien visitation movies (E.T. The Extra-Terrestrial and Close Encounters of the Third Kind) are considerably more benign than this film. But he does this more mature, nightmarish material nearly as well.

The constant gear-changing -- or tonal shifts -- may put some audience members off a bit. But it also has style to burn, and most of the cast is appealing, especially the brooding Csanyi, and Balla, whose sunny presence brightens up the dark proceedings.
It doesn't disappoint in the way of visceral thrills, and for a reportedly low-budget affair, the effects are pretty gruesome.
As a documentary, Rock School works just fine. As an advertisement for the Paul Green School of Rock Music, it's considerably less successful.
A sprawling comedy-drama that actually tries to say something -- not just about its characters, but about the Czech Republic and what it's turned into since becoming a capitalistic society.
movie_title: Up and Down (Horem Pádem) (Loop the Loop) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: At more than two hours, both Nossiter and the film go on too long, like a drunken party guest who doesn't know when to leave.
Admittedly, Mr. & Mrs. Smith operates on a one-joke premise. But - in a departure from a lot of what Hollywood has delivered so far this year -- at least the joke is funny.

That the film is watchable is largely due to the women, any of whom could have been the subject of a better, considerably more focused film.
The kids' enthusiasm for dancing continually buoys the material.

As a vehicle for Heather Locklear, the movie is a tasty enough concoction. Unfortunately, however, her storyline has been sandwiched with a pretty gooey, unpleasant plot that prominently features Hilary Duff.
Thanks to Bale's multi-layered performance, this is the best, most complex character to put on the Bat-cowl.
The film does have Dench and Smith, which counts for a lot. And watching the two of them is at least moderately entertaining.

A movie that features such old-fashioned comedic virtues can be refreshing, which makes it even more unfortunate that this particular G-rated comedy contains sexually suggestive humor and references.
Perhaps the least-satisfying of the many martial-arts/costume dramas that have followed in the wake of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: If anything, the film is proof that a European sex comedy can be just as boring as your run-of-the-mill comedy if the writing isn't up to snuff.
This more character-involved sequel is easily the best of the three films, which may be faint praise.
The movie might be perceived as being a little slow but it's surprisingly engrossing, and the occasional bits of humor are welcome and in keeping with the tone of the entire piece.

The film really hinges on the friendship between Chris and Lewis, which adds a needed emotional component. It's the convincing onscreen relationship between Gordon-Levitt and Daniels that makes the film work.
It does feature a few guilty laughs throughout -- and a couple of really big laughs toward the end.

It's certainly one of the more imaginative-looking Disney cartoons in recent memory. It also has one of the better stories for a Disney-released cartoon produced by Pixar, even if portions seem ripped off from the Back to the Future movies.
A somewhat clunky ending isn't enough to ruin Days of Glory, which features some good performances and has a slightly different take on a much-filmed subject.
