Pride completely wastes the talents of Terrence Howard.
It doesn't help that this science-fiction adventure aimed at families tries to be a little headier and mind-blowing than it probably should be.

While Sandler's performance is surprisingly subdued and in keeping with the tone of the film, the real star is underappreciated character actor Don Cheadle, whose forceful performance forces Sandler to bring his A-game.
Takes itself much too seriously, and as a result some of the supposedly dramatic moments are unintentionally hilarious.
movie_title: Beauty and the Beast: A Latter-Day Tale (2007)

movie_review_blurb: What buoys the film and really makes it work are strong performances by its cast, many of them young newcomers.

This character-heavy crime thriller from Argentina occasionally gets off track, straying into territory that has little to do with the main story line. But they are interesting digressions, and it's sort of nice to have a movie that's so unpredictable.
Though this cheery romantic comedy from England may be a bit familiar and predictable, the fresh-faced cast makes it appealing.
This insincere, even phony, film is so laugh-challenged that it practically defies its description as a romantic comedy. It's neither romantic nor funny.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [A] gimmicky and nearly suspense-free fantasy/thriller.
Drastically overplotted and overwritten and could have used some editing to make it a tighter, more modest character piece.
Builds tension and develops its characters slowly, and it is surprisingly engrossing.
An Unreasonable Man doubles as both a thinkpiece and a sympathetic portrait of its subject. But like Nader, the film is a little long-winded and infuriatingly single-minded.
Climates is pretty strong in its performances, but the rather luxurious -- some would say too-slow -- pacing may prove to be off-putting.
It's alternately mean-spirited and dumb, and it features few if any laughs.
The film uses cheap scare devices galore in an attempt to generate some suspense, but which instead just shows how desperate the filmmakers were.
This silly family comedy features some of the dumbest slapstick this side of the Disney Channel.
The material remains relevant, and the film as a whole is completely engrossing. (It may be nearly 2 1/2 hours long, but it doesn't feel like it.)
Has a curiously unsatisfying ending, and there's some material that leaves a somewhat scuzzy patina.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's sort of fun -- at least if you're someone who has a taste for gory slasher flicks.
An insufferable, poor-taste thriller devoid of substance and almost completely free of scares, not to mention original ideas.
This is not an awful movie, but it fails to capitalize on some real opportunities that could have made it better and deeper.
Sure to appeal to fans of action thrillers, as well as devotees of Shaun of the Dead.
It's the two characters' exchanges that make this predictable legal thriller rewarding.
Zellweger and McGregor work well together, and have believable chemistry. In fact, the entire ensemble cast is terrific.
While you can appreciate the filmmakers' attempts at do something different from R-rated gore fests and routine PG-13 horror movies, Manor is pretty dull.

A different approach from more straightforward Iraq War documentaries. And the film definitely has effective moments, especially those dealing with grief and the rough transition from military to civilian life.
movie_title: America At A Crossroads: Operation Homecoming: Writing The Wartime Experience (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Co-screenwriter/director Mark Fergus isn't able to build any palpable tension. And the fact that we're not really rooting for his protagonist to survive works against the material.
There are large portions here that are universally relatable, particularly the film's themes about fighting for freedom.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This really is LaBeouf's vehicle, and he proves to be an appealing star presence.

The convoluted resolution to the murder mystery suggests the filmmakers were simply making it up as they filmed. And judging by her listless, almost blase performance, Berry appears to be bored by the material.
Grindhouse runs three-plus hours and is simply too much of a good-bad thing.
Avenue Montaigne may not be the lightest, brightest film ever made, but compared to the glum and talky movies most people associate with French cinema, it's downright chipper.
[A] fascinating, if fictionalized, real-life tale, which plays out alternately as a drama, a comedy and a thriller -- and which works as all three.
The historical elements -- particularly those that deal with Japanese internment camps during World War II -- definitely make the movie worthwhile.
Director Michael O. Sajbel and screenwriter Cheryl McKay try to stuff so much of Jim Stovall's novel in that it feels a bit rushed.
The film is also quite action-heavy, which turns out to be its saving grace. The lengthy and rousing battle scenes are enough to outweigh most of the clunkier aspects ... sometimes just barely.
Minghella's screenplay may be a little too ambitious; it's overstuffed with plot and characters.
You might be tempted to classify it as an interesting failure, but all the crudities and the snail's pace make it hard to get through.
There are times when you're hard-pressed to recognize it as an Eastwood movie. It actually resembles work by the late Akira Kurosawa.

Patient filmgoers will be rewarded. The final half-hour of Curse of the Golden Flower is heavy on action. A large-scale war sequence is visually stunning, perhaps even rivaling Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings trilogy for its epic scale.

The ever-evolving onscreen relationship between Dench and Blanchett does make it watchable. And Dench really sinks her teeth into this material, making the unhinged Barbara one of those characters you hate to love.
It's probably time for Plympton -- who's been making films for nearly 30 years -- to try to do something a little loftier.
This fantasy blend of live-action and digital animation is just never quite as wondrous as it really should be.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There probably isn't a single character in Alpha Dog you would consider likable or sympathetic. And yet, the film almost works in spite of that. Almost.
Children of Men is a chillingly effective cautionary fable that provides provocative social commentary, but it also works as a compassionate character drama.
Even the stars seem to realize it's not working. The pivotal dramatic scene here involves Andy Garcia and Reynolds, neither of whom is quite able to keep a straight face. Not that you can blame them.
Filmmaker Todd Field seems to have completely missed the point of his source material, Tom Perrotta's tale of suburban angst, longing and temptation, which is at least slightly a parody.

Redemption comes far too late in The Painted Veil, an aloof and disappointing adaptation of W. Somerset Maugham's 1920s novel that features one of the more unlikable, self-involved main characters in recent memory.
Thr3e is exploitative nonsense that cheapens the studio that released it. And if that's not enough, the film is completely inept in its direction, story construction and performances.
Even earnestness and good intentions can't save Freedom Writers from feeling overly familiar. We've already seen this story many times in various forms.
Jean Renoir's classic 1939 satire hasn't lost any of its ability to both shock and enlighten.
movie_title: The Rules of the Game (La règle du jeu) (1939)

movie_review_blurb: Candy is pretty much the standard, downbeat, drug-addicts-in-love tale we've seen repeatedly over the years.
While this documentary features rare performance footage of hard-core punk-rock bands Black Flag and Bad Brains, it's not exactly the best-assembled or deepest cinematic exploration of the subject.
The real star here is former American Idol contestant Jennifer Hudson, who manages to steal the movie out from under Murphy, as well as some other big-star performers.
Character actor [Richard] Griffiths ensures that the film is watchable enough.
Cinematically, the [novel's] concept comes off as laughably ludicrous. And the unconvincing period trappings and performances in this adaptation certainly don't help.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Condemned has a nasty mean streak toward its female characters -- a real no-no that prevents it from being simple, dumb fun.
Catch and Release tries to hook audiences by changing gears between drama and comedy. It's a formula that's proven successful for many so-called 'chick flicks', but here it fails to reel you in.
Part romance, part horror movie, there isn't much chocolate in Blood and Chocolate, and there isn't really much blood, either, in this less-than-thrilling thriller.
Wild Hogs is every bit as terrible as you'd expect a film with John Travolta, Tim Allen and Martin Lawrence to be.
Reno 911!: Miami is pretty much a feature-length movie version of a television show that sometimes has trouble finding enough material for even one 30-minute episode.

When it's more grounded -- in normal, everyday family drama -- the film works fine. But it gets weirder as it goes along. In fact, it gets so far out and goes so far off track that recovery is impossible.
It's clear that the filmmakers believe a movie about political debate has to have a lot of speechifying. Consequently, it's so talky that it gradually loses our interest, which is a real shame.
Carrey's unconvincing performance here turns it into his funniest film in years.
This supernatural action/thriller can't decide whether it wants to go for laughs or chills, and some of the supposedly chilling moments are the silliest and most laughable ones.
Say what you will about Andy Warhol's movies -- they may have been boring, but at least they weren't as dull as as Factory Girl.
Smarter and warmer than most family-friendly fare.
... a dark comic thriller with at least as many twists and turns as your typical Spanish 'telenovela.'
Better-focused than The Good Shepherd, and its story is more interesting.
It's not horrible, though the rather chintzy production values have a glorified made-for-television look.
How this relentlessly crude film got a PG-13 rating instead of a deserved R is anyone's guess. Worse, it's also racially offensive and sexist.
The story proves to be elusive, and the robotic performances of the cast make it hard to care about any of the characters -- or to try to figure out what's supposed to be going on.
The film naturally has its share of gruesome moments, but it's also surprisingly dull and uninvolving.
Whitaker's riveting and deserved Oscar-nominated performance pretty much dominates -- almost to the point of overpowering -- this fictionalized drama, based on Giles Foden's novel.
This one has mind-blowing visuals that employ many 'organic' effects (del Toro prefers to use makeup prosthetics and other devices, eschewing computer graphics).
The film has O'Toole, who's as riveting as ever. Fans of the much-nominated actor will be happy to see that advancing age hasn't diminished his ability.
It's safe to say that it wastes the talents of a good cast -- one that definitely deserves better than this.
The film wisely focuses on Hugh Grant, who makes several of these bits funnier than they would otherwise be.
There's really nothing new about the way Grbavica looks at the mother-daughter dynamic. But it's still refreshing to see any film that does so with such honesty and realism.
Makes you wish [director Groening] would have kept the film to about 90 or 100 minutes. A little time spent in the monastery is fine, but nearly three hours is an endurance test.

A pretty lousy movie in general, though it's the film's somewhat accusatory Iraq War subject matter that's getting it some attention -- deserved or not -- that makes the whole thing a little distasteful.

This is the one summer movie so far this year that really delivers in a big way. It's got bigger and better action than other bloated blockbusters, and it has bigger and better laughs that any of its comedic competition.
...his [Burnett's] tale about a south central Los Angeles neighborhood is stunning, and it holds up remarkably well.
Tries a little too hard to duplicate the look and feel of [Napoleon Dynamite].
It's pretty clear where this is going from the first frame, though Posey's performance does keep you interested.

Perhaps the funniest thing about the movie is seeing how little chemistry there is between Sandler and Jessica Biel, who plays his love interest. (As strange as it sounds, Sandler has more chemistry with James.)
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Travolta's rather unfunny and sometimes tone-deaf turn in drag and a fat suit is the one sore-thumb element in what is otherwise a pretty energetic and enjoyable musical-comedy.
Jodorowsky's 1973 surreal fantasy is just too much to dig through.
As perplexing as large parts of it are, the film certainly isn't boring. And it's kind of fun trying to figure out what it's all supposed to mean.
One of the few movies out there that doesn't stoop to low-brow humor and bad-taste elements. The film's humor and drama is sweeter and comes from believable character and story development.
The mostly 2-D animation is top-notch quality, and it is a fascinating idea.

British television director David Yates and screenwriter Michael Goldenberg have made a surprisingly coherent film from Rowling's sprawling, 800 pages-plus novel. But at times it's still a tough slog.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's played in the most straight-faced fashion, with little humor to lighten things up. The heavy-handed film is almost laughable as a consequence.
French actress Isabelle Huppert has made a career out of playing women on the verge of ... something. Suicide, nervous breakdowns, disastrous affairs -- you name it, Huppert's characters have had it.
...the characters here are so unlikable that it's hard to care what happens to them.
Surprisingly, Bay actually subdues his usual, attention-deficit style for this sometimes rewarding, science-fiction action thriller.
This crude and unfunny comedy represents one of the low points in what has already been a disappointing summer-movie season.
The film does get a little overwhelmingly dark. This may be an accurate picture of what Piaf's life was like, but watching nearly 2 1/2 hours of it is a bit much.
The national health-care expose Sicko is likely to divide audiences as much as his previous films. But it's also one of his better works.
An amusingly wry effort that's refreshing, particularly amidst all the overblown, story-deficient summer blockbusters.
This leaden adaptation, which was co-written by Minot and Michael Cunningham, is so full of forced melodrama and clunky literary devices that it becomes a chore just to sit through.
Rescue Dawn is one of the best movies out there -- war or otherwise.
No matter how you feel about the actress, watching this once-promising talent go slumming in this kind of material is grotesque.
This adaptation of Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus' best-selling book has other problems, not the least of which is its rather unpleasant, patronizing tone and its one-note characterizations.
A half-hour of this nonsense would be fine. An hour is a bit much. Nearly an hour and a half is an endurance test.

Documentarian Jennifer Baichwal's film finds a way to comment on ecological and environmental destruction without bludgeoning audiences with heavy-handed messages. There is a mesmerizing quality to the film.

Husband-and-wife filmmakers Ravetch and Robertson capture some breathtaking images. And a global-warming warning, which is saved for the end, is much subtler than the one in last year's animated hit Happy Feet.
A clumsy, talk-heavy and crushingly heavy-handed hybrid. While it may have the best of intentions, Bamako is sometimes hard to watch.

Director Frank Oz has pulled off this kind of material before, most notably in Dirty Rotten Scoundrels. But Death at a Funeral is too crude, and a bit too mean -- in particular, the blackmailing subplot featuring Peter Dinklage.
While the film's preoccupation with sex and teens will immediately turn off many, there's no denying that a lot of this material is funny. Some of it is laugh-out-loud funny.
A smart and well-acted drama that is a refreshing change of pace from this summer's overblown blockbusters.
Around the hour mark, the movie takes a turn for the worse. Not to give too much away, but it pretty much turns into a dumber, gory thriller.
Writer/director Ham Tran sheds light on life in post-Vietnam War, and there are some very strong moments.

The film features the same noxious mix of racial humor, sexual innuendo and violent slapstick as its predecessors. A racially insensitive gag revisiting Abbott and Costello's 'Who's on first?' routine is painful to watch.
About all the film offers is some bad CGI effect work, a bored-sounding Jason Lee providing the voice of the heroic canine and lots of dumb slapstick.
Talk to Me helps make the case that Don Cheadle may be one of the most important American actors working in film today.
[It] feels honest and direct, which is more than you can say about a lot of movies these days.
Hot Rod is pretty dumb, and a good half of its gags fall flat -- but homages to cheesy '80s cinema and television are worth a couple of chuckles.

El Cantante hits several of the low points in the life of pioneering Salsa music singer Hector Lavoe. But it glosses over many -- if not all -- of the high points in his too-brief life and music career.
Patrice Leconte has taken a story about male friendship, in all its posturing and potential vulnerability, and turned it into a light, smart, crowd-pleasing comedy.
The Bourne Ultimatum hits the ground running -- quite literally. The film begins with an exciting foot-chase scene and doesn't let up.
[An] appealing and crowd-pleasing film.
While De Niro's direction is certainly stylish, the frosty performances are off-putting.
It's a character-driven story that lets the humor flow naturally from the story's details. Also, the handsome, colorful backgrounds here have a mind-blowing, photorealistic quality.
1408 offers proof that you really can make a creepy and effective, PG-13-rated horror movie.
Zoo would be laughable if it weren't in such bad taste.
[Director Hartley] has a solid lead in Posey, who's amusing, especially as her character gains confidence and as she begins to turn the tables on the duplicitous Fulbright and others.
The cast is good, particularly Azema, Arditi -- and Morante, who deserves more screen time than she gets.

Thankfully, Puccini for Beginners isn't quite as exploitative as you might expect for a movie about a bisexual love triangle. But that's about all the credit this flat-footed, would-be screwball comedy gets.

This psychological thriller does have a few effective moments. However, it goes a little further - too far, in fact. There are some sexually explicit moments in this that would likely garner an NC-17 rating had it been submitted to the U.S. ratings board.
This one appears to simply be scenes set in a rural Thai hospital that were strung together at random.
Even if the rest of the film was a complete dog, ,i>Away From Her would be worthwhile simply because it gives Julie Christie so much screen time.
This somewhat lowbrow fantasy spoof simply repeats the same jokes -- once, twice, three times ... or more.
Waitress has some unexpected twists and turns and features some refreshingly offbeat humor, as well as terrific performances by its cast.
Two screenwriters were responsible for this fascinating look at organized crime in China, as well as the continuing governmental policies that make the triads thrive.
movie_title: Triad Election (Hak se wui yi wo wai kwai) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Ludicrous plotting undermines the talented cast.
There's actually a sweet little romantic comedy at the core of Blind Dating, fighting its way to get out of the cruder, crasser outer shell.
One of the opening scenes in The Ex is a food fight, which is an apt metaphor for this comedy: It's a bit of a mess and pretty wasteful.
As odd as it is mesmerizing.
The best part of the film is Shannon, who shows surprising range here.

The action scenes are a blast, and there are some welcome comedic elements -- including yet another scene-stealing bit by J.K. Simmons, as sleazy newspaper publisher J. Jonah Jameson.
The plotting in After the Wedding is melodramatic, even a bit soap-operatic. Yet, unlike many Hollywood features and TV soaps, the material is done in a way that seems refreshingly real and honest.

As implausible and over-the-top as certain elements are, this is the one big summer movie that's actually fun. It doesn't take itself too seriously, and it features so much action that you don't really have time to think about plot inconsistencies.
The film runs nearly three hours long and feels like it.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Knocked Up has more heart than any of the Hollywood blockbusters released so far this year ... combined.
Sweet and surprisingly involving, and several of the songs deserve to be hits.
This is also not exactly what you'd call action-driven; it's a bit slow and talky. But those who are patient and open-minded will be rewarded with its unique rhythms and beauty.

As impressive as Jolie's transformation is, the film's real star is director Michael Winterbottom, who never lets the high-profile actress overwhelm his film, which is more of a character piece than a kidnapping drama.
There really aren't any laugh-out-loud moments. Even comic pros like Wanda Sykes, John Michael Higgins and Goodman are straining a bit here.
The story behind Crazy Love is pretty fascinating. But the storytelling in this documentary isn't always so fascinating.
Rich in story and character.
movie_title: The Earrings of Madame De... (Madame de...) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: It's more action-oriented and has a lot more welcome humor [than the first].
The movie plays out like a particularly unfunny, dysfunctional family sitcom and features even less action than its predecessor.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While it may not be quite as memorable as such classic sports films as Hoosiers, Rocky and The Natural, it does have a worthwhile girl-power message and an appealing cast, along with a fairly satisfying emotional climax.
Has lost none of its power to amaze and enthrall. And this magical adaptation of the much-filmed Jean-Marie Leprince de Beaumont tale clearly inspired much of the imagery for the Disney version.
movie_title: Beauty and The Beast (La Belle et la bête) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: So slow, cold and aloof that it's almost off-putting. As a result, it's hard to care much about what happens to any of these characters.
There is just enough good stuff to outweigh the bad.
It turns into yet another graphic Hostel-style killfest that eventually washes away all the fun ... with lots of blood.
Despite a few diverting and modestly amusing moments, Thirteen doesn't match the 2001 comic-caper remake Ocean's Eleven. And the whole hipper, cooler, more clever formula is starting to wear thin.
There's a troubling reliance on flatulence and scatological humor, as well as inside jokes that even some adults may not understand.
The Valet is a trifle with a few good ideas strewn about, but which feels rushed and too flimsy for its own good.
This very inside but modestly amusing show-business satire doesn't seem too far-fetched or exaggerated.
The film's format and style dictate that she has to hold our interest throughout, sometimes without dialogue.
The filmmaker can't help but place himself in the middle of things -- his occasional voiceover narration is more irritating than amusing. And he's got no real sense of comic timing.

movie_review_blurb: The film is fortunate to have these two stars -- McConaughey brings some much-needed life and spark, while Fox provides some gravitas.
Too heavy on the mocking and too light on the laughs.
As expected, Rocky Balboa is pretty cornball, cliched and predictable. Yet there's more life than you might think in the old war horse -- both the character and the concept.

Machado, a former assistant to Central Station filmmaker Walter Salles, doesn't seem to have a particular cinematic destination in mind for these characters, and the rather abrupt ending doesn't work.
The film is probably destined to be a cult success at best, since the TV program was an acquired taste and could be a little much, even when limited to 30 minutes.
Serrill is ... able to generate some genuine suspense, and the ensuing human drama -- most of it swirling around Russell, one of the few black students at the mostly white school -- is fascinating.

There are certainly worse ideas out there for movie comedies than My Super Ex-Girlfriend. (The Wayans brothers hit Little Man, for example.) However, there aren't many ideas that are more poorly executed than this one.
Smith may be an acquired taste, but Clerks II is his most consistently funny film since the first Clerks, a dozen years ago.
Some of the humor is a little crude for a PG-rated film, and the material does get dark. But the animation is bright and colorful, and it looks pretty spectacular.

The surprise here is that he's created a story mythology for this fantasy/thriller that's so ludicrous and convoluted that it's almost laughable. At times it seems his cast members are making up the story as they go.

While the soundtrack of Cuban dance music is superb, this historical drama is leaden and simply too long-winded for its own good.
A ludicrous, would-be Western hybrid.
Those unfamiliar with the book will probably be confused. And the film's statements about addiction and the drug wars aren't exactly subtle.
In You, Me and Dupree, Owen Wilson plays a freeloading houseguest who wears out his welcome after one day. The film wears out its welcome considerably sooner than that.

The whole thing leaves a bad taste in your mouth.

While this somber drug-abuse drama contains few surprises -- it's pretty much what we've come expect to expect from such material -- Cheung's convincing performance as a drug addict is what makes it watchable.
The film succeeds by following the Spellbound format and formula.
Director Gore Verbinski manages to pull all these story elements together and smoothly shifts gears as the story blends dark fantasy, goofy humor and melodrama (including a love triangle of sorts).

The whole thing is so mean-spirited, cruel and crude that all the funny jokes in the world couldn't make up for it.
While it has handsome production values and a talented cast, this is the type of shallow, vapid movie that tricks you into thinking it's better cinema than it actually is.

The would-be street hoopster characters of Crossover have plenty of flashy, original moves. Sadly, the movie itself has none.
This film wastes the talents of the entire cast.

As expected, the soundtrack is the highlight of Idlewild. Unfortunately, the film's rather thin plot keeps getting in the way of the music.
Unapologetically crude and politically incorrect, this is certainly not for everyone. But those with an appreciation for such things will be delighted.
A little predictable, but it does have a certain appealing cattiness and bite.

... it's probably the best movie Pollack has made in awhile.

The kind of metaphysical nonsense that gives New Age a bad name.
Remarkably unsubtle and by-the-numbers, and thanks to some curious plotting, it's also a bit shrill and unpleasant.
Little Miss Sunshine is a modestly amusing movie with good performances and several promisingly absurd situations.
Some modest charms and a few unexpected emotional punches.
Zeiger makes good use of archival footage, photos and sound bites from the period. And the frankness of his interview subjects is refreshing.
It's not exactly brain fodder. But it is fun.

The nature and sound of Johnston's music is an acquired taste, and that also goes for director Jeff Feuerzeig's documentary -- though the film is intelligent and approaches the various mental-health issues addressed here in a sensitive manner.
A thrill-less thriller.
Certainly this one doesn't stack up favorably with the first two movies, but the third cinematic X-adventure is far from the worst superhero film ever made -- even lately.
Judging by the cinematic results, Dan Brown's mega-best-seller is one of those books that should have remained on the printed page.
Self-involved and self-indulgent. It's almost as if [Zahedi] made the movie for himself, for his loved ones and for no one else.

In addition to a few laugh-out-loud moments, this animated comedy actually manages to say something about the perils of our own modern-day, consumerist society. (Though it's not done in a way that's too overt or preachy.)
One of the more balanced portraits of the war -- if for no other reason than it shows what everyday life is like for Muslims and Iraqis since the U.S. invasion began.
Duobuji shows he has a strong, charismatic presence in his role as the patrol leader, Ritai.
In the wrong hands this material could have gone awry. But screenwriter/director Rian Johnson's first feature never takes the easy way out.

Clunky romantic comedy, which has the annoying habit of turning dead serious at exactly the wrong moment.

movie_review_blurb: Stiller is clearly comfortable playing this kind of put-upon character, and his performance here is less forced than some of his recent work.
At times the film is labored and forced.
The soccer drama Goal! The Dream Begins is so formulaic and rambling that you can't help but get a little tired of it less than an hour in.

movie_review_blurb: It's pretty much a customary coming-of-age tale, though it is told with refreshing honesty and realism.
This comedy-drama has some modest charms.

Full of too much blah, blah. And way too much of the shrill, shrieking, screaming, carrying-on variety.
This earlier pairing between the two masters is another well-crafted and thought-provoking film. And it makes you wish that Reed and Greene had teamed for more than just three films.

movie_review_blurb: In Roman J. Israel, Esq., Denzel Washington establishes the inner life of his character without having to say a word.

movie_review_blurb: [The] panoramic expanses reinforce the dream-like, episodic quality of the pacing.

movie_review_blurb: The movie is a less assured version of Shira Piven's Welcome to Me, in which she and Kristen Wiig unleash the full neurotic potential of the "15 minutes of fame" expression. The Clapper only pays lip service to it.

movie_review_blurb: Like Young & Beautiful, Ozon can't figure out if he's empowering or exploiting his heroine.

movie_review_blurb: It's a retelling of the classic holiday tale - one told while under construction. In fits and starts, the writer's imagination pieces together everyday material along with some inner torments.

We feel for the characters without seeing or sharing their varied points of view. We only observe - dumbfounded and uncomprehending - like a pigeon staring down from a tree branch.

movie_review_blurb: Remarkable raw performances by Leonardo DiCaprio and Tom Hardy. Leaves you with feelings of isolation and determination and new found respect for all who settled America and braved the frontier. Stunning!

A dull ghost story that never gives any thrills to its more than patient audience who must endure characters that get lost in a haunted forest from which no one can escape. Horror was never so boring.
Classic Tarantino mixed with Agatha Christie and John Ford! Simply stunning 70mm photography and a dream cast that can't be beat!

Technically a reboot from the original 1977 film, J. J. Abrams breathes live back into the franchise, pleasing old fans and creating legions of new ones. I felt like I was 12 years-old again!
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Formulaic romantic comedy? Of course, but will satisfy the Valentine's Day crowd with enough laughs and romance for any couple. Rebel Wilson is a comic tornado and is worth the price of admission.
Deadpool is over-the-top funny, very bloody, violent and the best Marvel movie that's made for adults ! Not bad for an anti-hero that wears a mask, swings ninja swords and cannot die.
"Son of Saul" is an unforgettable and visceral experience from first time director, Laszlo Nemes - stays with you long after it's over.

An outstanding ghost story that delivers thrills and chills and moments of heartfelt tenderness. Director, James Wan raises the bar again for the horror genre with his original camera work and master storytelling.
Director, Duncan Jones delivers a fantasy-action epic that will satifsy hardcore Warcraft gamers and fans of the Fantasy genre.

Director Zach Snyder delivers an intense epic tale of DC Comics greatest heroes. Ben Affleck owns Batman and despite a long winded and flawed third act, a superb introduction into the DC Universe. See it in IMAX!
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sacha Baron Cohen crosses the line and every step of the way is a hilarious, action cult classic!
A suspenseful and glorified Twilight Zone episode that provides plenty of thrills and twists to keep you squirming in your seat. John Goodman delivers one of the best performances of his career!
$140 Million dollar spectacle that follows no coherent storyline but is filled with pointless action sequences with actors from Denmark, Scotland and England - all portraying Egyptian Gods.

Incredible feat for first time Director, Robert Eggers. "The Witch" is a chilling, original and authentic story of a New England family torn apart by fear and religious convictions in the midst of a witch in the nearby woods.
Outrageous action mixed with over-the-top one liners makes for a wild fun ride across the pond.
One of Disney's best animated films ever! Fun for adults and kids alike.

The Jesse Owens story! Inspirational and uplifting! A true American hero! Bring the whole family!

movie_review_blurb: If you're up for indulging in its insanity and sullying of Disney good girls Gomez and Hudgens, you'll no doubt love it, but if not you may want to let this spring break pass you by.

Provided you don't put too much thought into it and just enjoy the ride, you'll have a blast.
My kind of romantic comedy. It's funny, a bit silly and doesn't try to set the new standard for romance in the genre. It's exactly what you expect, but in a good way.
Isn't just a pleasant surprise, it's also the first 'get up and go see it!' movie of 2013.
Dumb as it may be at times, I still liked it well enough, but I'm pretty sure I would have loved it with a smarter script.
The year's best action thriller with excellent performances from its two leads and Mann's brilliant direction making something as pedestrian as a taxi ride a pulse-pounding thrill ride.

movie_review_blurb: This is a franchise whose filmmakers know what their audience likes and delivers movies that they'll love.

You really have an obligation to see it to witness what has a legitimate claim of being the best action film of all time.

If you're a fan of the series, this is finally the 'Resident Evil' experience you've been waiting on.

Luhrmann doesn't so much make films as he does experiences and he's done it again with a luxuriously engaging extravaganza that all but renders another adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald's classic unnecessary.
Another flawed, but fun animated film featuring the Man of Steel.

Inspired film making and the kind of blockbuster that I can only hope will spark the next wave of visionary sci-fi films in the same way that Kosinski was influenced and so wonderfully honors here.

One of the more inspirational sports films you'll see.

movie_review_blurb: Entertaining for what it is and the alpha male werewolves end up being a lot more fun than the brooding, moody vampires.
Yes, it's strongly geared to the teen audience, but don't hold it against the filmmakers and go in with any preconceived notions and you'll find it a fun opening chapter of a new franchise.
Easily transformed into the worst summer blockbuster of the year.
Fittingly for an election season that has now just ended, we're treated to a movie that's a candidate for one of the best films of the year.
'Skyfall' isn't the best James Bond film, but it's easily the most gorgeous entry of 007's world yet.
Never reaches the heights of Daniel Craig's first outing as 007, but it's enjoyable enough and continues the path of redeeming the franchise.

Neither a smear campaign nor propaganda piece, but rather a fascinating look at one of the more controversial presidents in recent memory that may end up changing your perspective on the Bush you only thought you knew.
A streamlined back to basics approach for Bond that hits all the right marks in rejuvenating the franchise for a new generation.
A few power-ups shy of a classic, but its winking look at the world of video games is fun, even if it doesn't reach its full potential.

An endlessly frustrating effort from filmmakers trying too hard to make you see their vision as a masterpiece instead of simply making one.
Craps out leaving you wondering how it all went so wrong.

Between Cohen's dizzying editing style, the ear-assaulting soundtrack and a leaky script, there's plenty of suspects that ruin this case.
Surprisingly a lot of fun, with a simple good vs. evil plot, nice action sequences and a battle of the ages between two of the biggest martial art movie masters.
Rarely has a movie had a more appropriate title.

It's like a picturesque, ride down a long countryside road in autumn bursting with wonderful imagery; richly developed characters complimented by an excellent score that quickly brings you into this small in scope, but big on brilliance effort.
A fully-realized achievement that does right by fans of the source material and is the new standard of excellence for Warner animated films.
movie_title: Batman: The Dark Knight Returns, Part 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It could have been the start of a new wave of modern era mob movies, but it's merely competent instead of trend-setting.
There's a lot to like here and with strong performances all-around, a fresh script with characters that sound and act real. Add this film to your essential Oscar viewing game plan.
Misses the mark and few who see it will feel like they got the happily ever after they deserved.
This ensemble is a lively fun bunch that warrants several curtain calls.
A scattered drama that can't be bothered to play by its own rules making for an uneven, inconsistent viewing experience.
An explosive throwback that will thrill action fans who love watching tough guys blow stuff up.
The character designs are adequate, the action scenes are decent and some of the jokes are funny, but it all feels too familiar and done far better before.
A compelling, nail-biting spy thriller.
Bigelow isn't trying to entertain the audience, but I'm not sure what she wants us to take from the film as the end credits start.
Bullet-ridden with clichés and a lousy script that wastes its talented cast, 'Gangster Squad,' will have you wishing you remembered where you put your copy of 'Casino' or 'The Untouchables.'
Not a life-changing romantic comedy, but it's funny enough, has charming leads and breezes by in its quick 97 minutes.
A gut-wrenching film and one you don't just watch, you experience.
So devoid of any spark that it feels like watching someone's boring vacation videos.
Ultimately a well-meaning effort that is simply remarkable for being so unremarkable.
It's all great fun until the ending, which feels a little too safe, simple and silly to what had otherwise been an enjoyably twisted horror film.
Easily the best film of its genre since 'Soul Food' and definitely makes for a excellent holiday season treat.
Ranges from being brilliant, controversial,talky,long and cartoonishly violent. Basically it's Tarantino at his best and worse.
Just try and resist the urge to give it a standing ovation when the credits start.
Cruise is all set to make this the start of a new action franchise and while he delivers, the rest of the film is a silly, plodding effort that never fully comes together.
It's great whenever Rudd and Mann are together and when they're not, things get dicey.
Gets off to a decent start for this next trilogy, but it's not the epic, genre-redefining event of the one that preceded it.
Not for the squeamish and is definitely for those that can handle a lot of sick and twisted violence. Recommended for true torture porn fans.
The kind of brilliant comedy that will have you gasping, laughing so hard you'll have tears in your eyes and rocking back in your chair from laughter.
A noticeable drop in quality from the first two, but it's still decent enough that you don't have to be embarrassed for liking it. That comes soon enough...
A fun homage to the 1987 original that's every bit as explosive and exhilarating.
Had the execution been tighter, it would be an easy recommendation, but as is, there's no need to rush off from Thanksgiving leftovers to see it.
So well done that it justifies every moment fans have not so patiently awaited the second installment of what has become the most satisfying franchise since 'Harry Potter.'
A movie that has a tremendous premise and awesome special effects that are ultimately hindered by a script that prevents its characters from every fully taking off.
Take notice Hollywood, your next most promising triple threat has arrived with one of the freshest and funniest comedies this year.
Reunited and it feels so good through the laughs and the cheers, 'The Best Man Holiday' is one of the most charming comedy/dramas in years.

Maybe you could stretch some deeper meaning out of it, surmising that Coppola wanted to make as vapid and empty a movie as her subjects and their inspiration. That's great for a Film & Society term paper, but it doesn't exactly make for a riveting movie.
The most thoroughly fan pleasing comic book film since 'The Avengers.' I'm already pumped up for 'Thor 3.'
Strikes a mighty blow to the summer blockbuster season and will charge up audiences just like the first 'Iron Man.'
A runaway powerhouse film packed with emotionally-gripping performances, outstanding direction and a script that challenges viewers like few other films have this year.
Packed with a staunch anti-war sentiment and anti-bullying message in a slick looking science-fiction package, it has a lot to say, but little of it is especially entertaining.
Features two action hero workhorses from the 1980s, but the film's decrepit script is the only throwaway relic in this otherwise entertaining action thriller.

The most powerful movie I never want to see again. This is not a film meant to entertain or be enjoyed, but rather provide the most unflinching, rawest portrayal of slavery ever put to film and McQueen accomplishes that masterfully.
Isn't just a great movie, it's a great experience that frequently astonishes, captivates and embraces the challenge of raising the bar on what we should expect from modern day films.
One of the best laugh til you cry comedies of the last decade.
A fascinating exercise in cinematic restraint resulting in a captivating, not to be missed film.
If Christopher Nolan never decided to direct a Batman movie, 'Batman Returns' would easily reign as the best film starring the Caped Crusader.
The sophisticated outrageous adult comedy we've been waiting for all year. It's smart, funny and has a charming message while hinting at Joseph Gordon-Levitt's seemingly limitless potential.

Isn't terrible and is actually pretty charming - but it feels dated and strictly sticks to the established genre format, playing out like a dusted-off script Jennifer Lopez had sitting on her shelf since the early 2000s.
The best cop/mob movie remains decidedly untouchable.

You might not fall out of your seat laughing, but the film is consistently enjoyable from start to the very clever and amusing finish and with its brisk 93 minutes, it's worth taking a dip in this tub.
The performances aren't enough to make this a must-see as the script leaves them hanging too often and may leave you steaming with disappointment.
A charming effort that successfully combines gorgeous modern animation with the retro feel of a Disney classic.
A promising film about a hit man that ultimately gets wacked because its star isn't suited for the role at all.
Thoughtful, relatable and often hilarious. Wisely timed for a Valentine's Day release, couples won't find a better option than this romantic crowd pleaser.

While not nearly as worthless a remake as the 2012 take on 'Total Recall,' this updated approach is nonetheless just as uninspired, turning the revenge-seeking super cop into a miscast comic book superhero.
A clunky, dull effort that lacks any measure of excitement or thrills, desperately leaving you wanting more and wishing its talented filmmakers could have done more with such an intriguing premise.
Warner Bros. Animated fans have come to expect a supremely high standard of excellence from the films featuring the characters from the DC Comics Universe and 'War' just doesn't measure up.

With Valentine's Day fast approaching, you may be tempted to give this film a shot, but don't. You'll be far better off going with stale chocolate and wilted flowers than treating any of your loved ones to this debacle.
With better visuals, it would easily be among the Top 5 DC animated films, but dubious designs keep it just out of elite class status.
A pleasant, harmless distraction that's plenty of fun if you want a lighter take on the world of caped crusaders

Beyond the expected excellent performance by Streep and a stellar cast headlined by Roberts - all of whom have been more enjoyable in better films - there's little reason to sit through what amounts to be a very miserable family reunion.
There's just so little to be enthusiastic about a film so laughingly bad and perfectly underwhelming. On the bright side, we've already got a strong contender for worst film of the year.

There may not be another filmmaker in better position to create the next 'Saving Private Ryan,' but this represents another passion project for Berg that fails to give audiences a reason to care as much as its director.
For 007 fans or action adventure/spy movie fans in general, it really doesn't get much better than "Goldfinger," a tremendous blockbuster that entertains on every level.
Fuqua once again proves his mastery of the cop/crime drama genre, making for the best of its kind since 'The Departed.'
Unlike anything else you'll see this year. It's a romantic drama that dares to be different and with Jonze at the peak of his storytelling prowess, it's easy to love.
Has its moments, but is largely forgettable and with so many better options currently in theaters, this is strictly a preliminary bout that can easily be skipped.

Like a hyperactive three-year-old. Sure, for a little while the over-the-top antics and outrageous moments are cute, but after three hours, it becomes exhausting and annoying leaving you simply waiting for it to finally be put to bed.

Don't get distracted by all the quick talking, double-crosses or backstabbing. Just enjoy some of today's most talented masters of their craft doing what they do best in a film that will leave you feeling anything but ripped off once it's over.
An audience-pleasing, if incomplete look behind the Walt Disney empire's curtain.

Two-thirds of the way through 'The Hobbit' trilogy and it's apparent that while this won't match the level of excellence of the LOTR films, Jackson still finds a little more magic left in Middle Earth.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It won't matter if you've never cared about racing before. Just sit back and enjoy Howard's latest exhilarating effort based on the real life story of one of the most competitive rivalries in sports history.

Too much of brilliantly good thing. It's like watching the director's cut that goes a bit deeper into the character development and filled with scenes the filmmakers loved, but realized weren't essential for the final cut.

Packed with hot women, a ninja-like character and zombies, it's the kind of movie a 15-year-old would make with a limitless budget and little concern for ratings. Good thing he knows how to make an incredibly fun movie.
movie_title: Planet Terror (Grindhouse Presents: Robert Rodriguez's Planet Terror) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The most enjoyable thriller I've seen in years and one of the easiest recommendations for fans of the genre I'll make all year.
A gut-busting effort that will leave you gasping for air, rocking in your seat and holding back tears of laughter.

Simply works because the filmmakers understood what audiences loved about the surprise 2010 hit and just deliver on that promise in creating a sequel overflowing with heart, charm and those awesome Minions.
On the short list of sequels that not only matched the quality of its predecessor, but arguably surpassed it to become one of the greatest films of its genre.
'The Heat' is about as generic a movie title as you can get, but calling the Sandra Bullock/Melissa McCarthy film 'The Disappointing F-Bomb Fiasco' may have been a bit too specific.

A movie that makes you feel dumber every second you're watching it and thanks to its two-hour plus run time, you'll be backed to a second grade reading level by the time the end credits mercifully arrive.
Isn't the same thinking man's zombie film as its predecessor, but it ramps up the action and will leave you on edge enough that you'll be searching for a nightlight before going to sleep.
A very entertaining film that's funny, good-natured and better than 95% of its non-Pixar animated competition.

Wants to be a little bit of everything - a tense, edge-of-your-seat thriller, a star-powered summer blockbuster and chaotic zombie epic, but ultimately like the film's antagonists, I didn't leave out feel very satisfied at all.
One of the genre's best pure zombie-fest films featuring regular folks against an army of the undead.
A phenomenal game-changer that could potentially redefine the world's most famous superhero for a new generation of moviegoers in the same way as Nolan's 'Dark Knight' trilogy.
Easily the most disappointing entry in the DC Comics animated film catalogue.
Would have benefited greatly from Singer trusting his talent and assembling a Superman movie that attempted to soar beyond the heights previously achieved decades ago.
Anderson unfortunately has all the subtlety of Kim Kardashian in a thong bikini so he can't resist the urge of teasing the pending eruption instead of doing any worthwhile character development.
Maybe it's possible for a director to make demon raping and urine drinking side-achingly funny, but that wasn't the case here.

For sentimentality's sake, it's great watching Reeve and company reprise their roles even if it's in the bastard child edition of the series, but this isn't just one of the worst comic book films, it's one of the worst films ever made.
movie_title: Superman IV: The Quest for Peace (1987)

movie_review_blurb: The fascinating curiosity that's worth watching, but the theatrical edition remains the more defining take on 'Superman's' sequel.
On some levels soars above its predecessor with a more personal story; credible, menacing villains and an impeccable cast.
The most influential, if not definitive comic book superhero origin story we'll ever see.
If you're in the mood for a lighthearted film this is a pleasant and consistently funny crowd-pleaser.
Don't take it too seriously and you'll have a good time.
A spellbinding caper that will keep you guessing right until the final act.

If you smile at the thought of giant robots fighting giant monsters, del Toro has crafted a cinematic love letter specifically with you in mind. Those not immediately sold on the premise should sit this installment of Rock'Em Sock'Em robots out.
One of those dull films where parents are gonna have to take one for the team and suffer through.
As bad as spending quality time with that annoying relative telling you how much better things were back in the day, but in the case of this movie they'd actually be right.
See it and prepare to be captivated by the most spellbinding sci-fi film of them all.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back (1980)

movie_review_blurb: Has an intriguing concept, but with tired jokes, dumb characters and uninspired direction, the execution is botched all around making for a perfect example of all that's bad with the romantic comedy genre.
The weakest of the good DC Comics Universe direct to video movies.
While there's some crater-sized flaws if you want to be nit-picky, this is Bay's finest, earnestly entertaining film and an easy crowd pleaser.

A cinematic catastrophe where the filmmakers seemed less intent on entertaining their audience so much as inducing nausea and seizures. Pass the Dramamine or take the title literally and skip this disaster.
Highly recommended even for fans who think Batman begins and ends with Nolan's trilogy.
This is about as simple and uncomplicated you can get, but it isn't trying to do anything beyond providing some quick and easy laughs in a refreshingly heavenly comedy.

Easily one of the year's worst films. It's so groan-worthy awful that it's actually insulting to its target teen demographic, who despite a higher threshold for mediocrity than most, definitely deserve better.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: For non-discerning action fans looking to satisfy your adrenaline rush, you can add this film to your most wanted list.
Feels like the limp, uninspired third installment of a franchise that should have been put out of its misery a film ago. Skip the further adventures of Kick-Ass and his Super Foul-Mouthed Friends.
A well-meaning, but overly long history lesson that largely finds its captivating hook whenever the attention is focused off its title character.
A tremendously fresh experience.

Packed with potential, but Blomkamp can't pull it together to make it work. He's conflicted if he wants to just make a fun blockbuster or a commentary on today's society, but not choosing a side results in a disjointed, lacking effort.
The kind of laugh till it hurts, spit-take funny, doubling over in your seat comedy that lesser films can only aspire to.
Such an uneventful outing really seems beneath Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg, the latter of whom recently appeared in a film with a dry humping teddy bear.
Years from now it may be looked at as the animated film that took the direct to video comic book movie market to another level of storytelling possibilities. Yes, it's that good.
movie_title: DCU: Justice League: The Flashpoint Paradox (2013)

movie_review_blurb: One of the best entries in the X-Men franchise and comes thisclose to being one of the best comic book movies if it weren't for a disappointing final act.
While the film easily straddles the lines of good taste, Carey doesn't push the limits enough to deliver on its 'good girl gone really bad' premise.

Every iota of logic, common decency and college educated critical self within me all but screamed that this film is an insult to my intelligence and an affront to the entire human race and I'd listen if I wasn't so busy laughing.
Just like the Russian crowd cheering on Rocky in 'Rocky IV,' I was rooting for a happy ending even though my cynical little movie critic mind knew the result should be obvious.
The ending leaves just enough of a cliffhanger that a fifth installment is all but guaranteed. If it's anything like this one, I'm down for the ride.
An endlessly creative mind-blowing film that captures everything right about the movie going experience. Johnson conjures up the most imaginative action/science fiction film since 'Inception.'
Despite the name, it's a pretty safe bet for an enjoyable film for the whole family.
It's not terrible by any means, just completely lacking that sense of amazement and anything-can-happen spirit that the six (or five if you're a 'Phantom Menace' hater) films had to spare.
Your love of 'Pineapple Express' will largely depend on how funny you find a movie with 85 percent of the jokes based on smoking marijuana.
for its target audience it's going to prove even better than finding that perfect pair of pants in your size.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Ferrell shows there's only so many times you can milk the same cow before the milk spoils.

If you can imagine the thrill of a Disney World ride with all its leaps, bounds, twists, turns and runaway dinosaurs, you've got a good sense of the wonder and excitement that awaits you with the surprisingly entertaining flick.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: an exciting, edge-of-your-seat summer flick.
Carrell delivers a winning performance in the summer's first must-see comedy ''Get Smart" and one of the best TV-to-film efforts yet.
It's puzzling to me why a quality romantic comedy/drama such as this gets sent to DVD purgatory
Brace the box office as 'The Incredible Hulk' smashes its way through a rock 'em, sock 'em romp sure to please summer audiences
those seeking a more meaningful romantic comedy should probably just rent 'My Best Friend's Wedding' instead.
You'll believe a (iron) man can fly in 'Iron Man,' the undisputed movie to beat this summer season.
I really question the casting of Wilson because he looked almost as bored making the movie as the audience that has to suffer through it
a flat-out winner that's funny and has a great message for kids and adults alike.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: accomplishes a rare feat even for the truly terrible movies in that it doesn't manage a consistent level of mediocrity but surpasses it seemingly with each and every scene proving that oh yes, it can and will get worse.
I'm starting to think that '24' and 'The Bourne Identity' have made it nearly impossible for me to enjoy the average or even slightly above average spy thriller.
has a tremendous premise and awesome special effects that are ultimately hindered by a plot that doesn't go deeper than its ''isn't this cool?" gimmick.
too afraid of deviating from the typical dance movie formula. And in all honesty, it's not such a great blueprint to bother following anyway.
If the Wachowski brothers failed to grasp anything else about their latest project, they know that it's all about family ... and speed

Clearly, Lee's efforts show a director who is passionate about the film's message and isn't just attaching his name to get a big paycheck. No, this is a labor of love but it's just as much of a labor to sit through.

At first glance, it seems like just another 'cute' movie where we see life through the eyes of an animal. Your first glance would actually be pretty accurate but as far as this genre goes, the kids should love it and adults won't need to keep checking the
Cera and Dennings save the film from being a complete waste of time with their quirky chemistry that's awkward, at times clumsy but consistently feels genuine.
I honestly wish it could change itself into a good movie, instead it ends up being one of the worst sequels I've ever seen.
Eddie Murphy's latest movie is not worth paying to see. Gee, imagine that?
the kind of brilliant comedy that will have you gasping, laughing so hard you'll have tears in your eyes.
proves there's plenty of life left in the Terminator franchise.
Maybe Howard and Hanks should have uttered a few 'Hail Marys' before filming?
Everything from the score, the slow motion effects to Abrams' ability to instantly draw you into this new universe quickly sets the tone for an engaging two-hour thrill ride.
You won't see much new, but you'll enjoy every moment of it.
The kind of film that really would benefit from a release later on in the year to receive award consideration along with all the other November-December contenders.
this first installment was actually entertaining enough that a sequel could work out the kinks to become a very solid franchise.
DreamWorks proves it can be a force in the animation genre with its highly entertaining effort here.
poised to be the comedy film to beat this year with its unique spin on the importance of best friends.
proves that some remakes can be just as entertaining if not more so, than the original.
The comic's tag line was "Who Watches the Watchmen?" and if you're not among those who are, you're likely missing out on the comic book film of the year.
the first drama about a hip-hop star's personal and professional life, rather than the culture itself, and it is worthwhile.
they don't make movies like this anymore
Yes I know it's only February but I feel pretty confident in declaring this farce a solid lock for Worst Film of 2009.
Director/co-screenwriter Sean Anders knows the best comedies are the unpredictable ones and he keeps the affair from getting stale with quick cuts and increasingly crazy scenarios for the characters.
If you're in need of a good nap, you might want to stop through this city of blinded lights, but otherwise, it's not worth a visit.
Oscar voters leery of voting for (gasp!) comic book movie, 'The Dark Knight,' for multiple accolades come award season finally have another option with the release of 'Body of Lies.'
If you're in the mood for a boring by the numbers romantic comedy, this is for you.
It's no illusion - "The Prestige" is the best film of 2006
still an overabundance of potty humor but as far as this franchise goes, I'll take improvements in baby steps
Jackson, Moore and Falco keep things from ever becoming too tedious even with a made for TV plot for a film.
...films like 'Battlefield Earth' and 'The Adventures of Pluto Nash' await a film of this magnitude because it gets awfully lonely on the island of misfit movies.
...one of the best action films I've seen in a long time.
"...one of the best films of its genre."
one of the year's best films.
certainly the animated movie of the year and, for my money, one of the best times you'll have at the movies all year.
as a football movie it scores, but as a drama that goes beyond the field and into the lives of the characters playing the game, it falls short of becoming a champ.
it's much like most of today's children entertainment - vapid and uneventful - or in other words, this is one fish tale that anyone will have a tough time swallowing.
Conran creates a wonderfully inventive, fun little world so exciting that one hopes that he returns to entertain us again with another tale of Sky Captain and co.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The year's best action thriller with excellent performances from its two leads and Mann's brilliant direction.
While Damon doesn't have the benefit of surprising anyone with its sequel, "The Bourne Supremacy," it proves just as enjoyable as its predecessor.
...makes me long for the quiet dignity of Arnold Schwarzenegger's performance in 'Batman and Robin.'
Much in the same way that Blade Runner redefined the science-fiction/ suspense genre in the 1980s, I, Robot will for a new generation.
Everyone involved created a masterpiece of comic book film that's better on every level than its predecessor...this is the summer movie you've been waiting for all year.
The Terminal is the anti-summer movie ... I'll wager that there will be few films released this year that will be this pleasant a surprise or engaging a movie.
"Prisoner" ironically feels much more unrestrained by the pressure of translating J.K. Rowlings' novels into films and is easier to just enjoy as a movie.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: I wish that Helen would just dump the kids since she sure would make for an interesting character if she weren't saddled with those kids.
If "Van Helsing," hyped as this year's first big summer blockbuster is any indication of the rest of the summer crop don't wake me until fall...or better yet winter.
It takes a movie like "Kill Bill Vol.2" to serve as a reminder that movies should be entertaining, even as perversely entertaining as this ode to Kung-Fu theater.

While there may be some plot holes or absurd conveniences if you were determined to look hard enough, the film is too much fun to bother worrying about it. Sit back and enjoy it, Captain Neeson has everything fully in control.
The bad news is that the inclusion of a bobble-head doll is not the worst part of this disappointing family comedy.
if you want some jokes that aren't prehistoric, you're better off letting this Ice Age defrost.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: the kind of romantic comedy that even the most unromantic lout in your life will enjoy.
Filled with stylistic violence, over-the-top acting and action and is completely deserving of its R-rating. In other words, I loved every minute of it.
Friedberg and Seltzer's philosophy seems to be - make fun of other movies first, worry about our own movie second. Of course, that means their movie is no good
One family reunion you don't want to miss.
Movie-goers would be better off spending their movie ticket money on the DVD box set of the television series.
The makers of "Must Love Dogs" clearly have an affection towards canines but they didn't seem to even like the audience.
"Stealth" hits the target dead on.
Sky High soars
It may not have Ginger or Mary Ann but this is one island you won't mind being stranded on for a few hours.
As the master chief, Burton combines all the right ingredients for a wholly unique and perfectly entertaining tale.
May look like the kind of movie geared specifically for the hip-hop crowd, but with its dazzling cinematography and heartfelt characters, it's a film for everyone from 50 Cent to Grandma Lucy.
Howard effortlessly makes the successful transition from a strong supporting character actor to a leading man that can carry a film.
So enjoyable I'd love to tune in every week to catch the adventures of Kidman and Ferrell.
The faux lover angle isn't exactly new but when a daughter is more or less trying to woo her mother, it's not original, just weirdly creepy if not a tad incestual.
Batman Begins is one of those rare action films that I found myself eagerly anticipating the sequel...even before the first film had ended.
Feels like watching an hour and a half block of a sitcom - one half hour is really funny, another good for a few laughs and the other the one you could catch in reruns.
Beyond the James Bond-style jokes and an excellent score by John Powell, the film is as flimsy as Jolie's outfits, but it's still fun.
Crowe delivers an Oscar-caliber performance in an emotionally powerful film.
One of the funniest films I've seen in years.
Fonda and Lopez take a potentially tired concept and give it new life
An ingenious spectacle that dares its audience not to get sucked into it's wildly imaginative world.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Sit through the roller coaster plot and enjoy Craven doing what he does best, but don't expect to walk out leery the next time you see a full moon.
While it's not the classic comedy that you haven't lived until you see it, 'Greek' is more than good enough for a few, goofy laughs.

Sacha Baron Cohen has nearly succeeded in his quest to be the film equivalent to Howard Stern. Crude and crass rather than challenging, shocking rather than stimulating, Cohen doesn't seem to care what he does so long as he gets people talking.
filled with over the top gore and unnecessary plot twists better off left unseen. Leave this one at the orphanage.
perfectly parodies the 'kill everything in sight and then blow it up for good measure' summer movie mentality.
an uneven start to a new franchise that may need a director with a completely different vision in order for it to be truly born again.
If you weren't particularly enamored with the first one, chances are this isn't gonna change your opinion on the Madagascar cast
Dowdell shows promise as a director and if he can reach the next level on his scripts, he'll be an independent director worth keeping an eye on in the future.
A summer movie spectacle you'll sit through and by the time you leave the parking lot, you'll be hard pressed to think of anything you liked about it.
a fun, family movie that doesn't aspire, or need to be, anything more.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: there's a lot to like here and a comic film more people should give another chance.
the kind of spectacular edge-of-your-seat epic that will have you hooked right from its jaw-dropping opening sequence and dare you to resist the urge to applaud when it's finished.

After suffering through a summer crammed with TV shows being remade into movies, it's refreshing to see a movie based on a TV show that is so entertaining that it actually makes you want to go and see the show of which the movie was created.
One of those spy thrillers that isn't nearly as thrilling, complex or engaging as the filmmakers think.
If you don't take it seriously, 'Ted' is hilarious at times, obnoxious too often and alternating between being mind-numbingly stupid or brilliant.
If only Kurtzman hadn't gotten so fascinated with the film's big secret, it could have delivered on its potential.
Go in with low expectations and you might be pleasantly surprised, but this isn't another Pixar bulls-eye.
If ever there was an "either you're in or out" movie in 2012, it's definitely this one and if you're in, it just might be the most satisfyingly guilty pleasure of the year.
There's little more to it than a glorified karaoke night that hardly warrants putting your lighters up.
The setup is intriguing, but just as Shelton gets her hands dirty with the mess her characters have made, it's winding down to a seemingly improbable conclusion.
One of those rare movies that's magical for the entire family.
Scott never manages to reach that next gear to really make it special. It's competent, but you likely won't feel as if you've just witnessed a modern-day classic by the time the credits roll.
Justifying the re-launch is a hurdle Webb is never quite able to clear, but what he does accomplish is making the most spectacular version of Spider-Man put to film yet.
has all the charm and good-natured enthusiasm that will appeal to children, but this is one that parents might love even more.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: the kind of all-out, over the top action movie they just don't make anymore, which is probably a good thing because the human brain can only take a movie that provides the equivalent to getting three consecutive adrenaline shots so many times.
It can't be said enough how much Smith's charisma and Jones' deadpan delivery almost save this movie and it's to their credit that this movie isn't as bad as it should be.

For those of us who know what we're in for with the series, the fifth installment is for better or worse, more of the same - albeit with the familiar levels of ridiculousness from its maddeningly inconsistent director/writer
You get exactly what you expect from it, but like the parents in the film, I wanted a lot more than just good enough.
Langella completely drives this film and he's amazing.
Maybe check back in another decade?
Comes tantalizingly close to reaching its potential, but a few ill-advised missteps keep it from passing with honors.

With a simple plot paired with great action scenes in its brisk run time, that's all I really need from the series and 'Resident Evil: Afterlife' puts some new blood and excitement into what was close to becoming a dead franchise.
As far as this franchise goes, it looks like it's game over as the only thing extinct is the creativity.
proves it's not necessarily 'game over' for the video-game movie genre.

This adaptation captures the spirit of the video games and with its fun, anything can happen mindset and tons of over the top violence, 'Resident Evil' proves there may be a future for video game movies yet.
Easily the most maddening aspect of it is that Headland takes a great cast, filled with incredibly likable actors and puts them in utterly unappealing roles.
great performances that will have the audience thoroughly entertained.
I somehow ended up admiring "Doomsday" for being the most unapologetically ridiculously, preposterous action movie I've ever seen.
So easy to relate to, but it's the film's unpredictable nature, great characters and hilarious script that makes it the comedy of the year.
Fey and Poehler have great chemistry and they truly compliment each other well
A phenomenal masterpiece whose creators aren't content with simply making a great comic book movie, but craft one that transcends the genre to become one of the best films this decade.
Just like a great dream you don't want to wake up from, even after the end credits start, you'll desperately crave five more minutes.
A star-studded salute to summertime spectaculars that more than gives action fans all they could want in a big-budget blockbuster.
easily the most ambitious and creative animated film this year.
While it fails in matching the unpredictable excitement of the original, this is more of what I'd want in Pirates sequels. Just a little less of it.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This is what would have been the end result of 'The Lord of the Rings' trilogy if Peter Jackson was more concerned with all-flash and no real substance.
A nice throwback to the original and a fun film in its own right.
Under Stanton's care 'John Carter' is the kind of tremendous fun-filled film that's worth going to the theater to see.
Whenever Guy Pearce's Snow is on screen, the film's a fun, brainless, action flick with a main character that deserves a better movie.
Downey continues his hot streak of performances %u2014 which by itself is worth the price of admission %u2014 and there's a lot to love about this big screen interpretation of Holmes. Case closed.
This masterpiece is definitely one experience worth braving text a lot guy, talking teen girls and parents who can't be bothered to get a babysitter to see in the theater.
It's taken many years for Disney to have a black lead, but the wait was worth it as this is one of Disney's best films in decades that wasn't done by Pixar.

It's not exactly Tweeter-material to say that Freeman has maintained a high standard of acting excellence for decades, but he truly delivers a memorable performance that channels Mandela expertly from his tone to posture and dignified grace.

There's a calamity far greater than the disintegration of the Earth's core that dooms the film '2012,' it's a lesser known phenomenon that most disaster films are smart enough to steer away from ... the magic of 'star power.'
a welcome return to enjoyable horror fare for a series that seemed to have lost its way.
a pleasant surprise that proves there is still some bite left in the crowded vampire genre.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A perfect example of movie making at its best and is a crowd-pleasing adaptation that captures everything that initially made its source material so revered.
flirts with greatness with an impressive first half filled with thrills and solid pacing but it stumbles in its more action-oriented second half.
fun entertainment and definitely worth seeing for fans of science-fiction/high concept films.
It's like one of those self-absorbed, self-important teens that don't understand they're not half as clever as they think.
attempts to lure audiences in with its fast-action but also provides a surprisingly thoughtful commentary on control and freedom and the means some will go to achieve it.
fails to provide audiences with more than a few madcap adventures and changes in scenery.
watching 'death' find new and inventive ways to kill people somehow still hasn't gotten old yet and this latest chapter in the series is just as entertaining as the others.

one of those endearingly cute, funny movies you'll see on cable and wonder why studios don't put their marketing machine behind this kind of film instead of the typical garbage we get passed off on us as summer 'entertainment.'

Just like 100-degree plus weather and muggy conditions, it's been a miserable summer movie season but fortunately Quentin Tarantino is ready to cool us off with a welcome refreshing dose of quality entertainment with his latest ingenious work 'Inglourious
It's not for everyone, but for sci-fi fans and audiences who want something different from the run-of-the-mill no-brainer Hollywood summer film, it's a must-see.
If the marketing suits at Paramount Pictures need a catchy slogan, might I suggest, 'G.I. Joe - hey, at least it's not Transformers.'
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Really there's no reason to see this but if you really need to satisfy your guinea pig fix, hit the local pet store. It's cheaper and far more entertaining.

While years of VH-1's 'Behind the Music' and TMZ have peeled away the mystique of celebrity musicians by showing the blemishes, warts and mishaps that come with fame, Bridges still manages to make this take on a out of his luck entertainer seem fresh.
definitely the best of the series and is easily the one summer blockbuster that delivers everything Potter fans could expect and more.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There hasn't been too many action films with a Christian overtone as the two genres don't necessarily go hand in hand, but the vastly entertaining 'The Book of Eli,' shows that fancy swordplay/shootouts and faith don't have to be mutually exclusive.
for a Scorsese film, it's missing that touch of greatness that's become synonymous with his name.
May very well be the best thrill ride of the year even after August. Don't miss it.
The action scenes more than make it worth watching, preferably in IMAX to really take in that spectacular skyscraper scene in its full glory.
A solid action film inspired by real-life events and hopefully will open the gates to a new genre starring African-American actors.

"With arguably the best supporting cast of the bunch, a cut-and-dried hero's hero who isn't portrayed as some cornball cheesy and a direct lead in to 'The Avengers,' this is my favorite of the Avengers set ups."
Easily one of the best action films I've seen in a decade and firmly cements Statham's status as this generation's coolest, kick-tail action megastar.
Finally offers fans of quality black comedies a new reason to go to the theater again.
The first genuine can't miss film of the year that you'll want to go back to the theater to see over and over again.
A messy mishmash of action movie clichés lost at sea (J14-Hit!)
