Delivers big time with everything longtime fans and newcomers alike could possibly want in a summer blockbuster that definitely surpasses the hype.
This may be the one time in recorded history where a second hangover is a good thing. Bartender, serve up another round with the wolf pack.
It's not the summer's must-see movie, but it's a fun welcome return to form for a series that proves there are still some exciting escapades of Jack Sparrow yet to be told.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Like its predecessors, it's the horror movie for people who don't want to be on the edge of their seats throughout the whole film.
It only took about 10 minutes for a wide smile to form across my face at the realization that 'oh, man they got it right!'
is as close to moviemaking perfection as you could possibly ask for and easily stands as not just the summer's best film, but an easy favorite for the year's best as well.
doesn't reinvent the romantic comedy genre like say a slam-dunk or alley-oop, but its stars make it an undeniable winner.
It's filled with the kind of embarrassing situations that only happen in movies and would probably make the viewer ashamed to watch it, if they weren't too busy cracking up laughing.
a fun experience and one of the best representations of the genre put to the big screen yet.
hardly a divine experience and should be thrown in bad movie purgatory.
Fuqua once again proves his mastery of the cop/crime genre, making for the year's first must-see film
a solid romantic comedy in every regard and avoids being the standard entertaining 'chick flick' by being very enjoyable for both sexes.
A bloody good - emphasis on the bloody - if occasionally flawed, companion piece that's nearly as entertaining a crowd-pleaser as its predecessor.
a charming date movie sure to please audiences.
For the uninitiated, it's enjoyable enough to see what the fuss is all about even if it will likely lead you to Netflix or other binge-viewing options for a marathon session afterwards.
For gangster aficionados, it should be a made movie even if there's some issues that hold it back from elite level gangster classic status.
One of those rare, assured films that isn't particularly remarkable yet is enjoyable and charming in all the ways that matter most.
It feels less like hopping on board a train and more climbing onto the bandwagon of dozens of Lifetime movies.
Even with all the awards and Oscars hype, it still won't do enough justice to one of the decade's most magical masterpieces.
While it won't win points for originality, The Bounce Back is a charming and occasionally really funny romantic comedy.
The darker tone might not make the film work for everyone, but it proves to be a riveting and rewarding experience for those able to stick with it.
A much bolder addition to the franchise that makes risky deviations from the winning formula. That those bold decisions pay off is impressive, most ...well, you know the rest.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One of those weird cases of a film that technically hits most of the appropriate marks, but is so lifeless it's hard to fully appreciate.
A spectacular disaster of a horror film that's more of an endurance test to try and make it through all of this woeful 94 minutes.
Office Christmas Party might not become an annual viewing tradition, but it's enjoyable enough for those seeking a raunchier holiday treat.
With a stunningly lavish world and a fascinating premise, Kubo and the Two Strings is a highly satisfying and entertaining adventure.
Exquisitely conceived and beautifully realized, Moonlight is one of 2016's most radiant and must-see films.
Despite some chemistry issues, Allied is a tense, unpredictable World War II romance drama that reinforces the notion that love is a battlefield.
Makes a convincing and frequently stunning argument that there's (magical) life after Harry Potter. While it's got a few issues, this is a charming kickoff to the franchise.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Monster represents a nerve-rattling comeback for the genre that should make long drives in the woods a lot more stressful for viewers.
A wonderfully complex, heartfelt tale in the midst of an encounter with the unknown. One of the smartest sci-fi films to come around in years and lands as one of 2016's best.
There's a joy impossible to deny. It's crafted by a team that can hardly contain its adoration for the material. That love is so apparent it might win over a new generation.
movie_title: Batman: Return Of The Caped Crusaders (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's never been another comic book film remotely close to the Doctor Strange experience and I can't wait for the doc to make his next theatrical house call.
This is sharp, focused and quality film making. Sit back and enjoy the flight. Capt. Hanks has everything fully under control in this a skillfully told and engaging effort.
Plays out like a bootlegged version of Fast and the Furious in xXx's clothing.
A more mature installment that seeks to challenge audiences as often as it cracks them up, Next Cut marks a charming and enjoyable evolution of the series.
Likely to be one of the year's hidden treasures. Expect to see this surprising thriller on a number of 'best films you didn't see, but should' lists come December.
Based on the concept, it's probably impossible to make a truly great Baywatch movie. But the film is a pleasant enough distraction.
It's not a fantasy genre game changer, but this is a clever, unique and most importantly fun way to tell a familiar tale.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Vol. 2 isn't a perfect movie, but it's easily Marvel Studios' most emotional offering yet.
Tries to capture buddy feel of 80s films, but lacks any of the charm or thrills. Maybe you won't turn it off if you stumble across it, but there's no reason to hunt it down.
A real treat that fans of quality film making and stellar performances should definitely add to their 2017 must-see list.
Repeated viewings will determine the exact slotting, but this is easily one of the finest efforts from Warner Bros. Animation.
Believe might be earnest to a fault, but it's hard to totally a knock a movie so eager to please.
Not only assures viewers there's plenty more levels of ludicrously entertaining levels to go, but asserts itself as a contender for best in the series.
Bethany has some interesting ideas that get buried in a far too familiar jump scare thriller. There's potential here, but it doesn't fully get explored.
This is the seventh film in The Swan Princess franchise, but it clearly hasn't reached midnight yet thanks to the charming newest entry in the series.
A weird film that it starts off tremendously promising before it free falls after morphing the franchise into just another superhero movie.
At its best, Skull Island delivers colossal big screen mayhem with the big guy standing tall. Could you really ask for anything more?
Strippers and zombies are always an entertaining combination, but Peelers goes the extra lap(dance) to create some absurd B-movie fun.
Full of wasted promise. Don't pull up a chair with this one. Best to leave your invitation lost in the mail.
Unlike any other comic book movie made so far, but for all that ambition and gratuitous violence, Logan is a taxing and overindulgent experience.
One of those rare mainstream films that defies definition. However you choose to label it, Get Out is a wholly engaging, entertaining and particularly relevant film.
Fist Fight gets a passing grade even if it doesn't earn full honors thanks to the performances of its two leads
By the time the end credits roll, the toughest choice was wanting to see it again or start counting down for Chapter 3.
Rings leaves a stain around what was once a fun thriller franchise.
Jack Goes Home triples down on weird and stays in a dark, twisted place. It's a grueling, joyless viewing experience.
For fans who've stayed on board, this is a rewarding final act. But for others who've long since tired of this ride, there's little reason to sail away for this voyage.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Desierto might not hold up the longer you try and analyze it, but as an in the moment thriller, it's brutally effective that keeps your attention right to the end.
As the current reigning king of comedy, Hart shows no signs of abandoning his throne any time soon.
In this divisive culture some have worked hard to establish it's important to see a film that reminds us that despite our differences, we all have a lot more in common.
Finding Dory is the kind of enthralling, immersive movie that will have your inner Inside Out crew working overtime handling all the emotions.
Now You See Me 2 proves it's hard to nail the same trick twice. There's still some fun to be had, but this is a second act that's definitely not as magical as the first.
Largely inoffensive if a bit tone oblivious, The Intern suggests a lot of experience goes a long way even in the modern business world.
The filmmakers fully embraced the zany fun and outlandishness of the TMNT universe. The result is a surprisingly faithful take that actually does justice to the property.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For a franchise centered on evolution, there's little here. It's the same tired story, action sequences and overplayed visuals since Singer started the series in 2000.
Exceeds all expectations as this marvelous epic ensures every other summer blockbuster is vying for second best.
For those willing to go along with its goofiness and not think too hard, Keanu is a pleasant and frequently hilarious surprise.
Vigilante Diaries is a comprehensive disaster. Close the book on this diary, there's nothing exciting to be found here.
More content cramming the Titans into the established formula resulting in an uninspired adventure that does little justice to one of the Titans' most iconic stories.
While it didn't have the feel good ending as WM 30, this year's event presents a ton of story lines that if handled correctly could keep the WWE rolling to Wrestlemania 32.
Easily the best video game based movie not based on an actual video game.
Pandemic is a zombie movie whose greatest battle isn't with the undead, but a gimmicky directing style that constantly threatens to derail the mostly enjoyable experience.
The first half is a solid followup to the Christopher Nolan Batman trilogy. Then the second half turns into a Zack Snyder movie, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Chalk up 10 Cloverfield Lane as 2016's first great surprise you never saw coming.
Of the numerous DC LEGO films, Cosmic Clash is one of the better entries in the franchise. Just be prepared to make a trip to the closest LEGO retailer afterwards.
movie_title: LEGO DC Comics Super Heroes: Justice League: Cosmic Clash (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Tripping over itself with rah rah 'Muerica sentiment and laughably over the top, dumb action, London Has Fallen is ludicrous and stupid, but consistently entertaining.
Clumsy, awkwardly staged and uninteresting, Camino is a misuse of Bell and a chore to endure.
Magical filmmaking and the new definitive work of Favreau's career.
Failing on every account to make its main character seem special, let alone legendary, Tarzan is one of the summer's weakest would-be blockbusters.
Is Three worth the journey for one amazing sequence? Probably. It's the kind of action scene we're not likely to see duplicated many times this year.
Too methodically-paced with little payoff The Phenom is like a flamed out prospect that can't make use of its potential.
While it's not a perfect movie, it is the perfect film for this precise moment in history. Nation isn't an enjoyable experience, but it's a necessary one.
An awkward attempt at retrofitting an actual tragedy onto the standard Hollywood disaster movie template.
It's best to consider ClownTown more of a horror/thriller parody. Its generic by the numbers approach to terrors in the wood would be slightly more tolerable.
I.T. doesn't even have the decency to be bad in a trashy, guilty pleasure manner.
A treat. With a story that works on multiple levels for young and adult audiences and outstanding performances, this is definitely a family film worth checking out.
While it might not launch a Western cinematic resurgence, The Magnificent Seven gives the genre a much needed shot in the arm. Say hello to the fall's first big blockbuster.
Knight and Day doesn't revolutionize the spy genre, but it's an entertaining, pleasant distraction with fun performances by Cruise and Diaz.
As a basic football film Greater is perfectly adequate, but it could have truly lived up to its title with stronger convictions on its faith component.
While largely unnecessary for those who fondly remember the 1989 original, this is a pretty decent remake.
Level Up has a ton of potential, but the filmmakers don't rise to the challenge of embracing its wondrous possibilities.
There's a great film about Durán's life fighting to break through, but it never quite connects. We're left with a good film that clearly doesn't reach its potential.
Hits all the marks of a classic. Count on a steady dose of nervous laughter and a sense of dread. And remember the title is a warning for the characters, not the audience.
Break out the chapter select function and zoom past the Batgirl subplot and this is one of Warner Bros. Animation's best efforts.
It didn't need to be anything more than another fun and entertaining entry in the DC movie universe. For better or worse for DC fans/haters, that's exactly what it delivers.
Clearly the theme with Jason Bourne is the franchise ain't broke so we're not fixing it.
A killer concept and better execution. Part adrenaline rush/part social commentary on insta-fame and Internet mob mentality, Nerve is smarter than the typical teen thriller.
Star Trek Beyond takes the series to a louder, hollow and more explosive frontier. Yes, it's still fun, but it comes by it in a cheaper, eager to please fashion.
For those willing to give it an honest chance Ghostbusters is a decent frivolous bit of summer blockbuster escapism. Nothing to be afraid of with that at all.
While not top dog of 2016's animal based animation films, The Secret Life of Pets is charming, if not spectacular.
A wonderfully made thriller that satisfies on every level. And I'm betting it will prove even more enjoyable upon repeated viewings.
Definitely a cut below in every regard and is just an all around poor excuse for a way to waste time.
Wonder Woman is easily one of DC's best movies, but it also belongs in the conversation of best comic book origin movies period.
This is the thriller equivalent of setting the timer on unnerving and letting it simmer for 97 nerve-wracking minutes.
Despicable Me 3 doesn't reinvent the franchise, but proves there's plenty of fun and wackiness left and more than enough creativity left for future installments.
It's that sense that Christine is still a work in progress that makes Lady Bird such an fascinating watch with enough intrigue to make a sequel viable.
A high quality effort that will play well with its intended demographic looking for a reminder of the importance of the role of the media in holding lawmakers accountable.
By taking it seriously, the filmmakers end up calling more attention to every absurd moment. Movie wise, there's few things worse than a dumb action movie tries to be serious.
Resident Evil Vendetta takes the best aspects of the video game high points and makes an amazingly intense and action-packed thrill ride.
Hostiles plays out like a classic Western with modern sensibilities. It's engaging, beautifully shot and features captivating performances.
A very cute and charming film with an inspired take on sibling rivalry that will prove useful for parents informing their only child they're about to have some company.
While not as accessible for general audiences as The LEGO Movie, The LEGO Batman Movie is a fan-pleasing effort that showcases everything that's awesome about The Dark Knight.
There's random moments of quality, but even by Christmas movie standards, Miss Me This Christmas is a misfire.
While it doesn't stray from the formula, this is a better than average Christmas film thanks to strong performances and overall charming presentation.
Shyamalan concocts a clever premise and delivers one of the most suspenseful thrillers this decade bolstered by an outstanding turn by McAvoy.
A cute Christmas movie. It's not meant to be taken too seriously and kept me entertained throughout even if at times I was poking fun of its predictability.
Further makes the case that no one does fantasy on del Toro's level.
Mudbound is going to be one of the hard to forget films of 2017 or this decade.
Gifted doesn't shake up the genre, but it's very well-acted and endearing. Sometimes that makes a movie special enough.
A great film and one of the must-sees for award season.
Hardly a groundbreaking picture, but it's worth seeking out for Kate Winslet's undeniable performance and the beautiful cinematography.
An exceptional, thought-provoking film featuring some of 2017's best performances. This truly deserves to be remembered come year-end award time.
With The Last Jedi, there's a welcome return of hope for the Sequel Trilogy.
One of the year's most riveting, beautifully shot and well-acted films. It's a heartfelt look at the lives of the downtrodden.
Not a terrible movie, but it's not original or fun enough to warrant the time commitment considering far better options just as readily available.
Another Pixar masterpiece. It sits comfortably with Toy Story 3, Finding Dory and Inside Out as one of the best Pixar films this decade.
The real nightmare is the tragic lack of creativity in this new look of one of the genre's greatest characters.
A Wrinkle in Time might not be for everyone, but for those who can appreciate it for exactly what it is, they're going to really enjoy one of the year's most creative films.
Death Wish is a poorly timed rebuttal. And a pretty lousy one at that.
Successfully helps to fill that Christian focused Christmas movie void with a fun adventure for children with a message that will resonate with parents.
The Cured is an easy recommendation for genre fans and for those who want a lot more brains in their zombie films.
It's not awful as far as B movies go, but it never quite manages to become entertaining enough to warrant a recommendation either.
Basically every great, good and decent war movie rolled into one amazing must-see spectacle.
Isn't trying to change the action movie game or shake up the martial arts sub-genre. It's just a simple, easy to digest film with a slew of incredible fight scenes.
That's the sound of the game being changed and everyone is going to have to follow the King. This should signal a major change to the superhero film landscape for years.
A decent addition to the Warner Animation ranks, but there's enough changes that fans of the original story might be disappointed it strayed so far from the source material.
As a big fan of Alien, I really enjoyed this... to a point. Then the second half left me thinking of the Geico commercial with the fisherman saying 'oooh you almost had it.'
Despite some flaws, this is an engaging film with an uplifting and encouraging message.
movie_title: Bilal: A New Breed of Hero (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Charming, funny and feels completely untainted with modern cynicism in a desperate attempt to be edgy and relevant.
This premise is a hard sell, but with more dialogue and less extreme rage, Taylor could have found a better lane for his idea.
A war film carefully designed to check off all the requirements of the genre without going deep enough in the ones that matter most.
Picture a less suspenseful, dumber and overall ill-conceived rip-off of Non-Stop and you've got The Commuter. Even Liam Neeson appears underwhelmed.
For a lower budget film, this is a very creative and enjoyable effort that plays out like a throwback sci-fi movie.
Molly's Game is very enjoyable thanks to the stacked deck of Chastain, Elba and Sorkin.
For franchise fans and haters, this more of the same - some decent scares, a couple of freak out moments and fun characters. It won't win over new fans, but won't disappoint.
Sets the table for an engaging film, but it never amounts to enough to be fully satisfying.
This isn't a misleading title. With its adrenaline rush pacing, terrific performances and unpredictable script, this is a film that doesn't stop surprising or entertaining.
Proving Wonder Woman wasn't just a happy fluke, Justice League boom tubes onto the playing field to finally challenge Marvel Studios' comic book movie dominance.
The premise doesn't invite much restraint, but just a little could have resulted in a terrific guilty pleasure instead of one that narrowly misses the mark.
The overall tone feels off with this weird mix of goofy, silly sequences and very mature adult themes.
Instead of being the next Equalizer, it's a slower paced investigative revenge piece that's lacking a harder edge.
Of all the films I've seen this year, this is easily the one I'd be most embarrassed at someone else catching me watching it.
Really is a case of good enough. There's enough to make for an amusing comedy, but like that disappointed teacher, you know it could have been so much better.
Even with the at times indulgent action scenes, Hitman's Bodyguard is tremendously funny and a great way to cap off the summer movie season.
A thriller featuring a flirty May/December romance competing with a standard slasher horror film makes for a bad (and boring) combination.
I'm not sure who the target audience is for Killing Ground, but I'm thrilled to not be part of it.
There's easily eight to 10 films this year that didn't deserve their blockbuster financing and distribution. Then there's films like this that show how to do more with less.
Hopefully the inevitable sequel will tell a better story and not rely so heavily on the goodwill of having a female kicking, punching and stabbing the bad guys.
I appreciated and liked a lot of what Nolan accomplished, but it was too impersonal and distant to fully love.
After watching Girls Trip, it's a battle for second place for the funniest comedy of 2017. Nothing else is going to come close.
Would-be sci-fi franchise starter proves on multiple levels that looks aren't everything.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Triumphantly completes one of the historically great trilogies in modern cinema.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A feel-great legit Oscar contender and one of 2017's most heartfelt and enjoyable efforts.
It's taken six films and three iterations of the character, but Spider-Man: Homecoming is finally the comic version Spider-Man come to the big screen.
Can't even rate guilty pleasure status.
Edgar Wright has little time for genre restrictions. Baby Driver is a unique and engaging presentation that avoids obvious comparisons.
A compelling character drama that doesn't need the gimmicks and tricks of a thriller to keep the audience invested.
In Rough Night, the wall is fully stained, but very little stuck. There's a ton of crap on the floor however.
Sci-fi mysteries aren't an overused genre so this isn't flying in a crowded space. Disappointingly it fails to distinguish itself from more traditional sci-fi fare.
Starts off too smart to end so stupidly.
It was hard at times not to view the film as the extended pitch to secure more financing. Kavanagh's passion project easily proves worthy of an investment.
The Villainess is the movie Quentin Tarantino wanted Kill Bill to be.
Never bad enough to be frustrating, but it could have been a lot more fun.
Instead of a film, this probably would play out better as a TV series to let all the various subplots breathe.
Armstrong is that rare superhero movie that's better when the hero is off camera.
Worth taking for a spin in your Netflix queue.
That Ragnarok can even be in the conversation for best Marvel Cinematic Universe movie is a major victory for Marvel Studios.
Sentimentality aside with the final film performance of Adam West, Batman vs. Two Face captures the magic and spirit of the fondly remembered TV series.
If you're looking for a terrifying horror/thriller, It will keep you up for many nights. But for a vintage 90s era scare, this will leave a smile on your face.
An enjoyable enough film despite pulling a significant bait and switch.
I thought the premise had potential, but Bad Match exceeded my expectations. This was a lot of fun and definitely worth checking out for thriller fans.
It's probably going to take another viewing to fully appreciate Blade Runner 2049. My gut reaction is it's a great movie bordering on masterpiece.
Serviceable enough to warrant a watch, but could have been better with a tad more mayhem and fun.
Will certainly please fans of the original and terrify a new generation.
There's enough potential here to suggest a sequel isn't the worst idea provided Abbess and Cachia learn from their mistakes.
movie_title: The Osiris Child: Science Fiction Volume One (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is like watching three master actors have a blast playing off each other. And it's a hard not to have get a thrill watching them in this charming and funny comedy.
Maybe its ultimate legacy is to be mercilessly mocked as the feature for a bad movie night. The potential for laughs might make it mildly entertaining.
Provided it finds the audience it deserves on Netflix #RealityHigh will likely be held in the same esteem for Millennials as its influences.
There's goons with mechanical arms, electric lassos, a two-stepping Tatum, robot dogs and an Elton John fight sequence. It's absurdly ridiculous and awesome as it sounds.
Out of dozens of ways to make an intriguing and potential fun new franchise, American Assassin whiffed on all of them.
Unlike It, Clowntergeist probably won't force viewers to leave a nightlight on.
100 Streets doesn't redefine the genre, but it's an all around solid film that's worth checking out.
The kind of Disney-fied production that gives audiences an underdog to root for and feel good about without offering much insight into its inspirational subject.
Kevin Feige and the rest of the Marvel Studios crew can rest easy in that Red Sparrow didn't beat them to making a great Black Widow movie.
You'd be hard-pressed to find a comic book film so faithful to the tone of its source material and absolutely nailing it. Cue Deadpool winking at the double entendre.
The year's most powerful and emotionally-gripping film seems as necessary and essential now as it did nearly 50 years ago.
The oddest and most frustrating film I've seen all year.
Too distant and lacks the heart to get you fully invested.
With its creative premise, terrific ensemble, mesmerizing visuals and dazzling musical numbers, it's a dream come true for fans of the revered Broadway production.
Might not be in the first tier of holiday classics, but its winning cast led by its captivating star make this one you'll want to keep in your Christmas viewing rotation.
A slight step in the right direction for Marvel Animation even if it only satisfies a small portion of the Marvel fan base.
movie_title: Iron Man and Captain America: Heroes United (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It doesn't take very long while watching this to get the sense that "Five Armies" was the film Director Peter Jackson has been itching to make all along.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Rock's brilliant skewering of Hollywood, celebrities and the fans obsessed with their every move results in one of the year's smartest, insightful and terrifically funny films of the year.
Not flashy, but backed by two of the year's finest performances, this intimate drama is a revealing look at one of the more fascinating individuals of our generation.
Even the biggest Allen fans will admit there's little extraordinary here as it fails to offer something most moviegoers will want to believe in let alone invest their time.
Despite revelatory performances from its two leads, this is a pretty miserable movie that will leave you wondering why you subjected yourself to such a downer.
Backed by a dynamic ensemble, a strikingly bold sense of direction and captivating original story, this is endlessly enjoyable and one of the year's true standouts.
Probably wasn't an essential sequel, but it delivers major laughs and tops its predecessor in nearly every way. You won't see a better comedy this year.
Skips the exhilarating games of the first two films and matures into a thought-provoking blockbuster that further distances the franchise from its would-be YA competition.
See it on a full stomach otherwise you'll be too busy salivating to fully appreciate one of the year's finest.
Prince-Bythewood provides a distinct and needed voice in the genre.
Will leave you completely satisfied with its service.
While it has some problems, Nolan aims higher than most filmmakers would dare attempt and comes oh so close to creating another undeniably classic space masterpiece.
A truly groundbreaking experience and a standout film of this or any year fully deserving the tag of a modern classic.
With every bloody, stylishly seductive moment, it crashes through comic book movie conventions to blast through the screen as a mesmerizing and captivating crowd-pleaser.
A sci-fi mind-screw that is rarely short on surprises and innovative ways to keep viewers guessing leading to a fascinating and unique thriller.
For a January comedy it's got enough laughs to be worth your RSVP.
Doubling as a horror suspense for the social media generation and the world's most effective anti-cyber bullying PSA, it's a fun thriller until its disappointing final act.
More a mash-up of two of the most highly regarded Batman stories in the last 20 years than its title implies it stands alongside the best efforts of Warner Bros. Animated.
This is a franchise where the filmmakers and stars willingly embrace the absurd so going in your motto should be 'everything is impossible, but awesome.'
Provided a cinematic equivalent of NOS to the franchise with a tone shift that helped make it one of the most popular and profitable action series in the last decade.
Considered the red headed stepchild of the 'Fast and Furious' franchise, but beyond the obvious missteps, it's a very fun outing that truly doesn't deserve its bad rap.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Loads up on colors, cars and characters to distract from what's missing under the creative hood, yet this spirited sequel is fun as it rarely takes itself too seriously.
A spectacular start to one of Hollywood's most surprising and popular franchises ever.
Your standard Ferrell/Hart vehicle that's rarely witty enough to live up to its potential, but still delivers enough laughs for those seeking a silly comedy.
Fittingly brainless parody, but sadly lacking wit, subtlety and humor, it proudly carries the torch of such crimes against comedy like 'Disaster Movie' and 'Epic Movie.'
Yeah, it's not perfect, but with Neeson as the lead, it just have to be serviceable and that's all he needs to make this an engaging no-frills action flick.
Too crude to be taken seriously and too family-focused to be a guilty pleasure, this is one company retreat you'll want to skip.
Ficarra and Requa repeatedly trying to fool the audience becomes like watching a magician do minor variations of the same trick expecting the audience to remain impressed.
Place your odds on this easily capturing a spot on 2015's Worst Films list if not earning the top spot.
Will likely prove one of those hidden cable or Netflix gems you'll be glad you stumbled onto during a random night of channel surfing.
Clearly meant to sell The Shield as stronger individuals than a unit, but a greater focus on the faction itself would have been more satisfying for fans.
movie_title: WWE: The Destruction of the Shield (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A beautiful mess better suited for the silent film era where annoyances like plot and a comprehensive script wouldn't be nearly as problematic.
While it doesn't reach the peaks of the upper echelon of the DC Animated stable, "Throne of Atlantis" gives reason for optimism with future New 52 Justice League films.
A realistic, heartbreaking look at a savage disease so eloquently exhibited by Moore given the proper respect by its filmmakers.
Feels like a movie that has a lot more to say, but can't figure out how to convey its message despite a fantastic effort from its leading man.
Another shining gem from Pixar's most endearing franchise and should be a new Halloween staple for all families.
More of the same, but what's in its favor, is Neeson's never-failing man's man toughness, which goes a long way in making for an entertaining film.
A smarter-than average action spectacle that's one of the best of the genre.
Ingeniously clever, fiendishly crafted and full of surprises you won't see coming, it's endlessly entertaining and emerges as an Oscar frontrunner.
Another fun, exciting James Bond adventure even if it's the first of the initial five 007 outings that doesn't live up to series' expectations.
An audacious, thrilling adventure that's the most epic adventure yet featuring everyone's favorite mutants.
The filmmakers are under the mistaken Michael Bay-like impression that audiences paying to see a movie entitled 'Godzilla' would be content with a movie focused on generic, underdeveloped humans.
Smart, scary and features a creative twist on the genre thanks to its unique found-film perspective.
I'm not quite sure where the film lost me exactly, but I'm thinking it was somewhere around the latex penis mold-making and the lactating mother scene.

Serving more as a decent introduction to a new character to the Batman mythos than a fully developed adaptation of the Grant Morrison storyline, 'Son of Batman' is entertaining, but hardly essential viewing for DC animated movie fans.
Not just the best Spider-Man movie, but also one of the best pure comic book movies we've seen so far.
If your first instinct after grabbing the newspaper ever was to reach for the comics section, 'Stripped' is absolutely essential viewing.
If you squint hard enough, there's a decent premise here, but that hope quickly fades after a scene where a dog relieves itself in the living room. It's a symbolic statement of the movie itself.

Serving as both a wondrous stroll down your childhood and a fantastic introduction to Kermit and company, this is a warmly inspired nostalgia kick that will delight both longtime fans and endear the franchise to a new generation.
Without question the undisputed best pure action movie sequel ever.
Go in knowing the film will deliver on butt-kicking Carano, but not much else and you'll be perfectly satisfied.
Marvel Studios' answer to 'The Dark Knight' is tremendously entertaining and likely the superhero blockbuster to beat not just for 2014, but possibly many years to come.
Another weak, uninspired effort that once again proves that if you want fun, exciting adventures featuring The Avengers your local theater is the only option worth considering.
Isn't your typical Schwarzenegger action film, but it's another thrilling Ayer's cop drama in his now trademark, gritty fashion that will leave fans riveted.
You may not find yourself goofily grinning and laughing at any other film this year as you will during this and that's fitting because they just don't build too many movies like this anymore.

To its credit, this isn't just another dumb video game adaptation that's a poor fit for the big screen. Nope, this by any classification would be a so-dumb-it's-stupid film regardless of its source material.

It doesn't take long to get the sense that the filmmakers desperately want this to be the next 'Twilight,' 'Harry Potter' or 'Hunger Games' instead of aiming higher and simply trying to be the first 'Divergent.'
Too formulaic and simple, Love is the kind of film you'd sorta halfway pay attention to while doing some household chores and still feel like it wasn't worth the investment.
Proves a summer blockbuster doesn't have to be based on a mainstream comic book or a sequel to be just as exciting, thrilling and entertaining.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Delivers as the epic summer blockbuster film of 2015 again and again. Avengers fans won't walk out the theater disappointed.
Provides a grandiose feeling that you're watching something truly special.
Still the only Transformers film worth watching.
Sputtering on fumes almost from the start, it captures a well-earned checkered flag as one of the worst films of 2014.
A wholly derivative, uninspired heist caper that isn't worth your investment.
While this hyper-violent, but satisfying, action thriller won't result in another Best Actor Oscar for Washington, it's a heck of a fun explosive effort.

Packed with thrills, daring surprises and compelling performances, this is no mere 'Hunger Games' imitator. 'The Maze Runner' sprints to the finish line at the forefront of the YA franchises ready to take the baton from Katniss and company.
A smooth, easygoing film that will please its target audience, even if it doesn't quite reach the heavenly heights of other inspirational efforts in the faith-based genre.
Brutal even by B movie standards, making for one of the longer 88 minutes no viewer should ever be forced to have to endure.
Packed with stylish visuals, a dream cast, tons of attitude and crazy over-the-top action, for better or worse it delivers exactly what you'd expect in a 'Sin City' sequel.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Has the playbook to create a compelling, engaging and even inspirational football film, but fumbles nearly every opportunity to create another gridiron classic.

I'm almost positive the world doesn't necessarily need a fourth 'Expendables' film, but if Stallone wants to get the band back together for another that is as fun as this one, then there's no reason to stop now.
A film that over the years I've come to appreciate far more than my initial viewing due to the brilliant, unforgettable effort by Robin Williams who gives one of his most haunting performances.

DC Entertainment thrills with one of its boldest and mature films yet while finally figuring out the secret to telling engaging and fun adventures of DC Comic characters beyond Batman and the Justice League.
Why does every filmmaker who tackles this property find some way to drop the shell?
Consistent with other recent offerings in the disaster genre - heavy on effects, light on script and characters.

With a shaky, distracting narrative, the film has a number of flaws, but Boseman's ferocious, fearless take on one of the most influential musicians of all time is the best cinematic equivalent to a one-man show you'll see all year.

It's been billed as the most out-there, bizarre and wacky of all the Marvel Studios films. Fortunately for comic book fans and audiences looking for a little something different it exceeds expectation to be the most fun-filled Marvel movie yet.
The latest disappointing effort from Luc Besson, is probably the closest you'll come to a very bad sci-fi acid trip.
Not terrible enough to work up enough emotion to make you mad, just once again frustrate you with the knowledge that you wasted time giving Cage yet another chance to disappoint you.

Save Christopher Nolan's "Batman," no film so brilliantly reinvigorated a franchise more than this, a thrilling opening act that's equally captivating and leaves you anxiously awaiting the next installment.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An absolutely absurd action extravaganza. It's doubly crazy, chaotic and all kinds of ridiculous fun.
To the cast's credit, the film is still a lot of fun, even if it's lacking much of the depth that made the original such a hit.
If it does anything right, it's making death by zombie bite the most depressing, hopeless fate ever, but it's nothing we haven't seen done with more heart and emotion.

For those Muppet fans fearing the last film was a fluke, no need to worry at all as even Statler and Waldorf wouldn't be able to find much to complain about with this immensely satisfying installment.
Promising start, but by the midway point the film devolves to a generic action film with themes you've seen countless times already.
With the ideal Bond, a worthy adversary, gorgeous Bond Babes and a director skilled enough to fully maximize their potential, this stands atop the rest as the best Bond film.
Some of 007's earlier adventures fail to hold up, but in a post-'Taken' world, 'Licence to Kill' certainly aged well and is a under-appreciated gem in the Bond catalog.
Just what the franchise needed to become more culturally relevant as the 1990s approached.
While it doesn't reach its full potential, Roger Moore's final 007 outing is still a largely entertaining if admittedly flawed adventure.
Like an awesome grab bag of the best horror films from the past 30 years packed into a fun and exhilarating horror thriller.
If you haven't seen 'Thunderball,' this is a lot more enjoyable, but matched up against one of the more exciting 007 films, 'Never Say Never' fails to do it better.
Considering Bond gets disguised as an ape, a crocodile and a clown, the film has a lot more to be embarrassed about than its title.
This is the one of the better stripped down Bond films. It's not flashy, the villains are grounded and Moore dials his take on 007 down significantly.
Perfectly embodying the best and worst of the Roger Moore 007 era, this is a fun Bond adventure that ultimately fails to fully meet its potential.
movie_title: The Man with the Golden Gun (1974)

movie_review_blurb: It's easy to see why 007 purists would loathe it, yet somehow 'Moonraker's' special brand of absurdity makes for one strangely entertaining Bond adventure.
If you want to see an out of place Bond effort that would have been vastly improved with Shaft or Superfly in the lead role instead of 007, give this a view.
Has its flaws, but being a boring Bond movie isn't one of them. It may not hit top tier status, but Connery makes "Diamonds Are Forever" another gem in the 007 mythos.
Connery's last exceptional Bond as it gives 007 a competent villain, a thrilling adventure in an unusual setting, great Bond Babes and one of the series' all-time best scenes.
Horror fans get treated to a sensationally scary and funny anthology that is assured to be a new staple in their Halloween viewing rotation.
A time-traveling adventure that desperately missed the fun, joyous charm of the original.
movie_title: Back to the Future Part II (1989)

movie_review_blurb: 'Spies' certainly embodies a strong Oscar contender and its star and director's vision raise it to the level of one of 2015's best films.
Between 'Hook,' the faithful 2003 adaptation and the 1953 classic, there's not a lot of fertile ground for new Pan stories and this prequel fails to validate its existence.
All it's missing is a 'Scream Queens' infusion of quality, biting character development, but the weak characters undermine a promising entry in the horror/comedy genre.
With a great villain, the series' definitive henchman, stunning Bond Babes, grand action and an all-time classic theme, this is a Bond film fully worthy of adoration.
Brosnan gives it his best and with Yeoh, he's got a capable dance partner, but this 007 edition felt like a retread story that was already old news.
An entertaining adventure mostly successful at bringing the early spirit of villains, gadgets and gear to Craig's grittier, realistic take on Bond.
At times it's slow and a bit too silly, but at its best, it's the worthy successor to 'GoldenEye' that Brosnan deserved.
A spellbinding character study mystery made even more fascinating by the thought that its premise is far closer to becoming reality than most of its sci-fi peers.
This isn't going to change anyone's life, but it's good for some cheap laughs, which is all audiences really should expect.
It's not a flawless film, but the heights Iñárritu reaches in tackling such an ambitious project make it easier to appreciate in spite of its deficiencies.
There's a great film here, but it's locked in a losing battle against a longer, more drawn out one. It's that amazing 15-minute story your friend drags out for an hour.
One of 2015's best, it's an acting showcase that reflects on the not that long ago good old days when journalists sought to reveal truth and weren't obsessed with clicks.
By vilifying the league so much instead of saluting the man who brought attention to the endemic, it fails to spark the discussion its filmmaker so desperately intended.
'Jedi' takes a little longer to get going, but once it does, the Star Wars finale ends on a satisfying and rewarding note for fans who watch it for the first of 50th time.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VI - Return of the Jedi (1983)

movie_review_blurb: Rest assured fans. You won't have to complain how Abrams further ruined your childhood. This is everything we initially loved about the franchise and exceeds expectations.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Filmmakers have tried for decades, but they can't make a better space saga. It's the perfect stand-alone science fiction film that's only rivaled by its darker sequel.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope (1977)

movie_review_blurb: With a willingness to take the Star Wars saga to its necessary darkest direction, 'Sith' delivers an epic, masterful payoff to the prequels.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Easily the most polarizing Star Wars film -- all but 5% of the fan base loathes Phantom Menace -- Attack of the Clones remains the most underrated entry in the saga.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: 'The Phantom Menace' is definitely the major reason most fans, even prequel apologists like myself, don't watch the Star Wars saga in chronological order.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: 2015's most multi-layered film. It's complex, charming, a little frightening, but ultimately it's a wholly unique viewing experience unlike anything I've seen in years.
With a loving look to the past and a confident glance towards the future, Creed is a triumphant entry in the Rocky franchise. This is Rocky V done right.
Movies this charming don't come around nearly often enough as they should but it helps make gems like Brooklyn shine all the brighter.
Faring far better than its uneventful first half, 'Part 2' spectacularly concludes one of the more popular and groundbreaking franchises in cinematic history.
It's rare to see a comedy go so spectacularly off the rails after such a promising start.
Better save the gift receipt if you're considering seeing 'Love the Coopers,' a convoluted, cinematic equivalent to that fruitcake nobody wanted.
Plenty entertaining, but consistent with most of Brosnan's Bonds, a few misguided decisions keep it from being a classic.
A space-faring winner that makes exploring -- and surviving -- the great beyond seem like the greatest adventure known to man.
A spell-bounding crime thriller, you don't simply watch 'Sicario,' you experience 2015's most intense, sophisticated adrenaline rush that doesn't let up until the end credits.
If you want to see a real Catwoman, check out Michelle Pfeiffer's turn in Batman Returns, but whatever you do, leave this kitty cat in the alley where it belongs.
There isn't a football cliche "The Replacements" doesn't tackle, but its all-star cast and easygoing approach make it one of the more enjoyable recent sports comedies.
On the heels of the tremendous 'Obvious Child,' which challenged conventions about the modern female, 'Trainwreck' doesn't feel nearly as groundbreaking and revolutionary.
While they're probably better-suited in hilarious background roles there's a lot of fun to be had for fans.
It's one of those classically awful movies that you almost have to see to truly appreciate why it well deserves its status as one of the worst movies of all time.
A riveting and emotional glimpse at one of wrestling's greatest and tragic dynasties.
movie_title: Heroes of World Class: The Story of the Von Erichs and the Rise and Fall of World Class Championship Wrestling (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's an energy that's undeniably spellbinding, but it feels too hollow.
Meant to kickstart a new trilogy, there barely seems to be enough left to say beyond getting back on the seemingly endless Skynet time travel loop. Just say it won't be back.
While it's not the best of the sci-fi genre, you don't have to go to a galaxy far, far away to enjoy every minute of it.
Opting to make an adult version scared straight instead of a thoughtful, provocative piece on marriage, Perry hopes to frighten couples to stay together with his latest drama.
Helander avoids the mistake of taking the story too seriously. It's a crazy premise and he embraces it in a way that's easier to accept than other president in jeopardy films.
On the best of all-time Wrestlemania list, it's hard to think of a lot this satisfying. WWE delivered big time here with the happy ending to the Yes Movement storyline.
I can't see another 2015 film topping its heart, emotion and complexity. You'll love it the first time, but it will prove even more enjoyable upon repeated viewings.
Strictly for younger viewers happy to laugh at Superman and company acting goofy. For other viewers, you've got 49 minutes to keep the kids distracted -make the most of it.
movie_title: Lego DC Comics Super Heroes: Justice League Vs. Bizarro League (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While it isn't going to end up on many 2015 Top 10 lists, this is a standard fun, check your brain at the door kind of summer blockbuster.
Underneath the silly carnage, there's a tremendously fun film, but as a starting point, it signals the start of a potentially big new franchise.
Smartly sticking to the winning formula that (mostly) kept fans entertained for eight solid seasons, this is a fitting hilarious curtain call for the beloved HBO series.
If all you honestly want out of it is to watch 'stuff blow up good,' you could still do a lot better than this uneven entry in the already overstuffed disaster porn genre.
Will likely get a mildly, if unenthusiastic, passing grade from its target audience, but for the non-believers, it's going to prove a tough and condescending experience.
Little fresh to hold your attention or better yet capture your imagination. A better future may be on the horizon, but it doesn't arrive in 'Tomorrowland.'
If you're up for the ride you'll be rewarded with the most senses- and (common) sense-shattering action spectacle in decades.
Guaranteed to feature 2015's best climactic battle atop a train set -- pardon the terrible pun -- 'Ant-Man' is freaking f-ANT-astic fun and the year's most pleasant surprise.
Just imagine how much more authentic, topical and engaging this would be if Rock made this film in 2015 instead of eight years earlier.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Batman: Bad Blood, assures everything remains status quo in terms of another outstanding action-packed and entertaining effort starring the Dark Knight.
Still holds up as a fun, unique entry in the action spy genre and launched Tom Cruise's second career arc as an action megastar.
Fuqua and Sutter don't spend the entire film chasing clichés and Gyllenhaal delivers such a strong performance that while it may at times be familiar, you'll remain engaged.
Feels like the worst kind of history lesson where we never learn why we're supposed to care about any of it.
Beyond its snow-covered chaos and majestic views, there's little to draw you in and keep you invested.
Were it not for the dreadful "Fantastic Four," this would easily be 2015's most unnecessary and worthless franchise reboot.
Just like its predecessor, this isn't an action film meant to be taken seriously. All you'll need to do is sit back, embrace the absurd craziness and enjoy the ride.
Another strong inspirational cinematic experience from the Kendrick brothers.
More than a decade later, no action series has quite managed to capture its blend of silky smooth action thanks to Statham's turn as the debonair hero for the new generation.
A fun throwback that makes for a perfect introduction to the DC characters for younger viewers.
movie_title: Lego: Liga da Justiça Vs. Liga Bizarro (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Essential Bond viewing. It should definitely be among the five Bond films to make someone a fan of the series.
Setting its sights firmly on taking the best YA film series crown once 'The Hunger Games' ends, "The Scorch Trials" is another exciting entry in a thrilling saga.
It's not going to revolutionize the genre, but there's something fitting about a stylish spy movie that doesn't spend so much time taking itself too seriously.
Still a fun movie even if it doesn't match the high standards of the rest of the series thanks to Woo bringing his trademark over the top action sequences.
A bombardment of projectile vomiting and a scene where the characters bathe in sewage - a meta moment that perfectly describes the experience of watching this movie.
Abrams' high stakes, every second counts pacing gets the best out of franchise star Tom Cruise resulting in easily the series' best pure action installment.
Marks yet another outstanding Bruce Timm production and a superior entry in the DC Entertainment catalog.
A fitting tribute to the world's most dangerous group and easily one of my favorite films of the year.
Lee and Kirby built Marvel Comics on the foundation of the FF and it's no stretch to say this franchise could still be going strong a decade later with a better opening act.
Largely an improvement over its predecessor, this is a decent attempt at bringing the FF's adventures to the big screen, but still a few fixes away from truly being fantastic.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Just give Marvel Studios the damned license back already.
Isn't the worst installment, but it's the least daring, challenging and fresh entry in the series.
An edgy drama and an effective cautionary tale well worth seeing.
Johnny Depp stars and, despite some pretty awful makeup, nails his performance as George Jung.
Ratner, who directs for the seventh time with this film, seems to be getting better by trial and error, and he turns in a rather terrific first half.
This is just about the lightest and most agreeable of the umpteen Iranian films I've seen.
movie_title: Roozi ke zan shodam (The Day I Became a Woman) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Deserves closer consideration than it received.
Only in the last five minutes does Mandoki let the hammer drop. Before that, Angel Eyes is quite compelling.
Desk Set is a big, shiny, doohickey coasting on the warm offerings of earlier triumphs.
Jack the Ripper has proven a far more durable movie baddie than Freddy, Jason and Hannibal combined.
Liberty Heights is worth a look, with its rich characters and dialogue, and its gorgeous cinematography by Chris Doyle.
It's disgusting and gripping at the same time.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Scorsese hadn't developed a personal vision yet, but a few moments during the heat of battle reveal a lively, playful camera. Not to mention the on-target performances by Hershey and her co-stars David Carradine, Barry Primus and Bernie Casey.
This horror film has a high-quality, professional feel but somehow lacks tension or any emotional connection.
A ripping success.

McGuigan imbues Wicker Park with a disorienting atmosphere and visual style, using available window panes and deep focus techniques like a split-screen effect to show simultaneous actions and emotions upon which the narrative twists and turns.

I know exactly nothing about skateboarding, but this wild, exuberant documentary puts it all in perspective, outlining a crew of 12 surfers-turned-skaters who pioneered the sport -- and, some say, the art form.
If a movie can draw this kind of talent for mostly miniscule roles, how can you go wrong?
It feels like I've seen dozens of films this year by first time writers and directors, and not one has stuck to me until now.
The movie takes a few small belly-flops now and then but is quite enjoyable.
A crackerjack documentary.
The coolest kid flick in ages.
Robert Altman adapted Christopher Durang's play for this peculiar comedy that can't ever seem to find its rhythm.
I needed stronger and more balanced characters to really care what happened.
Assault on Precinct 13 is one of Carpenter's best, an ultra-gritty cop story.
Dead Man Walking is one courageous film, one of the very best of its time.

Ian McKellen plays Richard III, and he's a twisted, blackened, serpentine, lurching, spitting, menacing villain with no redeeming qualities whatsoever. He is so hateful, it is easy to see why the Academy overlooked him.
I'm pleased to report that Shanghai Noon is the best Jackie Chan movie in many moons.
Though director George Miller took the post-apocalyptic tough guy Max a lot farther in the sequel The Road Warrior, Mad Max still packs in Miller's particular brand of black-comedy thrills.
I wish someone would explain to me why all these 19th Century costume dramas need to be so cheerless, so formal, and so godawful boring.
I like it when Hollywood apologizes. And I liked this movie. Apology accepted.
Ridiculously self-important and serious.
It's a tour-de-force of cinematic invention. But at the same time, it's just about the coldest, most pointless crime movie I've ever seen.
Brando pulls off astonishing things as Stanley Kowalski, and Vivien Leigh gives a performance that must have taken everything she had as Blanche DuBois.
The first 20 minutes of Snake Eyes are among the most imaginative and energetic minutes of film I've seen in a while.
Writer/director Richard Shepard manages a skilled, brilliantly-acted thriller with plenty of genuine suspense and fresh ideas.
Faithless comes with a pedigree that's hard to beat.
I say it's the worst.
I find it to be one of his most sublime achievements, filled with a sunny laziness and slow awakening.
The film avoids disease-of-the-week sentimentality with Ricci's calm, reasoning voice-over juxtaposing her erratic behavior; she realizes what she's doing but just can't stop.
A life-affirming and moving experience that should not be missed.
Usually Hollywood can't make movies that are as good as the best TV, so why not adapt bad TV shows into good movies? That's what they've done here with the new Lost in Space movie.
Comes up with unexpected moments of tenderness.
It's a refreshingly straightforward and honest attempt, flying in the face of the rest of the product out there, which is either manipulating and dumb or tricky and arty.
Oddly, the special effects have dated quite well, and the action scenes -- shot by relative newcomer John McTiernan -- work well, despite a few clunky spots.
Plays like a lively farce, full of fun and life, but at the same time tainted with the horror of reality.
Utterly timeless and essential viewing today.
movie_title: Lenny Bruce: Swear to Tell the Truth (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Because the small budget kept Lang sequestered on the studio lot, he found a way to use the sets for their claustrophobic, caged feel.

Soderbergh and Griffin concoct a doozy of a robbery, seemingly impossible with a new hitch around every corner. The cast, headed by Clooney, never loses its cool and never gives away a surprise beforehand.
Amistad is worth seeing just for people to know about this important story, this moment in history. But from the world's most powerful, successful and famous director, we expect more.
Robert Altman brings us an effective, if minor, crime film filled with the jazz sounds of Count Basie and Lester Young.
It's a highly enjoyable, fast-paced comedy about warring gypsy families who are after both money and true love (isn't that what all comedies are about?).
movie_title: Crna macka, beli macor (Black Cat, White Cat) (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Wenders adds in some cruddy early-80s video from time to time, and the film is an odd mixture of powerful emotions and rambling nothingness.
Director Amy Heckerling almost encourages the film's shapelessness, letting the individual moments speak for themselves, rather than molding a cohesive whole.
When the climactic rap battle takes place, it's one of the most mesmerizing scenes from all of 2002.
Legendary director Robert Altman gives us a crime movie that somehow makes an old story seem fresh and funny.
[A] gross-out classic.
Each and every action scene is stolen from some other movie.
Mansfield Park works because it not only comes from the novel...but also from Austen's letters and journals.
This black-and-white film already includes several Lyncian benchmarks: hissing noises, nightmare sequences, and moments of deadly quiet.
I kind of expected the film to keep up some kind of momentum with a slam-bang beginning like that. It never slows down to a crawl, but it never gets as good as its first ten minutes.
This intense, explosive Hong Kong thriller ushers in a new era of hyper-intelligent action.
I found myself involved during the screening but the experience had faded a few hours later.
Filled with bizarre colors, vintage 70s-era rock and truly imaginative ideas, it's still a thrill.
I found it endlessly fascinating.
