Despite a great cast and similarities to Ex Machina, this sci-fi movie doesn't really have much to say outside of a vague cautionary message. And it doesn't offer much in the way of thrills aside from the many killings.
Sometimes it can be good to think outside the box, but this strange, unsettling mishmash of dark fantasy, disturbing behavior, and child psychology is ultimately more dismaying than refreshing.
It's difficult for anyone involved to sell this weakly plotted, emotionally empty sequel as anything more than a lazy cash-grab. With the exception of one intense set-piece, it's even visually inept.
The original Kickboxer might have been cheesy, but it also had Van Damme's star power; the chronically uninteresting hero of this awful remake can't even get close to him.
May seem superficial, until you consider that this is also the life of actors.
Jon Favreau returns to the kid-friendly films he made earlier in his career (Elf and Zathura) and finds he still has a gift for breezy, good-looking, beautifully-paced, and well-told stories.
Often, it's a good thing when filmmakers make something that they'd actually like to see, but in this case, it might have been better if Kevin Smith had kept this odd little joke to himself.
A film that's more vital, intense, thoughtful and emotional than any 2016 movie by filmmakers less than half [Eastwood's] age.
Adam Nimoy directed this basic but very loving tribute to his father, daring to get a little more personal and a little less reverential than the average Star Trek fan might have.
An interesting, emotional companion piece to "Citizenfour."
As it grows more unreal, this "threequel" to the original Blair Witch Project becomes intensely scary, but it's undone by a weak set-up and irritatingly dumb, shallow characters.
Quite useful to watch and discuss.
Thrillers in which seemingly harmless outsiders worm their way into safe, secure, middle-class homes and then threaten them were popular in the '90s; this one feels like a pale copy.

Even though it stars an accomplished actress and has an intriguing design, this haunted-house movie doesn't have much to offer. The Disappointments Room's scares, mysteries, and character relationships are all numbingly routine.
This one was always more crowd-pleaser than poetry, but it contains simple, strong messages, codes of honor that still ring true.
In the end, the doc captures that magical way that movies can speak to us and transport us, and how, for some, that feeling becomes a way of life.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Many images in "Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children" are firmly of Burton's wondrous cinematic universe.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Stirring, provocative, flawed, bloody slave-revolt story.
Allied is beautifully constructed, with smooth, polished camerawork and editing, as well as evocative music and design. But it's never self-consciously arty.
Working with what he has, and doing what he does best, Michell has still created an emotionally gripping tale.
This strange, austere sci-fi art film may engage viewers looking for something different, but for most, it will be a queasy, unsettling experience, requiring much patience for little reward.
The original Bad Santa found just the right tone for its dark, vulgar humor -- but this sequel feels like a too-little, too-late attempt to recapture faded glory.
Spanish director Pedro Almodovar adapts three stories by Nobel Prize-winning writer Alice Munro; though his sensibilities are quite different from her style, the result is surprisingly satisfying.
Despite a high-class cast, this fantasy-battle movie -- based on a video game series -- is disorienting, makes very little sense, and, worst of all, is a terrible, humorless bore.
It all seems like an excuse for writer/director Mike Mills to revel in the time and place and play lots of cool music.
I liked these characters, and the movie mostly avoids squeamish moments of uncomfortable comedy, but it just went on and on with no real payoff for its extreme length.
This religious epic, a dream project of director Martin Scorsese for decades, is somewhat difficult and unwieldy, as well as a bit gory, but it's also magnificent, beautiful, and masterful.
I'd rank Paterson among [Jarmusch's] very best films. It's a treasure, and the best American film of 2016.
The story is a good one, and the movie never feels too heavy or preachy.
The performances are on the large side, but they're of an extremely high quality, and emotionally rending.
It's such a skilled job of directing and writing that the pages and pages of technical talk and lists of names and numbers all sound like actual dialogue.
Director Paul Verhoeven's first movie in French features an elegant, powerful Isabelle Huppert; she adds weight to what's really a pretty basic, stretched-out story filled with sex and violence.
"Live by Night" has slipped into theaters without a stir. The reason, regrettably, is that it's unexpectedly lifeless.
The fifth movie in this supernatural action/horror series isn't the worst, but it isn't very good, either; it has moments of mindless fun, but also too much seriousness and mood-killing awkwardness.
The hand-drawn animation is absolutely gorgeous... Yet I found The Red Turtle to be relentlessly depressing, tainted by cruelty.
A short capsule review cannot do this documentary's depth of intelligence justice, but suffice to say that it uses history and literature to peel back old wounds and reveal fresh ones.
Though it suffers from minor plot inconsistencies and some shaky camerawork, this thriller offers a fun, entertaining, "B"-level story; the terrific characters help fill in the blanks.
Hardly the first crime movie to play around with timelines (and not always successful at doing so), this thriller gets away with it due to intriguing characters, a snappy pace, and a few surprises.
"Loving" is the real deal. It's not a sermon. It's just a snapshot that proves we are all more than our skin colors. We are people, and we are capable of great love.
Award-winning director Ang Lee assembles a collection of effective scenes in this serious effort, but it also several moments that don't really work; in the end, it doesn't seem to add up to much.

Many horror movies are bad, but it's rare to find one that, like The Bye Bye Man, is so bad it's funny. Whether the problem was in the puzzling screenplay or in the production itself, something went dismally, hysterically wrong.
If, at the end of Cranston's run on "Breaking Bad," we all wondered whether he'd ever find a movie role as good as Walter White, this one is cause to shake our heads sadly.
Often, Patricia Highsmith's novels are adapted into high-class affairs, but this thriller feels refreshingly small-time and pulpy, getting closer to the story's raw emotions and impulses.
It can be exhilarating, thanks to Chazelle's marvelous use of space and color, and thanks to Justin Hurwitz's lovely score.

Yet another film about the Kennedy family may seem like an eye-rolling prospect, but Pablo Larrain's "Jackie" is so painfully alive, so painstakingly intimate, it rises above such simple descriptions.
Norwegian director Andre Ovredal follows up his terrific Trollhunter with an equally smart and satisfying chiller.
It's an absolute must-see.
The movie has a few weird, cool set designs using grungy, pastel colors.

Filmmaker M. Night Shyamalan launches a full-fledged comeback with this tense, satisfying horror-thriller. Split is refreshingly infused with thoughtful ideas and sly suggestion, rather than gore or brutality.
Middlebrow mediocrity served up by the Weinsteins on a silver platter for awards season.
It's extremely simplistic, but it's also rousingly effective.
One of those rare teen movies that actually gets teens right.
This war drama contains an earnest plea, a call for sympathy and understanding for soldiers suffering from PTSD; but the movie is so scattershot, somber, and confusing that it never comes together.
This horror movie tries to set itself apart from other demon-possession movies by inventing an interesting new mythology, but eventually it gets tired, bogged down and lost in its own rule book.
It's an interesting story, and it's very prettily told, but Ford doesn't seem to get inside the grisly, Straw Dogs-like themes of the story-within-the-story.
Jessica Chastain plays a fascinating role, an unapologetically powerful woman, capable of ugly behavior as well as kindness, and refreshingly unexplained.
Much like Elvis & Nixon, Michael Shannon stars in another small-scale film, focused mainly on two characters, and excels at it.

The end result is transporting, but also moving; it's a wake-up call, asking us to think about how much attention we really pay to what's around us, and - perhaps more importantly - what to do about it?
Gives viewers a chance to sit back and ponder questions and thoughts about the nature of being human and our relationship with the world.
This ridiculous thriller centers on just about the dumbest scheme ever invented for a movie, yet the filmmakers don't show any awareness of the plan's absurdity; it's played dismayingly straight.
Though it has a decent premise and a great cast, this supernatural thriller can't seem to overcome its crushingly mediocre screenwriting and filmmaking techniques. It's highly forgettable.
Though it's certainly worth a look, "Rogue One" is a minor "Star Wars" story.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Chilean director Pablo Larrain's biopic twists the formula around and explores surprisingly intimate and universal themes, while still guiding expert performances.

"Moana" sails straight and true, effortlessly, and with a great deal of joy and delight. It's perhaps not as clever or funny as this year's earlier Disney offering, "Zootopia," but it's wonderful in its own island way.
Though all of these actors are highly skilled, they are all directed to a very high pitch, with much stressing and bitterness, and it made me want to reach for the aspirin.
Director Brett Haley manages to take an underused subject, i.e. a character over 70, and make a movie that's deeply soulful and sweetly easygoing.
Manages to stay on the road with a measure of charm and goodwill, as well as a nice touch of the bittersweet.
It keeps up a whirl of color and cheerful spirit and ends with a brief but believable argument full of good cheer and goodwill toward men.
Though it won't convert any new fans, this silly, breezy sequel manages to capture the same blend of lowbrow humor, affectionate characters, and love for cheesy sci-fi movies as the first movie.
Unfortunately, this visual glory is the movie's best asset.
Perhaps [Del Toro's] loveliest film so far, easily on par with his masterpiece "Pan's Labyrinth."
[Kaurismaki's] first film in some six years, The Other Side of Hope is, happily, more of the same, but with some themes relevant to today's confused world.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As a story, it's a frenzy, bizarre even by today's standards, and when Gillespie includes clips of the real-life participants, it's almost a shock that it wasn't fictional.
Taking a cue from Ed Wood, this loving portrait of a terrible filmmaker could have indulged in ridicule, but instead it's about passion and dedication.
Richard Turner is an amazing figure.
Add... its magical array of visuals - an entire "Land of the Dead" is realized - and its kind, loving representation of Mexican culture, and "Coco" becomes a force for good in the world.
This drama is under-directed to the point of being alternately lifeless and awkward, but the main character has an appealing spunkiness that sometimes elevates the film.
I still like the movie for the way it immerses itself in each moment, and for the intense way it moves and sounds.

Certainly J.J. Abrams' 2015 "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" was more than satisfying, but Johnson steps it up several notches, digging deeper into characters, and even adding nuance to the "Star Wars" mythos.
Even the darkest moments, such as bird-shaped monsters or inner demons trying to cause chaos, are matched by moments of incredible beauty, light, and hope.
movie_title: Birdboy: The Forgotten Children (Psiconautas, los niños olvidados) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a zippy, appealingly off-kilter comedy that offers a pleasant evening's entertainment.
So brutally long, and takes so many right-angle doglegs, it's difficult to imagine that earlier screenplay drafts were thrown out; things just keep being tacked on.
Kogonada makes a striking debut with Columbus, a movie about architecture nerds that is itself composed like great architecture.
Recalls the talky, intellectual, but swoony summer romances of Eric Rohmer.
Gary Oldman plays Churchill, and suffice to say that if he finally wins an Oscar, it will not be undeserved.
It's not terrible, and the characters are likable, but, much like its vague title, this teen crime thriller, which also has elements of comedy and romance, never finds its center or its voice.
Writer/director Jared Moshe clearly loves and appreciates the Western genre, and here he's created one that's not only classical, skillful, and unpretentious but a fresh angle on an old story.
[A] sweeping slice of Americana, epic, but also intimate.
This documentary gets the best of both worlds, building a personal story of the likable, trustworthy Nye, as well as offering a serious, hopeful love letter to science itself.
A brutal, skillful psychological horror movie.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Though it owes a great deal to other social media-obsessed movies, this dark comedy still has enough fresh venom and crazy cleverness to make it a fresh satirical entertainment.
This umpteenth sequel in the Amityville franchise isn't that great, but it's surprisingly better than most of the other entries.
Resurrecting an old Coen brothers script, this would-be dark comedy is a depressing misfire, a baffling, awkward combination of nasty thrills and grim, ham-fisted social commentary.
Though "Thor: Ragnarok" may feel like a lightweight entertainment, it comes packed with the same ingredients that made Whedon's "The Avengers" so good.
One of the best filmmakers of our time, Richard Linklater has done it again; this extremely funny, deeply affecting dramedy about loss and regret is handled with genuine simplicity and sincerity.
Walks a fine line between ridicule and morbidity but maintains a humane balance, exploring a disturbed character in an empathetic way.
Approaching this true story with his usual tendency toward lightness and simplicity (i.e. without complexity or nuance), director Rob Reiner takes a compassionate look at an unsung president.
The movie must be commended for attempting a lead character that is not entirely likable; it's only through Gheorghe that we discover something worthwhile in the sad, suffering Johnny.
It gazes disturbingly, absurdly head-on as humans unused to conflict find themselves challenged.
So sharply written that it cuts, the third movie from award-winning playwright Martin McDonagh is a dramedy that starts with cleverness and wit, then opens up into something truthfully human.
A striking directorial debut by Greta Gerwig, this tender, semi-autobiographical love letter to Gerwig's hometown explores the gulf between childhood and adulthood with touching, witty humor.
Amazing.
Highly personal, searching, inventive, and constantly evolving in the most delightful ways.
Captures the thrill, the joy, the wonder of looking up into the night sky and seeing something uniting, something bigger than all of us.
I love all these cuddly Christmas cartoons.

The first three films in this series favored a gray, grimy look, in which the bright red and blue uniforms looked like they needed a wash. "Justice League" turns up the lights and brings back boldness and brightness.
As in his harrowing Nightcrawler, Dan Gilroy tells the story of a brilliant, ill-fitting outsider in a vivid workplace, but this movie fails due to puzzling, choppy character arcs.
The bright, fluid, elegant "Murder on the Orient Express" seems refreshingly smart and old-fashioned, like an export from the old studio days of Hollywood.
The movie isn't too concerned with age differences or hitting biographical highlights. Rather, it tries to get at the heart of how these two connected.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's exciting and essential, and one of my favorite films of 2017.
Director Paul Thomas Anderson takes a break from films that are trying to "say something" to return to a story about people; this is one of his best, most beautiful, and most perverse works.
Vega's performance is extraordinary and clearly the heart and muscle of the movie.
The first half of this drama is slow and awkward, mainly due to the stars' amateurish acting; but once it finally gets going, Eastwood's skilled touch reveals itself.
Emerges with not one single laugh.
It's an excellent, proud movie, and it has a lot to be proud of.
'Early Man' is a minor entry in the Aardman catalogue, but still quite likable and funny.
This playlike dramedy is sharp and good-looking (in black and white), but it's also shrill and aggressive, hurling nasty, witty barbs at the speed of suffering; it's smart without being thoughtful.
This dreamy, languid drama drifts appealingly from character to character, somehow finding profound emotional weight and layers in the relationships between people and their belongings.
Alex Garland's second directorial outing after the excellent Ex Machina, this brainy, metaphysical sci-fi is even more ambitious and more amazing. But its challenging conclusion could be a hard sell.
This horror-thriller uses its dozens (hundreds?) of hidden cameras as a gimmick, which constantly distracts from the story ... even though the story and themes are absurdly thin.
The movie is not without its moments, especially its rare moments of quiet.
Director Eli Roth's remake of the 1974 Charles Bronson movie (both based on Brian Garfields' novel) is not only awful, it's also incredibly thoughtless, with a brutish, simpleminded argument.
No matter how many exotic hairstyles and makeup jobs [Lawrence] gets, "Red Sparrow" does not have a breath of life in it.
Topaze is something of a pre-code comedy, but there is so much thought and sophistication crammed into its 78 minutes that it seems a shame to describe it in such vulgar terms.
This movie is truly messed up and I thoroughly enjoyed it.
This 10-years-later sequel to one of the staples of the "home invasion" horror subgenre is aggravatingly typical, with baffling lapses in logic, dumb characters, and annoying, all-powerful killers.
This soft, languid road movie benefits from accomplished actors Mirren and Sutherland; they share a genuine chemistry, but despite some lovely moments, the film meanders and becomes lost.
Though it runs a longish 110 minutes, for the majority of the time, it's a smart, jam-packed movie with plenty to enjoy.
This moment of women rising up and taking control of their own empowerment is the perfect time to release a documentary about Hedy Lamarr.
This strange, ambitious genre movie is notable for its huge cast of horror icons from the 1970s, '80s, and '90s, but it's more horrifying than scary and not always good, though certainly interesting.
This attempt at an American-style Bollywood musical is earnest at best and sappy, naïve, and overly sweet at worst; it does have lively moments, but it mainly inspires aggravation and eye-rolling.
This third movie in the Cloverfield series deflects attention from a giant monster and instead focuses on an odd, unstable mishmash of moods and tones, gamely held together by a fine cast.
The wonderful "Paddington 2" managed to be wondrous, hilarious and kindhearted, all at the same time, effortlessly. "Peter Rabbit," on the other hand, is all effort.
In the directorial debut from mile-a-minute screenwriter Aaron Sorkin, he opts to get out of his own way and stick to the script; the result isn't perfect, but it's energetic and entertaining.
This almost totally fails as a comedy, with broad, unfunny, dumb jokes (such as Wilson and a young boy urinating on each other), though it's marginally better during the goopy, heartwarming parts.
Based on an Agatha Christie novel (reportedly one of her own favorites), this mystery is beautifully shot, with great set design, but it suffers from its odd pace.
Despite now-infamous last-minute tinkering, this fact-based tale emerges as a fine pulp thriller, bathed in director Ridley Scott's trademark visual richness and with a few real-world life lessons.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This fourth entry in this successful horror series is an example of diminishing returns; though the characters are still interesting, it's clear that less care and attention were given to this movie.
It wants to be a very pro-Indian movie, but has very little use for them.
Neeson's fourth pairing with director Jaume Collet-Serra, this thriller is far from great, but the duo's usual blend of non-stop action and silly suspense still works like crazy.
This coming-out story is fairly routine, but it sets itself apart from dozens of similar stories with its deeply felt musical fantasy sequences.
Slow going and never quite sure of itself.
There's no shortage of movies about male sad-sacks who are stuck in a rut, but this one, though predictable, is mildly funny and warmly likable thanks to fine casting and sympathetic performances.
A pretty good, tighter, shorter movie might have been rescued from this dumb, disagreeable behemoth, but nobody bothered.
This nimble, kinetic, ultra-dark horror-comedy rampages through its gleefully wicked story without overwhelming its characters.
Filmmaker Greg Barker's documentary is both an inspiring portrait of an American leader and a shattering reality check.
In 2015, I marveled at the very existence of a movie that championed good manners and kindness, but I had no idea how much more those things would matter in 2018.
More like experimental cinema than a mainstream movie, this dark, unsettling, somewhat plotless film takes an unusual, colorful, and arty look at millennial narcissism and loneliness.
It's preoccupied with textures and touch, with fabric, food and foliage. Yet it's a sensuous telling of a rather pessimistic story.
Though it's not exactly brilliant, this indie romcom is passably charming, and it finds offbeat atmosphere in an uncharted corner of Hollywood: scuzzy places where the glamorous would fear to tread.
Fans of the real house... will find some things to cherish in the first half of "Winchester," but by the time it ends, it's like a spent rifle. It made a lot of noise, and now it's empty.
Action-heavy take on classic books has peril, edgy jokes.
It's a great story, but the fictional biopic Breathe is the most typical kind of slick Oscar bait.
Manages to avoid most of the genre trappings by telling a more focused story, a story that's about something, rather than simply someone's "life story."
Exploitation director Greg McLean chooses a numbingly middling approach to tell this true exploration story; the movie is too blunt to be sympathetic but also too careful to be thrilling.
This crime thriller has a promising director and a strong cast, but it's a total mess, with baffling flashbacks, excessive padding, and an overall poor execution.
Watts does his bit with a remarkable job of pacing, clarity, action, humor, etc. His action scenes are genuinely exciting and tense, and his character interactions are funny and warm.
This is a sheerly enjoyable film that shed a little more light on how the movie biz works, as well as how the human heart works.
movie_title: Harold And Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It still can't quite transcend its sitcom structure - but it's at least honest and funny.
"Detroit" is yet another masterpiece from that most singular of American directors, Kathryn Bigelow.
Theron fights, punches, kicks, and shoots her way through this beautifully choreographed, narratively complex, but slightly sluggish action movie...

This romantic war drama -- Sean Penn's fifth feature film as director -- is an all-around dud. It's poorly shot and edited, crushingly heavy-handed, woefully misguided, and, to top it off, miserably long.
It will have you digging out your old copies of 'Energy' and 'Kerplunk!' for a fresh listen.
movie_title: Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "An Inconvenient Sequel" is a more personal film, finding Gore in moments of self-reflection.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Low-budget action movies don't have to be dull or uninspired, but this one sure is. The actors phone in their performances, playing characters who are blandly unaffected in any way by the silly plot.
Despite having spent some time on the shelf, this thriller is far from a dud; it's surprisingly taut and gripping, relentlessly suspenseful, and takes only a few not-too-bright shortcuts.
Essential drama about violent chapter in U.S. history.
Actor-turned-screenwriter Taylor Sheridan makes his directorial debut with this smart, solid crime movie that, while not without its flaws, makes excellent use of open spaces and haunting quiet.
Director David F. Sandberg takes on this fourth film in the Conjuring franchise, and although it offers little that's new, it's so skillful and spirited that it works.
Based on Walls' best-selling memoir, this drama could have been edgier, but it follows a certain genre type, comfortably presenting itself as a four-hankie weepie graced with fine performances.
This dramedy from several SNL veterans has a pretty strong case of the cutes, and it doesn't always connect, but at the same time it's genuinely imaginative and sweetly likable.
Directing brothers Ben Safdie and Joshua Safdie have created an ode to intense 1970s New York crime cinema, but with their own vivid, confined close-up take, bathed in artificial, carnival colors.
This slight drama doesn't have very much to it, but any movie about a middle-aged woman is a welcome rarity, and in it, Hunter proves she can still bring life and spirit to any kind of material.
Directed by brothers Abel and Burlee Vang, this horror movie looks great and busts open a few old genre chestnuts, but it's also predictable, bland, and not all that scary.
Based on Stephen King's novels, this sludgy science fiction/fantasy dud reduces King's epic vision to a series of mindless cliches, surrounded by lazy dialogue and half-baked visual effects.
'Endless Poetry' raises the possibility that artists young or old can still challenge barriers and ask questions about life.
It manages to feel quietly moving and quietly profound in unexpected ways, and I think it is Morris's best film in a long time.
movie_title: The B-Side: Elsa Dorfman's Portrait Photography (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Christopher Nolan's first non-fantasy movie is bold, visceral, and powerful, with many moving sequences -- though some of his filmmaking choices can be challenging.
"The Big Sick" definitely gets extra points for its real-life factor.
This is my favorite of the movies adapted from Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's novel, and the first one in color.
It's a great, simple story, and, in the history of action movies, ought to be considered alongside Die Hard and Speed.
Another in a long line of Tarantino-inspired, multi-character comic crime capers, this movie stays on its toes during a whirlwind of sly humor, cool-headed characters, and colorful situations.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Hawkins turns in a heartfelt performance as real-life painter Maud Lewis (1903-1970), carrying a biographical drama that's lovely and gentle without ever becoming soft or sentimental.
An extremely simple idea unfolds into a no-frills thriller that's so insidiously gripping that it verges on throttling; shark fans shouldn't miss seeing this on the big screen.
Though definitely not for mainstream tastes, Ana Lily Amirpour's bizarre, beautiful film feels like an arthouse movie from an earlier time, more of a dare than a comfort, more active than passive.
Newcomer Shipp Jr. is well cast as Tupac, but the movie, unlike Tupac's own storytelling, is sluggish and generic; it doesn't adequately capture the artist's unique genius.
Plotwise, director Sofia Coppola doesn't change much from Clint Eastwood's 1971 take on novelist Thomas Cullinan's story, but moodwise, she gives it her own special, dreamy-thoughtful visual style.
An exciting, gleeful movie.
A wry delight.
The film has a remarkable patience and beauty, taking the time to live in its offbeat, unsettling moments.
Heineman's documentary may be a little static, but with its sympathetic depiction of fear and hiding, it paints a vivid, terrifying portrait of life under a powerful, evil regime.
Not only smart, dazzling and entertaining, it speaks to fears and concerns that are as relevant today as they were in the 1960s when the series originated.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The general playful tone... helps a great deal, and the cinematography and editing are appealingly glossy and smooth throughout.
Packed with talented comedy stars, this misguided misfire isn't just unfunny; it doesn't seem like it was ever supposed to be -- it wanders, lost between a serious crime drama and a biteless satire.
This modern-day, teen-centric take on W. W. Jacobs' classic horror story The Monkey's Paw is a not-scary dud that suffers from both uninspired scares ad extremely shallow, annoying characters.
This very special movie casts a fine, delicate spell; many may resist it, but those who go along with it may find themselves profoundly moved, transported to a soul-stirring, poetically cosmic place.
Some of the movie's images -- such as an immense marketplace in an alternate dimension, or the complex structure of Alpha itself -- are absolutely breathtaking.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Brendan Muldowney directs this historical dirge, which is plagued by snooze-inducing seriousness, a dutiful reliance on genre chestnuts, and an overall lack of excitement. Game of Thrones this most certainly is not.
Plays as if its creators spent too much time trying to guess what people wanted to see, and not enough on what kind of movie they'd like to make.
With basically no association with Open Water 1-2 other than the "stranded with sharks" set-up, this sequel is so dreadful that it will have you rooting for the sharks.
A richly entertaining tale.
This lighthearted dramedy treads the stalest, most worn-out story grooves imaginable, but thanks to its cultural sensitivity and sweetly lovable characters, it's very difficult not to like.
While the film is definitely amusing and touching, it, for whatever reason, never quite grows into hilarious or moving.
I do wish the film had gone a little farther in its structure... but otherwise, I love it.
Though Neeson is commanding in his role, and though Felt's story is a powerful one, this political drama eventually fails to rise above an overly explanatory, visually static storytelling style.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This cheap-looking, poorly acted horror movie makes absolutely no sense and is far more awkward and annoying than scary; it falls directly into that "what the heck were they thinking?" category.

This remake of the popular 1990 hit starts with the same intriguing idea and goes down the same superficial, empty-headed path. Although, unlike the original, this take on Flatliners is sadly unaware of its own shallowness.
Leone's violent epic Western is an essential masterpiece.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: So much is absolutely spellbinding, particularly the visuals and sound. Many scenes are hauntingly, eerily still.
Written and directed by fashion industry sisters Kate and Laura Mulleavy, this experimental, drug-hazed movie looks interesting, but whatever it's up to, it doesn't quite seem to achieve it.
Reportedly the first fully painted animated film in history, this seven-years-in-the-making effort is often breathtakingly beautiful.
I know it's hard to believe, but this sixth movie in the Child's Play/Chucky slasher series is actually surprisingly well made.
Hong Kong action director Ronny Yu... brings a slick, kinetic, cartoonish energy to the proceedings.
Simply, an important film as well as an entertaining one.
This thriller casts Chan in a bracing, dynamic role but then wastes that potential as the story sidelines him, focusing instead on other characters in rooms explaining the plot to each other.
Tackling a serious subject but looking like a bad after-school special, this drama is terribly forced and indelicate; it tries to deliver an important message but feels more like a cheap thriller.
Though it obviously borrows from Groundhog Day, this gleefully silly slasher movie has a playful spirit, likable characters, and even some half-decent life lessons.
And the characters might have been one-dimensional, defined by their loss and presented as helpless, but they're not. They have realistic strengths and weaknesses.
Like "Far from Heaven," it's a great movie about movies, and about other things as well.
Complex gangster epic has strong violence, sex.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)

movie_review_blurb: it doesn't take itself too seriously, and it seems to have respect for both the story's hero and its villain.
This horror movie begins with an intriguing idea -- exploring the pitfalls of social media -- but quickly succumbs to routine setups and payoffs typical of most uninspired ghost stories.

movie_title: A Tale of Love and Darkness (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderfully creative, soul-soothing work.
Daniel Ragussis' debut feature is better at being suspenseful than it is at being socially relevant; but at the same time, it has moments in which it terrifies and inspires despair and dread.
Kubo and the Two Strings champions the pure pleasure and power of storytelling; it's simple, but spectacular.
This documentary is one of Herzog's best; it's thoughtful yet entertaining, amusing yet heartbreaking, and sometimes simply beautiful.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Entertaining, mature thriller has language, violence, sex.
There are many important WWII stories worth telling, but sometimes movies, like this one, take the wrong approach, and we end up with something that's poorly made, tedious, and depressing.
This well-made action-chase movie could have easily fallen apart along its well-worn story grooves, but nifty characters and electric dialogue, along with intense action, keep it alive.
A gentle, whimsical tale, focusing on wonder in an age when most kids' movies focus on noise and movement.
This animated comedy is decidedly not for kids; it's rambunctiously filthy in more ways than one. And while it's not exactly hilarious, it's at least consistently amusing and has a positive attitude.
This Netflix original film falls into the old "weepie/women's picture" category, but it stays stubbornly rooted in characters and moments.
Michel Gondry's coming-of-age road movie Microbe and Gasoline is, surprisingly, his best film since Be Kind Rewind, or even Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.
Appealingly rich and cluttered, as well as fascinating and funny.
The only one who actually seemed to care is Tony Gilroy, who wrote or co-wrote the four previous movies (and directed the fourth). He didn't even show up for this dud. Now that was a smart move.
This lightweight thriller for the new millennium is flashy, with decent, likable characters and adrenaline-fueled thrills, even if it grows ever more implausible and ultimately disposable.
Gleefully irreverent, and with a so-crazy-it-must-be-true vibe, this exuberant comedy manages to be wildly entertaining while simultaneously finding alarming cracks in the fabric of American society.
"Hell or High Water" is a great genre picture: film noir cannily combined with a Western, but with a modern-day setting.
At some point, with Smith and Robbie getting most of the screen time, this team was supposed to jell and form a unit whose members depend on one another. Frankly, they don't.

The 13th overall movie in the Star Trek franchise turns out to be good luck for everyone. It's a fresh, satisfying return to the beloved characters of the 1966-1969 TV series and to a rousing sense of teamwork.
This is boldly independent work, with more than enough painful, searing drama to leave a mark.
It's so structurally and rhythmically free-flowing -- so jazzy -- that I think it's still worth a look.
Trying to explain what happens in CRIMINAL is bad enough -- you run up against all the things that make no sense -- but then there's the clumsy, jumbled, thoughtless way it's all put together.
Laced with subtle performances and rich characters, Jason Bateman's The Family Fang is a big improvement over his last movie, the overly cynical-but-cute Bad Words.
As Alice battles roiling oceans, travels through time, storms the red castle and tries to save the space-time continuum it becomes apparent that no one actually cares.
Violent, boring, badly told video game-based fantasy.

Me Before You might have been a profound movie, but it instead goes for an easy marketing niche, copying a template that has previously proven successful with female moviegoers of a certain age range.
In many ways, Finding Dory improves upon its predecessor, although it still doesn't rank as any kind of major achievement for the beloved animation studio.
The result is enjoyable, but feels perhaps a bit slight, as if, with a little more time, more depth may have been achieved.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Brian De Palma is currently one of America's best filmmakers, or at least one of its most stylishly singular, and... "De Palma" cannily sheds light on exactly why.
A totally routine movie that tries to combine a message about trafficked children with a lowbrow thriller about loved ones going missing in a foreign country.
It feels more like a dashed-off, phoned-in attempt at a story, as if told by a busy grownup with better things to do.
This aggravating, confusing zombie thriller now has the dishonor of being arguably the worst movie ever made based on a Stephen King novel.
I loved it... It seems to me that it's one of [Spielberg's] gentlest and most beautiful films.
Tremendously moving.
These four women combine their efforts to help create what could be the funniest movie I've seen in this dismal year.
I think there's enough here to make Cafe Society worth seeing.
Warmly humorous, and compassionate.
The acting is good, and the story is well-told, but THE INFILTRATOR is more serviceable than extraordinary.
With Carpenter's clear, widescreen direction and his skill and enthusiasm at their highest peak, this is a masterpiece.
Dietrich's fiery performance is irresistible, especially the way she stomps her feet and fires eye-daggers to get what she wants.
Though it borrows from Pet Sematary and other chillers and doesn't offer much in the way of fresh scares, this effective ghostly horror movie works thanks to characters with strong emotional centers.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Door (2016)

movie_review_blurb: When her family decided to spend nine months in a cabin in the Yukon, filmmaker Suzanne Crocker brought her camera, and the result is a quietly revealing story about a family's quality time together.
movie_title: All The Time In The World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Depp gives one of his richest performances as James "Whitey" Bulger.
"Sicario" can be relentlessly cynical, but it's also mesmerizing, and exhilarating.
A deeply personal, remarkably intelligent, and profoundly moving experience, Jenni Olson's The Royal Road is not easily labeled.
This superb movie helps restore [Weber's] reputation.
Some have complained that the 123-minute movie is a slow starter, but Levitt's feverish, dedicated performance energizes the first half.
The Martian is no masterpiece, but it is a fine film from a talented director.
The tone is dreary and deadpan, and by turns funny, sad, lovely, and meditative. But, in completing his trilogy, Andersson ends Pigeon with a new kind of shocking depth.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: For a movie that's supposedly about life experience, The Intern shows very little.
A very well made, moving soap opera.

Written by the talented Hossein Amini and clearly inspired by spy and detective movies of the 1940s, this seems to have been a labor of love. But SHANGHAI is so convoluted that it eventually becomes lost.
It's a wonder how this stinker of a script -- packed with foul language, sex references, and scatological jokes -- attracted such a strong cast in the first place, and the finished film is no better.

It's one of those movies that tries hard to "stay true to the material," forsaking anything personal in the process, as if the filmmakers were simply empty vessels whose only job is to bring this important story to the masses.
The doc is a bit more loony than the recent SNL film, but it's still just a bit too tame - i.e. lots of talking heads - to truly represent its subject.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The horror meta-movie has been done before (Scream), but this one edges past mere cleverness with a strangely touching emotional core: What would you do if you met a shadow of your lost mother?
It's no "Pan's Labyrinth," but it is as intricately, astoundingly designed and as entertaining as del Toro's "Hellboy II: The Golden Army."
Even if it's less gloriously beautiful than its predecessor, the new movie is a little warmer, and also includes a pretty basic, but powerful and relevant ... argument against surveillance.

It may even be the best newspaper movie since "All the President's Men," although its conspiracy story cuts deeper - molested children rather than crooked politicians - and its villain (the Catholic Church) more dangerous.
The Oakland-born filmmaker Ryan Coogler has worked more miracles with the 40 year-old Rocky series.
Even as the critical part of my brain was working, I, too, found myself strongly affected by the words and actions of this teenage hero.
It's an almost dreamy piece of work, with very little preaching about the state of homelessness today and instead a deep pondering of existence, surfaces, and identity.
After several perplexing misfires, writer/director M. Night Shyamalan has scaled back, gone for a lower budget and a lighter tone, and emerged with his most effective movie in over a decade.
Starting off promisingly with an utterly gruesome prologue (you'll never eat chicken nuggets again) and some funny, likable characters, this horror-comedy eventually becomes both bland and tasteless.
Even if the movie stumbles over a few clunky plot turns, Williams' final live-action performance is a powerful one, still and deep, calling on limitless reserves of pain and longing.
It even has a few laughs and a few nostalgic riffs. But eventually, like an old arcade game, the whole thing feels two-dimensional, and all surface.

Director Mark Neveldine is known for his loony, kinetic cult movies, but this demon-possession tale, despite its shock ending, can't quite get past the limitations of a genre that peaked with The Exorcist (1973).
It's well made and worthy of polite applause, but probably won't be watched too many more times.
Here comes Ant-Man, bringing all the surprise and joy we got when we wandered into the first Iron Man or Guardians of the Galaxy. And fun! Yes, fun.
The original Sinister was a passable chiller, but the sequel feels more like a vague attempt to continue a lucrative franchise than to create anything truly compelling or spooky.

It's horrifying to consider just how this movie operates, generating so-called thrills based on a blind, empty-headed fear of foreigners. Adding dumb plot twists and bad shaky-cam makes for an insultingly poor movie.
Zac Efron and Emily Ratajkowski are both extremely attractive people who seem better suited to modeling than acting; they give empty portrayals as empty characters in an empty film.
This post-apocalyptic drama does away with mutated monsters, evil power mongers, chases, explosions, and grisly effects and simply, effectively focuses on the deeds and emotions of three people.
It may seem, at a glance, like something awfully cutesy and potentially annoying. But if you look just below the surface, it contains Coixet's usual mature, humanist touches.
The Tribe is constantly riveting, and even if there is one other movie without spoken dialogue this year, Shaun the Sheep Movie, you still won't see anything else like it.
The fourth "Transporter" movie is broken down, out of gas, and any of a dozen other dead car metaphors.
While this movie could have been an overly earnest drama or an embarrassing slapstick farce, it settles somewhere comfortably in between.
This Chinese battle epic features exciting, show-stopping fight scenes, but the storytelling in between is almost non-existent, as if lazily looking for ways to kill the time.
Director Eli Roth returns to the director's chair with this vile, abhorrent, incompetent, dumb, hateful cannibal torture film. The movie goes wrong in so many ways, it's hard to know where to start.
It offers layered characters, operating in a vivid world.
Acclaimed indie filmmaker Ramin Bahrani, who regularly and bravely focuses on heartbreaking trials of life while keeping his stories rooted in humanity, turns in some of his finest work here.
Zwick's new movie, Pawn Sacrifice, somehow feels more like a struggle than a statement, and it's arguably his best movie in a couple of decades.
A few chuckles here and there...
Todd Haynes has directed Carol, from a screenplay by Phyllis Nagy, with superb precision.
[Singh's] movies generally receive the same reviews: impressive visuals, pathetic storytelling. "Self/less" does not deviate. The movie might have been better titled "Less," with no "Self" involved.
The Good Dinosaur is a strange little thing, bursting with beautiful nature imagery, good intentions, and odd ideas.
Although there's nothing new in "The Night Before," and other similar seasonal naughty comedies have been funnier, it has a genuine heart.
Kung Fu Panda 3 actually feels like part of the story, like it has a good reason to exist on its own, aside from just being an investment for a movie company.
Establishing himself as a director of tough genre films, John Hillcoat offers this multi-faceted, devilishly complex crime thriller without wasting any time on needless background.
This drama attempts to open an earnest discussion of bipolar disorder, and it can be informative, but its message is muddled and indecisive.
This is a movie that, because it deals with secrets, promises thrills and possibly a measure of terror; but, in fact, everything is based on an anti-climax, and the result is a resounding "so what?"
This Western doesn't have anything terribly wrong with it -- terrific cast, fine story and acting, appealing scenery -- but somehow it just never sparks to life.
It's a big, swirling movie, shot by the great Roger Deakins, full of movies and the joy of movies.
The computer-generated creatures have smooth and cheerful lines, like old-style "stretch-and-squash" animation. The movie is wonderfully fluid and graceful.

Malick, with the help of cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, finds many, many images of great beauty among the concrete and steel of Los Angeles, and, at times, Knight of Cups is an immersive, poetic experience.
Playful, irreverent and loads of fun.
Anyone who was calling for a sequel to Olympus Has Fallen should've been careful what they wished for; this sequel borrows shamelessly from many action classics and ends up lifeless and dim.

Everything is shrouded in a kind of black sludge, and frankly, it's depressing. Even the would-be iconic meeting of Superman, Batman and Wonder Woman looks like it was ground out from an old Xerox copier.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's not quirky, nor is it exactly cautionary. It casually mentions all the various forms of lethal stuff we could be breathing at any moment, in any part of the world, and then ends with a shrug.
Strayed's inner journey for herself doesn't really work as an outer journey for a movie audience.
Michelle is too much of a caricature; she doesn't have the soul of, say, Megan in Bridesmaids or Susan in Spy. She never feels like a person. She learns lessons, but she never has doubts or fears.

Sometimes bad behavior can be entertaining, but in this cynical story of the music industry, it's simply depressing. There's no vicarious thrill, no exhilaration, only uninspired, unpunished meanness.
With laid-back ease and an organic understanding of characters and dialogue, Richard Linklater (Boyhood) has crafted an excellent, breezy comedy.
This shocker of a thriller is an intelligent, atmospheric slow burn that spends its early moments on interactions and emotions, avoiding obvious exposition or setups.
The performances are electric and more or less worth the price of admission.
The filmmakers keep the mystery going, indicating that the movie's not just another dashed-off attempt to cash in.

The Expendables 2 (2012) was somehow a marked improvement, with better action and more downtime between characters ... but it was less of a hit. And now THE EXPENDABLES 3 moves back in the wrong direction again.
Clip shows like this are always fun for die-hard movie buffs (including critics), especially in a case like this, when the clips are much more potent than the completed films.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's as if David Lynch collided with a truckload of martial artists and brawlers, and the resulting explosion created this strange, moody universe, full of odd sound cues; shocking, dreamlike imagery; and less flashy, more vivid fight scenes.
As with his Oscar-winning The Great Beauty, Italian director Paolo Sorrentino brings a gorgeous, dreamy visual style to this drama, even if it's not quite as profound as it wants to be.
Despite a high-concept idea and a good cast, this crime thriller feels somewhat half-baked and rushed. It might once have been promising, but it seems like something went wrong along the way.
"Star Wars: The Force Awakens" is simple and highly entertaining, a rollicking adventure that avoids anything about trade federations or blockades.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "The Hateful Eight" is much tighter, and more tightly-wound, than "Django Unchained," and it's a great deal of fun.
Thanks to a committed performance by DiCaprio and extraordinary cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki, this revenge Western isn't terrible, but its grandiose treatment belies a rather dull, flat story.
This ghost story starts off well, with an interesting setup and characters, but then it starts relying too much on cheap jump-scares and eventually lets the mystery slip away and fall apart.

It's impossible not to think of Clint Eastwood in his great Westerns when watching his youngest son, Scott, in this poor one, and the comparison isn't favorable. Both the movie and its star seem empty.
Bad acting, clunky cinematography and editing, heavy violence, and a less-than-genius screenplay make this a totally disposable action movie, not even recommendable to die-hard Willis ans.
Celebrated screenwriter Charlie Kaufman has fashioned this existential crisis as a dark, bizarre stop-motion animated movie, and while it's extraordinary in many ways, it's clearly not for kids.
This sequel is funnier, particularly when Hart suffers some kind of humiliation or takes a beating. This can't be healthy, for Hart, or for the audience.
Assuming viewers are uneducated, or that they simply do not care, the film's off to a swell start.
Though it may not feel as profound as the first two entries, Ip Man 3 is ultimately more watchable and more purely entertaining.

This bizarre, quasi-existential neo-Western thriller is full of brainy chit-chat but doesn't actually offer any real ideas. The characters are so thin that the outcome of their conflict doesn't really matter.
While it's not a terribly original entry in the "creepy doll" horror subgenre, this fright flick nonetheless offers interesting characters, a strong cast, expert pacing, and a spooky atmosphere.
Westbound feels slightly different from the other entries, probably due to the absence of producer Harry Joe Brown and screenwriter Burt Kennedy, but it still has some extraordinary passages.
All in all, Island of Lost Souls works on every level; it rattles your nerves while you're watching it, and it haunts your dreams after it's over.
Though it might not be gut-bustingly hysterical (or even particularly memorable), Lazer Team is still momentarily enjoyable.
This exceptionally intelligent, atmospheric horror movie more closely recalls Ingmar Bergman than Wes Craven, as it's centered around human foibles as well as dealing with a hint of the supernatural.
Though it borrows liberally from the classic Shane and doesn't really offer anything new, this lowkey Western still works, thanks to patient storytelling and a batch of strong performances.
A warmhearted, gentle and funny animated film
Focuses on the strengths and shortcomings of the two women characters, several generations apart, and captures an uncommonly powerful portrait of both.
For this tense real-life drama, director Peter Berg weaves a wide, vivid tapestry of Boston; it's an admirable feat, but his unrefined techniques grow exhausting after a long 130 minutes.
This band of strong, fascinating characters overcomes the otherwise awkward combination of script elements.
Wyler really started showing his skills with this outstanding film featuring a top-notch performance by John Barrymore.
[A] great American comedy.
[An] odd, funny, strangely mesmerizing three-part comedy.
It's a unique, indelible and hilarious film, and certainly one of the best of its era.
Despite their constant chatter, the characters come alive without seeming too intellectual or too removed.
It's not exactly top-tier Hitchcock, but it features enough good stuff to make it at least worth one viewing.
Roman Polanski somehow brought his brand of paranoid horror to the Hollywood mainstream with rousing success.
This third installment takes a less reverent and a more behind-the-scenes approach.
This is arguably David Cronenberg's masterpiece.
The film is Wong's most visually striking, with Wong and Doyle constantly inventing intoxicating new angles for every shot.
It's fascinating in an overwrought kind of way, and even though it was not filmed in Pittsburgh, it's still filled with all of Romero's usual touches.
A well-paced, dumb, fun movie.
The production has a patient, observant tone, which almost disguises the fact that Momma's Man can't decide what kind of movie it wants to be.
Mizrahi is such a flambouyant character that we are fascinated by him the whole time he is on camera. He seems to have a natural comic timing, as do the editors of the film.
Lemmon and Spacek are the film's highlight... It's a winning formula, and it's too bad that there isn't more of it.
I found it uninspiring. I couldn't get a handle on Young's character, who at times seems to be a dumb slab of meat, and at other times is reciting poetry.
Eastwood is one of our greatest living filmmakers, and he turns in a good, well-made movie, but his straightforward, bread-and-butter approach doesn't always work with material this grim.
It's all crazy enough to work for a while, but the 124 long minutes don't pass soon enough.
Ulmer's third masterpiece, after The Black Cat (1934) and Detour (1945); it's one of his few films that overcame its wretched budget.
[Smith] has gone and made his most mature and romantically affecting film since Chasing Amy.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Crush is a half-comedy, half-weepie that doesn't really work, though Andie MacDowell is quite wonderful.
Even something this ridiculous has its inventive charms, not least of which are the wonderfully chintzy invisibility effects.
Arguably William Friedkin's funniest film.
A snappy little 76-minute, black-and-white item, this film noir dared to look at the dark side of Monroe's giggly sex appeal.
Some of the best moments occur in fantasy and/or dream sequences in which Bush faces his darkest fears, and Stone gets across his most secret theories.
The film lurches from terrible tragedy to happy montage and back again, never attempting to rise above a typical weepie.
The movie's excellent design and mood almost -- almost -- outweigh the stupid story.
It's as laid-back as any Hollywood movie about itself has ever been.
It fails to let us live vicariously through these sailors and actually join them on their trip. And it fails because it's a reality show.
I think I started to come close to understanding it; regardless, I'm very fond of it, and it's easy to get swept away by its lonely majesty.
It's fairly ridiculous (the apes are clearly people in suits), but it's light and brisk and fun, with a nice open-air feel.
The movie was clearly made with a lot of love, and it has one deciding factor that sells it: Robert Downey Jr.
The movie pretty much follows the original story, without using its new twist in any interesting ways.
movie_title: The Two Faces of Dr. Jekyll (Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde) (1960)

movie_review_blurb: The story has more twists than a pretzel, and they're all just as delicious.
Fares slightly better [than The Two Faces of Dr. Jekyll].
Gets extra credit for trying something different.
This is one of Hitchcock's best and least appreciated films, with the Master getting a creative boost after a minor slump.
Wilder somehow sustains the lively pace and humor for the two-and-a-half hour color comedy.
Akira Kurosawa and Toshiro Mifune team up for one of their most basic and enjoyable samurai films.
Compulsively watchable four-hankie weepie.
A worthwhile... meticulously reported film, splashed with [Morris'] own, unique style.
For his fifth feature film, Guy Ritchie happily ignores his previous two misfires and goes back to what he does best, making dime-store, knockoff pulp thrillers.
It's a superb achievement, and Demme's best foray into fiction since The Silence of the Lambs.
It quickly descends into [Wood's] signature style: few -- if any -- of the shots match, the acting is atrocious and the dialogue sings with its own unique rhythms of awfulness.
We could have had something really representing the vibrant Aussie film industry.
Sean Penn plays Milk as if he were born to the part... it's a true physical and spiritual embodiment.
Boyle uses the stomping rhythms of Bollywood showtunes just as he used the thrusting beat of Iggy Pop to drive Trainspotting, and the result is his best picture since that 1996 hit.
I've Loved You So Long is very thin and artificial; characters behave erratically and illogically for no other reason than to serve the forward thrust of the plot.
The movie charts the rise and fall of the label without ever centering on any characters or relationships; it's history without personality.
It's Howard's second really good film.
[An] assured, amazing 72-minute debut Israeli film, in which every delicate shot counts for the greater emotional impact.
Writer David Hare and director Stephen Daldry don't seem particularly interested in the material; rather, the picture seems cranked out by a computer that has been programmed to make Oscar nominees.
Though the film lacks the humor of, say, "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" as well as the sheer adrenaline of something like Near Dark (1987), it has a definite appeal of its own.

It doesn't sound like much, but Reichardt and co-writer Jonathan Raymond create a loose universe in which the characters actually seem to be moving through time, waiting, making decisions, cursing fate, eating, sleeping and waiting some more.
Simplistic and soapy, Nothing Like the Holidays nonetheless succeeds in warming the cockles.
It's an impressively big film, and even when it's bad, it's bad in a big way.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gran Torino is a strange coda, an autumnal epilogue, and yet if you love American movies and their history -- of which Eastwood is a huge part -- you need to see this.
If only the swift, snappy humor could have lasted into the third act, but the emotional thrust is still there, and Doubt is a fascinating picture.
Though it plays up its own social relevance, it actually works something like an uncomfortably realistic docudrama.
The first thing Steven Soderbergh's four-hour epic biopic does is to sidestep anything you might expect from a four-hour biopic.
It's frankly all a bit too much, without the whimsy of something like Big Fish (2003), or the wit of Fitzgerald.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's pleasant and won't ruffle the nerves of any stressed-out parents.
Feels both too cluttered and too safe.
It's a great deal of fun, playing not unlike a crafty caper film with loads of spine-tingling suspense.
Call me nuts, but even with all the dysfunction and suffering, I found lots to cherish about this artistically personal holiday film.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Kung Fu Panda puts most other recent action movies to shame with its astonishingly beautiful, fluid, fast, clean use of movement and space.
The overall film has a nice, warm feel; this was more of a lark than any kind of social agenda.
No matter what else is going on in Soul Men, it's difficult not to be moved by the posthumous performances of Bernie Mac and Isaac Hayes

Whether it's ironic or funny or deeply intelligent, JCVD may actually be one of my favorite movies this year.
What finally emerges is a tender, moving relationship between two confused, lost young people.
Perhaps the best in the "Ranown" series, alongside Seven Men from Now, Ride Lonesome one never once strikes a wrong note.
The Tall T has some of the best sequences in the "Ranown" series.
This is a lighter effort than usual, with more of a male bonding angle. It's also the most needlessly complicated of the series.
It works well enough to get you riled up.

The duo would capitalize on this balance in the later monster movies, but it works just as well here.
Famed action director Don Siegel saw an element of raw danger in Elvis and gave him his very best role in this excellent quasi-Western.
A terrific bread-and-butter Western.
Beart will take your breath away each time she's on screen.
The overall film has a well-developed sense of atmosphere that most films of today are missing.
Offers a completely one-sided view of Castro and his life and career.
One of the greatest achievements in American film.
The sinister occurs within the confines of the beautiful, like a disease eating away a beautiful tree from the inside.
A good deal gorier and more disturbing than the original. Certainly it's far better than the soulless 2003 remake.

So joyous and uplifting that you just want to pluck it off the screen, put it in your pocket and carry it around with you.
Stanwyck was too strong to play this simpering role.
Cronenberg makes the most out of the sterile building and creates some memorably shocking images.
movie_title: Shivers (They Came from Within) (The Parasite Murders) (1975)

movie_review_blurb: Even after decades of performing the same songs, the energy never flags.
movie_title: Standing in the Shadows of Motown (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Wilder plays the suspense well, but this movie belongs to Laughton, who makes his every line resonate like music and thunder.
Cheadle comes away unscathed. His commanding performance is the first, best reason to see this.
Far and away the finest section is the final showdown, smoothly and swiftly shot with excessive violence and gore.

It's a shame to see such vibrant material treated in such a routine, nostalgic manner, but the energy of the material and especially of the Germs music occasionally rescues the movie from its unimpressive, superficial stretches.
The screenplay is a tad overwritten, but the acting is fine, and die-hard vampire fans will want to check it out.
Oswald, who never graduated past B-movies and television, makes masterful use of the frame, pitting his dark thriller elements against a full-color, widescreen frame.
Some of the early imagery... seems to suggest that anything is possible in this "crazy" universe, but the wrap-up is just so aggravatingly bland.
A fleet-footed, featherweight comedy riddled with cliches, but nonetheless charming and winning.
Baby Mama quickly and lazily adopts all the annoying attributes of the usual fare.
Cool Hand Luke now seems more like a well-made entertainment than any kind of American masterpiece.
People have always been, and always will be, impressed with big movies; this Western was one of the very biggest.
Aside from all this nonsense, it never loses its John Ford touch.
Transforms George Cukor's witty, bitchy The Women (1939) into a cuddly, weepy big-screen sitcom.
The plot is grippingly complex and at the same time laughably ludicrous, and it has one of the best wrap-up lines ever filmed.
Didn't I review this coming-of-age picture back in the spring when it was called Charlie Bartlett?
The great Minnelli was surely one of the masters of the American musical, but Gigi was one of his misfires.
Director Bill Melendez concentrates on atmosphere more than anything else; he sets up unrelated jokes, or simply enjoys watching the autumn leaves fall gently to the ground.
movie_title: It's the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown (1966)

movie_review_blurb: It feels as if they're old friends who have worked together for decades, slipping into an easy camaraderie as well as a credible depiction of blue-collar beat-walkers. (Better still, they look like they're having fun.)
Aside from the zombie classics and taken by itself, Martin is also a kind of masterpiece.
Fassbinder's second film feels rarely moves, but simmers with a kind of rancid, unnamable anger.

Like the computer animators at Pixar, the stop-motion wizards at Aardman realize their technical prowess would be wasted without a worthy script.
Life may be messy, but it's usually entertaining.
Paulie isn't a complicated film, but it is heartfelt. And for a change, parents in the theater won't feel embarrassed by the things their children are laughing at.
Similar to Like Water for Chocolate, Big Night celebrates the sensuality of food. It will produce more salivating than an afternoon at Pavlov's lab.
Just when it seemed the courtroom drama was suffering a fatal case of John Grisham, A Civil Action" rescues the genre.
The Coen Brothers wander down some dead ends in The Man Who Wasn't There, but they still reach a surprising, grim conclusion James M. Cain would admire.
Though Wild Wild West's story never comes together (what Salma Hayek's character has to do with anything is a mystery), it generates a good amount of laughs.
Mr. Deeds" oddly enough is enjoyable while it follows Capra's outline. Only when it goes its own way in the third act does the comedy fall apart.
Forget Antz. A Bug's Life is the computer-animated insect movie that really buzzes.
How good is "L.A. Confidential"? Kim Basinger gives a convincing performance - that's how good.
Mendes has assembled "American Beauty" from other groundbreaking films. His ambition lies in the way he presents "American Beauty" as a modern version of the major films he copies.
Filled with calculated sentiment, this is not a movie but a feature-length shill for Academy Awards nominations.
Waking Life" tells us not to be afraid to think the big thoughts, not be dulled by our daily tasks.
A repellent parade of gore.
Few critics have been as skeptical of Julia Roberts' talents as I, but "Erin Brockovich" has won me over.
Clooney and Lopez are so laid back, they anesthetize the proceedings.
An entertaining polemic filled with world-class performances,
Asking serious questions about such movies usually is pointless, but how stupid do director Dewey Nicks and writer David H. Steinberg think women are?

This is just the type of "dignified" tragedy Louis B. Mayer loved to churn out in the 1940s, where characters - even the unsavory ones - acted so noble they practically turned to statues before your eyes.
Its potential as a spicy spoof of Hollywood's incestuous relation with the entertainment press has been Ephroned away in favor of bland romantic comedy.
With only his second film Anderson proves himself a director so in command of his medium he can ignore convention and make films his own way.
Any dungeon master worth his 20-sided dice could have whipped up a better scenario.
It may not be original, but it is smart. More importantly, it's scary.
Scott oversells every shot.
Captures the yearnings and motives - both romantic and pathetic - of guys in their 20s like no film since Diner.
Babe needed a sequel as much as Citizen Kane or Casablanca.
Silence of the Lambs" could terrify. "Hannibal" only disgusts.
The plot works on a mechanical level, but "The Peacemaker" reveals the Bond movies are smart to oil the cogs with humor and sex appeal.
The farce promised by "The Associate" disappoints, but Goldberg and Wiest's sister act is surprisingly affirming.
Eye of the Holder makes you wonder how bad are the scripts that Ashley Judd and Ewan McGregor turn down.
An underrated actress, Bullock capably fulfills the demands of her role as a pill-popping drunk. But the story never allows Bullock to escape the comfort zone of a romantic comedy.

A worst-case scenario of what happens when an actor turns director. Norton loves his fellow actors so much he cannot bear to reduce their scenes. So stuff that shouldn't make the cut of even the special edition DVD stays in the film.

This sounds like a disaster along the lines of "Dudley Do-Right," but writer-directors Deborah Kaplan and Harry Elfont pull off a surprisingly spry spoof of the very way pop culture - especially music - is marketed to teenagers.
Lillard and Cardellini earn their Scooby Snacks, but not anyone else.
A Cheech and Chong movie for the art-house crowd.
One advantage "Space Cowboys" has over "Armageddon" is that Eastwood is a more laconic director than Michael Bay. Then again, who isn't?
There are two ways to not see this invisible man. The best option is skipping the movie.
Harden deserves recognition more than her co-stars, if only because she creates the sole sympathetic character.
A perfectly acted, sardonic thriller aimed at the intelligent adult audience Hollywood studies have abandoned.
The Fast and the Furious" is the perfect movie to watch on DVD. You can hit a few buttons and check out the three action scenes worth seeing, surrendering only 10 minutes of your life.
As directed by Chris Columbus and written by Steve Kloves, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" is a film with no personality of its own, despite being filled with many unforgettable personalities.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Down to Earth" follows the plot of "Heaven Can Wait" the way a robot follows its programming.
No film scholar would pick the populist Spielberg as the esoteric Kubrick's successor. It's as unlikely as Orson Welles collaborating with Walt Disney.
Despite its attacks on fascism, "The Believer" itself carries the taint of anti-Semitism, implying that self-hatred is a Jewish trait and that Danny's case is unusual only in its extremity.
The sisterly writing team of Karen and Jill Sprecher create that deadly form of cinema, the play mistaken for a movie.

Damon does not look like a guy who could break your arm like a matchstick, and that's why "The Bourne Identity" works. Watching this second coming of Richie Cunningham suddenly unleash his fists and feet and elbows (and Bic pen) of fury is chilling.

Woo has as much right to make a huge action sequence as any director, but how long will filmmakers copy the "Saving Private Ryan" battle scenes before realizing Steven Spielberg got it right the first time?
The ensemble's performances are to be savored.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Sum" is Jack Ryan's "do-over." Give credit to everyone from Robinson down to the key grip that this bold move works. Especially give credit to Affleck.

Bad Company" never knows what it wants to do. It tries to mix urban comedy with international espionage; it tries to mix the theme of individual redemption with the threat of mass destruction; it tries to mix Anthony Hopkins with Chris Rock.
Undercover Brother" is much, much funnier than even the first Austin Powers movie. Its trailer is funnier than the second Austin Powers movie.
The Weitz brothers succeed mostly because they are smart enough to let Grant be Grant and Hornby be Hornby. As in "High Fidelity," the script brims with pungent, quotable dialogue.

Aside from a few striking similarities, "The Salton Sea" maintains its own identity. Its structure may not be as tricky as "Memento's," but "Salton Sea" reveals its own surprises with fewer attention-grabbing devices.
When not bludgeoning a business rival with an ax, well-heeled killer Patrick Bateman bludgeons the audience with the film's messages.

Though "Earnest" is Wilde's most famous work, this film is not as rich as Parker's version of "An Ideal Husband." However, it remains light and entertaining as the bright cast has a wonderful time saying marvelously funny things.
Takes the killer's mind games with the detective to a disturbing level. Not since Seven has the bad guy so successfully undermined his pursuer's moral center.
The battling Yoda looks ludicrous, like Kermit the Frog in a Matrix fight scene.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron" proves traditional animation still can feel its oats when filmmakers have a worthwhile story to draw on.
Nine Queens" is street smart without being grim, nimble without being lightweight. And it delivers a payoff worth the wait.

For every articulate player, such as skateboarder Tony Hawk or BMX rider Mat Hoffman, are about a half dozen young Turks angling to see how many times they can work the words "radical" or "suck" into a sentence.
Several uninteresting, unlikeable people do bad things to and with each other in "Unfaithful." Why anyone who is not a character in this movie should care is beyond me.

Someday rational thought will return and I will realize "Spider-Man" does not rank among the milestones of cinema. But someday is not today. Today "Spider-Man" may as well be "Lawrence of Arabia," so delirious has it made this longtime fan.

Despite its terrible title "Drive Me Crazy" proves more substantial than bubble gum. The story is less comedy than drama, populated by teenage characters who are - you had better sit down for this - believable.
Tucci's slow-paced storytelling in "Big Night" was brave and worked beautifully, but the same technique in "Joe Gould's Secret" becomes annoying.

For its first half this plays like a character-driven, antiestablishment caper of the 1960s and '70s. As the story progresses, the characters turn rotten. When the establishment is more appealing than the maverick heroes, something has gone wrong.
It looks scary, but it doesn't feel scary. The elements are in place, but they're too familiar. Surprise is gone.
It's as if Travolta wanted to destroy his career again just to see if he could stage another comeback.
Grease" hasn't improved much in two decades. It remains a juvenile remembrance of a mythologized '50s, a musical lacking grace.
The biggest kick is watching two charismatic actors at the top of their form essentially play each other.
Like the politicians it criticizes, the film loses sight of its ideals.

Winterbottom takes a recent history the rest of the world already was beginning to forget and throws it into a sharp, human focus.

You have to wonder where we stand as a society when something like "Con Air" passes for entertainment.
More entertaining than it ought to be, considering how sloppily it was put together.
Zesty chases and Van Damme's always exciting fights scenes fit well within a story that carries more intrigue than the average kick-and-crash extravaganzas.

The best thing about "The Thomas Crown Affair" is that it doesn't give a hang if the 14-year-olds show up.

Pierce Brosnan's second outing brings a vigor the series hasn't seen since 1977's The Spy Who Loved Me.

With "Jurassic Park III" Johnston inherits the series one film too late. There are only so many ways a dinosaur can chase people through a jungle.
A thriller driven by considerable suspense before taking a wrong exit somewhere near the end.
It is 1964's "The Fall of the Roman Empire" on both ends, with "Spartacus" in the middle.

When a film's most sensible character commits suicide within the first 15 minutes it cannot be a good sign.

The makers of gay-themed films often ignore this rule: Romantic comedy clichés don't become innovative just because the lovers are the same sex.
IMAX is a format where the sheer scale overpowers its flaws.
The Mexican" turns violent in the last half hour, betraying the sense of fun.

This wants to spoof macho action movies.... But lacking a coherent script to link the jokes, these Angels are left without a prayer.
The combination of the distant noises and the raw fear in the voices will throw a chill into anyone's blood.
Amelie's lesson for us is that every moment is one that we all share, no matter how we spend it.
The story hits a wall with an abrupt, dismal ending.

An old-fashioned adventure yarn accelerated for a video-game era, an H. Rider Haggard novel rocketing by at 150 MPH.

Disney's finest achievement since 1942's "Bambi," a film it resembles in many ways.

How sweet it is to see a romantic comedy with characters who act and talk like adults.

Combining the traditions of the English country house murder mystery and the 1960s musical, 8 Women is nutty French fun.

Competent and nothing more.

movie_review_blurb: Concentrates more on Chan's comedy than his kung fu.
movie_title: Twin Dragons (Shuang long hui) (Brother vs. Brother) (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Trying their hand at hope, Payne and Taylor reveal they should stick to cynicism. But Nicholson's performance is powerful enough to shade this artificial sunshine.

Both flawed and delayed, Martin Scorcese's Gangs of New York still emerges as his most vital work since GoodFellas.

A 1950s film that could not have been made in the 1950s.
