movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining, often amusing exercise made to look more artistic and intellectual than it really is.
The Master of Disguise finds Carvey woefully out of practice.
An old-fashioned scary movie, one that relies on lingering terror punctuated by sudden shocks and not constant bloodshed punctuated by flying guts.

movie_review_blurb: The movie is not as terrible as the synergistic impulse that created it.
The outrageous pee-pee poo-poo jokes from the second movie haven't gone away, but the knowing spy humor from first movie has returned.
So aggressively cheery that Pollyana would reach for a barf bag.

movie_review_blurb: Sayles' pace is leisurely, but the characters and story keep us engrossed.
The filmmakers take the story so seriously Reign of Fire becomes the dullest movie imaginable about fire-breathing lizards. It's Godzilla written by Strindberg.
A solid, intelligent drama where excellent performances fall slightly out of tune with superb technical work.

The filmmakers are more ambitious than wise. While distancing themselves from the Disney animation of the early '90s, they forgot those films were seamlessly written. The weaknesses of Atlantis are all in the script.
A mature, intelligent thriller that bends the audience's perceptions and expectations with every scene.
An ambitious, perception-bending metaphor for life at the end of the 20th century. It doesn't always make sense, but it seems to make sense, which is the key thing in science fiction.
A fantasy achievement where the action, the characters and the message are equally strong. Most importantly, it leaves us hungry for The Two Towers.

movie_review_blurb: A playful holiday diversion.
The most compelling big-screen diagnosis of investigative journalism since All the President's Men.

Farnsworth proves the greatest special effect is the human face.
The movie that the first one should have been.

The rare adaptation that celebrates the spirit of the TV show that spawned it instead of disgracing it.
A literate screwball comedy.
A masterpiece of insanity. ... the greatest unintentional comedy since Glen or Glenda.
A great Indiana Jones movie without Indiana Jones.
Deserves all the praise showered upon the overrated Shrek.

A hell of a lot more fun than any film bearing John Grisham's name.

The jokes come on like gangbusters.
Like a smart boxer, Girlfight knows when to be light on its feet and when to hit hard.
Allen made funnier films when he thought he was Ingmar Bergman.

At First Sight, at second sight, at third sight - it doesn't matter how many times you look. This movie never decides what it wants to be.

The Stepford Wives fails to find a comfortable tone. The humor is never black enough, the plot never important enough.
It restores one's faith in Mandy Moore's film career.
A decent vehicle for Bynes.

movie_review_blurb: A compelling and compassionate portrait of a survivor.
The most rousing, most engaging and most successful movie musical in ages.

This film is 100 percent devoid of surprises. It's the story of an underestimated underdog that's like every other kid-friendly, life-coachy story about an underestimated underdog.
"Shadows" is an 88-minute valentine to cinema, a reminder of why we continue returning to the multiplex, and an abiding faith in the power of film to transport us to faraway places.
Snakes on a Plane is pure escapist fun and absolutely nothing more.

Despite some missteps, this film stands as a moving portrait of a husband and father who reclaims his will to live with the unlikely help of a hand puppet. And the main reason it's so moving? Mel Gibson.
Even the more jaw-dropping camera angles and shocking smash-ups start to feel redundant after director Scott Waugh revisits them for the third or fourth time.
Wanted isn't quite the real Slim Shady of hip-hop comedies. But you might lose yourself in a few of its amusing moments.
It's just unfortunate that a movie about such a daring man ultimately takes few risks.
Well-intentioned but astonishingly flat.

The point of Haunted Mansion is for audiences to sit back and enjoy the ride, which is easy to do thanks to an engaging story, the striking, Gothic-inspired set by Oscar-winner John Myhre and some delightful special effects.
MacLachlan's strong jaw line and his valiant attempt to act so very Cary aren't enough to save this film.
Once this movie's momentum gets going, watching it is like experiencing a schlocky monster movie, Lord of the Flies and Peter Gabriel's Shock the Monkey video all at once.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: So stupefyingly hideous that after watching it, you'll need to bathe in 10 gallons of disinfectant, get a full-body scrub and shampoo with vinegar to remove the scummy residue that remains.
Occasionally charming but ultimately forgettable bit of fox-trot fluff.
After the Sunset fizzles so quickly that it's hard to care about the answers to any of the cliched mysteries it attempts to solve.
Makes a fine first moviegoing experience for tots.
A pretty laughless affair.
As admirable as some of the film might be, it's ultimately too sluggish and dreary to be very memorable.
Stands as yet another example of how easy it is for filmmakers to fail at romantic comedy.
The Skeleton Key delivers on all formulaic counts, except one: It never serves up any truly nightmare-inspiring scares.
Writer-director Jeffrey Blitz brings wit and pathos to the story of a compulsive stutterer.
Combining cutouts with 3-D digital animation, Ocelot turns every frame of his film into a beautiful, dynamic page out of a picture book.
movie_title: Azur et Asmar (Azur and Asmar: The Princes' Quest) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [Has] such obviously humble intentions that busting on it is a bit like harassing the junior high school outcast who just wants to eat his tater tots in peace.
It's the sleeper hit that makes audiences too petrified to ever sleep again.
This feels less like a movie and more like a strategically programmed effort to turn as many demographic groups as possible into mooshy, gooshy, candy-heart-munching morons.
A movie that shows us the desperation and danger of living under martial law in Taiwan during the early '80s, yet somehow never delivers the emotional gut punch the subject matter deserves.
[It] plays like an empty but diverting beach read. Your brain recognizes that the dialogue, for example, doesn't come from any place that remotely resembles relationship reality.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: All we can think of is how much we miss the Robert Englund Freddy. Man, that guy knew how to have a killer good time.
Even the obligatory blooper reel that runs during the closing credits is painful in its desperation to generate laughs.
An engrossing and classically suspenseful story
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps the filmmakers deserve credit for their one show of restraint: No jokes in this movie have been made at the expense of Justin Bieber.
Much of it plays like an unintentional mash-up of the numerous wrong-side-of-the-law sagas that preceded it.
[It's] certainly an immersive experience that's decidedly difficult to shake. The problem is that it's also the most excruciating sit in recent cinematic memory.
[A] disjointed drama filled with one-dimensional characters and melodrama so Lifetime movie-esque that it careens into unintentional comedy.
There's something particularly enjoyable about settling into a film whose pleasures reside in quiet moments, understated performances and the reading of subtitles.
[The film] treads in some traditional teen-movie territory[...] But it also subtly conveys the stillness and sense of purpose that comes from scanning the skies [...]
While it may not be a fully realized take on Dick's forward-thinking work, it's still a far better film than the Verhoeven version.
It tries to make up for what it lacks in coherence and character development by splattering guts-and, occasionally, the head-spiraling prophecies of Billy Zane-all over the place.
movie_title: Evil - In the Time of Heroes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Love the Coopers" is one of the most jumbled, tonally misguided holiday movies in recent memory. It is an insult to tidings of comfort as well as joy, and a complete waste of the time and talents of its ensemble cast.

When Guillermo del Toro set out to co-write and direct Crimson Peak, a work of Gothic horror as gorgeous as it is preposterous, the word "restraint" must have been missing from his movie-making mission statement.
Burnt is plated beautifully but lacks the complexity of flavor it so desperately wants to achieve.
It's a movie where every pause is long and every line of dialogue is supposed to carry great meaning, but ultimately sounds weighed down by excess pretension.
As Radcliffe says from the beginning, we know this story. Since we already do, the longer this particular version of it continues, the more we wonder why we're bothering to sit through it.
A Very Murray Christmas, which deserves to exist for the sake of its title alone, is very Murray, but it's more understated, Wes Anderson-era Murray than, say, madcap, Caddyshack Murray.

Think of every trope associated with animated family movies and you'll find them all in Norm of the North, a thoroughly uninspired story of a polar bear attempting to save his habitat from a hypocritical hippie seeking to develop condos in the Arctic.

When a modern love story elicits a few laughs while also showing off a New York that, under the direction of Christian Ditter, looks like a glimmering fairy land... you probably, honestly, won't really care that it doesn't reflect reality.

Kung Fu Panda 3 follows that same template almost to the letter and punctuation mark. But it's so engaging and entertaining that its reliance on that well-worn hero's journey narrative doesn't feel stale.
The best animated film of the year, as well as one that conveys a message rarely heard in movies for children: Getting exactly what you hoped for isn't the end of the journey.
It's difficult to watch Nina and not compare it to What Happened, Miss Simone?... because the non-fiction version paints a more complete, nuanced portrait of a complicated woman.
When Aniston's character casually mentions Groundhog Day and Flag Day in conversation, I immediately thought to myself, "Be quiet, you, or Garry Marshall will get even more bad ideas."
After paying good money to take your family to see this film, you may be dealing with some anger-management issues of your own.
Lucero compensates for ... missteps with subtly persuasive visual choices and narrative restraint.
Even professionals sometimes take a loss, and that's what Money Monster ultimately feels like: an investment that doesn't quite pay off.
After Allegiant, some moviegoers may decide their work with this franchise is done here.

Vardalos, who once again wrote the screenplay and also stars, has built this sequel on the premise that everything that happened in the previous film should be recreated in the second, but in a way that feels even less organic.
Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie, while amusing in spots, too often plays like a moderately decent TV-reunion show that's diminished by its attempt to be a theatrical feature.

No matter how unsinkable you are, no matter how hard you try to use The Force, it's impossible to look at that image of mother and daughter, fiercely by each other's sides, and do anything other than cry.
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A significant, necessary piece of work, one that stays with you long after you rise out of your theater seat.

Winfrey delivers a performance that's on another level. It can be challenging, even when she's convincing in a film or on a series, to forget that we're watching Oprah. But as Deborah Lacks... Oprah Winfrey completely disappears.
movie_title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In summary, the new Dirty Dancing is disappointing and a bit all over the place. But its biggest sin is that it's bloated and boring.
Barriers and boundaries are established and only partially torn down in this laudatory but nevertheless moving film about one of the most famous and overanalyzed women to ever breathe oxygen.
movie_title: Diana, Our Mother: Her Life and Legacy (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As is often the case in documentaries like this, absorbing all those details as part of one, tightly edited story gives them an impact they lack when digested in individual pieces over time.
This is a documentary that could and should be shown in film schools.
What Too Funny to Fail does do is make it clear, more broadly, that groundbreaking comedy is hard even when you've got a dream team creating it.
Jane Craig is a feminist heroine in a way that few female romantic-comedy protagonists since have been, even the ones we consider strong and independent.
[...] If [director] Mock had dug deeper [...] she could have made a documentary about a still-maddening moment in America's not-so-distant history that was not merely good, but truly great.
Practically every moment of its seven-and-a-half-hour running time is thought-provoking, astonishing, sobering, hilarious, tragic, and sometimes all of those at once.
Maybe the best thing about The Peanuts Movie, with detail so perfect that it brings tears to my eyes, is the way that Charlie Brown daydreams.
Even though it contains a few scary moments, I think this is a movie that parents should take their elementary school-aged children to see.
It's impossible not to care about the people on screen.
This film can't decide whether it's a Noah Baumbach-ian character study or an episode of NBC's Revolution.
The warmth of spirit behind this project allows its missteps to be mostly forgiven.
[...] Perhaps because the fake-doc construct has become so familiar [...] the bar for turning that approach into something fresh and genuinely funny is simply too high for this movie to clear.

16 Acres is a 9/11 documentary, but not that kind of 9/11 documentary [...] it explores the stew of hope, frustration, ambition, and PR spin-cycling involved in the decade-plus effort to rebuild what terrorists so quickly tore down.
It sticks mostly to one track, taking audience members on a journey that, sadly, via the movies or their own lives, they already may know a little too well.
Animated in form but completely listless in content.

[The film is] supposed to serve as a reminder that, low moments and all, this is truly still a wonderful life[.] Instead, it's a reminder that Robinson and Williams have each made some wonderful movies. But this isn't one of them.
[...] directors Matthew Pond and Kirk Marcolina have made a documentary that, like its protagonist, overflows with wild tales of con jobs, diamond-pilfering, and daring dashes from law enforcement
movie_title: The Life and Crimes of Doris Payne (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A frequently sumptuous pleasure to watch.
...as a tightly constructed look at the more serious symptoms of Peter Pan syndrome, The Almost Man mostly works.
These kinds of Hollywood pop stardom portraits usually flop or fly based on their casts and the ebullience of their musical scenes. "Get on Up" wins on both fronts.

If the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences decides to add an Oscar category called Best Performance by a Toddler in an Indie Film Directed by His Own Father, Jude Swanberg would easily smoke any precocious competition.
...A Will For The Woods transforms into a truly moving experience, and a testimony to the difference that a single life can make in the lives of others.
Innocence is about what it means to confront death and mortality. But what it needs more than anything is some life in it.
Deftly weaves together various media in a way that breathes its own youthful, stream-of-conscious life into the documentary genre.
A few scenes succeed in generating legitimate tension, but this movie isn't so much a nail-biter as a very occasional hangnail-chewer.
It's a thoroughly subjective and effective attempt to capture how it must have felt to be Marlon Brando.
What ultimately gives My Old Lady its structure and heft are the moments when two of the actors get stuck in a room together, and let the dialogue fly.
Perhaps "Sneakerheadz" needs a sequel, one that more directly interrogates the shoe manufacturers themselves about the hazards of pumping up so much hype about their product.
Who needs words when every frame is worth a thousand of them?
Co-directors Dan Sickles and Antonio Santini approach their subjects with healthy curiosity and consistent respect.
It's almost as if everyone involved in Set Fire To The Stars got a little too understated for their own good.
The most observant movie-watchers, especially those conversant in the language of crime dramas, will see some of the narrative curveballs coming long before the wind-up.
The portrait of BASE jumping founding father Carl Boenish, effectively captures the irrepressible energy of a man who never tired of taking flying leaps.
This is a profile of a decent man who is permanently associated with a revered pop-cultural icon.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Emptying The Skies, a documentary based on Franzen's story that borrows its headline as its title, ultimately makes a more searing imprint on the psyche.
Attie and O'Hara do a wonderfully restrained, effective job of portraying the never-ending repetitive loop that is military life.
"Furious 7" buzzes with a frenetic energy so contagious, there's no sense in resisting it. Like its predecessors, this film has no shame about being its high-octane, gloriously ridiculous self.
As it stands, The Hand That Feeds is an illuminating sidebar to the conversations around the U.S. economy and immigration reform.
There's something about this project that, despite checking all of the requisite plot and sensibility boxes, doesn't convey as an organic work of SpongeBob-ishness.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Beware the deadly shoe-knife.
Features the original song 'Pimps Don't Cry,' The first clear Oscar front runner of the year.
Wright proves himself an expert technician with Scott Pilgrim vs. the World, surely one of the most visually dense pieces of pop cinema ever made.
Two words: LASER FINGERS!
Newcomer Joey King is a blue-eyed dynamo who brings Ramona Quimby vividly to life and steals the show from her veteran co-stars.
When it gets around to the righteous fightin' and killin' bits, The Expendables more than delivers on its promise to be the manliest movie ever made.
A singular film that seeps into your brain so much so that you might leave the theater looking at the world differently.
Stays afloat on the strength of its leads even as the plot gets sillier and the 110 minute runtime has you fidgeting in your seat.
A spine-ripping good time that evokes the spirit of the original films.
The good news for those eagerly anticipating this live-action, big budget adaptation is that the 3D isn't horrible. The bad news? Just about everything else is.
The new, more assertive Bella Swan is the most welcome addition to the Twilight Saga -- that, and the sly humor Rosenberg's snuck into Eclipse.
An hour and 40 minute long, five-way, PG-13 roast with more lame jokes than actual laughs.
Delivers the goods as an engaging animated adventure and also gives the characters we've come to love the farewell they deserve.
Kutcher and Heigl have such forced chemistry that it's hard to believe they'd ever fall in love, much less stay married in blissful blah-dom.
Eat Pray Love only superficially advocates independence and growth while serving up a steaming pile of pseudo-spiritual hyperbole.
Pity the intelligent moviegoer.
The film, mirroring its anti-hero, settles on not being despicable by being just good enough.
Has plenty of good, old-fashioned blood & guts and the kind of full frontal nudity that's guaranteed to send young boys into puberty.
A smart send-up of the Superman myth and the age-old precept of good vs. evil.
A 'hood comedy with heart.
Cyrus begins to feel exactly like all those indie movies we desperately hoped it wouldn't turn out to be like -- quirky, talky, and yawn-inducingly familiar.
Get ready for a long eight months, Potterites.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A mess of a movie that reaches a completely ridiculous and unexpected (but not in a good way) conclusion.
Blows a noisy raspberry in the face of old media while the mocking warble of a Natasha Bedingfield song plays over the end credits.
Every shred of true story credence becomes lost in a flurry of facepalm-worthy character decisions, headache-inducing edits and stupid, preposterous action.
Basically Planes, Trains and Automobiles with Robert Downey Jr. and Zach Galifianakis, minus the earned sentiment and John Hughes cred.
Incomprehensible story, cheesy dialogue, poor execution, cheap production value - Saw 3D hits for the cycle of bad filmmaking.
Wastes its earnest poignancy with a script reliant on corny storytelling clichés.
Perverse gender politics are at play here in this insemination fantasy about a man hijacking a woman's uterus in a long play to win her heart.
Builds gradual tension on repetitious scenes of domestic tranquility before shattering the calm with an escalating series of events.
Affleck's overall directorial instincts are sound; breathtaking car chases and ear-rattling shoot-outs are thrillingly executed.
Stone's charisma sells her preternaturally mature character and makes the script's snarky, pop culture-referencing dialogue snap.
Taut and slickly directed, Devil is actually one of the more solid genre movies we've seen all year.
It feels real, even if in the back of your brain you know it's about as authentic as the girl who quit her job via dry-erase board.
Resorts to a clichéd and over-the-top ending that negates all of the effective ambiguity that made the middle third of the film so nail-bitingly tense.
A slick thriller comprised of equal parts pretty actors, urban crime drama clichés, and cheesy lines... The Italian Heat Job for Dummies.
Whimsical, heartwarming, and a tad bittersweet.
In the long, miserable history of Aaron Seltzer and Jason Friedberg's joint film making career, Vampires Suck is a definite improvement.
The only truly new element here is the use of 3-D, which occasionally brings various stunts leaping off the screen and into your lap, whether you like it or not.
The most chopped up, stitched together Frankenstein job in recent memory.
Makes little sense, but earns points for the operatic, slow-motion vampire equivalent of the Barf-a-Rama scene from Stand By Me.
A must-see for sci-fi and horror nuts, even if Natali throws away a perfectly compelling first two acts in favor of the big 'Oh no they didn't' ending.
Director Garry Marshall bounces so quickly from story to story that by the time you see so-and-so shtupping so-and-so again, you've forgotten which dramarama belongs to whom.
Anne Rice was right; angels are just as hot and just as deadly as those bloodsuckers from Twilight and True Blood.
One step forward for Kristen Bell, one giant leap backward for womankind.
Slow and silly plot notwithstanding, if you like your Mel Gibson out of control and a little bit crazy, this movie is for you.

Despite its patronizing theme, and however much you're tired of Amy Adams's wide-eyed, neurotic shtick, Leap Year has a winning charm that sneaks up on you and makes you fall in love with Matthew Goode %u2013 I mean, with it.
If pretentious hipster kids annoy you in real life, they'll bug the hell out of you in Youth in Revolt.
The Next Three Days is a popcorn thriller through and through. Unfortunately, it's also painfully boring.
Thanks to Michael Sheen's innate charms, Brian Clough is redeemable even at his meanest and most self-destructive.

In presenting Keats as much in Brawne's eyes as she in his, we watch Fanny's growing interest in John, we wait with her for his letters, we share in her anguish when all seems lost -- Campion suggests that he was her "bright star" as well

Despite some admirably committed performances, the film is marred by a few plot contrivances that cast unbelievability into a story that strives to be about real relationships, real politics, and real economics.
It's Nazis, melodrama and intrigue galore as Paul Verhoeven adds his patented Verhoeven touch to this sordid tale of a Jewish girl in hiding during World War II.

The film champions its "terrorist" and vilifies its family man-turned-desperate lawman, and argues that when the lines between good and bad are forever blurred, forgiveness is mankind's only salvation.
What further elevates Deliver Us From Evil beyond the poignancy and courage of O'Grady's victims and the sorrow of their devastated families is Berg's access to the pedophile himself.
Obliterates the poignancy it's attempting to establish by being a weird, mismatched hybrid of political drama, adventure thriller, and road comedy.
Filled with entertaining action sequences and a dazzling supporting cast, Operation Stormbreaker succeeds in serving up tasty fare for the older set, as well as kids.
Scott Caan's second directorial effort is an intimate, comical gem of a film...
El Cantante is driven by the rhythmic, pulsating sounds of Lavoe's music, without which the film would be nothing.
In place of legitimate tension and suspense, The Wolfman features more cheap jump scares and loud scary noises than every J-horror film ever made put together.
I'm pretty sure these 12-year-olds could leave the entire cast of The Expendables in body bags.

Director Columbus never quite gets comfortable juggling the film's myriad characters, grandiose-but-stale CGI effects, and PG-friendly battle scenes, speeding headlong through endless plot points rather than taking the time to make any of them matter.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: One of the first truly Oscar-worthy films of 2010.
It's a Shrek-derful Midlife Crisis
A rollicking, epic-scale franchise-starter that's equal parts intrigue, action and Gyllenhaal, with a dash of feisty romantic banter thrown in for good measure.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If only it were two and a half hours of Liza doing Beyonce numbers. Now that would be a truly fabulous two and a half hours well spent.
Who needs heavy analysis when all you want is a cute fix?
If you're just going to see men in robot suits blow each other up while classic rock blares on the soundtrack, Iron Man 2 will do just fine...
The end credits cast sing-along to a cover of 'Insane in the Brain' completes the litany of idiotic filmmaking choices that made the whole thing so unwatchable to begin with.
It's a BYOBB film: Bring your own barf bag.
Thanks to the film's re-imagining of Freddy as accused child molester, an uncomfortable veneer of ickiness looms that makes it hard to truly enjoy...
Poor Tracy Morgan with chunks of fecal matter stuck to his face. I laughed, and then I wanted to barf. Then I LOLed some more.
Best supporting character whose nudity is also a plot point: Mark Wahlberg...
Not enough Bubo!
In addition to a knack for corny plot lines and montages of young people making out along the Southeastern coastline, Sparks has a sixth sense for making audiences cry.
A film that makes family night at the movies worth the price of admission again.
Matthew Vaughn lovingly brings the comic book series to the big screen with an unabashed geekiness that will delight anyone who has a favorite superhero.
Despite the script's too-neat constructions, this pulpy potboiler is a solid think piece and companion film to Fuqua's 2001 Oscar-winning Training Day.
If the subtext's too heavy for you, you can choose to ignore it and instead read The Crazies as a survival guide to what to do when the zombie outbreak hits.
If you don't normally find Tracy Morgan hilarious, you may not experience the same level of blissful enjoyment from the jokes about his poop as I did.
Shutter Island feels disappointingly like a minor work. But hey, who says every film has to be a masterpiece?
Burlesque razzle-dazzles its way through a litany of familiar showbiz clichés and comes out, for the most part, with sequins and false eyelashes intact.
I laughed -- but after next week, I might not remember why.
For all the girl power messaging in Tangled's marketing campaign, this updated Rapunzel is a fairly terrible role model for little girls.
While it's a bright, grimy, candy-colored mess, at least Suicide Squad is here to lighten up the place, break a few vases, take a few shots, and have some fun.
The idea that a secret sequel could bring a long-stale franchise like this back to life is, frankly, the most surprising thing to happen to horror in ages.

When Beyond soars, it hits a sweet spot of perfectly balanced stakes, momentum, character development, callbacks, music, and action, blasting at full power in particular in one memorable space-battle set piece that punches in just the right moments.
With a crackling sense of purpose and a surplus of reverence for their predecessors, new Ghostbusters Wiig, McCarthy, McKinnon, and Jones plant their own flag on a beloved sci-fi comedy franchise.
One of the strangest and most utterly engrossing documentaries of the year.
The Witness takes a heartaching deep dive into a story we already thought we knew.
'X-Men: Apocalypse' gives 'X-Men: The Last Stand' a run for its money as the worst entry in the long-running franchise.
Shane Black, the buddy action auteur, is back in his wheelhouse-and he's delivered another inspired onscreen pairing in the blundering one-two punch of Gosling and Crowe.

Finally, a big budget superhero sequel that manages to be both effortlessly entertaining and utterly sobering, instead of just one of those things-or, as we've endured too frequently in the past, neither of them. (Looking at you, Batman v Superman.)
Watching Batman and Superman rage at each other like little boys makes for a pretty tedious two and a half hours.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If you're ready to subject yourself to the most balls-out, bonkers action ride of the year, then you are precisely the maniac for whom the flashy, gory first-person action-thriller Hardcore Henry was made.
Zoolander 2 death-marches its way through a tiresome succession of espionage movie clichés and cameos.
Deadpool is at once a welcome antidote to the played out superhero universe and an anomaly, destined to be trapped in its spandexed outliers.
Stirring, soulful, and incendiary.
Barack and Michelle's Before Sunrise-esque first date makes for a charming indie romance.
One long feature-length skin-crawl, a comic exercise in visceral discomfort that's all the more entertaining if you can check your gag reflex and lean into the ick.
Bay, never one for subtlety, cranks up the sentimentality in his most patriotic film to date.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: You might find yourself alone one night imagining your dinner screaming with every bite you take, and then wonder: Is that half-eaten slice of pizza plotting cheesy vengeance upon me... or am I the half-eaten slice of pizza?
Perfectly safe and plenty full of the Force... but leans on geek nostalgia to reboot a beloved property by hitting predictably familiar story beats.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: At times, Skiptrace feels like the most Jackie Chan movie Jackie Chan has made, certainly in recent years, and possibly ever.
Sully wants to be life-affirming Oscar bait, but it's more like Clint Eastwood's Book Club For Dads Who Shop In Cargo Pants At Costco.
Empty, fleeting stuff that resonates only long enough for the next car chase/fight scene/shoot-out to come along.
"It" fills its 135-minute run time with enough impressive visuals to keep its audience rapt, if not as emotionally invested as the source material deserves.
Plaza shines here in her most multifaceted role to date, fearless in her willingness to take Ingrid to cringe-worthy depths with a chameleonic precision.
Not only owns its dumbness, but hurtles itself all the way back around through a flurry of genitalia jokes and F-bombs to splash unapologetically in an R-rated surf of winking postmodernism.
What makes the torment worth enduring is the trio of ferocious performances at its center, bare and ugly and unvarnished.
Despite Donahue's best efforts in a grand finale sleep session with life-or-death stakes, the premise never lives up to its promise.
Bold and brutal in shocking spurts, the indie horror drama from writer-director O'Shea is a startling debut that leaves a fresh mark on the genre while celebrating its forbears.
Contained yet expansive, nostalgic yet new, Rogue One introduces striking heroes and villains and fills its two hours and 13 minutes with a narrative that fits snugly into canon.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There are no princes hanging around, no boys to really think about, no girly hang-ups or thingamabobs to fritter over, and no romantic subplots to distract from what's truly important: survival, independence, identity, self-belief.
More mature than its predecessors and the first blockbuster of the modern superhero era ideally viewed on a magic mushroom trip.

A frequently frustrating but surprisingly entertaining genre mishmash that's at least upfront about its central conceit: Ben Affleck is definitely, 100 percent going for it as Hollywood's first autistic assassin.
A ghost story both on its surface and far below it -- a haunted house tale in which the tangible dangers of the war outside are so immediate that no one really sees what's happening within the walls.

I've heard the patrons felled by Raw's more outré scenes, in a film filled with gaping flesh wounds and at least one sensual eyeball-licking, were men, which only underscores the film's power as a feminist fable.
The rewards are subtle but a bit too far in between; much of it feels familiar, which will bring both comfort and frustration to fans.
Knox bares her soul for the cameras in Amanda Knox, which achieves what all that media overexposure never tried to do all those years ago: It makes her seem human.
It's relentlessly brutal and surprisingly hilarious, the blackest of black humor seeping from its pores.
Fuqua's Magnificent Seven is Fast & Furious on horses -- The Wild Bunch for people who will never bother to see The Wild Bunch
A ferocious debut from writer-director Elizabeth Wood... a bold and brash cautionary tale filled with a lifetime's worth of terrible decisions.
Even the look of The Good Dinosaur's main character seems outdated, blocky, and out of place in his own world.
Visceral echoes of real life accidentally make the over-the-top action feel more prescient than anyone could have intended.
A coming-of-age feminist fairy tale and just the film we need right now.
By the time my seatmate was filling up her second Human Centipede II barf bag, we had to call an ambulance to the theater. Thank goodness for practical swag?
Yes, this is a mixed martial arts movie. It's also one of the most heart-wrenching and deeply felt films of the year.

The potential to bring Harry Shum Jr.'s sweet dance moves into the third dimension is wasted, and unlike Jon M. Chu's dynamically-lensed Justin Bieber: Never Say Never concert doc, Glee 3D feels disappointingly flat.

It may sound silly, but watch Hauer go from shuffling, hesitant outsider on the fringe to vigilante hero raining down justice in the streets with his 12-gauge and you see one of the year's best, most heartbreaking and unhinged performances thus far.
Bridesmaids proves that modern comedies about women don't have to be insipid, boring or downright loathsome. Who knew?
It's The Seventh Seal meets Get Him to the Greek meets Lord of the Rings as if filtered through Uwe Boll's hack-tastic brain.
